Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "Female proband, born full term at 37th week, with a birth weight of 2 Kg and a head circumference of 32 cm. Parents are healthy and had a consanguineous marriage.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The affected child has features typical of Wiedemann–Rautenstrauch syndrome (WRS) such as a large head, prominent forehead, beaked nose, craniofacial disproportion, reduced subcutaneous fat, thin skin, and rigid joints. Additionally, she had right-sided facial palsy, craniosynostosis, and scaphocephaly. Eye examination revealed hazy cornea, inability to close right eye, glaucoma, proptosis, and ectopia lentis. Other features include talipes calcaneovalgus, bilateral hydronephrosis, and ventricular septal defect, along with long hands and feet. She also had bilateral polydactyly of hands, generalized lipodystrophy, and partial syndactyly in the 2nd and 3rd toe. Sparse scalp hairs (alopecia) and prominent veins were noted. She was on a ventilator for the first few days after birth and received platelet transfusions on the 5th and 7th postnatal days.",
  "Physical Examination": "The affected child exhibited a large head, prominent forehead, beaked nose, craniofacial disproportion, reduced subcutaneous fat, thin skin, and rigid joints. Right-sided facial palsy, craniosynostosis, and scaphocephaly were noted. Eye examination found hazy cornea, inability to close right eye, glaucoma, proptosis, and ectopia lentis. Other observations included talipes calcaneovalgus, bilateral hydronephrosis, and ventricular septal defect. Presence of long hands and feet, bilateral polydactyly of hands, generalized lipodystrophy, partial syndactyly in the 2nd and 3rd toe, sparse scalp hairs (alopecia), and prominent veins were also recorded.",
  "Past Medical History": "Parents are healthy and did not reveal any disease phenotypes.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Platelet transfusions were given on the 5th and 7th postnatal days."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "Female proband, born full term at 37th week, with a birth weight of 2 Kg and a head circumference of 32 cm. Parents are healthy and had a consanguineous marriage.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The affected child has features typical of Wiedemann–Rautenstrauch syndrome (WRS) such as a large head, prominent forehead, beaked nose, craniofacial disproportion, reduced subcutaneous fat, thin skin, and rigid joints. Additionally, she had right-sided facial palsy, craniosynostosis, and scaphocephaly. Eye examination revealed hazy cornea, inability to close right eye, glaucoma, proptosis, and ectopia lentis. Other features include talipes calcaneovalgus, bilateral hydronephrosis, and ventricular septal defect, along with long hands and feet. She also had bilateral polydactyly of hands, generalized lipodystrophy, and partial syndactyly in the 2nd and 3rd toe. Sparse scalp hairs (alopecia) and prominent veins were noted. She was on a ventilator for the first few days after birth and received platelet transfusions on the 5th and 7th postnatal days.",
  "Physical Examination": "The affected child exhibited a large head, prominent forehead, beaked nose, craniofacial disproportion, reduced subcutaneous fat, thin skin, and rigid joints. Right-sided facial palsy, craniosynostosis, and scaphocephaly were noted. Eye examination found hazy cornea, inability to close right eye, glaucoma, proptosis, and ectopia lentis. Other observations included talipes calcaneovalgus, bilateral hydronephrosis, and ventricular septal defect. Presence of long hands and feet, bilateral polydactyly of hands, generalized lipodystrophy, partial syndactyly in the 2nd and 3rd toe, sparse scalp hairs (alopecia), and prominent veins were also recorded.",
  "Past Medical History": "Parents are healthy and did not reveal any disease phenotypes.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Platelet transfusions were given on the 5th and 7th postnatal days.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) revealed compound heterozygous variants in the FREM1 gene (c.247 C>T; p.His83Tyr and g.14,769,868 InsA) on chromosome 9p22.3. The missense variant in exon 4 and splice site variant in intron 27 were analyzed and predicted to be damaging. Both variants were absent in all public databases including ExAC, gnomAD, and 1000 genomes. The missense variant (p.His83Tyr) was inherited from the father and the splice site variant (g.14,769,868 InsA) from the mother. Sanger sequencing confirmed perfect segregation of the identified variant within the family. In silico analysis revealed the mutant residue is located near a highly conserved position, bigger and more hydrophobic than the wild-type residue, possibly leading to structural issues."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a newborn male, born at 37 weeks and 3 days of gestation, weighing 2,377 g. The delivery was by elective cesarean section, and the infant was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "A gastric mass with a mosaic-patterned internal echo was detected on fetal ultrasound since week 21 of gestation. Frequent vomiting and aspiration were observed during oral feeding. Vomiting improved after introducing nasoduodenal tube feeding; however, aspiration pneumonia still occurred. Laryngoesophageal or tracheoesophageal communication was strongly suspected. At 93 days of age, the patient underwent resection of the gastric tumor via partial gastrectomy. Toupet fundoplication and gastrostomy were introduced to establish stable enteral feeding. Gastroesophageal reflux was significantly improved thereafter. A laryngoscopic repair of the laryngotracheoesophageal cleft (LTEC) was performed at 198 days of age, successfully preventing aspiration pneumonia. The patient was discharged at 315 days of age.",

  "Physical Examination": "Esophagogastroduodenoscopy performed at 23 days of age revealed a pedunculated polypoid lesion of the gastric fornix 8 mm from the esophagogastric junction. The lesion was covered with a smooth, whitish mucosal layer. A detailed and thorough inspection using laryngoscopy was performed at 30 days of age to confirm LTEC (type III). During surgery at 93 days of age, the tumor was palpable on the posterior wall of the fundus, near the gastric cardia.",

  "Past Medical History": "No past medical history was provided in the given information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Postnatal abdominal ultrasound confirmed a tumor at the gastric fornix near the gastric cardia measuring 11.4 × 12.4 mm. No cystic or calcified components were identified in the tumor. An upper gastrointestinal contrast study performed 2 days after birth revealed a shadow defect in the gastric fornix. The angle of His was dull, and severe gastroesophageal reflux was observed. Additionally, aspiration of the regurgitated contrast medium resulted in an extensive bronchogram."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a newborn male, born at 37 weeks and 3 days of gestation, weighing 2,377 g. The delivery was by elective cesarean section, and the infant was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "A gastric mass with a mosaic-patterned internal echo was detected on fetal ultrasound since week 21 of gestation. Frequent vomiting and aspiration were observed during oral feeding. Vomiting improved after introducing nasoduodenal tube feeding; however, aspiration pneumonia still occurred. Laryngoesophageal or tracheoesophageal communication was strongly suspected. At 93 days of age, the patient underwent resection of the gastric tumor via partial gastrectomy. Toupet fundoplication and gastrostomy were introduced to establish stable enteral feeding. Gastroesophageal reflux was significantly improved thereafter. A laryngoscopic repair of the laryngotracheoesophageal cleft (LTEC) was performed at 198 days of age, successfully preventing aspiration pneumonia. The patient was discharged at 315 days of age.",

  "Physical Examination": "Esophagogastroduodenoscopy performed at 23 days of age revealed a pedunculated polypoid lesion of the gastric fornix 8 mm from the esophagogastric junction. The lesion was covered with a smooth, whitish mucosal layer. A detailed and thorough inspection using laryngoscopy was performed at 30 days of age to confirm LTEC (type III). During surgery at 93 days of age, the tumor was palpable on the posterior wall of the fundus, near the gastric cardia.",

  "Past Medical History": "No past medical history was provided in the given information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Postnatal abdominal ultrasound confirmed a tumor at the gastric fornix near the gastric cardia measuring 11.4 × 12.4 mm. No cystic or calcified components were identified in the tumor. An upper gastrointestinal contrast study performed 2 days after birth revealed a shadow defect in the gastric fornix. The angle of His was dull, and severe gastroesophageal reflux was observed. Additionally, aspiration of the regurgitated contrast medium resulted in an extensive bronchogram.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Fetal magnetic resonance imaging revealed a tumorous lesion measuring 11 mm in diameter at the fornix. The excised gastric polypoid lesion measured 2.7 × 1.6 × 1.5 cm and was lined by a smooth mucosal layer. The cut surface had a solid and myxoid appearance. Histological examination revealed that the epithelium was composed of multilayered columnar epithelium around the pedicle and multilayered squamous epithelium at the apex. The subepithelial stroma was edematous, and structures mimicking bronchial glands were observed. A layer of cartilage formed an inverted U-shape in the stroma, which served as the backbone of the polypoid lesion. Immunostaining revealed epithelial cells positive for TTF-1 around the pedicle, which is characteristic of bronchial epithelium. At the apex, diffuse staining of MUC4 in all layers of the stratified squamous epithelium was observed. The staining pattern of MUC4 was different from that of normal stratified squamous epithelium, in which MUC4 was positive only in the basal cells. The diffuse staining pattern resembled that of squamous metaplasia in the respiratory tract."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 13-year-old boy from a non-consanguineous family. He was born and raised in a location with access to community clinics and a local city hospital before being admitted to a provincial tertiary children's hospital.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with recurrent fever for more than 1 month. The first fever occurred without obvious causes in early September 2021, with a maximum temperature of 39.0°C accompanied by headache. He was initially treated with anti-infective treatment in a community clinic for 4 days, after which the temperature returned to normal. Two weeks later, he experienced fever above 39.0°C again, with gradually shortening intervals between fever episodes. He was then treated at the local city hospital with ceftriaxone and methylprednisolone for septicemia, and his temperature returned to normal after 5 days. The night before admission to the provincial tertiary children's hospital, he experienced a high fever again. Throughout the illness, he had poor appetite and sleep. After admission, his temperature rose to 40.3°C on the 2nd day. Empirical anti-infective treatment with cefotaxime (1.0 g q6h) was initiated after a comprehensive septicemia screening. 48 hours later, the patient's temperature remained constantly over 40.0°C, and the tenderness in the right upper abdomen worsened.",

  "Physical Examination": "The physical examination revealed mild tenderness in the upper abdomen without rebound tenderness. The liver and spleen were palpable 4.0 cm under the ribs.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no history of Caroli's disease. There was no mention of any other significant past medical history for the patient or his family.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory results after admission showed a slight increase in inflammatory biomarkers. Coagulation, liver function, and tumor markers were within the normal range. Repeated blood cultures were performed but yielded no positive findings."
}"

He was then treated at the local city hospital with ceftriaxone and methylprednisolone for septicemia, and his temperature returned to normal after 5 days. The night before admission to the provincial tertiary children's hospital, he experienced a high fever again. Throughout the illness, he had poor appetite and sleep. After admission, his temperature rose to 40.3°C on the 2nd day.   "Further Diagnostic Tests": "An emergency abdominal ultrasound revealed multiple cysts in the liver and hepatosplenomegaly, with no obvious renal cysts. An abdominal computerized tomography (CT) scan showed prominent dilation of the intrahepatic bile ducts. A magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography (MRCP) was performed, revealing multifocal dilatation of the intrahepatic bile ducts associated with hepatomegaly. Both CT and MRCP showed an obvious 'central spot sign.' Genetic testing was suggested for the child and his parents, but the parents declined due to economic reasons."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is an eight-year, four-month-old female child. She is the only child of her parents. The family history indicates third-degree consanguinity.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The child presented with a complaint of decreased hearing in both ears since childhood. Poor developmental motor skills, delayed speech, and language development were reported. The patient was diagnosed with hypothyroidism. Dysmorphic facial features were observed, including low bat ears, micrognathia, high arched palate, and nasal alae hypoplasia. }"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 30-year-old man from an unspecified geographic location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a 1-year history of persistent, painless swelling of the lower lip, and a notable tongue edema with a scrotal appearance. He has a history of celiac disease and atopic diathesis. He reported seven episodes of facial nerve palsy occurring since he was 17 years old. Previously, other dermatologists had prescribed topical and oral corticosteroids, which provided only partial benefits and temporary improvements. Dermoscopy of the lower lip showed a pattern of globular vessels regularly distributed throughout the entire lesion with white lines drawing a sort of negative network.",
  "Physical Examination": "Clinical examination revealed important tongue edema with a scrotal appearance and persistent, painless swelling of the lower lip.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of celiac disease and atopic diathesis. He also reported seven episodes of facial nerve palsy since he was 17 years old.",
  "Initial Test Results": "There are no initial test results included in the provided information."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 39-year-old male, employed as a construction worker. He is asthmatic and was diagnosed with Chronic Spontaneous Urticaria (CSU) in 2015.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "In 2019, in addition to CSU hives (Urticarial Activity Score, UAS7 = 40), the patient developed episodic hand and feet swellings and large oedematous plaques at different areas of the body surface without experiencing any systemic symptoms. The reactions followed manual tasks involving vibration, starting 5 hours after exposure and lasting >24 hours. The patient identified drills, pneumatic hammers, and excavator machines as the main triggers for the angioedema. He did not recall experiencing prior difficulties handling these tools for the previous 20 years. The time of exposure to these tools was variable, ranging from 0 to 8 hours. The patient noticed that the longer the exposure, the more intense the symptoms were, especially after driving the hammer excavator. Severe symptoms were observed 1 day after driving a surface drill rig for a full workday. While the oedema remained, the patient was unable to work properly with his hands, leading to repeat absences from work. The patient did not experience worsening of his clinical condition in relation to other physical agents (including heat or cold).",

  "Physical Examination": "A cutaneous biopsy showed features compatible with urticaria. The vortex vibratory urticaria/angioedema provocation test was positive showing a 0.5-cm increase in the mid-forearm perimeter, intense pruritus, increased local temperature, localized hives beginning 3 minutes after the cessation of the stimulus, lasting 20 minutes, and an oedematous plaque coinciding with the vortex edge, at the area where the vibration was maximum, which could be observed 5 hours later. A dermographic urticaria provocation test (FricTest), and a delayed pressure urticaria challenge with the suspended weight method (7 kg for 20 minutes, with readings at 5 and 24 hours) were negative.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of asthma. He was diagnosed with Chronic Spontaneous Urticaria (CSU) in 2015. There is no family history of chronic urticaria.",

  "Initial Test Results": "A blood test showed an increase of C-reactive protein (PCR) (14 mg/l), D-dimer (721 ng/ml) and IgE levels (772 KU/l)."
}"

Cases.Final Name: Chondrodysplasia with joint dislocations, gPAPP type
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "21-year-old primigravida, consanguineously married, 20 weeks gestational age, female, geographic location not specified.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "Referred due to fetal ultrasound showing short long bones suggestive of lethal skeletal dysplasia. First trimester scans revealed increased nuchal translucency (3.1 mm) and increased nuchal fold thickness (5.3 mm) at 14 weeks. Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) for common aneuploidies indicated low risk. At 20 weeks, ultrasound showed bilateral short femur length (1.55 cm), tibia (1.28 cm), humerus (1.39 cm), radius (1.56 cm), and ulna (1.59 cm) all greater than 4 SD below the mean. Abdominal circumference was 12.2 cm, head circumference was 17.2 cm, and FL/AC ratio was 0.127 (ratio <0.16 is suggestive of lethal skeletal dysplasia). Bilateral club foot and mild polyhydramnios were present. Long bones appeared broad with minimal bowing in lower limbs. Specific morphological details of hands were not appreciated. Thoracic circumference at the level of cardiac chamber was 12.5 cm, and the ratio of thoracic-abdominal (TC/AC) circumference was 0.93. The elbow joint appeared abnormal although specific details were not ascertained.",
  "Physical Examination": "Postnatal fetal examination at 20 weeks GA showed the fetus weighed 250g with a head circumference of 17.5 cm, abdominal circumference of 1.5 cm, interpupillary distance of 2.5 cm, and inner canthal distance of 1.5 cm. Facially, the fetus had high forehead, hypertelorism, crease below lower eyelids, depressed broad nasal bridge, anteverted nares, broad nasal base, long thin philtrum, low set ears, small mouth, and microretrognathia. Other external features included short neck, bilateral hitchhiker thumb, bilateral single transverse crease, bilateral club foot (right side more severe than left), left fifth toe curved and dorsiflexed, right foot with increased gap between T1/T2 and T4/T5, and right T5 slightly laterally deviated. Observed were all four short limbs with bowing of lower limbs.",
  "Past Medical History": "",
  "Initial Test Results": "Initial ultrasound scans at 14 weeks GA showed increased nuchal translucency (3.1 mm) and increased nuchal fold thickness (5.3 mm). NIPT for common aneuploidies reported low risk."
}"

  "Clinical Presentation": "Referred due to fetal ultrasound showing short long bones suggestive of lethal skeletal dysplasia. First trimester scans revealed increased nuchal translucency (3.1 mm) and increased nuchal fold thickness (5.3 mm) at 14 weeks. Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) for common aneuploidies indicated low risk. At 20 weeks, ultrasound showed bilateral short femur length (1.55 cm), tibia (1.28 cm), humerus (1.39 cm), radius (1.56 cm), and ulna (1.59 cm) all greater than 4 SD below the mean. Abdominal circumference was 12.2 cm, head circumference was 17.2 cm, and FL/AC ratio was 0.127 (ratio <0.16 is suggestive of lethal skeletal dysplasia). Bilateral club foot and mild polyhydramnios were present. Long bones appeared broad with minimal bowing in lower limbs. Specific morphological details of hands were not appreciated. Thoracic circumference at the level of cardiac chamber was 12.5 cm, and the ratio of thoracic-abdominal (TC/AC) circumference was 0.93. The elbow joint appeared abnormal although specific details were not ascertained.",
  "Physical Examination": "Postnatal fetal examination at 20 weeks GA showed the fetus weighed 250g with a head circumference of 17.5 cm, abdominal circumference of 1.5 cm, interpupillary distance of 2.5 cm, and inner canthal distance of 1.5 cm. Facially, the fetus had high forehead, hypertelorism, crease below lower eyelids, depressed broad nasal bridge, anteverted nares, broad nasal base, long thin philtrum, low set ears, small mouth, and microretrognathia. Other external features included short neck, bilateral hitchhiker thumb, bilateral single transverse crease, bilateral club foot (right side more severe than left), left fifth toe curved and dorsiflexed, right foot with increased gap between T1/T2 and T4/T5, and right T5 slightly laterally deviated. Observed were all four short limbs with bowing of lower limbs.",
  "Past Medical History": "",
  "Initial Test Results": "Initial ultrasound scans at 14 weeks GA showed increased nuchal translucency (3.1 mm) and increased nuchal fold thickness (5.3 mm). NIPT for common aneuploidies reported low risk.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Fetal MRI at 20 weeks confirmed short limbed fetus with slightly bowed long bones in lower limbs and short long bones in upper limbs; both elbow joints were deformed with poor outline of distal humerus. CNS, spine, and abdominal viscera were normal. Estimated total lung volume was 24.8 mL with an O/E ratio of total lung volume of 1.6. Genomic DNA extraction and sequencing of the fetus and parents identified a previously unreported homozygous 2 bp duplication in exon 2 of the IMPAD1 gene (c.473_474dup; p.(Thr159*)). The variant caused a frameshift leading to premature truncation of the IMPAD1 protein at amino acid 159. This variant was in a heterozygous state in both parents.Postmortem Radiographic Evaluation: Confirmed short long bones (< 4SD) with symmetrical involvement of proximal, middle, and distal bones, showing minimal bowing. Both distal humeri were deformed with a broad proximal end and minimal sclerosis. Clavicles appeared thick with an abrupt angle at the junction of the middle and outer third. Scapulae were stout and rounded. Bilateral subluxation of elbow joints was observed. Hands showed bilateral hitch-hiker thumb deformity with broad and short phalanges. Right great toe had excessive outward angulation. No fractures were noted. Skull bones were normal. Decreased vertebral height globally, small vertebral bodies in the lumbar region, and absent vertebral bodies in the upper cervical region were observed. A hemivertebra was present at D5. The thoracic cage was normal. The pelvic bones were horizontally oriented ileum. Growth cartilage showed focal cystic degenerative changes and separation of chondroblastic columns with vacuolated cytoplasm and occasional cytoplasmic inclusions.Genetic Analysis: Sequencing using ABI 3130 Genetic analyzer of the DTDST gene did not reveal any clinically significant variant. Whole exome sequencing using Agilent Sureselect clinical research exome V2 capture kit on Illumina HiSeq2000 identified a homozygous 2 bp duplication in exon 2 of the IMPAD1 gene, causing a frameshift mutation (c.473_474dup; p.(Thr159*)) leading to premature truncation of the protein. The variant was absent in population databases (1000 genomes, gnomAD) and in-house databases. Both parents were heterozygous for the mutation.Histological Examination: Hematoxylin–eosin staining of the growth cartilage showed focal cystic degenerative changes and separation of chondroblastic columns, with chondrocytes displaying vacuolated cytoplasm and occasional inclusions. Alcian blue staining revealed markedly less intense staining at pH 1 compared to pH 2.5, indicating reduced sulfated glycosaminoglycans."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 28-year-old parous woman. She and her partner are second-degree consanguineous. The patient was referred to the health service at 35 weeks' gestation. The fetus was male.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "A first trimester ultrasound raised suspicion of short long bones. At 16 weeks, long bones remained shortened with fixed flexion bilaterally at the elbow, wrist, and knee joints, as well as bilateral talipes. Serial scans continued to document severe shortening of the long bones, eventually lagging 10 weeks behind dates at 33 weeks' gestation. The long bones progressively appeared more angulated and fractured. By mid-gestation, bilateral fractures of the femur and humerus were diagnosed, and kyphosis of the lower lumbar spine was documented. At 35 weeks' gestation, the woman was transferred to a tertiary centre due to new-onset fetal cardiac findings. The fetus was in breech presentation. Significant cardiomegaly was noted. The right heart was enlarged, secondary to severe tricuspid valve regurgitation, pulmonary valve insufficiency, and a small arterial duct. The left heart structures were normal, with preserved biventricular systolic function and a normal atrial rhythm. There was no history of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory intake during the pregnancy. Mid-trimester cardiac screening had reported normal cardiac size and connections. Delivery was planned 12 hours later, after administration of a single 11.4 mg dose of betamethasone. At 35+5 weeks, a live male baby was delivered by caesarean section, weighing 2,500 g with Apgar scores of 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 min, respectively. Features of facial dysmorphism as well as a pan-systolic murmur were noted on initial examination. The newborn required immediate intubation and was transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit on 100% FiO2. Following birth, the limb fractures and contractures were clinically evident. The admission was further complicated by a pulmonary haemorrhage and the infant succumbed at day 44 of life.",

  "Physical Examination": "On initial examination of the newborn, features of facial dysmorphism as well as a pan-systolic murmur were noted. Following birth, limb fractures and contractures were clinically evident.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient and her partner have no significant personal or family history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "CMA testing reported a homozygous (partial) deletion of the PLOD2 and PLSCR4 gene, in the long arm of chromosome 3, band q22.1 to q24, measuring approximately 0.067–0.087 Mb in size. The partial deletion of PLOD2 would likely result in a non-functional copy whereas the consequences of the partial deletion of PLSCR4 are uncertain. A cardiac echocardiogram confirmed tricuspid valve dysplasia with severe regurgitation. There was antegrade flow across the pulmonary valve and the arterial duct was restrictive. There were additional findings of an anterior mitral valve prolapse with mild mitral regurgitation and mild impairment of left ventricular systolic function."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 28-year-old parous woman. She and her partner are second-degree consanguineous. The patient was referred to the health service at 35 weeks' gestation. The fetus was male.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "A first trimester ultrasound raised suspicion of short long bones. At 16 weeks, long bones remained shortened with fixed flexion bilaterally at the elbow, wrist, and knee joints, as well as bilateral talipes. Serial scans continued to document severe shortening of the long bones, eventually lagging 10 weeks behind dates at 33 weeks' gestation. The long bones progressively appeared more angulated and fractured. By mid-gestation, bilateral fractures of the femur and humerus were diagnosed, and kyphosis of the lower lumbar spine was documented. At 35 weeks' gestation, the woman was transferred to a tertiary centre due to new-onset fetal cardiac findings. The fetus was in breech presentation. Significant cardiomegaly was noted. The right heart was enlarged, secondary to severe tricuspid valve regurgitation, pulmonary valve insufficiency, and a small arterial duct. The left heart structures were normal, with preserved biventricular systolic function and a normal atrial rhythm. There was no history of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory intake during the pregnancy. Mid-trimester cardiac screening had reported normal cardiac size and connections. Delivery was planned 12 hours later, after administration of a single 11.4 mg dose of betamethasone. At 35+5 weeks, a live male baby was delivered by caesarean section, weighing 2,500 g with Apgar scores of 3 and 6 at 1 and 5 min, respectively. Features of facial dysmorphism as well as a pan-systolic murmur were noted on initial examination. The newborn required immediate intubation and was transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit on 100% FiO2. Following birth, the limb fractures and contractures were clinically evident. The admission was further complicated by a pulmonary haemorrhage and the infant succumbed at day 44 of life.",

There were additional findings of an anterior mitral valve prolapse with mild mitral regurgitation and mild impairment of left ventricular systolic function.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "At 16 weeks, ultrasound showed shortened long bones with fixed flexion bilaterally at the elbow, wrist, and knee joints as well as bilateral talipes. Cases.Final Name: fibular aplasia, tibial campomelia, and oligosyndactyly (FATCO syndrome)
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male neonate born at approximately 35 weeks of gestation by cesarean section. His birth weight was 1875 g (10th percentile), length was 40 cm (below 3rd percentile), and head circumference was 29.5 cm (10th percentile). The parents were consanguineous (first cousins), with the mother being 34 years old (G5P3+1) and the father 39 years old.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The neonate was born to a mother who had premature contractions leading to premature rupture of membranes. His Apgar scores were three in the first minute and seven in the fifth minute. He was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) soon after birth with grade II respiratory distress and skeletal deformities. On admission, the baby was tachypneic with a respiratory rate of 65 breaths/min, but other vital signs were within normal ranges. On day three of life, the baby developed repeated apnea attacks, mostly due to early onset sepsis. His condition continued to deteriorate, and he died at the age of seven days from septicemia and disseminated intravascular coagulation.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed brachycephaly without unusual facies. Multiple prominent skeletal deformities were observed, including oligodactyly of the right hand (only three fingers: thumb, little finger, and one in between), and a shorter right lower limb than the left due to abnormal angulation in the middle of the tibia, with overlying skin dimple. Ectrodactyly in the right foot was noted, manifesting as syndactyly between the two medial toes, separated from the little toe by a wide gap, characteristic of split hand/foot malformation. The left upper and lower limbs were normal. Chest examination revealed bilateral decreased air entry with mild intercostal and subcostal retractions. No abnormalities of the head, neck, heart, abdomen, or genitalia were discovered.",

  "Past Medical History": "The mother had gestational diabetes mellitus controlled by insulin. She took vitamins and tocolytics for premature contractions but did not receive prophylactic antibiotics. She had no history of antenatal steroid use. The parents had a strong history of previous children with congenital anomalies: their first (boy) and fourth (girl) babies were normal and healthy, but the second (boy) had cerebral palsy of unknown cause and died at the age of seven years. The third pregnancy was terminated in the fifth month due to multiple congenital anomalies. The parents had disregarded previous medical advice to receive genetic counseling.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The sepsis workup included complete blood count, C-reactive protein, and blood culture, which revealed positive growth of group B Streptococci bacteria."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 12-year-old male Syrian child with a normal karyotype (46 XY). He was born at 39 weeks of gestation after a normal pregnancy and delivery to a 28-year-old primigravida/G8P6 mother.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The child was breastfed with good cry and appetite, without any change in skin color, bowel bladder problems, or cleft lip/palate. He had a normal level of intelligence. Prenatal diagnosis was not available due to lack of information and resources with the family.",

  "Physical Examination": "On physical examination, coxa valga was observed in both hips, while the upper limbs were normal. A flexion contracture of both knees was observed with no mobility of the quadriceps mechanism. The left leg was shortened with a palpable bony protuberance in the medial thigh proximal to the knee joint, with the absence of the Patella. The lateral branch articulated the fibula suggesting an immobile knee joint. Examination of the right leg revealed a shortened leg with a palpable fibula lateral to the knee. The tibia was absent with severe knee varus deformity on both sides. Both feet also revealed equinovarus deformity with a small width. An ectrodactyly was observed in both feet of hallux on the right foot, and hallux and 2nd toe on the left foot.",

  "Past Medical History": "No history of maternal drug ingestion, alcohol, tobacco, illicit drug, diabetes mellitus, or infection was reported. No parental consanguinity was present and family history was negative for any birth defects. Family history was negative for any congenital abnormalities (VACTERL association) or limb deficiencies.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Ultrasonography of pelvis and abdomen revealed no renal or visceral abnormalities. Echocardiography at the time of admittance revealed no congenital heart defects."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 15-year-old African-American boy.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with generalized calcific nodules, progressive contractures, and muscle weakness beginning at six years of age. At six years old, he had trouble bending his knees, with progressive contractures and proximal muscle weakness predominantly affecting the elbows and knees. At seven, the first calcific nodule appeared on his right upper arm after a fall. Multiple nodules arose on his trunk and extremities, spontaneously and without any trauma, developing into skin eruptions exposing white chalky material without drainage. The patient had no history of skin rashes, hypohidrosis, hypotrichosis, or findings consistent with poikiloderma. He was a fraternal twin born uneventfully by vaginal delivery at 39 weeks with a birth weight of 2070 g. His development and intellectual status have been normal. There was no family history of POH, poikiloderma, or pulmonary fibrosis, and his fraternal sister is unaffected.",
  "Physical Examination": "On examination at 11 years old, the patient showed short stature and significant failure to thrive with minimal subcutaneous adipose tissue (weight of 17.0 kg (−6.4 SD) and height of 124.4 cm (−3.4 SD)). There were significant generalized hard nodules varying from small to plaque-like appearance involving the trunk and extremities. He had limited mobility due to extensive joint contractures of bilateral upper and lower extremities significantly involving elbows and knees. Muscle strength was noted to be 2/5 bilaterally throughout. There was no malformation of the great toes.",
  "Past Medical History": "",
  "Initial Test Results": "Biochemical evaluation showed vitamin D insufficiency [25(OH) vitamin D = 20 ng/mL, reference range 30–70 ng/mL] with normal levels of parathyroid hormone 34.6 pg/mL, fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF-23) 72 pg/mL, alkaline phosphatase 158 U/L, calcium 8.8 mg/dL, and phosphorus 5.0 mg/dL. Electromyography, performed due to the observed muscle weakness, was negative."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 15-year-old African-American boy.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with generalized calcific nodules, progressive contractures, and muscle weakness beginning at six years of age. At six years old, he had trouble bending his knees, with progressive contractures and proximal muscle weakness predominantly affecting the elbows and knees. At seven, the first calcific nodule appeared on his right upper arm after a fall. Multiple nodules arose on his trunk and extremities, spontaneously and without any trauma, developing into skin eruptions exposing white chalky material without drainage. The patient had no history of skin rashes, hypohidrosis, hypotrichosis, or findings consistent with poikiloderma. He was a fraternal twin born uneventfully by vaginal delivery at 39 weeks with a birth weight of 2070 g. His development and intellectual status have been normal. There was no family history of POH, poikiloderma, or pulmonary fibrosis, and his fraternal sister is unaffected.",
  "Physical Examination": "On examination at 11 years old, the patient showed short stature and significant failure to thrive with minimal subcutaneous adipose tissue (weight of 17.0 kg (−6.4 SD) and height of 124.4 cm (−3.4 SD)). There were significant generalized hard nodules varying from small to plaque-like appearance involving the trunk and extremities. He had limited mobility due to extensive joint contractures of bilateral upper and lower extremities significantly involving elbows and knees. Muscle strength was noted to be 2/5 bilaterally throughout. There was no malformation of the great toes.",
  "Past Medical History": "",
  "Initial Test Results": "Biochemical evaluation showed vitamin D insufficiency [25(OH) vitamin D = 20 ng/mL, reference range 30–70 ng/mL] with normal levels of parathyroid hormone 34.6 pg/mL, fibroblast growth factor 23 (FGF-23) 72 pg/mL, alkaline phosphatase 158 U/L, calcium 8.8 mg/dL, and phosphorus 5.0 mg/dL. Electromyography, performed due to the observed muscle weakness, was negative.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Skeletal survey radiographs revealed extensive heterotopic ossification involving soft tissues and muscles surrounding the bilateral humeri and proximal ulnae, bilateral femurs, and bilateral tibias/fibulas. Computed tomography of the chest, abdomen, and pelvis revealed extensive ossifications of the muscles including the right latissimus dorsi, left scalene, bilateral pectoralis, bilateral external oblique abdominal, right iliacus, bilateral gluteal, left adductor, and left hamstring. There was also involvement of the subcutaneous tissues of the right upper back and left lower quadrant of the abdomen, left posterior sacral region, bilateral hips, and along the fascia superficial to the erector spinae muscles, extending to the skin, with no evidence of pulmonary fibrosis. No abnormal ossifications were seen in the bony structures. Trio-clinical exome sequencing of the proband and both biological parents revealed a novel de novo heterozygous, likely pathogenic variant in the FAM111B (c.1462delT, p.Cys488Valfs*21) in the proband. There was no evidence for a rare sequence variant in the protein-coding regions or splice-site junctions of the GNAS or ACVR1 despite full sequence coverage. The sequence change in FAM111B deletes one nucleotide in exon 4 of the FAM111B (NM_198947.3:c.1462delT), causing a frameshift at codon 488. The new reading frame ends in a stop codon, 21 positions downstream, and is expected to replace the C-terminal portion of the FAM111B with 21 alternative amino acids. This variant is absent from large population studies (Genome Aggregation Database, gnomAD). 3D protein modeling further ascertains how this mutation might affect protein structure and function. Models of the wild-type and c.1462delT sequences of FAM111B were built using I-TASSER. Sequence analysis predicted the resulting Cys488 might be a crucial residue in the potential zinc-binding site. Zinc is essential for numerous processes including protein structural support and enzyme catalysis. Zinc has been shown to inhibit the activity of cysteine proteases, suggesting that alteration of this site alone would cause hyperactivity of the enzymatic portion of FAM111B. Models of other pathogenic variants, including p.Arg626Gly, p.Try621Asp, and p.Ser628Asn, showed that the overall protein structure appeared minimally disrupted, but the area around the putative zinc-binding site was altered. In the p.Cys488Valfs*21 frameshift model, normal predicted folding could not occur, the zinc-binding domain was eliminated, and the overall truncated, N-terminal protein structure was significantly altered."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 17-year-old male who has been practicing recreational indoor climbing for a few months. Geographic location and other demographic details were not provided.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient developed progressive pain and swelling of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint of the third finger. This led him to stop all physical activities due to the pain. He reported no history of local trauma, infection, or other pathology of the finger before the onset of the present symptoms. After 3 months, he consulted his family doctor. Standard X-rays at this stage were interpreted as a non-union of a fracture of the proximal epiphysis of the middle phalanx.",
  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination at 4 months showed tenderness of the dorsum of the PIP joint, without swelling, and full range of active and passive PIP motion.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient reported no history of local trauma, infection, or other pathology of the finger prior to the onset of the present symptoms.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Standard X-rays were interpreted as a non-union of a fracture of the proximal epiphysis of the middle phalanx."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
    "Basic Information": "The patient is a two-year-old girl. Her parents are non-consanguineous. She resides in Tianjin, China.",
    "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted due to progressive enlargement of the abdomen resulting from hepatomegaly. Laboratory examinations revealed nocturnal fasting hypoglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and significantly elevated levels of transaminases. Hepatomegaly was confirmed with both abdominal ultrasound and abdominal computed tomography enhanced scan.",
    "Physical Examination": "Physical examination showed no obvious growth retardation. Furthermore, electromyography excluded myopathy, and cardiomyopathy was ruled out by electrocardiogram and echocardiography.",
    "Past Medical History": "There is no past medical history or familial medical disorders reported.",
    "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory examinations revealed nocturnal fasting hypoglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and significantly elevated levels of transaminases. Abdominal ultrasound confirmed hepatomegaly. Electromyography excluded myopathy, cardiomyopathy was ruled out by electrocardiogram and echocardiography."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
    "Basic Information": "The patient is a two-year-old girl. Her parents are non-consanguineous. She resides in Tianjin, China.",
    "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted due to progressive enlargement of the abdomen resulting from hepatomegaly. Laboratory examinations revealed nocturnal fasting hypoglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and significantly elevated levels of transaminases. Hepatomegaly was confirmed with both abdominal ultrasound and abdominal computed tomography enhanced scan.",
    "Physical Examination": "Physical examination showed no obvious growth retardation. Furthermore, electromyography excluded myopathy, and cardiomyopathy was ruled out by electrocardiogram and echocardiography.",
    "Past Medical History": "There is no past medical history or familial medical disorders reported.",
    "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory examinations revealed nocturnal fasting hypoglycemia, hyperlipidemia, and significantly elevated levels of transaminases. Abdominal ultrasound confirmed hepatomegaly. Electromyography excluded myopathy, cardiomyopathy was ruled out by electrocardiogram and echocardiography.",
    "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Peripheral blood of the patient and parents were sent for whole-exome sequencing (WES), Sanger sequencing, and qRT-PCR at MyGenostics company (Beijing, China). Genetic analysis revealed biallelic novel pathogenic variants in the AGL gene. Sanger sequencing identified a previously unreported heterozygous variant in exon 5 of the AGL gene: c.597delG (p. Q199Hfs*2) (NM_000642), inherited from the mother, causing the glutamine at position 199 to change to histidine, leading to the insertion of a stop codon at position 200. Furthermore, the heterozygous deletion of exon 13 found by WES was also a previously unreported variant, which was inherited from the father. qRT-PCR results showed that the relative copy number of exon 13 in the control and the patient’s mother were normal, while the proband and the father had half of the normal copy number, confirming the absence of exon 13. This deletion causes deletions of amino acids from position 538 to 578, leading to the termination of transcription at the 540th amino acid. Both variants in the AGL gene could cause the early termination of gene transcription. The patient inherited both variants, becoming a compound heterozygote."
}"

Cases.Final Name: Progressive sensorineural hearing loss-hypertrophic cardiomyopathy syndrome
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "21-year-old man from Abu Dhabi",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with progressive exertional dyspnea and exercise intolerance that limited his activities of daily living, symptoms he had experienced since childhood. His medical history included recently diagnosed bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), bilateral primary open-angle glaucoma, and inappropriate sinus tachycardia. Pertinent cardiac medications included bisoprolol and ivabradine. His family history was notable for consanguinity but unremarkable for cardiac or genetic disorders.",
  "Physical Examination": "On examination, the patient was bradycardic (pulse rate, 55/min) with a blood pressure of 133/82 mm Hg. His oxygen saturation was 100% on room air. The 6-minute walk test distance was 40% of predicted. Physical examination revealed no evidence of decompensated congestive heart failure (HF) but was notable for multiple craniofacial dysmorphisms, including synophrys (fusion of the eyebrows), dolichocephaly (anterior-posterior elongation of the skull), low-set ears with small lobes, and a high-arched palate.",
  "Past Medical History": "Medical history included recently diagnosed bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), bilateral primary open-angle glaucoma, and inappropriate sinus tachycardia. Family history was notable for consanguinity but unremarkable for cardiac or genetic disorders.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Electrocardiography showed sinus bradycardia (heart rate, 53/min), left ventricle (LV) hypertrophy by Sokolov-Lyon criteria, lateral and inferior T-wave inversions, and high-voltage QRS complexes. Initial laboratory testing showed normal plasma creatinine (0.8 mg/dL) and N-terminal pro B-type natriuretic peptide levels (<50 pg/mL). Stress transthoracic echocardiography showed an LV ejection fraction of 66% with biventricular hypertrophy. The free wall of the right ventricle (RV) measured 1.1 cm in thickness. The LV had concentric hypertrophy, most notable at the posterior and lateral walls of the apex, which measured 1.7 cm. The LV basal septum measured 1.3 cm, and the LV basal posterior wall measured 1.1 cm. There was moderate chordal systolic anterior motion with no resting left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) gradient. There was no provokable LVOT obstruction with the Valsalva maneuver or administration of amyl nitrate."
}"

Pertinent cardiac medications included bisoprolol and ivabradine. His family history was notable for consanguinity but unremarkable for cardiac or genetic disorders.",
  "Physical Examination": "On examination, the patient was bradycardic (pulse rate, 55/min) with a blood pressure of 133/82 mm Hg. His oxygen saturation was 100% on room air. The 6-minute walk test distance was 40% of predicted. Physical examination revealed no evidence of decompensated congestive heart failure (HF) but was notable for multiple craniofacial dysmorphisms, including synophrys (fusion of the eyebrows), dolichocephaly (anterior-posterior elongation of the skull), low-set ears with small lobes, and a high-arched palate.",
  "Past Medical History": "Medical history included recently diagnosed bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), bilateral primary open-angle glaucoma, and inappropriate sinus tachycardia. Family history was notable for consanguinity but unremarkable for cardiac or genetic disorders.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Electrocardiography showed sinus bradycardia (heart rate, 53/min), left ventricle (LV) hypertrophy by Sokolov-Lyon criteria, lateral and inferior T-wave inversions, and high-voltage QRS complexes. Initial laboratory testing showed normal plasma creatinine (0.8 mg/dL) and N-terminal pro B-type natriuretic peptide levels (<50 pg/mL). Stress transthoracic echocardiography showed an LV ejection fraction of 66% with biventricular hypertrophy. The free wall of the right ventricle (RV) measured 1.1 cm in thickness. The LV had concentric hypertrophy, most notable at the posterior and lateral walls of the apex, which measured 1.7 cm. The LV basal septum measured 1.3 cm, and the LV basal posterior wall measured 1.1 cm. There was moderate chordal systolic anterior motion with no resting left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) gradient. There was no provokable LVOT obstruction with the Valsalva maneuver or administration of amyl nitrate.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed no evidence of fibrosis and demonstrated normal perfusion and viability. There were increased trabeculations in the RV apex and in the lateral wall and apex of the LV, but no wall-motion abnormalities or abrupt transition in the thickness of compacted myocardium; these findings did not meet criteria for LV noncompaction cardiomyopathy. Metabolic stress testing showed peak oxygen uptake at 13% of predicted and a blunted chronotropic response (63% of predicted for age) despite excellent effort. Right heart catheterization showed a mildly reduced cardiac output using the Fick method (3.67 L/min), an elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (16 mm Hg), tall A and V waves (both 24 mm Hg), and rapid X and Y descents. The pulmonary artery pressure (34/16 mm Hg; mean, 22 mm Hg), RV pressure (40/10 mm Hg), and right atrial mean pressure (8 mm Hg) were at the upper limit of normal. Metabolic testing revealed marked lactic aciduria (1,650.1 μmol/mmol creatinine [Cr]; reference range, 2.9–47.2 μmol/mmol creatinine) and elevated plasma lactate (3.9 mmol/L; reference range, 0.5–2.2 mmol/L). Creatine kinase (74 U/L) and aldolase (4.4 U/L) levels were normal. The plasma acylcarnitine profile showed increased levels of medium-chain species and multiple long-chain species. The plasma amino acid profile revealed a moderately elevated alanine level of 620 μmol/L (reference range, 177–583 μmol/L). The chromosome single-nucleotide polymorphism array was normal, and the HCM multigene panel—including cardiac β-myosin heavy chain, myosin binding protein gene, and cardiac troponin T—was unremarkable. Mitochondrial genetic testing revealed a pathogenic homozygous c.385G>A (p.Gly129Arg) mutation in the BCS1L gene. The patient did not undergo muscle or cardiac biopsy. Evaluation for cardiac transplantation is ongoing."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The case involves female monochorionic-biamniotic twins born preterm at 28 6/7 weeks of gestational age through vaginal delivery in an unspecified geographic location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The pregnancy developed spontaneously without any infectious or familial risk factors. Antepartum betamethasone treatment was completed. The newborn adaptation was regular with Apgar scores of 8-10 at 1 and 5 minutes for the first twin (FT), and 6-9 for the second twin (ST). Both twins had an appropriate weight for gestational age, categorized at medium-high percentiles (72nd percentile and 85th percentile, respectively). The perinatal clinical course was largely unremarkable except for mild precocious hypoglycemia in ST, which was corrected intravenously. The twins were discharged at 37 2/7 weeks of postconceptional age in good general conditions. At the first follow-up at 3 months chronological age, FT's growth continued normally, but ST experienced significant weight increase (reaching the 97th percentile), developed a wide glabellar nevus simplex, moderate macroglossia, and an enlarging but reducible umbilical hernia.",
  "Physical Examination": "FT presented with a hemangioma precursor on the right hand and wrist, while ST had a mild reducible umbilical hernia. Both twins exhibited camptodactyly. At 3 months of chronological age, ST showed a wide glabellar nevus simplex and moderate macroglossia. The umbilical hernia in ST had grown larger but remained reducible. No hemihypertrophy was noted.",
  "Past Medical History": "No infectious or familial risk factors were reported. The pregnancy developed spontaneously without complications.",
  "Initial Test Results": "A blood sample for Methylation-specific multiple ligation-dependent probe amplification (MS-MLPA) was drawn from each twin to analyze the BWS critical region (11p15.5-p15.4 locus)."
}"

The newborn adaptation was regular with Apgar scores of 8-10 at 1 and 5 minutes for the first twin (FT), and 6-9 for the second twin (ST). Both twins had an appropriate weight for gestational age, categorized at medium-high percentiles (72nd percentile and 85th percentile, respectively). The perinatal clinical course was largely unremarkable except for mild precocious hypoglycemia in ST, which was corrected intravenously. The twins were discharged at 37 2/7 weeks of postconceptional age in good general conditions. At the first follow-up at 3 months chronological age, FT's growth continued normally, but ST experienced significant weight increase (reaching the 97th percentile), developed a wide glabellar nevus simplex, moderate macroglossia, and an enlarging but reducible umbilical hernia.",
  "Physical Examination": "FT presented with a hemangioma precursor on the right hand and wrist, while ST had a mild reducible umbilical hernia. Both twins exhibited camptodactyly.   "Past Medical History": "No infectious or familial risk factors were reported. The pregnancy developed spontaneously without complications.",
  "Initial Test Results": "A blood sample for Methylation-specific multiple ligation-dependent probe amplification (MS-MLPA) was drawn from each twin to analyze the BWS critical region (11p15.5-p15.4 locus).",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "During the first surveillance ultrasound of the abdomen in ST, an adrenal cystic mass was discovered. Meta-iodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) scintigraphy confirmed a cystic neuroblastoma, which was successfully surgically removed. In a follow-up analysis, methylation levels for IC2 LOM were confirmed in ST using DNA from buccal mucosa by pyrosequencing, while FT's methylation level was comparable to normal controls."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient was a 2-month-old female infant born after 37 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2730 g.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "At 2 months, she experienced her first episode of syncope due to repetitive TdPs that degenerated into VF. Her ECG revealed typical T wave alternans, markedly prolonged QT-intervals (RR = 570 ms, QT = 501 ms, QTc = 664 ms), 2:1 atrio-ventricular (AV) block, and recurrence of TdP. The echocardiography showed no congenital heart defects nor hypertrophy. Mexiletine was administered as an initial therapy, which resolved the 2:1 AV block to a 1:1 conduction. Propranolol was also started, which suppressed recurrence of TdP. The patient also suffered from recurrent seizures unrelated to TdPs from 4 months after birth. An electroencephalogram at the age of 7 months displayed hypsarrhythmia. She showed severe developmental disability and hypotonia, and thus she was barely able to roll over at the age of 3. The patient was also diagnosed with autism spectrum disorder at the age of 2. With the medications, the patient’s ECG at the age of 5 showed slightly prolonged QTc (RR = 559 ms, QT = 346 ms, QTc = 462 ms). Since the pharmacotherapy successfully suppressed her TdP, implantable cardioverter-defibrillator (ICD) was not implanted. Unfortunately, the patient suddenly passed away at 5 years old during a nap.",
  "Physical Examination": "The patient’s face was characterized by dysmorphic features such as high arched palate, full cheeks, and congenital clasped thumb, but no syndactyly. She showed severe developmental disability and hypotonia, and was barely able to roll over at the age of 3.",
  "Past Medical History": "There were no findings that indicated hypoglycemia or immunodeficiency related to TS. Her family history was negative for SCD, LQTS, arrhythmia, or neurological abnormalities.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Her ECG revealed typical T wave alternans, markedly prolonged QT-intervals (RR = 570 ms, QT = 501 ms, QTc = 664 ms). Echocardiography showed no congenital heart defects nor hypertrophy. An electroencephalogram at the age of 7 months displayed hypsarrhythmia. The patient’s ECG at the age of 5 showed slightly prolonged QTc (RR = 559 ms, QT = 346 ms, QTc = 462 ms)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 31-year-old pregnant woman (gravida 1, para 0) referred at 25 weeks’ gestation. Geographic location: Chicago, IL, USA. Race: Not specified. Gender: Female.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred for fetal echocardiography at 25 weeks’ gestation. Echocardiographic examination showed fetal PMV associated with coarctation of the aorta (CoA). In the four-chamber view, the mobility of the mitral valve leaflets was limited without thickening, and the shape of the mitral valve leaflets and some chordae resembled the 'Ω' symbol in diastole. Further examination showed all chordae inserted into the posteromedial PM. The short-axis view detected the posteromedial PM but did not identify the anterolateral PM. These findings led to a diagnosis of PMV. A systematic scan revealed CoA and a small left ventricle. Multidisciplinary consultation with a pediatric cardiac surgeon resulted in the parents deciding to terminate the pregnancy at 30 weeks’ gestation due to high surgical risks and difficulties associated with reoperation. Autopsy of the fetal heart and copy number variation sequencing were performed with parental consent.",
  "Physical Examination": "Not applicable.",
  "Past Medical History": "No specific details provided on the past medical history of the patient or the family.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Echocardiography at 25 weeks’ gestation revealed limited mobility of mitral valve leaflets in a four-chamber view and all chordae inserted into the posteromedial PM. Short-axis view detected the posteromedial PM but not the anterolateral PM. Systematic scan detected CoA and a small left ventricle (aortic isthmus, Z score -3.47; left ventricular end-diastolic dimension, Z score -2.41; left ventricular inlet length, Z score -1.82)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 31-year-old male smoker from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the emergency department with episodes of atypical chest pain radiating to the left arm for 5 days. There was no history of fever, cough, or contact with COVID-infected patients. The patient had decreased vision in the left eye, starting at the age of 10 years which progressed to blindness. He was diagnosed to have IGFBP7 mutation which causes eye manifestations in the form of FRAM (Familial Retinal Arterial Macroaneurysms). His younger brother was also diagnosed to have FRAM and IGFBP7 mutation at the age of 23. The rest of his siblings and parents are asymptomatic.",

  "Physical Examination": "On clinical examination, the patient was vitally stable with a pulse rate of 74 beats/min and blood pressure of 125/74 mm/Hg. He was afebrile and oxygen saturation at room air was 95%. Cardiac examination revealed normal character of first and second heart sound without additional sounds. Fundoscopy showed bleeding retinal artery macroaneurysms in the right retina and sub-retinal gliosis suggesting laser treatment for prior retinal arterial aneurysm.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of decreased vision in the left eye starting at age 10, which progressed to blindness. He was diagnosed with IGFBP7 mutation causing eye manifestations in the form of FRAM. His younger brother was also diagnosed with FRAM and IGFBP7 mutation at age 23. The rest of his siblings and parents are asymptomatic.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Electrocardiogram showed normal sinus rhythm with T-wave inversions in lateral leads. Blood investigations showed a mildly raised white blood cell count of 13.08 109 /L (normal 3.9–11 109 /L). The troponin was raised at 637 ng/L (normal = 34 ng/L) and the repeated level showed 1938 ng/L and it peaked up to 5484 ng/L the next day. Echocardiography showed normal biventricular systolic function with normal valves. There were no regional wall motion abnormalities. Chest X-rays did not show any significant findings. C-reactive proteins were high but PCR for COVID was negative."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Coronary angiogram was performed which showed a large aneurysm in the proximal segment of the left anterior descending (LAD) artery. Myocardial bridging was noted in the mid-segment of LAD. There were non-obstructive calcified plaques in the right coronary artery. CT scan of the brain with contrast was done to assess associated intracerebral aneurysms which did not show any significant abnormality."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 22-year-old woman presented to the ophthalmology clinic.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient has a 2-week history of a visual field defect in the left eye. She was diagnosed with a large hemangioma involving the right retina, upper face, lower face, and upper neck at age 3 months and received pulsed dye laser and intralesional laser photocoagulation surgery. Additionally, she experienced vision loss in the right eye at age 5 years due to the retinal hemangioma. Fundus photographs of bilateral eyes show multisegmental thick perivenous sheathing which might indicate vasculitis. Optical coherence tomography (OCT) of the left eye shows deposits at the disrupted ellipsoid zone, and a visual field test shows temporal hemianopia of the left eye. Other ocular examinations of the left eye were within normal ranges. The light reflex and extraocular motility in the left eye were normal. She denied having headaches, dizziness, or nausea.",

Other ocular examinations of the left eye were within normal ranges. The light reflex and extraocular motility in the left eye were normal.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A contrast-enhanced MRI revealed multiple serpiginous signal-void channels at the retrobulbar region of the left orbit with probable compression on the left ophthalmic nerve. Subsequent cerebral angiography demonstrated the total occlusion of the horizontal cavernous segment of the left internal carotid artery (ICA), along with collaterals from the left ophthalmic artery to recanalize the ophthalmic segment of the ICA. Some collaterals from the left middle meningeal artery and the distal internal maxillary artery supplying the left ophthalmic artery were also noted. The total occlusion of the terminal segment of the right ICA was detected with prominent collaterals from the right ophthalmic artery to recanalize the bilateral anterior cerebral arteries. Leptomeningeal collaterals from the bilateral posterior cerebral arteries supplying to the bilateral middle cerebral artery territories were noted. Flat-panel computed tomography angiography depicted prominent collaterals around the optic canal compressing the optic nerve, which is presumed to be the cause leading to her symptoms."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 2-year-old female, born at 36 weeks 6 days gestational age by caesarean section due to non-reassuring fetal status. She is the second child of healthy nonconsanguineous parents.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was diagnosed with Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) prenatally through a fetal echocardiogram. A Blalock-Taussig shunt was performed at 9 months of age. At 18 months, she was referred for assessment of developmental delay, microcephaly, and growth retardation. Her developmental milestones were delayed: head control at four months, rolling at six months, sitting at 13 months, crawling at 18 months, walking with support at 21 months, and speaking words at 2 years old. The patient exhibited dysmorphic features including wide face, broad forehead, puffy eyelids, broad nasal base, broad and prominent philtrum, pointed chin, full cheeks, and prominent ears.",

  "Physical Examination": "At birth, the patient's weight was 1680 g (− 2.0 SD), length was 43.5 cm (− 1.5 SD), and occipital-frontal head circumference (OFC) was 29.4 cm (− 1.7 SD). At 18 months of age, her height was 68.8 cm (− 3.9 SD), weight was 5.7 kg (− 4.2 SD), and OFC was 40 cm (− 4.3 SD).",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) diagnosed prenatally. She underwent a Blalock-Taussig shunt procedure at 9 months of age.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient's karyotype and chromosomal microarray were normal."
}"

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was diagnosed with Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) prenatally through a fetal echocardiogram. A Blalock-Taussig shunt was performed at 9 months of age. At 18 months, she was referred for assessment of developmental delay, microcephaly, and growth retardation. Her developmental milestones were delayed: head control at four months, rolling at six months, sitting at 13 months, crawling at 18 months, walking with support at 21 months, and speaking words at 2 years old. The patient exhibited dysmorphic features including wide face, broad forehead, puffy eyelids, broad nasal base, broad and prominent philtrum, pointed chin, full cheeks, and prominent ears.",

At 18 months of age, her height was 68.8 cm (− 3.9 SD), weight was 5.7 kg (− 4.2 SD), and OFC was 40 cm (− 4.3 SD).",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) diagnosed prenatally. She underwent a Blalock-Taussig shunt procedure at 9 months of age.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A head MRI at 13 months of age revealed a slight loss of white matter volume and hypoplastic corpus callosum, with no other anomalies. Exome sequencing was performed with a mean depth of coverage of 103.13 per base, and 96.3% of the coding region was covered by at least 20 reads. A de novo missense CAMK2B variant (NM_172079.2:c.895 A > G (p.Lys299Glu) NC_000007.14:g.44241708 T > C (hg38)) was identified. This variant was confirmed by Sanger sequencing and classified as 'Likely pathogenic (PS2+PM2_supporting+PP2+PP3+PP4)' according to ACMG 2015 variant interpretation guidelines. No other candidate variants were detected."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 57-year-old woman from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with symmetrical erythematous patch and painful ulcers on the lower extremities. She had a 7-year history of recurrent chronic livedoid vasculitis (LV). She complained of severe pain of the skin and numbness of the legs. The patient had been previously diagnosed with livedoid vasculitis at a local hospital and was treated with corticosteroids, aspirin, and Chinese medicine for local recurrence, but these treatments were ineffective. After diagnosis, the patient was prescribed oral aspirin, cyclosporine A, and minocycline for 1 month, which were also ineffective. The patient experienced intense pain that affected her quality of life. Subsequently, Adalimumab was administered by subcutaneous injection of 80 mg, followed by 40 mg every 2 weeks, in combination with oral minocycline (100 mg/day for 1 month). The patient showed progressive and rapid improvement of pain, erythema, and wounding after 2 weeks. Almost complete remission of LV was achieved after the third dose. The patient continued treatment with adalimumab 40 mg subcutaneously a month alone, with gradually extended treatment intervals, without recurrence and adverse effects.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed erythema, painful and crusted perforated ulcers, white atrophy, and small white atrophic scars around the ankle area and lower extremities.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a 7-year history of recurrent chronic livedoid vasculitis.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory findings including antinuclear antibodies, ds-DNA, anticardiolipin antibodies (IgA and IgG), rheumatoid factor, C3, C4, ASO, C-reaction protein, and coagulation were negative. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate was increased."
}"

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with symmetrical erythematous patch and painful ulcers on the lower extremities. She had a 7-year history of recurrent chronic livedoid vasculitis (LV). She complained of severe pain of the skin and numbness of the legs. The patient had been previously diagnosed with livedoid vasculitis at a local hospital and was treated with corticosteroids, aspirin, and Chinese medicine for local recurrence, but these treatments were ineffective. After diagnosis, the patient was prescribed oral aspirin, cyclosporine A, and minocycline for 1 month, which were also ineffective. The patient experienced intense pain that affected her quality of life. Subsequently, Adalimumab was administered by subcutaneous injection of 80 mg, followed by 40 mg every 2 weeks, in combination with oral minocycline (100 mg/day for 1 month). The patient showed progressive and rapid improvement of pain, erythema, and wounding after 2 weeks. Almost complete remission of LV was achieved after the third dose. The patient continued treatment with adalimumab 40 mg subcutaneously a month alone, with gradually extended treatment intervals, without recurrence and adverse effects.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed erythema, painful and crusted perforated ulcers, white atrophy, and small white atrophic scars around the ankle area and lower extremities.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a 7-year history of recurrent chronic livedoid vasculitis.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory findings including antinuclear antibodies, ds-DNA, anticardiolipin antibodies (IgA and IgG), rheumatoid factor, C3, C4, ASO, C-reaction protein, and coagulation were negative. The erythrocyte sedimentation rate was increased.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A skin biopsy was performed, which showed fibrin degeneration of some small blood vessel walls and small thrombi. The diagnosis of LV was made based on clinical presentation and pathological findings."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 62-year-old woman from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "In February 2022, the patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of breathlessness and an intermittent fever for more than 20 days. She had a history of epistaxis episodes and sporadic bleeding 40 years ago, mostly triggered or exacerbated by exertion or stress. During her current hospitalization, she recovered and was discharged on the 20th day after being treated with antibiotics, diuretics, cardiotonic drugs, and other supportive care measures. The patient was later hospitalized again for dyspnea, during which she experienced a major seizure lasting about an hour. She was treated with mechanical ventilation and sedation, and was cured without complications.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed telangiectasias in the oral mucosa and hand, wet rale from the bottom of the left lung, an atrial fibrillation rhythm, and mild edema in both lower limbs.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's medical history included brain abscesses and a video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery for pulmonary neoplasm 6 months prior to the current admission, with a histopathological diagnosis of hemangioma. Regarding her family history, one of her sisters and her young daughter both suffered from nasal hemorrhage, but they refused to undergo imaging screening and genetic testing.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Comprehensive laboratory testing was mostly normal, with the exception of mild anemia. Assessment of thrombophilia revealed no significant abnormalities except for a higher D-dimer. Transthoracic echocardiography showed an obvious enlargement of the left heart and right atrium, massive tricuspid regurgitation (14.9 cm2), and elevated pulmonary artery systolic pressure (42 mmHg). Right heart catheterization indicated no pulmonary arterial hypertension with a mean pulmonary artery pressure of 20 mmHg, a pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 9 mmHg, and a pulmonary vascular resistance of 2.16 Wood."
}"
