Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 46-year-old female. No specific geographic location is mentioned.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient developed weakness in the lower limbs and moderate low back pain for four months. She was referred to the National Institute of Neurology and Neurosurgery Manuel Velasco Suarez for further evaluation. The patient reported overflow incontinence and constipation with difficulty evacuating for one month of evolution.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed diminished strength in lower limbs, with 2/5 in the right pelvic limb and 3/5 proximal and 2/5 distal in the left pelvic limb based on Daniel's strength scale. The patient had a sensitive affection with hypoesthesia located in the T6 dermatome. Patellar and Achilles stretch reflexes were poorly evoked. The rest of the examination was normal.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no significant past medical and surgical history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were mentioned in the provided information."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 46-year-old female. No specific geographic location is mentioned.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient developed weakness in the lower limbs and moderate low back pain for four months. She was referred to the National Institute of Neurology and Neurosurgery Manuel Velasco Suarez for further evaluation. The patient reported overflow incontinence and constipation with difficulty evacuating for one month of evolution.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed diminished strength in lower limbs, with 2/5 in the right pelvic limb and 3/5 proximal and 2/5 distal in the left pelvic limb based on Daniel's strength scale. The patient had a sensitive affection with hypoesthesia located in the T6 dermatome. Patellar and Achilles stretch reflexes were poorly evoked. The rest of the examination was normal.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no significant past medical and surgical history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were mentioned in the provided information.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A spinal MRI was performed. The thoracic region showed a hyperintense signal image in the spinal cord from T6 to T11 levels in T2 and short tau inversion recovery (STIR) sequences, which occupied more than 80% of the circumference of the spinal cord in axial sections. This image was consistent with cytotoxic edema or myelomalacia. The image also showed enlarged perimedullary vessels in the posterior epidural region, with hyperintense signal voids in T1 and a hypointense signal in T2 sequences. A spinal DSA was subsequently performed, which revealed a right perimedullary fistula type I, with a feeding artery of the radiculopial branch and a perimedullary venous drainage of the segmental artery of the right L2. The fistula was satisfactorily embolized with a 20% histoacryl-lipiodol emulsion."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is an Italian male who initially presented at age 2 years. The diagnosis was delayed until age 4 years when he came to medical attention.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a history of recurrent upper airway infections, coarse facial features with enlarged skull, hepatosplenomegaly, umbilical and inguinal hernias, and joint contractures with claw hand deformity. He also exhibited psychomotor delay (total intelligence quotient 79 based on the WPPSIIII score), hyperactivity, and attention difficulties. At age 4, instrumental assessments revealed dysostosis multiplex (whole-body radiography), enlargement of perivascular spaces (brain MRI), and aortic and mitral stenosis (echocardiography). Weekly enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) with intravenous idursulfase (Elaprase®, Takeda) at the standard dosage (0.5 mg/kg, total dose 12 mg) was initiated. The patient experienced several symptoms suggestive of infusion-associated reactions (IARs). About 18 hours after the first infusion, he experienced fever and vomiting for 2 days, initially attributed to a concurrent viral infection. At infusion 3, after the first 10 minutes, the patient presented with cough and hoarse voice. The infusion was immediately stopped, and the patient was successfully treated with iv chlorphenamine and methylprednisolone. At subsequent infusions, the patient was premedicated with iv chlorphenamine and methylprednisolone. At infusion 8, 1 hour after the end of the infusion, the patient presented with mild facial maculopapular rash, which resolved spontaneously within 12 hours. This symptom was more severe at the next infusion.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient presented with coarse facial features, enlarged skull, hepatosplenomegaly, umbilical and inguinal hernias, and joint contractures with claw hand deformity.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of recurrent upper airway infections.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Biochemical analyses showed elevated urinary GAGs, with total urinary GAGs 95.8 mg/mmol creatinine (nv < 26.8), HS 47.8 mg/mmol creatinine (nv < 1.2), DS 32 mg/mmol creatinine (nv < 11.4) (MS/MS spectrometry). I2S activity in dried blood spots was low at 0.5 umol/h, 4.1% daily mean activity (MS/MS spectrometry seven-plex kitPerkinElmer®). Idursulfase skin prick tests (SPT; idursulfase 2 mg/ml) and intradermal tests (dilution 1:1000, 1:100, 1:10 of idursulfase 2 mg/ml) were negative. Tryptase levels at the time of the reaction and anti-idursulfase IgE antibodies were also negative, but non-neutralizing anti-idursulfase IgG antibodies were positive."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The case involves a non-consanguineous couple seeking preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) at the Institute of Reproduction and Genetics, Chongqing Health Center for Women and Children in Chongqing, China. The couple had experienced abnormal pregnancies.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The couple visited the institute three times due to abnormal pregnancies and to consult for PGT. Pedigree data were obtained from the couple and their parents. Clinical assessments, including ultrasonic examination and assisted reproductive technology (ART), were performed in the related clinical departments. The couple underwent controlled ovarian stimulation (COS) using a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) antagonist protocol. The COS was initiated on day 2 of the cycle with 250 IU recombinant follicle-stimulating hormone. GnRH antagonist was given on cycle day 8. Human chorionic gonadotropin was administered as a trigger on cycle day 10, and transvaginal oocyte retrieval was performed after 36 hours. As a result, 13 oocytes were obtained, and five blastocysts were biopsied after intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI).",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination details were provided in the given information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The couple had a history of abnormal pregnancies. No other specific past medical history was provided.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were provided in the given information."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The case involves a non-consanguineous couple seeking preimplantation genetic testing (PGT) at the Institute of Reproduction and Genetics, Chongqing Health Center for Women and Children in Chongqing, China. The couple had experienced abnormal pregnancies.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The couple visited the institute three times due to abnormal pregnancies and to consult for PGT. Pedigree data were obtained from the couple and their parents. Clinical assessments, including ultrasonic examination and assisted reproductive technology (ART), were performed in the related clinical departments. The couple underwent controlled ovarian stimulation (COS) using a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) antagonist protocol. The COS was initiated on day 2 of the cycle with 250 IU recombinant follicle-stimulating hormone. GnRH antagonist was given on cycle day 8. Human chorionic gonadotropin was administered as a trigger on cycle day 10, and transvaginal oocyte retrieval was performed after 36 hours. As a result, 13 oocytes were obtained, and five blastocysts were biopsied after intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI).",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination details were provided in the given information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The couple had a history of abnormal pregnancies. No other specific past medical history was provided.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were provided in the given information.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Whole-Exome Sequencing (WES) was performed using the Agilent SureSelect Human All Exon V6 Kit and sequenced on an Illumina NovaSeq 6000 platform. Single-nucleotide variants (SNVs) and InDels were called using Genome Analysis Toolkit (GATK) and annotated with Ensembl Variant Effect Predictor. Variants were filtered using multiple databases and annotated according to ACMG guidelines. Sanger sequencing was used to validate MKS1 mutations in the aborted fetuses and the couple. RT-PCR and qPCR were performed to analyze MKS1 expression. Western blot analysis and co-immunoprecipitation (co-IP) were conducted to study protein expression and interactions. For Preimplantation Genetic Testing for Monogenic Disorders (PGT-M), whole-genome amplification of each embryo biopsy sample was performed using the MALBAC WGA kit. A total of 60 single-nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) markers linked to the mutation alleles were selected for linkage analysis. The mutation site and SNPs were amplified, and the products were sequenced. Chromosomal copy number and mutation site analysis were performed."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a female child, delivered by cesarean section at 40 weeks and 4 days of gestation. Her birth weight was 3750 g. The family is described as a normal couple without close relatives, and the family history is negative.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The child began experiencing seizures one hour after birth, occurring 5-6 times a day and lasting around 10 seconds each. The seizures were characterized by head tilting back, upper left eyes staring, hands clenching, upper limbs flexing and shaking, treadmill movements of lower limbs, and purple coloration around the mouth. These seizures continued, with the same presentation on the 18th day after birth. Treatment included phenobarbital, vitamin B6, levetiracetam, midazolam, oxcarbazepine, and a ketogenic diet starting at 4 months. ACTH was administered at 9 months. Further treatments included oxazepine, sodium valproate, topiramate, nitrazepam, and lacosamine, along with continued ketogenic diet. Seizures were gradually controlled after one and a half years. At 2 years and 10 months, the child could raise her head, laugh, and babble, but could not chase after animals, sit alone, or speak. She had involuntary movements such as head tilting back and hand and foot twisting. A few days after this follow-up, the child developed pneumonia and respiratory failure after catching a cold, followed by seizures. She was admitted to the emergency intensive care unit, received endotracheal intubation ventilator-assisted ventilation and active anti-infection treatment. Three days later, she died of central respiratory failure.",

  "Physical Examination": "At 2 years and 10 months, the child's head circumference was 45 cm. She had a narrow forehead, wide eye distance, round nose, and thick lips. The muscle strength of the limbs was level IV, and muscle tone was increased. Pathological signs were negative.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no history of asphyxia, hypoglycemia, or pathologic jaundice during the perinatal period. The child exhibited global developmental delay and hypertonia. Oral baclofen was administered to reduce muscle tension, and rehabilitation training was performed, but developmental progress was limited.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Video electroencephalogram (VEEG) at 1 month and 15 days showed interictal multifocal epileptiform discharges, noticeable bilaterally in the occipital region. At 8 months, VEEG revealed extensive, multifocal epileptic discharges between seizures. At 1 year and 2 months, VEEG showed slow background activity, with no occipital-dominated rhythm and interictal multifocal epileptiform discharges. At 1 year and 6 months, VEEG displayed no occipital dominant rhythm, bilateral occipital spikes, and slow waves, with no seizures detected."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Brain MRI on the 27th day after birth revealed a blurred T1 high signal in the hindlimb of the internal capsule, a lack of white matter, and a high T2 signal. At 6 months, brain MRI showed deep sulci, delayed myelination, little white matter, and thin corpus callosum. Brain CT at 2 years and 10 months demonstrated brain atrophy. Single whole-exome sequencing, copy number variation, and mitochondrial gene testing were performed at 5 months, with no pathogenic variants found that were extremely consistent with the phenotype. At 2 years and 5 months, trio sequencing was completed using whole-exon next-generation sequencing (NGS). The analysis revealed a compound heterozygous variant of the ACTL6B gene. One variant was a heterozygous deletion of exons 1-4, inherited from the father. The other variant was a c.1017 + 3G > T mutation in the intron region, inherited from the mother."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 47-year-old white female from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient has a history of seizures since 2 years old. The first epileptic event was characterized by sudden loss of awareness, followed by generalized clonic movements and sialorrhea, with no fever or other precipitating symptoms. From 20 years old to the current clinical evaluation, the patient experienced focal onset impaired awareness seizures. These were characterized by an aura of desire to cough or a feeling of dry throat, followed by staring, mouth automatisms, bimanual automatisms, and head shift to the left side, evolving to a postictal state lasting about 2 minutes. The overall seizure time was brief, lasting around 1 minute, with secondary generalizations rarely occurring (only four events during lifetime). The awake seizures had a minimal frequency of two to three per week, worsening in frequency close to the menses phase. There was no history of status epilepticus. A second type of event was reported, described as agitation and frenetic rubbing of the left ear with the ipsilateral hand during sleep, occurring with an average frequency of one to two events each week. The patient had undergone several antiseizure drug trials including valproate, phenytoin, lamotrigine, and phenobarbital, with variable degrees of tolerance and seizure control. The current antiseizure medication was carbamazepine and clobazam, without achieving seizure freedom.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were reported in the given information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no perinatal disorders. There was no history of epilepsy or seizures in the family. The patient's parents were non-consanguineous.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Prolonged (62 h) non-invasive video-EEG monitoring was performed. It showed symmetrical and slightly disorganized base activity, with 778 bilateral interictal epileptic discharges (84.1% in the left anterior temporal region and 15.9% in the right anterior temporal region). Six electroclinical seizures were recorded: five focal onset impaired awareness motor seizures during the awake period and one during sleep. All recorded seizures had the ictal onset and symptomatogenic area in the left temporal lobe. Brain MRI showed left hippocampus atrophy and right hippocampus malrotation. Neuropsychological testing found low scores in episodic memory (verbal and non-verbal), language, speech, constructive praxis, and working memory. Quality of life was assessed using Quality of Life in Epilepsy Inventory-31 (QOLIE-31), with a pre-operative score of 45.4."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 26-year-old female from Mexico.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented to the hospital in June 2015 with dyspnea, heart palpitations, and lower extremity edema. Due to declining functional status, she was admitted. In November 2016, the patient presented with miscarriage, transvaginal bleeding, and declining functional status that necessitated admission to the General Hospital, Cd. Mexico. On examination, the patient was pale and ill-appearing. The exam was remarkable for a high left parasternal murmur and reinforcement of the second pulmonary noise, cyanosis, and acropachy. Heart rhythm and respiratory sounds were normal.",

  "Physical Examination": "The exam revealed a high left parasternal murmur and reinforcement of the second pulmonary noise. Cyanosis and acropachy were observed. Heart rhythm and respiratory sounds were normal. The patient was pale and ill-appearing.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no pathological antecedents prior to her initial presentation in June 2015.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory results revealed BNP 350 pg/mL, Hb 10.5, Hct 32.8%, serum iron 29 mg/dL, total iron binding capacity: 223 mcgg/dL. Arterial blood gas analysis showed PO2 42 mm Hg. Body plethysmography showed normal pulmonary volumes. An electrocardiogram revealed sinus rhythm, heart rate 103 bpm, AQRS +120, deep S in D1, late R in AVR and the presence of qR waves in V1. The exam was remarkable for asymmetrical inversion of ST segment and T wave from V1 to V4. A chest x-ray showed cardiomegaly, prominence of the pulmonary artery and curvilinear opacity that extended downward from the right pulmonary hilum, bordering the cardiac silhouette, to the cardiophrenic angle."
}"

A chest x-ray showed cardiomegaly, prominence of the pulmonary artery and curvilinear opacity that extended downward from the right pulmonary hilum, bordering the cardiac silhouette, to the cardiophrenic angle.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Transthoracic echocardiography in June 2015 revealed a pulmonary artery systolic pressure of 120 mm Hg, a dilated right ventricle, and paradoxical movement of the septum. Right heart catheterization showed pulmonary artery pressure 95 mm Hg. Acute adenosine vasodilator challenge was negative. CT angiography revealed partial anomalous venous drainage. A transesophageal echocardiogram showed TAPSE of 13 mm, interatrial communication of 17 mm of diameter upper venous sinus type and right to left shunt. Both pulmonary right veins drained to the lower vena cava in a supradiaphagmatic portion. Pulmonary systolic arterial pressure was 98 mm Hg. Another right heart catheterization was performed, confirming the previous diagnosis of severe pulmonary hypertension that is not responsive to vasodilator challenge."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male newborn born at term by cesarean section to parents who were second cousins. The mother was 29 years old and gravida 2, para 1. The birth weight was 2.25 kg.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "An antenatal fetal ultrasound scan at 35 weeks gestation showed evidence of intrauterine growth retardation. An ileostomy was performed at 48 hours after birth for jejunal obstruction. At the age of 15 days, the child presented with failure to thrive, difficulty in feeding, and apneic spells since birth. The child required tube feeding from birth. The cry was feeble. The child deteriorated and died at 1 month of age. An autopsy was not performed.",

  "Physical Examination": "At 15 days old, the patient's weight was 2.25 kg, length 40 cm, and occipito-frontal circumference 31.5 cm (all less than the third centile). The skull was dolichocephalic with a receding forehead. The ears were low set with prominent antihelices. He had narrow and slightly upslanting palpebral fissures, a proud, prominent nose, almost no glabellar angle, micrognathia, microstomia with a high arched palate and a short neck. Both testicles were descended. He had long hands with narrow fingers and hyperconvex nails. The fingers were clenched with the second and fifth fingers overlapping the third and fourth. Abduction at the hips and extension at the knees was limited. He had 'rocker bottom' feet with clinodactyly of the fourth and fifth toes on both sides. He was hypotonic and neonatal reflexes were absent.",

  "Past Medical History": "No specific past medical history was provided.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Results of hematological and biochemical studies were normal. Karyotype (G-T-G banding at 550 band level) was normal. Echocardiogram was normal."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A male neonate born via elective Caesarean section at 38 weeks was identified with limb abnormalities on the first day of birth at a secondary hospital in February 2020. The infant's birth weight was 2580 g (50th centile), the birth length was 50 cm (50th to 70th centile), and the head circumference at birth was 34 cm (50th centile). He was the 5th pregnancy of a healthy mother. The family belonged to a middle socio-economic household from an urban area.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The neonate was identified with fibular hypoplasia, tibial campomelia, and oligodactyly. All reported antenatal scans were unremarkable. There were no prenatal complications, and the mother had no antenatal drug usage or comorbidities like diabetes or hypertension. The infant was kept under observation in the nursery for 6 hours. The parents were informed about the nature of the deformity and given follow-up with an Orthopaedic consultant for treatment options. A possible surgical management with the fabrication of a new orthosis was also proposed, including follow-up in 3-6 months to review limb length. Follow-up with a Geneticist was also advised for future pregnancies. Unfortunately, the patient was lost to follow-up.",
  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed shortened and bowed right lower limb at the distal third of the tibia. Only two toes were found on the right extremity with absent middle 3 toes, whereas the left lower limb was normal. There was no associated facial dysmorphism or upper limb abnormality. No findings suggesting congenital hip dysplasia were found on hip ultrasound.",
  "Past Medical History": "There was no family history of limb abnormalities, and the only significant aspect was a consanguineous marriage. The mother had no history of prenatal complications, antenatal drug usage, or any other comorbidities like diabetes or hypertension.",
  "Initial Test Results": "No significant initial test results such as blood count, blood coagulation biomarkers, blood inflammatory biomarkers, ECG, ultrasound other than hip ultrasound, and X-ray were reported."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The cases involve two siblings, a girl (Case 1) and a boy (Case 2), referred to the Genetics Department of a hospital in Oradea, Romania. The patients are from a family with young, unrelated parents.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "Both siblings were referred for short stature and severe lower limb deformities. Case 1, a girl, was born at 40 weeks with a birth weight of 3000 g and birth length of 48 cm. Case 2, a boy, was born at 38 weeks with a birth weight of 4200 g and birth length of 50 cm. Both pregnancies had physiological evolution and vaginal delivery.",

  "Physical Examination": "",

  "Past Medical History": "The mother's maternal grandfather had disharmonic dwarfism, excruciating bone pain, waddling gait, and moderate genu varum deformity of the lower limbs.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests were focused on the assessment of phosphorus, alkaline phosphatase, PTH and 1.25 (OH)2 vitamin D at periodic intervals of 3, 6 and 12 months, according to the protocol established by the Endocrinology Commission of the Romanian Health Ministry."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The cases involve two siblings, a girl (Case 1) and a boy (Case 2), referred to the Genetics Department of a hospital in Oradea, Romania. The patients are from a family with young, unrelated parents.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "Both siblings were referred for short stature and severe lower limb deformities. Case 1, a girl, was born at 40 weeks with a birth weight of 3000 g and birth length of 48 cm. Case 2, a boy, was born at 38 weeks with a birth weight of 4200 g and birth length of 50 cm. Both pregnancies had physiological evolution and vaginal delivery.",

  "Physical Examination": "",

  "Past Medical History": "The mother's maternal grandfather had disharmonic dwarfism, excruciating bone pain, waddling gait, and moderate genu varum deformity of the lower limbs.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests were focused on the assessment of phosphorus, alkaline phosphatase, PTH and 1.25 (OH)2 vitamin D at periodic intervals of 3, 6 and 12 months, according to the protocol established by the Endocrinology Commission of the Romanian Health Ministry.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Molecular investigations were performed using next-generation sequencing (NGS) with a multi-gene panel of 13 genes selected based on associations with hypophosphatemia. The genes included in the panel were ALPL, CLCN5, CYP2R1, mCYP27B1, DMP1, ENPP1, FAH, FAM20C, FGF23, FGFR1, PHEX, SLC34A3, and VDR. Genomic DNA was extracted from peripheral blood lymphocytes using a bead-based method. The sequencing library was prepared by ligating sequencing adapters to both ends of DNA fragments and size-selected using the bead-based method. Regions of interest (exons and intronic targets) were targeted using a hybridization-based target capture method. The sequencing libraries were sequenced by Illumina's sequencing-by-synthesis method, using paired-end sequencing. Sequence alterations were confirmed using bi-directional Sanger sequencing. A heterozygous variant of PHEX was identified: c.565C > T, p.(Gln189 *), and classified as pathogenic."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "45-year-old female patient.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient consulted the ophthalmology department for a change of optical correction and had a corrected visual acuity of 1.0/1.0. A confrontation visual field was normal. Fluorescein angiography confirmed the diagnosis by showing in the left eye a multiple retinal hemangioma visible in the mid-periphery facing the branches of the superior temporal arches. In the right eye, there was a single angioma over the inferior temporal arch branches.",
  "Physical Examination": "The anterior segment was normal. Tonometry was within normal limits. A myosis fundus revealed a normal posterior pole with a suspect vascular lesion over a branch of the superior temporal vascular arch of the right eye. A funds examination after pupillary dilation showed an uncomplicated bilateral hemangioma with no other associated signs.",
  "Past Medical History": "No particular pathological history.",
  "Initial Test Results": "The anterior segment was normal. Tonometry was within normal limits. A confrontation visual field was normal. Renal ultrasound returned normal. A urinary vanylmandelic acid (VMA) assay was normal."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "In April 2020, a 20-year-old woman from an unknown location presented with fatigue and shortness of breath and was hospitalized at our clinic.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "Six months prior to her admission to our clinic, the patient experienced an abnormal menstrual period and was admitted to another hospital. She had elevated white blood cell (WBC) counts, anemia, and thrombocytopenia and was diagnosed with primary myelofibrosis (PMF) based on bone marrow aspiration results. Her biopsy exhibited myelofibrosis (MF) grade 2. She was treated with ruxolitinib (10 mg, per oral, twice daily) without regular follow-up. Magnetic resonance imaging and enhancement indicated cirrhosis, splenomegaly, and a large cystic mass in the right ovary. The details regarding cirrhosis and the cystic mass were not further investigated or documented.",
  "Physical Examination": "On admission, the patient presented with anemia and abdominal swelling resembling that of a pregnant woman. Physical examination revealed that she had a height of 148 cm, which was inconsistent with her family members, and a weight of 45 kg with a body mass index of 20.5. Additional physical features included a webbed neck, low posterior hairline, epicanthus, and a sixth toe on her right foot.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no significant medical history. Her personal and family history were unremarkable. All her relatives were described as being healthy and tall.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Initial laboratory tests revealed a peripheral blood cell count with a WBC count of 1.93 × 10^9/L, hemoglobin (Hb) count of 38 g/L, and platelet (PLT) count of 84 × 10^9/L. Liver enzymes were elevated with a glutamic oxalacetic transaminase level of 77.95 U/L (normal range: 13-35 U/L) and a glutamic-pyruvic transaminase level of 84.1 U/L (normal range: 7-40 U/L). Cholesterol and glucose levels were within normal ranges. The hepatitis panel, HIV test, and autoantibody screenings were negative. The carbohydrate antigen level of CA125 was 78.5 U/mL (normal < 35 U/mL). Gonadal hormones such as serum β-HCG and luteinizing hormone were within normal ranges. Liver fibrosis markers were significantly elevated. Ferritin levels were significantly decreased, normal ceruloplasmin levels, and the absence of ophthalmic signs such as Kayser-Fleischer rings excluded the diagnoses of hemochromatosis and Wilson’s disease. Echocardiography showed no structural defects in the heart and major vessels. Abdominal ultrasound showed a large cystic mass measuring 30 mm × 148 mm on the right ovary, indicative of a serous cystadenoma."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Chromosome analysis of bone marrow cells revealed 45, X/46, XX, confirming the diagnosis of Turner syndrome (TS). Bone marrow aspiration indicated the coexistence of megakaryocytic emperipolesis and immature megakaryocyte cluster formation. The biopsy exhibited MF grade 1. Gene mutation testing revealed MPL and SH2B3 mutations. Abdominal CT revealed splenomegaly (114 mm × 100 mm × 163 mm), cirrhosis, and portal hypertension. The CT scan also detected an ovarian cystic mass measuring 236 mm × 143 mm × 255 mm on the right side."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The study included 269 congenital cataract (CC) patients from the Home for Cataract Children of the Zhongshan Ophthalmic Center, seen between March 2016 and January 2021. The patients and their available family members were included in the study.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "Patients underwent a thorough ocular examination. Facial photographs were taken with a digital camera. Anterior segment photographs were taken using slit-lamp photography (BX900; HAAG-STREIT AG, Bern, Switzerland). Detailed clinical data, including basic information, family history, and other medical history, were recorded in case report forms.",

  "Physical Examination": "Ultrasound biomicroscopy (UBM) (SW-3200L; Tianjin Suowei Electronic Technology Co., Ltd., Tianjin, China), fundus photography (VISUCAM 224, Carl Zeiss Meditec AG, Jena, Germany), B-scan ultrasound (Aviso, Quantel Médical, Clermont-Ferrand, France), and optical coherence tomography (OCT) (CIRRUS HD-OCT 5000, Carl Zeiss Meditec AG, Jena, Germany) were performed to screen the anterior and posterior segment disorders.",

  "Past Medical History": "Detailed clinical data, including family history and other medical history, were recorded in case report forms.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No specific initial test results were mentioned in the provided information."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The study included 269 congenital cataract (CC) patients from the Home for Cataract Children of the Zhongshan Ophthalmic Center, seen between March 2016 and January 2021. The patients and their available family members were included in the study.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "Patients underwent a thorough ocular examination. Facial photographs were taken with a digital camera. Anterior segment photographs were taken using slit-lamp photography (BX900; HAAG-STREIT AG, Bern, Switzerland). Detailed clinical data, including basic information, family history, and other medical history, were recorded in case report forms.",

  "Physical Examination": "Ultrasound biomicroscopy (UBM) (SW-3200L; Tianjin Suowei Electronic Technology Co., Ltd., Tianjin, China), fundus photography (VISUCAM 224, Carl Zeiss Meditec AG, Jena, Germany), B-scan ultrasound (Aviso, Quantel Médical, Clermont-Ferrand, France), and optical coherence tomography (OCT) (CIRRUS HD-OCT 5000, Carl Zeiss Meditec AG, Jena, Germany) were performed to screen the anterior and posterior segment disorders.",

  "Past Medical History": "Detailed clinical data, including family history and other medical history, were recorded in case report forms.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No specific initial test results were mentioned in the provided information.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Genomic DNA was extracted from peripheral blood samples of patients using QIAamp DNA Mini Kit (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany). Whole exome sequencing (WES) was performed in all of the probands using the Agilent v6 targeted sequence capture library process method with the Hiseq 2500 platform (Illumina Inc., San Diego, CA, USA). A copy number variation (CNV) kit was applied to the data. During CNV calling, two event-segmentation algorithms (circular binary segmentation and the hidden Markov model for germline (hmm-germline)) were chosen. An in-house tool utilizing both copy numbers and B-allele frequencies aligned against chromosome coordinates was designed for CNV event visualization. The threshold parameter for copy number reversion from the log2 ratio was altered to '-1.6, -0.8, 0.5, 1'. The B-allele frequencies were computed using the samtools mpileup tool. The AnnotSV program and corresponding annotation databases were used to annotate detected CNV events on each sample for clinical interpretation. An iterative approach was used to train the reference for CNV identification, starting with 60 samples and excluding samples with events over 1 Mbp in each iteration until more than 30 samples were left after exclusion."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 29-year-old woman. She has two first-degree relatives with similar endoscopic findings.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient reported intermittent diarrhea associated with abdominal pain for 7 years. Two years after the onset of symptoms, she received a diagnosis of Whipple's disease based on previous endoscopy. The patient was treated with continuous sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim, but there was no improvement of the condition. Recently, she was admitted for repeated endoscopy, which revealed multiple yellowish, elevated, coalescent lesions in the second duodenal portion. Antibiotics were discontinued, and the patient and her relatives are being followed up and treated for disorders related to the accumulation of cholesterol esters.",

  "Physical Examination": "Endoscopy revealed multiple yellowish, elevated, coalescent lesions in the second duodenal portion.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had been diagnosed with Whipple's disease two years after the onset of symptoms. She had been treated with continuous sulfamethoxazole and trimethoprim without improvement. Two first-degree relatives also had diagnoses of Whipple's disease with similar endoscopic findings.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests revealed normal liver biochemical results. Dyslipidemia was observed with total cholesterol 210 mg/dL, low-density lipoprotein 132 mg/dL, high-density lipoprotein 25 mg/dL, and triglycerides 184 mg/dL."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 5-day-old Caucasian female. She was born at 38 weeks 6 days gestation via cesarean section due to maternal preeclampsia. Her birth weight was 3.7 kg, and her discharge weight was 3.5 kg (loss of 6% of birth weight; she measured large for gestational age). The infant spent 3 days in the newborn intensive care unit (NICU) due to hypoglycemia.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The infant presented to the emergency department (ED) with a chief complaint of poor feeding and emesis. She had been breastfeeding, but when she failed to latch to the breast, feedings were switched to a combination of expressed breast milk and standard infant formula. She had consistently been taking 2 oz every 2 hr and spitting up approximately 1 oz. Before coming to the ED, she took 2 oz and had emesis of the entire 2-ounce feeding, which was non-bloody and non-bilious. The infant was brought to the ED by her mother 7 hr after being discharged from the NICU.",

  "Physical Examination": "Vital signs on arrival at the ED included a rectal temperature of 37.4 °C, blood pressure of 78 mmHg/56 mmHg, a pulse of 132 beats per min, respiratory rate of 41 breaths per min, and oxygen saturation of 99% in room air. Her weight was 6.68 kg. The infant awakened appropriately for age, head was normocephalic and atraumatic, anterior fontanelle was soft and flat. The sclera was white; the oral mucosa was moist without oral lesions. Her color was pink with a 2 s capillary refill time, normal cardiac rate and rhythm without a murmur, and 3+ peripheral pulses. Breath sounds were clear and equal throughout, with good air entry. The umbilical stump was intact, without redness or drainage. Her abdomen was mildly distended, slightly tender to palpation with hypoactive bowel sounds. The abdominal skin was without erythema or cellulitis. She had normal female genitalia.",

  "Past Medical History": "Apgar scores were eight at 1 min and nine at 5 min. A meconium stool was passed within the first 24 hr of life. The infant spent 3 days in the NICU due to hypoglycemia which improved with feedings and did not require intravenous (IV) fluids. She received a vitamin K injection, but her mother refused erythromycin eye ointment and the hepatitis B vaccine. The patient's mother was a 38-year-old gravida 2, para 2, with a history of hypertension. She was group B streptococcus negative at the time of delivery. Family members included a mother, father, and a 15-month-old sister who was well and had no medical issues.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Diagnostic tests ordered in the ED included bedside glucose, complete blood count with differential, point of care electrolytes, urinalysis, and a one-view abdominal x-ray. All laboratories were within normal limits with a glucose of 84 mg/dL (normal range 40−90 mg/dL), white blood cell (WBC) count of 8.4 (normal range 8−20), hemoglobin 17.9 (normal range 15−21 g/dL), hematocrit 52 (normal range 41% to 65%), platelet count 335 (normal range 150−450 £ 10/L). The WBC count differential included 22% neutrophils, 53% lymphocytes, 16% monocytes, and 9% eosinophils; an absolute neutrophil count of 4,452 mL. Electrolytes were within normal limits with an anion gap of 12 (normal range 5−15). Capillary blood gas results included a pH of 7.39 and a base excess of 1."
}"

She received a vitamin K injection, but her mother refused erythromycin eye ointment and the hepatitis B vaccine. The patient's mother was a 38-year-old gravida 2, para 2, with a history of hypertension. She was group B streptococcus negative at the time of delivery. Family members included a mother, father, and a 15-month-old sister who was well and had no medical issues.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Diagnostic tests ordered in the ED included bedside glucose, complete blood count with differential, point of care electrolytes, urinalysis, and a one-view abdominal x-ray. All laboratories were within normal limits with a glucose of 84 mg/dL (normal range 40−90 mg/dL), white blood cell (WBC) count of 8.4 (normal range 8−20), hemoglobin 17.9 (normal range 15−21 g/dL), hematocrit 52 (normal range 41% to 65%), platelet count 335 (normal range 150−450 £ 10/L). The WBC count differential included 22% neutrophils, 53% lymphocytes, 16% monocytes, and 9% eosinophils; an absolute neutrophil count of 4,452 mL. Electrolytes were within normal limits with an anion gap of 12 (normal range 5−15). Capillary blood gas results included a pH of 7.39 and a base excess of 1.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "The abdominal x-ray was read as early pneumatosis in the loops of bowel in the subhepatic region on the right."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 16-year-old male, born as a monozygotic twin. He is from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially applied to the dentist with various dental problems. A lesion was observed in the jawbone on a panoramic X-ray image, leading to a referral to the head and neck surgery department. The patient had been experiencing intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain for about a year. In systematic examination, a rigid and immobile mass, approximately 2x2 cm in diameter in the left mandible was revealed. A subcutaneous lipomatous mass approximately 2x2 cm in diameter was found in the left lumbar region. Total colectomy and ileorectal anastomosis were performed after providing information about treatment options to the patient and his family. The patient was discharged without any problems on the 7th day after the operation.",

  "Physical Examination": "A rigid and immobile mass, approximately 2x2 cm in diameter, was found in the left mandible. A subcutaneous lipomatous mass approximately 2x2 cm in diameter was observed in the left lumbar region.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no reported disease in the family history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient's laboratory parameters were normal. Eye examination and thyroid ultrasound (US) were also normal. A panoramic X-ray image revealed a lesion in the jawbone."
}"

  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 16-year-old male, born as a monozygotic twin. He is from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially applied to the dentist with various dental problems. A lesion was observed in the jawbone on a panoramic X-ray image, leading to a referral to the head and neck surgery department. The patient had been experiencing intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain for about a year. In systematic examination, a rigid and immobile mass, approximately 2x2 cm in diameter in the left mandible was revealed. A subcutaneous lipomatous mass approximately 2x2 cm in diameter was found in the left lumbar region. Total colectomy and ileorectal anastomosis were performed after providing information about treatment options to the patient and his family. The patient was discharged without any problems on the 7th day after the operation.",

  "Physical Examination": "A rigid and immobile mass, approximately 2x2 cm in diameter, was found in the left mandible. A subcutaneous lipomatous mass approximately 2x2 cm in diameter was observed in the left lumbar region.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no reported disease in the family history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient's laboratory parameters were normal. Eye examination and thyroid ultrasound (US) were also normal. A panoramic X-ray image revealed a lesion in the jawbone.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Maxillofacial computed tomography (CT) examination revealed a sclerotic lesion compatible with osteoma, with exophytic, partially lobulated contour, measuring approximately 17 mm in diameter. Facial magnetic resonance (MR) examination showed a 17x12 mm sized low-weighted signal with no contrast enhancement in the lateral part of the left mandibular ramus. The lesion originated from the left mandibular ramus and had cortex continuity with the left mandibular ramus cortex. Colonoscopic examination was performed by gastroenterology. A few mucosal polyps with diameter less than 5 mm were detected in the rectum, while approximately 30-35 polyps were found in all of the other colon segments. All segments were pathologically sampled via biopsy and snare polypectomy. Colonic polyps were adenomatous polyps with mild and severe dysplasia, rectal polyps were adenomatous polyps with mild dysplasia. Adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene mutation test revealed heterozygous mutant. Rectosigmoidoscopy was performed and no other polyp was seen in the rectum. Upper gastrointestinal system endoscopy, small bowel passage examination and abdominal MR showed no pathological findings."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 16-year-old Tunisian boy characterized by retinitis pigmentosa, polydactyly of the left foot, kidney cysts, and learning difficulties.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with his first episode of pericarditis at the age of 12 years in Tunisia, treated successfully with colchicine (1 mg/day). Echocardiography at that time showed pericardial effusion of 4–5 mm. No pericardiocentesis was performed. He continued colchicine for 3 months. In Italy, he experienced three further recurrences of pericarditis at one-year intervals, treated with colchicine (0.5 mg/day) and ibuprofen (600 mg/day), progressively decreased to 200 mg/day twice a day. During the last episode, he underwent pericardiocentesis, evacuating 900 ml of serum-hematic liquid. Culture and cytological examinations were negative. He was treated with colchicine (1 mg/day) and ibuprofen (1,800 mg/day), progressively reduced to 600 mg/day. The patient came to a medical facility at the age of 16 for retrosternal pain. He was treated with colchicine (1 mg/day), indomethacin (150 mg/day, gradually tapered to 75 mg/day), and prednisone (5 mg/day). After 2 months, the patient returned with worsening chest pain. Therapy with Anakinra (100 mg/day) was started due to cortico-dependent and colchicine-resistant pericarditis. The patient showed quick improvement and prednisone, indomethacin, and colchicine were discontinued. At his last visit, the patient had no dyspnea or thoracic pain and continues Anakinra at 100 mg/day.",
  "Physical Examination": "On his first visit, blood pressure was 130/90 mmHg with negative cardio-thoracic and abdominal physical examinations. After 2 months, physical examination revealed blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg and heart rate of 110 beats per minute, but cardio-thoracic and abdominal examinations were negative. At his last visit, the patient appeared in good general condition with no dyspnea or thoracic pain.",
  "Past Medical History": "His parents were not consanguineous, and there are no other cases of BBS in the family. No other past medical history provided.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Initial blood tests including complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), PCR, troponin, liver and kidney function, and electrolytes were within normal ranges. Chest x-ray and electrocardiogram were negative."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 54-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented with disturbance of consciousness, psychiatric symptoms, behavioral change, cognitive impairment, seizure, and hypotension for 11 days. The day before his first symptom, a resection of his right colon was performed in a local hospital, and appendiceal goblet cell carcinoma (aGCC) was diagnosed by the pathologist. After initial treatment, the symptoms of psychiatric symptoms and seizures disappeared one month later, but the patient remained cognitively impaired (Mini-mental State Examination score = 9). Seven months later, the patient was readmitted to the hospital with progressive head and trunk tremors, dysarthria, and gait instability for over 1 month. There was no improvement or deterioration of the neurological symptoms 3 months after the second admission.",

  "Physical Examination": "Neurological examination revealed head and trunk tremors, cognitive dysfunctions, bilateral gaze-evoked nystagmus, and cerebellar ataxia.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's family history was unremarkable. Exposure to toxic substances was denied.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Routine laboratory tests were unremarkable, except for increased carbohydrate antigen 125 (35.2 U/ml; normal range, < 24 U/ml) and blood ammonia (53.7 µmol/L; normal range, 9-33 µmol/L). The anti-amphiphysin antibody tested by immunoblotting was positive in both cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serum. CSF analysis remained unchanged during the second admission."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 54-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented with disturbance of consciousness, psychiatric symptoms, behavioral change, cognitive impairment, seizure, and hypotension for 11 days. The day before his first symptom, a resection of his right colon was performed in a local hospital, and appendiceal goblet cell carcinoma (aGCC) was diagnosed by the pathologist. After initial treatment, the symptoms of psychiatric symptoms and seizures disappeared one month later, but the patient remained cognitively impaired (Mini-mental State Examination score = 9). Seven months later, the patient was readmitted to the hospital with progressive head and trunk tremors, dysarthria, and gait instability for over 1 month. There was no improvement or deterioration of the neurological symptoms 3 months after the second admission.",

  "Physical Examination": "Neurological examination revealed head and trunk tremors, cognitive dysfunctions, bilateral gaze-evoked nystagmus, and cerebellar ataxia.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's family history was unremarkable. Exposure to toxic substances was denied.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Routine laboratory tests were unremarkable, except for increased carbohydrate antigen 125 (35.2 U/ml; normal range, < 24 U/ml) and blood ammonia (53.7 µmol/L; normal range, 9-33 µmol/L). The anti-amphiphysin antibody tested by immunoblotting was positive in both cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and serum. CSF analysis remained unchanged during the second admission.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was initially unremarkable. During the second admission, brain MRI showed mild cerebellar atrophy. Positron emission tomography with computed tomography (PET/CT) scans revealed no tumor metastasis. Immunohistochemical staining of tissue blocks showed positive results for CK20, CDX-2, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and neuroendocrine markers (synaptophysin and chromogranin). The expression of Ki67 protein was about 10%. MUC1 and MUC2 were also positive. Immunohistochemistry revealed positive CD3+ T cells, CD8+ T cells, and CD20+ B cells in the tumor tissue. However, CK7, CD138+ plasma cells, CD68+ macrophages, and IgG were negative in the tissue. Tumor cells showed reactivity with amphiphysin-Abs. Tissue-based indirect immunofluorescence assay (TBA) of the patient's serum revealed IgG antibody to Purkinje cells of the monkey cerebellum and dentate gyrus glia cells of the monkey hippocampus."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 9-year-and-11-month-old girl from an unspecified geographic location. She was born at the 32nd gestational week by cesarean section with a birth weight of 2650 g. There is no consanguinity between her parents.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted due to polyuria, polydipsia, fatigue, and abdominal pain. She had a bifid big toe on her left foot, which was surgically corrected when she was eight years and 11 months old. Bilateral clinodactyly of the 3rd, 4th, and 5th toes was observed. The patient was diagnosed with CFNS (craniofrontonasal syndrome) due to a heterozygote mutation in the EFNB1 gene c.429_430insT (p.Gly144TrpfsTer31). She was also diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis and type 1 diabetes mellitus (T1DM). Autoimmune thyroiditis was also diagnosed. Her 47-year-old mother had similar phenotypical features and the same EFNB1 mutation, compatible with CFNS diagnosis. The mother was diagnosed with euthyroid autoimmune thyroiditis.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient's weight was 24 Kg (−1.54 SDS), height was 136 cm (+0.18 SDS), body mass index was 12.98 kg/m2 (−2.25 SDS), and head circumference was 49 cm (−2.44 SDS). She had hypertelorism, a wide and flattened nose base, bilateral epicanthus, strabismus in the right eye (sursoadductorius), a bifid nasal tip, a flat nasal bridge, dry and curly hair, low-set ears, brachycephaly, a short-webbed neck, and low hairline. Nails on both hands and feet were concave with longitudinal splits. Pubertal examination showed breasts in Tanner's stage 1 and pubic hair in stage 2. Palpation of the thyroid gland revealed soft and non-tender thyromegaly. Anthropometric measurements were conducted, including bi-ocular width, craniofacial length, face width, intercanthal width, nasal length, nasal tip protrusion, length of the upper half face, and upper lip length. Various indices were calculated based on these measurements.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a bifid big toe on her left foot at birth, which was surgically corrected at eight years and 11 months of age. There was no other significant past medical history reported for the patient. The patient's mother had similar phenotypical features and the same EFNB1 mutation, indicating a family history of CFNS.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory findings showed venous glucose of 449 mg/dl, ketonuria at pH 7.07, and HCO3 of 8.2 mmol/L. Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) was 11.2%, C-peptide was 0.51 ng/mL, anti-insulin antibody was 28.5 IU/mL, anti-glutamic acid decarboxylase antibody was 35.63 IU/mL, and anti-islet antibody was positive. Complete blood count, serum electrolytes, liver transaminases, kidney function tests, and lipid profile were all in the normal range. Serum-free thyroxin (fT4) was 0.9 ng/dL, anti-thyroglobulin antibody was >1000 IU/mL, and anti-thyroid peroxidase (TPO) antibody was >1000 IU/mL. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (1.5 mIU/L) and serum IgA (1.64 g/L) were in the normal range. Tissue anti-transglutaminase IgA and anti-endomysium IgA antibodies were negative. Thyroid ultrasonography showed an enlarged thyroid gland with a diffusely heterogeneous coarse echotexture and multiple discrete hypoechoic micronodules."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a child under the care of pediatric neurology and traumatology services.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with axial lateralization to the left and a significant painless asymmetry at the level of the shoulder girdle. After surgery for Chiari malformation type I, the patient developed meningitis and was hospitalized for intravenous treatment, with good evolution and resolution. One month post-surgery, the patient showed a reduction of the syringomyelic cavity to 5 mm. However, scoliotic posture persisted with a final angle of 31°, for which a thoracolumbosacral orthosis (TLSO) was indicated. The patient is currently under follow-up by clinical, neurology, ophthalmology, and pediatric traumatology teams.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient presented axial lateralization to the left, with symmetrical tone, volume, muscle mass, and strength. Bicipital and patellar reflexes were 2/4. There was a significant painless asymmetry at the level of the shoulder girdle.",

  "Past Medical History": "",

  "Initial Test Results": ""
}"

  "Initial Test Results": "",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Brain and spine MRI was performed due to suspicion of scoliosis secondary to neuroanatomical alteration. MRI results showed a descent of the cerebellar tonsils to C2 (22 mm), associated with extensive syringomyelia measuring about 14.8 mm of the spinal cord. These findings confirmed the diagnosis of Chiari malformation type I. A follow-up imaging one month after surgery showed a reduction of the syringomyelic cavity to 5 mm."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 3-year-old boy from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was first referred to the department in 2020 with complaints of recurrent fever with no apparent cause for more than 10 months. Each episode of fever generally lasted for about 1–5 days, with intervals of approximately 15 days between episodes. During fever episodes, the temperature was about 37.5ºC with occasional increases up to 39ºC, accompanied by bilateral conjunctival congestion and urticarial-like rash. The patient did not experience fatigue, headache, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, cough, asthma, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, joint swelling, or pain.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were reported in the given information.",

  "Past Medical History": "No past medical history or family medical history was provided in the given information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Routine blood examination showed elevation in leukocyte count, neutrophil count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP), and serum amyloid protein (SAA) levels. Specific numerical values for these tests were not provided."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 3-year-old boy from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was first referred to the department in 2020 with complaints of recurrent fever with no apparent cause for more than 10 months. Each episode of fever generally lasted for about 1–5 days, with intervals of approximately 15 days between episodes. During fever episodes, the temperature was about 37.5ºC with occasional increases up to 39ºC, accompanied by bilateral conjunctival congestion and urticarial-like rash. The patient did not experience fatigue, headache, nasal congestion, runny nose, sore throat, cough, asthma, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, joint swelling, or pain.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were reported in the given information.",

  "Past Medical History": "No past medical history or family medical history was provided in the given information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Routine blood examination showed elevation in leukocyte count, neutrophil count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP), and serum amyloid protein (SAA) levels. Specific numerical values for these tests were not provided.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Whole exome sequencing identified a heterozygous variation of NLRP3 gene (c.784-786delinsTGG) in the coding region that resulted in amino acid substitution of arginine for tryptophan at codon 262 (p.R262W), which is a missense variation. The frequency of variation in this database is normal. Through family verification analysis, the parents of the subject had no variation at nucleotide locus 784 in the coding region, suggesting a spontaneous mutation. According to the ACMG guidelines, this mutation was preliminarily determined to be pathogenic. The mutation was validated using Sanger sequencing. Two software programs were used to verify gene function: 1. PolyPhen-2 predicted this variation to be probably damaging with a score of 1.000. 2. MutationTaster predicted this variation to be disease causing with a score of 0.999."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 4-month-old girl, born by C-section at 40 weeks of pregnancy, and is the third child of healthy non-consanguineous parents. She was born with a birth weight of 2400 g and a length of 48 cm. Geographically, the case occurred in an unspecified location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "At the age of 4 months, the patient presented with growth retardation evidenced by a height of 55 cm (3rd percentile) and a weight of 4100 g (below the 3rd percentile). Cognitive development was reported as normal. Craniofacial anomalies noted include microretrognathia, downslanting palpebral fissures, a high forehead, low-set and posteriorly rotated dysplastic cup-shaped ears, absence of medial lower lid eyelashes, a smooth philtrum, and a high arched palate. There was also an absence of the right thumb and duplication of the right second finger. The feet examination revealed inward rotation of the halluces. At 5 years old, the patient exhibited hypernasal speech, nasal emission, compensatory substitutions, and consonant and vowel distortions. Mild conductive hearing loss was noted upon audiometric testing. Clinical oral examination showed microdontia of the primary dentition. Serial ophthalmological examinations were normal. The patient is currently under the care of a multidisciplinary team with plans for individualized speech/language therapy, intensive dental therapy, and orthopedic management.",
  "Physical Examination": "On physical examination at 4 months old, the patient had a height of 55 cm (3rd percentile), a weight of 4100 g (below the 3rd percentile), and a head circumference of 47 cm (N). Physical anomalies included craniofacial abnormalities such as microretrognathia, downslanting palpebral fissures, high forehead, low-set, posteriorly rotated and dysplastic cup-shaped ears, absence of medial lower lid eyelashes, smooth philtrum, and a high arched palate. Limb anomalies included the absence of the right thumb and duplication of the right second finger. The feet examination revealed inward rotation of the halluces. At 5 years old, examination revealed hypernasal speech, nasal emission, compensatory substitutions, consonant and vowel distortions, and microdontia of the primary dentition.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother had an uncomplicated pregnancy apart from an intrauterine growth retardation detected at 28 weeks. She had two previous medical abortions and no history of alcohol, smoking, or drug abuse. The rest of the family history was unremarkable. The patient had feeding difficulties due to orofacial malformations and spent 21 days in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU).",
  "Initial Test Results": "Routine hematological and biochemical tests were normal. Brain ultrasound, abdominal ultrasound, and echocardiography also showed normal results. Radiographic examination revealed radial hypoplasia, absence of the right thumb, duplication of the right second finger, and hypoplastic malar and mandibular bones without proximal radioulnar synostosis."
}"

At 5 years old, examination revealed hypernasal speech, nasal emission, compensatory substitutions, consonant and vowel distortions, and microdontia of the primary dentition.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother had an uncomplicated pregnancy apart from an intrauterine growth retardation detected at 28 weeks. She had two previous medical abortions and no history of alcohol, smoking, or drug abuse. The rest of the family history was unremarkable. The patient had feeding difficulties due to orofacial malformations and spent 21 days in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU).",
  "Initial Test Results": "Routine hematological and biochemical tests were normal. Brain ultrasound, abdominal ultrasound, and echocardiography also showed normal results. Radiographic examination revealed radial hypoplasia, absence of the right thumb, duplication of the right second finger, and hypoplastic malar and mandibular bones without proximal radioulnar synostosis.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Cytogenetic analysis showed a normal female karyotype with 46 chromosomes. Whole exome sequencing (WES) revealed a heterozygous de novo variant c.900del, p.(Met301Cysfs*19) in the SF3B4 gene, with de novo status confirmed by parental testing."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 24-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location. His race is not mentioned.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a progressive increase in stature even after 18 years of age, growing taller than his peers and becoming the tallest in his family. He developed bilateral knock knees and difficulty in walking. He had not sustained any fracture in his lifetime. He had normal libido but was yet to father a child. He was 188 cm tall with an arm span of 200 cm. The upper segment lower segment ratio was 0.8. There was prominent outward bending of both legs at the knee suggestive of genu valgum with an inter-malleolar distance of 24 cm and Q Angle = Right 28°, Left 26°.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed the patient's height of 188 cm and arm span of 200 cm. The upper segment lower segment ratio was 0.8. There was prominent outward bending of both legs at the knee suggestive of genu valgum with an inter-malleolar distance of 24 cm. The Q Angle was measured as Right 28°, Left 26°.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had not sustained any fracture in his lifetime. There was no similar illness in the family. His father was 170 cm tall. His mother died of breast cancer. His elder sister is married with one child.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Biochemical investigations showed the patient was euthyroid and had normal blood glucose levels with no features of insulin resistance. His lipid profile was essentially normal. Bone mineral density (BMD) determined by DXA scan gave a Z score of −2.5 at both neck femur and −2.6 at the lumbar spine. The corresponding T-score was −2.5 and −2.6 respectively. Semen analysis showed azoospermia."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 24-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location. His race is not mentioned.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a progressive increase in stature even after 18 years of age, growing taller than his peers and becoming the tallest in his family. He developed bilateral knock knees and difficulty in walking. He had not sustained any fracture in his lifetime. He had normal libido but was yet to father a child. He was 188 cm tall with an arm span of 200 cm. The upper segment lower segment ratio was 0.8. There was prominent outward bending of both legs at the knee suggestive of genu valgum with an inter-malleolar distance of 24 cm and Q Angle = Right 28°, Left 26°.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed the patient's height of 188 cm and arm span of 200 cm. The upper segment lower segment ratio was 0.8. There was prominent outward bending of both legs at the knee suggestive of genu valgum with an inter-malleolar distance of 24 cm. The Q Angle was measured as Right 28°, Left 26°.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had not sustained any fracture in his lifetime. There was no similar illness in the family. His father was 170 cm tall. His mother died of breast cancer. His elder sister is married with one child.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Biochemical investigations showed the patient was euthyroid and had normal blood glucose levels with no features of insulin resistance. His lipid profile was essentially normal. Bone mineral density (BMD) determined by DXA scan gave a Z score of −2.5 at both neck femur and −2.6 at the lumbar spine. The corresponding T-score was −2.5 and −2.6 respectively. Semen analysis showed azoospermia.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Clinical exome sequencing was undertaken. Two variants were detected in the CYP19A1 gene. The first variant was a novel single nucleotide deletion of Thiamine at the 570th base of the cDNA (c.570delT), resulting in a truncated non-functional aromatase protein of 204 amino acids. This mutation was reported as likely pathogenic according to the American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics (ACMG) classification. The second variant was a novel missense mutation in Exon 5 corresponding to the 344th base of the cDNA (c344G>A), resulting in a change of the 115th arginine to glutamine in the protein. This was a variant of uncertain significance as per ACMG classification. Docking studies of the ligand (PROTOPORPHYRIN IX CONTAINING FE) showed reduced binding affinity in the mutant version compared to the wild type. CoNSURF analysis indicated residue R115 belongs to a highly conserved region. Sanger sequencing of the father showed the presence of the later mutation (chr 15: c.344G>A, p. Arg115Gln) in heterozygous form."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 41-year-old multigravida (G6P5) woman from Syria, in her 33rd week of gestation.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the maternity unit complaining of uterine contractions. She had no antenatal checkups or ultrasounds due to living in a war-affected area in Syria. She mentioned working in picking 'Capparis spinosa' during her pregnancy. A spontaneous development of labor occurred with spontaneous rupture of membranes, followed by normal vaginal delivery of a live female newborn. The newborn died 2 hours after delivery despite several resuscitation attempts. The mother was discharged the next day without any complications.",

  "Physical Examination": "The newborn exhibited special facial and cranial features, including hypotelorism with a single nostril, a blind-ended nose, and craniosynostosis. Other organs were normal. The esophagus was patent, allowing passage of a nasogastric tube through the mouth.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's medical and surgical history was unremarkable. She had four healthy children and one deceased infant due to cerebral atrophy. Consanguineous marriage and familial malformations were denied. The patient negated any drug exposure or infection during pregnancy. She also denied smoking.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests were within normal limits. An ultrasound on admission showed severe polyhydramnios and hydrocephalus."
}"

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the maternity unit complaining of uterine contractions. She had no antenatal checkups or ultrasounds due to living in a war-affected area in Syria. She mentioned working in picking 'Capparis spinosa' during her pregnancy. A spontaneous development of labor occurred with spontaneous rupture of membranes, followed by normal vaginal delivery of a live female newborn. The newborn died 2 hours after delivery despite several resuscitation attempts. The mother was discharged the next day without any complications.",

  "Physical Examination": "The newborn exhibited special facial and cranial features, including hypotelorism with a single nostril, a blind-ended nose, and craniosynostosis. Other organs were normal. The esophagus was patent, allowing passage of a nasogastric tube through the mouth.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's medical and surgical history was unremarkable. She had four healthy children and one deceased infant due to cerebral atrophy. Consanguineous marriage and familial malformations were denied. The patient negated any drug exposure or infection during pregnancy. She also denied smoking.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests were within normal limits. An ultrasound on admission showed severe polyhydramnios and hydrocephalus.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Computed tomography scan of the newborn showed a single, severely dilated ventricle in the midline of the brain, characteristic of alobar holoprosencephaly. The cisterna magna was also very dilated. There were no clear anatomical landmarks of a corpus callosum, a thalamus, or a falx cerebri. A single nasal cavity that ends blindly and a single nostril were also observed. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of cobocephaly was made."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The proband is a male child, the second in his family, born full-term by normal spontaneous delivery with a birth weight of 3,250 g and a birth length of 50 cm. He has a normal 46 XY karyotype.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "At the age of 9 months, the proband exhibited growth delay and was first consulted by an endocrinologist. Despite the growth delay, no thyroid pathology was found. Since infancy, the patient has been under the observation of neurology and ophthalmology specialists, recording symptoms such as organic brain lesions, delayed speech development, multiple stigmata of dysembryogenesis, and strabismus. At the age of 3, the patient had a significant growth delay with a height of 80.5 cm (SDS = -3.83) and a height velocity of 4 cm/year (SDS = -2.93). Despite comprehensive endocrinological assessments, no dysfunction of the thyroid or adrenal glands was evident. The bone age was estimated at 8-9 months. A growth hormone stimulation test with clonidine revealed a maximum STH release level of 7.2 ng/ml, indicating partial somatotropin deficiency, leading to a recommendation for growth hormone treatment, initiated at the age of 4 years and 6 months. No adverse effects except high IGF-1 levels were reported from the treatment. By age 17, the patient’s height SDS before GH treatment was -4.11, improving to -3.53 after the therapy. Despite lacking a molecular diagnosis until the age of 16, the patient showed a range of phenotypic abnormalities throughout development.",
  "Physical Examination": "Facial abnormalities included a triangular face, narrow bridge of the nose with a broad nose tip and big nostrils, low columella position, horizontal and broad mouth fold, thin vermilion, philtrum lower lip, deep-set eyes with antimongoloid slant, and big low-set ears, though big ears and long eyelashes were exceptions. Skeletal abnormalities included bilateral brachyphalangy of the thumb and shortening of the fourth and fifth toes, without a short neck or additional rib pairs. The proband exhibited a high-pitched voice and limited speech composed of simple words. Intellectual disability was evident, and the proband attended a special school. No nystagmus, hearing problems, deafness, choanal atresia, multiple dental caries, malocclusion, heart and kidney abnormalities, malabsorption syndrome, cryptorchidism, hypothyroidism, or epilepsy were noted.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient was monitored by a specialized hospital for children with short stature since the age of 3 years. The parents have normal heights (mother: 163 cm, father: 183 cm) with a target proband height of 173 ± 6.5 cm.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Blood hormone levels (TTH, free thyroxine (T4), cortisol, prolactin, and IGF-1) were measured. The peak STH level was 7.2 ng/ml after the clonidine stimulation test. Bone age was based on radiological analysis of the hands, estimated at 8-9 months when the proband was 3 years old. Standard growth measurement techniques showed a height SDS < -2, with initial height measurements of 80.5 cm (SDS = -3.83) and height velocity at 4 cm/year (SDS = -2.93)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 63-year-old woman from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was initially taken to the emergency room due to unconsciousness around 6:00 a.m. in April 2016. She was discharged the same day after treatment for severe hypoglycemia. Six days later, she lost consciousness again at 6:00 a.m. and was taken to the emergency department. She received another glucose solution infusion due to hypoglycemia, which alleviated her hypoglycemic symptoms. One year ago, a bean-like hard mass was found in the right breast, which gradually increased to the size of a soccer ball, accompanied by redness of the skin, pinprick-like pain, and nipple ulceration. The patient denied a history of hypoglycemic drug use and a history of poor appetite and wasting. After admission, the patient was given a continuous 10% glucose solution (40 ml/h) intravenously, as well as thyroid hormone supplementation (Levothyroxine Sodium Tablets 25 μg qd) and potassium supplementation. On the second day of admission, the patient appeared drowsy and unresponsive at 7:00 am, with blood glucose measured at 2.2 mmol/L. She was given 50% glucose solution, 40 ml of intravenous injection, and an accelerated glucose drip rate (60 ml/h). After that, the blood glucose fluctuated between 2.9 and 4.5 mmol/L. A right mastectomy and resection of a large mass in the right chest wall were performed 1 week after admission.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination after admission revealed no enlargement of superficial lymph nodes and a BMI of 22.5 kg/m2. The right breast was large. The mass was soft and uneven in texture. Skin temperature was significantly elevated, and nipples were cauliflower-like with erosion.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was diagnosed with nasopharyngeal carcinoma 20 years ago, and there was no recurrence after radiotherapy.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial blood examination showed severe hypoglycemia (1.4 mmol/L). After treatment, her serum blood sugar level was restored to 9.5 mmol/L. Six days later, her blood glucose was 1.9 mmol/L. Blood examination after admission showed hypokalemia (3.08 mmol/L) and a normal glycosylated hemoglobin level (5.4%). Thyroid hormone values were: FT3 = 2.53 pmol/L (Ref. = 2.63–5.70 pmol/L), FT4 = 6.56 pmol/L (9.01–19.05 pmol/L), and TSH = 6.209 MIU/L (0.35–4.94 MIU/L). The blood routine, liver and kidney function, and tumor markers were normal, and insulin antibody (IAA) was negative. During a hypoglycemic episode, blood tests revealed severe hypo-insulinemia (<0.1 μU/ml), low C peptide (0.09 ng/ml), low insulin release index (<0.002), low GH (0.075 ng/ml), and normal IFG1 levels. Other hormonal indicators suggested normal pituitary–adrenal axis and pituitary–sex hormone axis."
}"
