Ultrasound of lymph nodes showed no enlargement of cervical, axillary, and inguinal lymph nodes. Mammography showed a large occupying lesion in the right breast. A puncture biopsy of a breast tumor confirmed fibroepithelial tumor. Postoperative immunohistochemical staining was as follows: ER epithelial (+), PR epithelial (+), HER2 (-), CD117 (-), CD34 (-), P53 (+), CK5/6 (-), and Ki-67 about 2%. The nipple had no tumor involvement."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 16-year-old girl.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented with primary amenorrhea associated with severe pain in the lower abdomen for 2 to 3 days, which was cyclic in nature and spasmodic in character. After the first surgery, the patient was discharged in stable condition on the seventh postoperative day. However, after two-and-half months, the patient again presented with similar complaints of pain in the lower abdomen and amenorrhea.",

  "Physical Examination": "On initial examination, her general condition and vitals were stable. Fully developed secondary sexual characters were observed. The hymen was intact, with a central opening. No bulge was observed on supra-pubic pressure. On examination under anesthesia, the transverse septum was identified high up in the vagina.",

  "Past Medical History": "No specific past medical history was provided.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Ultrasonography revealed hematocolpos initially. After the patient's return two-and-half months later, ultrasonography showed hematometra and hematocolpos."
}"

  "Initial Test Results": "Ultrasonography revealed hematocolpos initially. After the patient's return two-and-half months later, ultrasonography showed hematometra and hematocolpos.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Magnetic resonance imaging initially revealed a thick transverse vaginal septum in the upper one-third of the vagina. On the patient's return, repeat magnetic resonance imaging revealed a 3 to 4 centimeter thick septum in the upper one-third of the vagina with a stenosed (fibrosis in the passage) vagina. Laparoscopic imaging was performed during the second surgery."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 25-year-old nulliparous woman with a single pregnancy at 40 weeks 4 days' gestation. She is from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the labor and childbirth service for term prelabor rupture of the membranes. An emergency cesarean section was scheduled due to retention of fetal head descending and persistent occipito-posterior position. On arrival at the operating room, the patient was slightly anxious but had normal vital signs and oxygen saturation. She received 500 ml of lactated Ringer's solution prior to anesthesia. The cesarean section was uneventful, lasting 38 minutes with an estimated blood loss of 300 ml. Two minutes after the end of the procedure, the patient coughed suddenly and developed acute symptoms including hypotension (systolic blood pressure 60-70 mm Hg), hypoxemia (oxygen saturation 60-70%), tachycardia (110-120 beats per minute), dyspnea, cyanosis of lips and nails, and bilateral scattered wheezing on chest auscultation. The patient was treated with mask ventilation using 100% oxygen, intravenous hydrocortisone, metaraminol, epinephrine, and intravenous fluids. After approximately 20 minutes, her vital signs normalized, cyanosis disappeared, and lung sounds became slightly coarse. She was then transferred to the intensive care unit. Skin rashes were observed on her neck, waist, and limbs.",

  "Physical Examination": "Initial examination showed normal vital signs and oxygen saturation. During the acute event, the patient developed cyanosis of lips and nails, and auscultation of the chest revealed bilateral scattered wheezing. After treatment, lung sounds were slightly coarse. Skin rashes were observed on the patient's neck, waist, and limbs.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's previous medical history was unremarkable.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient's vital signs and oxygen saturation were initially normal. During the acute event, systolic blood pressure dropped to 60-70 mm Hg, oxygen saturation fell to 60-70%, and pulse increased to 110-120 beats per minute."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 13-year-old female adolescent from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with primary amenorrhea and a 6-month history of monthly, progressively worsening lower abdominal pain lasting 7 days at a time. She initially presented to an emergency department (ED). She was diagnosed with suspected imperforate hymen and recommended for follow-up. Upon presentation to the pediatric gynecology office, she was in minimal discomfort. She was started on continuous combined oral contraceptive suppression.",

  "Physical Examination": "Abdominal examination showed mild suprapubic tenderness without distention. Pelvic exam with a lubricated cotton swab revealed obstructed pink vaginal mucosa (without a bulge) just proximal to the hymenal fringe. On rectal exam, a large bulge was palpated anteriorly at a depth of 4 cm proximal to the anal opening, and the uterus could be palpated just inferior to the umbilicus.",

  "Past Medical History": "No specific past medical history was provided in the given information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "A pelvic ultrasound performed at the ED showed hematometrocolpos with blood products distending the uterus and vagina. The uterus appeared normal in shape."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 36-year-old man from the 'Bicêtre family'. His geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient consulted for bilateral lower limb lymphedema. He was diagnosed with Dehydrated Hereditary Stomatocytosis (DHS) due to severe perinatal edema. At puberty, he experienced intermittent lower limb edema (feet, ankles, calves), particularly during hot periods, that completely regressed during cold periods. At age 32, he underwent surgery for hydrocele. Following this, edema became persistent, regardless of the season, bilateral, and predominantly affected the right lower limb. The patient had the most severe perinatal symptoms that required pre- and post-natal ascites drainage, exchange transfusion, and mechanical ventilation; these symptoms resolved at 8 months of age.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed increased calf volume associated with upslanting toenails and moderately increased thickness of the dorsal face of the second toe (Stemmer's sign), confirming the lymphedema diagnosis. Pitting edema was also seen on the anterior faces of the lower legs, especially on the right side. Lymphedema involved the ankle, including the retromalleolar space. The patient's body mass index was 29.7 kg/m2 (94 kg, 178 cm). He had no distichiasis or other clinical symptoms.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had severe perinatal edema that resolved after several months. He has mild chronic hemolysis without anemia, varying degrees of pseudohyperkalemia, and moderate iron overload. At age 32, he underwent surgery for hydrocele. Cardiac, renal, and hepatic causes of edema were excluded. The patient's mother's previous pregnancy had ended at 27 weeks of gestation. She was expecting dichorionic–diamniotic twins: one died in utero with anasarca and the other after 1 day of life of an unknown cause. DHS was diagnosed in four family members: the patient, his mother, and his two daughters. All affected family members had perinatal edema, severe in two cases, that resolved after several months.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Venous ultrasound was normal and no thrombotic sequelae ensued. Dynamic lower limb lymphoscintigraphy showed low radioactive tracer speed in both limbs."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 36-year-old man from the 'Bicêtre family'. His geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient consulted for bilateral lower limb lymphedema. He was diagnosed with Dehydrated Hereditary Stomatocytosis (DHS) due to severe perinatal edema. At puberty, he experienced intermittent lower limb edema (feet, ankles, calves), particularly during hot periods, that completely regressed during cold periods. At age 32, he underwent surgery for hydrocele. Following this, edema became persistent, regardless of the season, bilateral, and predominantly affected the right lower limb. The patient had the most severe perinatal symptoms that required pre- and post-natal ascites drainage, exchange transfusion, and mechanical ventilation; these symptoms resolved at 8 months of age.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed increased calf volume associated with upslanting toenails and moderately increased thickness of the dorsal face of the second toe (Stemmer's sign), confirming the lymphedema diagnosis. Pitting edema was also seen on the anterior faces of the lower legs, especially on the right side. Lymphedema involved the ankle, including the retromalleolar space. The patient's body mass index was 29.7 kg/m2 (94 kg, 178 cm). He had no distichiasis or other clinical symptoms.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had severe perinatal edema that resolved after several months. He has mild chronic hemolysis without anemia, varying degrees of pseudohyperkalemia, and moderate iron overload. At age 32, he underwent surgery for hydrocele. Cardiac, renal, and hepatic causes of edema were excluded. The patient's mother's previous pregnancy had ended at 27 weeks of gestation. She was expecting dichorionic–diamniotic twins: one died in utero with anasarca and the other after 1 day of life of an unknown cause. DHS was diagnosed in four family members: the patient, his mother, and his two daughters. All affected family members had perinatal edema, severe in two cases, that resolved after several months.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Venous ultrasound was normal and no thrombotic sequelae ensued. Dynamic lower limb lymphoscintigraphy showed low radioactive tracer speed in both limbs.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Static, noncontrast MR lymphography visualizing lymphatic vessels in contrast to the background, and noncontrast water IDEAL T2 fast spin-echo imaging were performed. Next generation sequencing (NGS) was used to screen for genes involved in chronic hemolysis. The patient's PIEZO1 gene harbored three rare single nucleotide variations (SNVs): c.1792G>C p.Val598Leu, c.2344G>A p.Gly782Ser, and c.2423G>A p.Arg808Gln. These SNVs in cis were confirmed by Sanger sequencing of DNA from all four family members and co-segregated with DHS. Exome sequencing screened for all known primary lymphedema genes and confirmed the three PIEZO1 SNVs. No additional pathogenic variations were identified in ADAMTS3, CCBE1, CDH7, CELSR1, DCHS1, EPHB4, FAT4, FLT4, FOXC2, GATA2, GJA1, GJC2, HGF, IKBKG, KIF11, MET, NSD1, PMM2, PTPN14, RASA1, SHANK3, SOX18, TSC1, TSC2 or VEGFC."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a previously healthy nine-month-old Japanese boy.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient developed edema shortly after being diagnosed with respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection by his family doctor approximately 10 days before admission. He had a temperature of 39°C the day before admission. He presented with marked edema, peripheral cyanosis, facial pallor, and tachypnea (respiratory rate of 36/min). He was diagnosed with NS with sepsis. Treatment with prednisolone, albumin, furosemide, and cefotaxime was initiated. Subsequently, he became afebrile, and his white blood cell count and CRP levels improved; however, the severe edema persisted. On the 7th day of hospitalization, he had a generalized tonic-clonic convulsion. Based on the MRI results and other negative findings, mitochondrial disease was deemed unlikely as a cause of the nephropathy and basal ganglia lesions. Further, there were no other risk factors of basal ganglia lesions including hypoxia, hypoglycemia, or vitamin deficiency.",
  "Physical Examination": "The patient presented with a temperature of 39°C, marked edema, peripheral cyanosis, facial pallor, and tachypnea with a respiratory rate of 36/min. He had no external malformations, including microcephaly and facial or limb malformations. Blood pressure was in the normal range (84/55 mmHg).",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient was previously healthy with no past medical history provided.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Investigations revealed heavy proteinuria (urinary protein 7,552 mg/dL, 6.62 g/day), hypoproteinemia (albumin 0.2 g/dL), leukocytosis (41,600/µL), and an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) level (13.03 mg/dL). Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) examination showed no pleocytosis and CSF culture was negative; however, blood culture detected Streptococcus pneumoniae. Around day 7, lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels peaked at 535 IU/L, and creatinine (Cr) levels increased to 0.55 mg/dL. The platelet counts began to decrease on day 8. Blood tests on the 10th day revealed thrombocytopenia (platelets 30,000/μL), anemia (hemoglobin 8.4 g/dL) with schistocytes, decreased haptoglobin (4.0 mg/dL), and hypocomplementemia (C3 19 mg/dL, C4 7 mg/dL, CH50 < 14.0/ mL). Abnormal coagulation tests showed prothrombin time (PT)-ratio was 1.60, antithrombin (AT) III was 17%, fibrinogen was less than 35 mg/dL, fibrinogen/fibrin degradation products (FDP) was 44.1 μg/mL, and elevated D-dimer was 42.8 μg/mL."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 10-year-old female. She was born by cesarean section at term with a weight of 3,500 g (50th–75th centile). At the age of 10 years, her height was 132 cm (10th–25th centile), and weight was 27 kg (10th–25th centile). The patient is from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the clinic with congenital heart disease, dextrocardia, and coarse facial appearance. She had a history of growth retardation. At 3 days old, computed tomography showed dextrocardia. She underwent a cardiac operation for ventricular septal defect at 5 months old. At the neonatal period, she had physiological jaundice. Developmental milestones were normal; she started walking and talking at the age of 1 year. A mucopolysaccharidosis test was performed at another center previously, and the result was normal.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had a coarse facial appearance. Abdominal ultrasonography showed that liver, spleen, and stomach had no pathologies, and they were located in correct anatomical positions.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a cardiac operation for ventricular septal defect at 5 months old. She had no bleeding problem up to the age of 10 years.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient had a platelet count of 312,000. Brain MRI results taken at the age of 3 years were normal. Chromosome analysis was performed on cells from a heparinized peripheral blood sample. A total of 50 metaphases were evaluated, and a deletion in the long arm (q24q25) of chromosome 11 was detected: 46,XX,del(11)(q24q25)."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Array-CGH was performed using 4 × 180K CGH+SNP oligoarray. A 9-Mb deletion of 11q24.2q25 was detected: arr[hg19] 11q24.2q25(125,852,593_134,934,196)×1. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 25-year-old woman. Her geographic location is not explicitly stated, but she was initially hospitalized in Suwon Hospital before being transferred to a tertiary hospital.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the nephrology department due to acute kidney injury (AKI). Four days prior to admission, she was confirmed with COVID-19 infection. From the next day, she experienced gross hematuria and was hospitalized in Suwon Hospital on the third day of COVID-19 infection. Despite management with packed RBC transfusion, hydration, and diuretics, her urine output did not recover and serum creatinine continued to increase. She was transferred to a tertiary hospital for consideration of renal replacement therapy and renal biopsy. Upon arrival at the tertiary hospital, she had an alert mental status with an acute ill-looking appearance. She reported mild nausea and headache. During the first 3 hospital days, her urine output was 880 mL, 400 mL, and 600 mL respectively. Her serum creatinine increased to 13.97 mg/dL. She started hemodialysis on hospital day 4. Renal biopsy was performed on hospital day 5. During hemodialysis sessions, the patient complained of nausea and headache, which improved over time. After 5 hemodialysis sessions, her urine output started to increase and serum creatinine started to decrease. As her renal function recovered, her general condition improved. She stopped hemodialysis and was discharged on hospital day 13. Two weeks after discharge, her serum creatinine had fully recovered to 0.78 mg/dL.",

  "Physical Examination": "At the time of admission to the tertiary hospital, her blood pressure was 128/84 mmHg, pulse rate was 72 beats per minute, and body temperature was 36.9 °C. On physical examination, her lungs, heart, abdomen, and nervous system were normal.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was diagnosed with iron deficiency anemia in another hospital several years ago, with a hemoglobin level of about 7.0 mg/dL at that time. She had no other underlying diseases except anemia. She had not been exposed to any nephrotoxic agents recently.",

  "Initial Test Results": "At Suwon Hospital: WBC 3.57*103/μL, RBC 2.18*106/μL, hemoglobin 5.5 g/dL, platelet 101*103/μL, prothrombin time 11.6 seconds, activated partial thromboplastin time 24.5 seconds, BUN 79.4 mg/dL, creatinine 8.31 mg/dL, estimated glomerular filtration rate 5.87 mL/min/1.7 m2, LDH 6260 U/L, total bilirubin 2.6 mg/dL, AST 250 U/L, ALT 41 U/L. Urine analysis showed dark-amber color, specific gravity 1.012, pH 6.5, leukocyte esterase 2+, nitrite 2+, protein 1+, blood 2+. Urine microscopy showed RBC 101 to 200/HPF and WBC > 200/HPF.

At the tertiary hospital: WBC 2.8*103/μL, RBC 2.56*106/μL, hemoglobin 7.0 g/dL, platelet 94*103/μL, MCV 85.4 fL, MCH 27.4 pg, MCHC 32.1 g/dL, reticulocyte count 1.84%. Peripheral blood smear showed normocytic hypochromic anemia with anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, and schistocytes. Anemia study showed serum iron 33 ug/dL, TIBC 275 ug/dL, ferritin 576 ug/L, haptoglobin < 10 mg/dL. Coagulation tests showed PT 13.0 seconds and aPTT 38.0 seconds. Serum biochemistry showed BUN 87.6 mg/dL, creatinine 9.70 mg/dL, eGFR 4.91 mL/min/1.7 m2, LDH 2146 U/L, total bilirubin 1.4 mg/dL, direct bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL, AST 141 U/L, ALT 41 U/L, CRP 5.88 mg/dL. Urinalysis showed amber color, specific gravity 1.009, pH 6.5, WBC ester 3+, nitrite -, protein 2+, blood 4+, glucose −, ketone −, bilirubin −, urobilinogen <1.0. Urine microscopy showed many RBCs/HPF and many WBCs/HPF. Ultrasound image showed normal echogenicity of both kidneys with length of 12.6 cm of right kidney and 13.2 cm of left kidney, with no evidence of hydronephrosis."
}"

Flow cytometry for paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) was performed, leading to the final diagnosis of PNH."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is an Omani female in her 30s from Sohar.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with complaints of difficulty and painful swallowing (odynophagia) for one year. The dysphagia was of gradual onset and progressive, starting as difficulty swallowing solids, which then recently developed into difficulty swallowing both solids and liquids with feelings of food and drinks 'being stuck in her throat'. She reported having easy fatiguability as well as unintentional weight loss. She denied any fever, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, heartburn, hematemesis, melena, joint pain, skin rashes or Raynaud's phenomenon. The patient had a history of chronic iron-deficiency anemia of several years and had not taken iron supplements previously. The patient denied any abnormalities in the menstrual cycle and had no pregnancies in the past. The surgical history was unremarkable.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient appeared tired but was fully conscious and cooperative. The patient was vitally stable. Conjunctival pallor, glossitis and angular stomatitis were noted. On hand examination, the patient also had koilonychia and pallor. No lymphadenopathy or skin rashes were seen. On abdominal examination, no tenderness or organomegaly was present, but a round, firm, smooth mass (diameter of 3 cm approximately) over the lower abdomen was palpated. It was immobile and non-tender.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of chronic iron-deficiency anemia of several years. A family history of G6PD deficiency was reported to be present in siblings. No family history of gastrointestinal malignancy or autoimmune disorders was present.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory studies on admission showed microcytic hypochromic anemia secondary to iron deficiency. No leukocytosis or leukopenia was noted. Thyroid, liver and renal function tests were all within normal levels. Autoimmune workup (including rheumatoid factor, anti-nuclear antibody, erythrocyte sedimentation rate and antibodies specific to Sjogren's syndrome and scleroderma) was unremarkable. Ultrasound of the neck and abdomen was unremarkable. Ultrasound of the pelvis revealed a uterine fibroid measuring 5 × 5.5 cm."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 36-year-old female from Hangzhou, China.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted on April 28, 2021, with complaints of middle and upper abdominal pain and discomfort for more than 1 month, combined with systemic skin yellowing and itching for 2 weeks. One month prior to admission, she experienced intolerable middle and upper abdominal pain and discomfort without obvious inducement. Two weeks before admission, she developed gradually aggravating abdominal pain, yellow sclera, yellowish skin all over the body, and skin itching. The patient initially visited Zhongshan Hospital, Fudan University, where tests were conducted. A liver mass puncture was performed on April 7, 2021. The patient did not receive further treatment at that time and later sought treatment at the current hospital.",

  "Physical Examination": "On admission, physical examination revealed right upper quadrant tenderness (+), no rebound tenderness, no enclosed mass, negative Murphy's sign, and negative shifting dullness.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of diabetes for 1 year and was regularly treated with 1 tablet of metformin (Tid) and 1 tablet of acarbose (Tid) orally.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests after admission showed: Liver function: alanine aminotransferase 242 U/L, aspartate aminotransferase 404 U/L, r-glutamyltransferase 1516 U/L, total protein 63.4 g/L, albumin 27.6 g/L, globulin 35.8 g/L, total bilirubin 308.2 µmol/L, conjugated bilirubin 224.9 µmol/L, indirect bilirubin 83.3 µmol/L, lactate dehydrogenase 3433 U/L, C-reactive protein 23.5 mg/L, and HbA1c glycosylated hemoglobin 6.4%. Blood coagulation routine: prothrombin time 15.1 s, international normalized ratio 1.42, D-dimer 350.0 µg/L. Blood routine: WBC: 12.7 * 109/L, NEU: 81.9%, hemoglobin: 89 g/L, RBC: 3.48 * 1012/L, PLT: 593 * 109/L. Abdominal ultrasound showed multiple hypoechoic masses in liver, irritable gallbladder wall, and hypoechoic nodules in front of the pancreas. Chest CT revealed pulmonary nodules, exudation in both lower lobes, bilateral pleural reactions, and a small amount of right pleural effusion."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "At Zhongshan Hospital, Fudan University, the following tests were performed: CA199: 101.0 U/ml, AFP: 4.5 ng/ml. Abdominal CT showed multiple space-occupying lesions in the liver. PET-CT showed multiple MTs, hilar lymph node metastasis in the liver, and cervical lymphadenitis. Liver mass puncture pathology report showed: poorly differentiated carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry results were provided in detail. At the current hospital, contrast-enhanced CT of the abdomen showed diffuse mass-like and nodular slightly hypodense lesions, some of which were fused, with significant ring enhancement in the arterial phase, continuous ring enhancement in the venous and delayed phases, and local wall thinning and irritability in the right and left branches of the portal vein. The hepatobiliary ducts were dilated, and the gallbladder wall was thickened and edematous. A small amount of ascites was noted. Contrast-enhanced MR of the liver showed diffuse nodular mass shadows in the liver, with mild enhancement of nodular mass shadows and ring-like enhancement changes on contrast-enhanced scans. The left branch of the portal vein was not clearly displayed, the right branch of the portal vein was possibly locally invaded, the hepatic vein and the bile duct in the hilar area were not clearly displayed, the bile duct at the upper level was slightly dilated, and the left upper quadrant was turbid, with the possibility of local nodules."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 63-year-old man from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a hepatic mass that had been detected by computed tomography (CT) at another clinic. He had a history of alcohol consumption, drinking about 36 g of alcohol per week for 40 years. At 5 months post-operation, the patient complained of right flank pain, and CT showed a new mass measuring 7.3 cm in the right adrenal gland. After 6.5 months post-operation, the adrenal mass disappeared, but other recurred masses were noted on the posterior aspect of the right kidney and both lungs. Despite changes in treatment, additional recurred masses developed in the liver, lung, and brain. The patient passed away 12 months after the surgery.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were reported in the given information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of alcohol consumption, drinking about 36 g of alcohol per week for 40 years. No other past medical history was reported.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Routine laboratory tests and liver function tests showed normal values. Viral marker tests showed negative serum hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and hepatitis C antibody (anti-HCV), and positive serum hepatitis B antibody (HBsAb). The patient's serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level was very high at 22,815 ng/mL. The protein induced by vitamin K antagonist-II (PIVKA-II) level was elevated to 183 mAU/mL (normal range, <40 mAu/mL). Other tumor markers such as carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and carbohydrate antigen19-9 (CA19-9) levels were also slightly increased to 6.1 ng/mL and 80.9 U/mL, respectively."
}"

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were reported in the given information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of alcohol consumption, drinking about 36 g of alcohol per week for 40 years. No other past medical history was reported.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Routine laboratory tests and liver function tests showed normal values. Viral marker tests showed negative serum hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) and hepatitis C antibody (anti-HCV), and positive serum hepatitis B antibody (HBsAb). The patient's serum alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) level was very high at 22,815 ng/mL. The protein induced by vitamin K antagonist-II (PIVKA-II) level was elevated to 183 mAU/mL (normal range, <40 mAu/mL). Other tumor markers such as carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) and carbohydrate antigen19-9 (CA19-9) levels were also slightly increased to 6.1 ng/mL and 80.9 U/mL, respectively.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A prior CT identified a nine-centimeter-sized mass in the anterior section of the liver. Additional liver ethoxybenzyl diethylenetriamine pentaacetic acid-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging revealed heterogeneous enhancement in the arterial phase and delayed wash-out in the delayed phase. No systemic metastasis was found initially. Pathological examination after right hemihepatectomy revealed a multinodular solid mass, measuring 9.0 × 8.0 × 6.0 cm. The mass was well-demarcated, yellow-whitish, soft, and firm with multifocal necrosis and hemorrhage. The tumor consisted of poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) (20%) and large- and small-cell-type neuroendocrine carcinoma (NEC) (80%) components. The tumor invaded the right anterior portal vein and microvessels. There was no lymph node metastasis. Immunohistochemically, chromogranin and synaptophysin were positive in the areas of NEC and negative in the areas of HCC. AFP and hepatocyte antigen were positive in the areas of both NEC and HCC."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 22-year-old Chinese male smoker who consumes 10-20 cigarettes per day.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was first admitted to the department in August 2021 with acute progressive binocular vision blurring. He had been experiencing kinetic tremors, dysarthria, and personality change since 2017 without any treatment. He complained of 4-week binocular vision blurring associated with progressive slow reaction, unsteady walking, executive dysfunction, and declined mental status. The patient presented with photophobia or tearing but denied pain with eye movements. He denied anti-obesity, alcohol, herbals, or illicit drug use before entering the hospital. Three ophthalmic examinations prior to treatment revealed declining vision: first time: right eye −0.5, corrected visual acuity 0.4; left eye −0.5, corrected visual acuity 0.15; second time: right eye −0.75; left eye −0.75; third time: right eye −1, corrected visual acuity .1; left eye −1, corrected visual acuity 0.1.",

  "Physical Examination": "On admission, his physical examination revealed dysarthria, gait disturbance, and altered mental status. The patient had no scleral icterus, rash, pedal edema, asterixis, or focal neurologic deficits. K-F rings were noted on slit-lamp examination. Fundus examinations showed a slow light response and pallor in the temporal side of the optic disc.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no other risk factors for liver or eye disease, and no known family history of any ophthalmologic, neurologic, or hepatic diseases.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests revealed prolonged PT/INR and APTT, and decreased ceruloplasmin at 54 mg/L (200-600 mg/L). 24-h urinary copper excretion was 117.5 μg/24 h (15–60 μg/24 h). The serum level of ceruloplasmin was low at 8.19 mg/dl (22–58 mg/dl). Static perimetry revealed diffuse visual field defects in the left eye."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed symmetric hyperintense changes visualized in T2-weighted images of the basal ganglia, particularly the putamen. A central nervous system demyelination laboratory test was taken, and AQP4-IgG, MOG-IgG, MBP-IgG, and GFAP-IgG were all negative. The most common mutations of Leber's hereditary optic neuropathy (LHON), 11778, 14484, and 3460, were also negative."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 38-year-old Caucasian male from an unspecified geographic location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted for evaluation of a progressive (over the course of the last year) gait difficulty, which led to frequent falls, and episodes of vertigo. He was previously diagnosed with complicated neonatal jaundice, bilateral cataracts at the age of twenty, hypothyroidism at the age of twelve, testicular cancer at age of twenty-six, episodic diarrhea (with onset 12 months ago), attention deficit and hyperactivity disorder, and dyslexia in puberty. Neuropsychological evaluation revealed a borderline normal intellectual capacity. There was no family history of hereditary neurological disease, although the patient's parents were distant cousins. The combination of clinical signs of the patient was suggestive of a disorder affecting the cerebellum and potentially spinal tracts, with a chronic and progressive time course.",
  "Physical Examination": "Physical (non-neurologic) examination showed no abnormalities. Neurologic examination revealed nystagmus, cerebellar ataxia of upper and lower limbs, pyramidal tract signs more pronounced in the lower limbs causing a spastic-ataxic gait, and a marked defect in proprioception and pallesthesia. Muscle strength was mildly decreased only in the distal muscles of the lower limbs symmetrically. A symmetrical atrophy of the intrinsic foot muscles was also noted. Ophthalmological and cardiological assessment showed no abnormalities.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had complicated neonatal jaundice, bilateral cataracts at the age of twenty, hypothyroidism at the age of twelve, testicular cancer at age of twenty-six, episodic diarrhea (with onset 12 months ago), and was diagnosed with attention deficit and hyperactivity disorder and dyslexia in puberty. There was no family history of hereditary neurological disease, although the parents of the subject were distant cousins.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory blood tests, including complete blood count, biochemistry, coagulation, lipidemic profiling, levels of Vitamin B12, copper, NMO, MOG and paraneoplastic antibodies, viral serology testing, and treponemal assays, were unremarkable. A lumbar puncture showed mild elevation of protein (99 mg/dL, normal range 15–60 mg/dL)."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain and cervical spine demonstrated bilateral, symmetric, T2-weighted hyperintense lesions involving the dentate nuclei and the deep cerebellar white matter, substantia nigra, internal capsules, extending to the dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts. A mild atrophy of the cerebellar vermis was noted. Electrodiagnostic studies (EDX) of the lower limbs revealed low amplitude sensory nerve action potentials (sNAPs) with low nerve conduction velocities in the examined sensory nerves, low amplitude compound muscle action potentials (CMAPs) of the right tibial nerve, low nerve conduction velocities of the examined motor nerves, consistent with a mixed polyneuropathy, and increased F wave latency. Nerve conduction studies of the upper limbs showed normal amplitudes of sensory and motor action potentials with a mild decrease in nerve conduction velocities. The electromyographic study revealed chronic neurogenic motor unit potentials of the right tibialis anterior muscle. Genetic testing revealed homozygosity for the variant (mutation) c.1410_1411del in CYP27A1 gene and heterozygosity for the variant (mutation) c.1409A>C in MTHFR gene. Plasma sterol profile showed cholestanol levels at least 5.5-fold higher than normal reference values, and 7-dehydrocholesterol levels were multiple times higher than its upper normal reference value."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 7-year-old male from Sudan. His weight is 20 kg (10th percentile) and height is 118 cm (25th percentile).",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient had a history of two episodes of mycobacterial lymphadenitis and recurrent typhoid fever. He was referred to the pediatric immunology clinic due to newly diagnosed disseminated tuberculosis (TB) affecting the lungs and multiple lymph nodes, including mesenteric lymph nodes. At 6 months of age, he experienced fever and left axillary lymphadenitis, which did not improve with oral and injectable antibiotics. At 2 years of age, he developed fever, weight loss, and cervical lymphadenopathy. He also had recurrent febrile illnesses associated with abdominal pain and mesenteric lymphadenitis, diagnosed as typhoid fever based on high antibody titer on Widal test. The current TB condition started 6 weeks before referral. The patient presented with high-grade fever, mainly at night with sweating, severe abdominal pain, significant weight loss, and fatigability. Two weeks later, he developed a cough, initially dry then becoming productive with thick mucoid sputum without blood. There was no abdominal distension, diarrhea, constipation, vomiting, chest pain, or shortness of breath.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient appeared to have normal growth. No specific physical examination findings were reported.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's family history is significant. Four other family members across two generations, including his father, have a similar condition. The father had recurrent TB adenitis since early childhood and three episodes of meningitis, including one confirmed tuberculous meningitis and two cases of Aspergillus meningitis. As a result, the father is deaf, blind, and has shunted hydrocephalus. The patient's mother is phenotypically healthy and not blood-related to the father. A maternal cousin had disseminated BCG infection leading to early infantile death. There is a positive family history of recurrent adenitis among members of the patient's paternal family, including his paternal aunt and paternal cousin. The patient had no history of other infections such as pneumonia, otitis media, or skin, bone, or joint infections.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Complete blood count and lymphocyte subset results were obtained (specific values not provided in the text). Immunological investigation revealed elevated IgG (2,117 mg/dl; normal range: 380–1,400 mg/dl), normal IgM (69 mg/dl; normal range: 37–225 mg/dl), normal IgE (53 IU/ml; normal range up to 155 IU/ml), and low IgA (19 mg/dl; normal range: 30–250 mg/dl). Dihydrorhodamine reduction (DHR) test by flow cytometer showed normal oxidative burst. Chest x-ray showed bilateral prominent hilar lymph nodes. Abdominal ultrasound scan showed minimal intra-abdominal fluid and mesenteric and para-aortic lymph node adenitis."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 28-year-old woman from Hunan, China was admitted to the hospital.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a recurrent cough for 6 years and wheezing for 7 months, aggravated for half a month in May 2021. She started to cough sputum in September 2014, and was initially treated for pulmonary tuberculosis with anti-tuberculosis medication, which improved her symptoms until 2015. During her first visit to the hospital in 2015, she had cough with fever, and lab tests showed elevated leukocyte count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein level, and serum total IgE (2,500 IU/ml). Chest CT revealed multiple cavitary lesions and bronchiectasis. Cultures confirmed infections of aspergillosis and Staphylococcus aureus. She was treated with teicoplanin and itraconazole, which relieved her symptoms. In 2019, she began coughing intermittently with worsening dyspnea and wheezing. During a second visit in December 2020, blood tests showed elevated eosinophil count and serum total IgE (>2,500 IU/ml). A pulmonary function test indicated moderate obstructive pulmonary ventilation dysfunction. Chest CT showed bilateral multiple bronchiectases, pulmonary bulla, and atelectasis. The diagnosis was allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA). She was prescribed oral voriconazole, methylprednisolone, and inhalers but showed no improvement. Since February 2021, she was given omalizumab but was readmitted due to aggravated symptoms. She denied any history of food or drug allergies, and her family history was negative for inherited genetic diseases. She had recurrent infections, skin rashes, a minor traumatic fracture, cutaneous abscesses, a pelvic abscess, tubal occlusion, and primary infertility. Further medical history review and whole-exome sequencing indicated a heterozygous missense mutation in exon 15 of STAT3, leading to a final diagnosis of AD-HIES. She was prescribed omalizumab, Seretide inhalation, and oral corticosteroids. During 6 months of follow-up, she did not experience recurrent infection, and her symptoms and lung function improved.",
  "Physical Examination": "On admission, her body weight was 58 kg. Physical examination revealed facial flushing, a full moony face, buffalo back, and mossy skin changes on the scalp. Moist rales were heard on bilateral lung fields.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had multiple skin rashes and pruritus since childhood. She had a minor traumatic fracture of the right calf at age 12, required incision and drainage of cutaneous abscesses at 13, and had a diagnosis of pelvic abscess, tubal occlusion, and primary infertility. Her family history was negative for inherited genetic diseases. Her parents and younger sister are wild-type genotypes.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests on her first hospital visit in 2015 showed elevated leukocyte count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, C-reactive protein level, and serum total IgE (2,500 IU/ml). Chest CT revealed multiple cavitary lesions and bronchiectasis. During her second visit in December 2020, blood tests showed elevated eosinophil count (0.97 × 10^9/L) and serum total IgE (>2,500 IU/ml). Pulmonary function test indicated decreased FVC (2.41 L), decreased FEV1 (1.54 L), and decreased FEV1/FVC (63.68%), indicating moderate obstructive pulmonary ventilation dysfunction. Chest CT revealed bilateral multiple bronchiectases, pulmonary bulla, and atelectasis. During her admission in May 2021, laboratory findings revealed moderate C-reactive protein level (33.6 mg/l), normal leukocyte count and erythrocyte sedimentation, elevated serum IgE (770 IU/ml), and negative results for various specific antibodies and factors."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a female, born prematurely at 32 weeks via emergency cesarean section due to fetal distress. The patient was born in a geographic location not specified, and is of unspecified race. The parents are first-degree cousins, and the mother is gravida 2 para 0 + 1.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "At birth, the patient was intubated, resuscitated, connected to mechanical ventilation, and kept in the neonatal intensive care unit for almost two months due to an Apgar score of 6 at 5 minutes. Her birth weight was 1.9 kg, head circumference 32 cm, and length 40 cm. At 15 hours of age, she experienced high blood pressure (104/70) and was found to have a significant heart murmur. Chest X-ray revealed cardiomegaly, suggesting patent ductus arteriosus. Despite treatment with fluid restriction, increased positive end-expiratory pressure, Lasix, and two doses of hydralazine, her condition worsened, leading to a diagnosis of congenital heart failure. At nine weeks of age, she was managed with digoxin, diuretics, and ventilation for congenital heart failure of unknown cause and had difficulty controlling hypertension. At 10 months, she presented with a puffy eye and high blood pressure (130/85), squint on the right eye corrected by surgery, restricted joint movement, bilateral infantile polycystic kidney disease, and renal resistant hypertension. At three years of age, she was noted to have mild mental retardation, low IQ, delayed speech and development, short stature, rickets, dental caries, and bilateral genu valgus deformity. By 11 years, she experienced recurrent tonsillar attacks, underwent adenotonsillectomy, and had dysmorphic features suggesting Turner syndrome, which was ruled out. At 12 years old, she was admitted for high blood pressure (200/40) due to non-compliance with medications. At 13 years, normal kidney imaging and function were noted, but resistant hypertension remained unexplained. Whole-exome sequencing at 16 years confirmed generalized arterial calcification of infancy (GACI) type 1. At 17 years, she developed SLE, confirmed by positive ANA, anti-dsDNA, anti-SM antibodies, and low C4 complement. An echocardiogram showed a large pericardial effusion with severe concentric left ventricular hypertrophy.",
  "Physical Examination": "Initial clinical examination at birth was normal. At 15 hours of age, a significant heart murmur was detected. At 10 months, she had a puffy eye, squint on the right eye, no pallor or jaundice, bilateral equal air entry with no added sound, loud first and second heart sounds, lax abdomen with no organomegaly or masses, restricted upper limb joint movement, and normal lower limbs. By three years, she had bilateral genu valgus deformity. At 11 years, recurrent tonsillar attacks were noted. At 17 years, an echocardiogram showed a large pericardial effusion and severe concentric left ventricular hypertrophy.",
  "Past Medical History": "The first pregnancy of the mother ended in miscarriage at six weeks, and the mother failed to conceive for four years before spontaneously conceiving. The patient was diagnosed with hypertension, congenital heart failure, bilateral infantile polycystic kidney disease, rickets, dental issues, bilateral genu valgus deformity, SLE, and generalized arterial calcification of infancy (GACI) type 1. Her family history included a recent pregnancy in the mother with a fetus diagnosed with idiopathic arterial calcification, which died in utero.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Initial vital signs and clinical examination at birth were normal. A significant heart murmur was detected at 15 hours of age, and chest X-ray revealed cardiomegaly. Hypertension was present from infancy, with blood pressure readings as high as 122/84 and 130/85. Urinalysis showed urine protein of 30 g/L and creatinine of 49 mg/dL."
}"

  "Basic Information": "The patient is a female, born prematurely at 32 weeks via emergency cesarean section due to fetal distress. The patient was born in a geographic location not specified, and is of unspecified race. The parents are first-degree cousins, and the mother is gravida 2 para 0 + 1.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "At birth, the patient was intubated, resuscitated, connected to mechanical ventilation, and kept in the neonatal intensive care unit for almost two months due to an Apgar score of 6 at 5 minutes. Her birth weight was 1.9 kg, head circumference 32 cm, and length 40 cm. At 15 hours of age, she experienced high blood pressure (104/70) and was found to have a significant heart murmur. Chest X-ray revealed cardiomegaly, suggesting patent ductus arteriosus. Despite treatment with fluid restriction, increased positive end-expiratory pressure, Lasix, and two doses of hydralazine, her condition worsened, leading to a diagnosis of congenital heart failure. At nine weeks of age, she was managed with digoxin, diuretics, and ventilation for congenital heart failure of unknown cause and had difficulty controlling hypertension. At 10 months, she presented with a puffy eye and high blood pressure (130/85), squint on the right eye corrected by surgery, restricted joint movement, bilateral infantile polycystic kidney disease, and renal resistant hypertension. At three years of age, she was noted to have mild mental retardation, low IQ, delayed speech and development, short stature, rickets, dental caries, and bilateral genu valgus deformity. By 11 years, she experienced recurrent tonsillar attacks, underwent adenotonsillectomy, and had dysmorphic features suggesting Turner syndrome, which was ruled out. At 12 years old, she was admitted for high blood pressure (200/40) due to non-compliance with medications. At 13 years, normal kidney imaging and function were noted, but resistant hypertension remained unexplained. Whole-exome sequencing at 16 years confirmed generalized arterial calcification of infancy (GACI) type 1. At 17 years, she developed SLE, confirmed by positive ANA, anti-dsDNA, anti-SM antibodies, and low C4 complement. An echocardiogram showed a large pericardial effusion with severe concentric left ventricular hypertrophy.",
  "Physical Examination": "Initial clinical examination at birth was normal. At 15 hours of age, a significant heart murmur was detected. At 10 months, she had a puffy eye, squint on the right eye, no pallor or jaundice, bilateral equal air entry with no added sound, loud first and second heart sounds, lax abdomen with no organomegaly or masses, restricted upper limb joint movement, and normal lower limbs. By three years, she had bilateral genu valgus deformity. At 11 years, recurrent tonsillar attacks were noted. At 17 years, an echocardiogram showed a large pericardial effusion and severe concentric left ventricular hypertrophy.",
  "Past Medical History": "The first pregnancy of the mother ended in miscarriage at six weeks, and the mother failed to conceive for four years before spontaneously conceiving. The patient was diagnosed with hypertension, congenital heart failure, bilateral infantile polycystic kidney disease, rickets, dental issues, bilateral genu valgus deformity, SLE, and generalized arterial calcification of infancy (GACI) type 1. Her family history included a recent pregnancy in the mother with a fetus diagnosed with idiopathic arterial calcification, which died in utero.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Initial vital signs and clinical examination at birth were normal. A significant heart murmur was detected at 15 hours of age, and chest X-ray revealed cardiomegaly. Hypertension was present from infancy, with blood pressure readings as high as 122/84 and 130/85. Urinalysis showed urine protein of 30 g/L and creatinine of 49 mg/dL.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Echocardiography showed thick left ventricular wall thickness, moderate mitral regurgitation, left-to-right shunt across patent foramen ovale, and patent ductus arteriosus. A DMSA scan at 10 months showed compensatory hypertrophy of the left kidney. Ultrasound revealed bilateral kidney cysts. X-rays showed multiple joint calcifications. Whole-exome sequencing confirmed GACI type 1 at 16 years of age. Chromosome analysis ruled out Turner syndrome. A CT scan showed significant calcification on the descending aorta. Laboratory testing for SLE confirmed by positive ANA, anti-dsDNA, anti-SM antibodies, and low C4 complement at age 17. Echocardiogram revealed large pericardial effusion and severe concentric left ventricular hypertrophy. 24-hour urinary protein was elevated."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 55-year-old woman from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the Emergency Department with febrile neutropenia, with a temperature of 38° C and a neutrophil count of 0.31 × 109/L. The presumed source of infection was a painful lower-limb ulcer, which had been present for approximately 5 months prior to her presentation. This ulcer had not responded to antibiotics or a dressing regimen in primary care. In the hospital, she was initially treated with IV antibiotics and granulocyte colony-stimulating factor. A treatment team was formed that consisted of dermatology, rheumatology, vascular surgery, anatomical pathology, and wound care nursing specialists. The patient had longstanding neutropenia, first diagnosed approximately 30 years prior, and had two recent presentations with respiratory sepsis. She had also recently been admitted for management of a similar necrotic wound and cellulitis of her right breast, which healed following antibiotic therapy. The patient's ambivalence at accepting disease-modifying treatment reflected a long-held sense of mistrust and disappointment in her RA management to that point.",

  "Physical Examination": "On initial examination in hospital, a tender 8 × 4-cm ulcer was present above the medial malleolus. The ulcer base was composed of dark granulation tissue with minimal slough. The ulcer border was well demarcated but irregular, and the surrounding skin was violaceous. No rheumatoid nodules, petechiae, purpura, or digital infarctions were apparent. There were no varicose veins or skin changes suggestive of chronic venous insufficiency.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a 20-year history of anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP)-positive rheumatoid arthritis (RA) complicated by Felty's syndrome (FS). She had longstanding neutropenia, first diagnosed approximately 30 years prior. Methotrexate had been poorly tolerated in the past, and the patient had declined to commence any other disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs). She instead preferred to remain on long-term prednisone monotherapy (5 mg). Along with her FS, the patient had a background of type 2 diabetes mellitus (hemoglobin A1c of 7.2%), Hashimoto thyroiditis, obesity, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and poor mobility.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient's anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide and rheumatoid factor titers were greater than 196 U/mL (reference range, <5 U/mL) and 325 IU/mL (reference range, <30 IU/mL), respectively. Her hemoglobin A1c was 7.2%. Wound swabs on multiple occasions identified likely colonization by Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and mixed skin flora."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A biopsy of the wound was performed. No pathogens were identified by tissue culture or acid-fast stain."

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 3-year-old male child.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The child presented with a history of intermittent high-grade fever, multiple joint pain, and swelling since six months of age. His mother reported that he was fine between episodes and achieved developmental milestones normally for his age. The family history indicated that the patient's mother, a 29-year-old female, suffered from inflammatory deforming polyarthritis since the age of five years and had been treated as rheumatoid arthritis. She also had a history of intermittent papular skin rash over the dorsum of her hand and recurrent redness of the eyes. The patient's younger sister, aged twelve months, had developed multiple non-pruritic, non-tender white papules over both limbs for the past month. Otherwise, the child was healthy and playful.",
  "Physical Examination": "On examination, the child had active synovitis in bilateral proximal interphalangeal joints (PIP) 2–5, ankles, and wrist. He also had multiple papular lesions over the upper limbs and trunk with significant xerosis. The patient's mother had boggy swelling at PIP joints with flexion contracture, suggestive of camptodactyly, and white papular lesions over both upper limbs. Ophthalmological examination of the mother was unremarkable.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother suffered from inflammatory deforming polyarthritis since the age of five years and had a history of intermittent papular skin rash and recurrent redness of the eyes. The patient's younger sister developed multiple non-pruritic, non-tender white papules over both limbs for the past month.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Investigation revealed neutrophilic leukocytosis, normal ESR, negative rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP antibody, and antinuclear antibody (ANA) in the child. The mother's investigations showed negative rheumatoid factor, anti-CCP antibody, and ANA."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Clinical exome sequencing for the index case showed a heterozygous mutation at the NOD2 gene (exon 4, c.1000C > T, p.Arg334Trp). Using InterVar bioinformatics software, this mutation was found to be pathogenic according to the 2015 ACMG/AMP guidelines. The mother and younger daughter were also positive for the same mutation (c.1000C > T, p.Arg334Trp; mother homozygous, younger daughter heterozygous), confirmed by Sanger sequencing."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 3.4-year-old Caucasian girl, born at term by spontaneous delivery with a weight of 3500 g. She is the second child of healthy non-consanguineous parents. The patient's geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the emergency room on August 5, 2019, for recurrent acute otitis with vomiting, intermittent sensory disturbance, and irritability. Eleven months earlier (September 2018), she had a similar episode of acute infectious otitis with somnolence, confusion, and lethargy. During the current admission, she was sleepy but reactive to stimuli, with no neurologic deterioration (Glasgow coma score of 15/15). The patient was treated with intravenous sodium benzoate, sodium phenylacetate, and L-arginine, which rapidly normalized plasma ammonia levels in less than 24 hours. She was then put on a protein restricted diet (1.3 g/kg/day) supplemented with L-carnitine (100 mg/kg/day), L-arginine (100 mg/kg/day), and sodium benzoate (230 mg/kg/day), resulting in metabolic correction and clinical improvement. The otitis episode resolved after amoxicillin treatment (80 mg/kg/day) for 7 days. Eighteen months later (February 2021), the patient relapsed with a similar clinical picture: recurrent otitis associated with irritability, intermittent sensory disturbance, and confusion.",

  "Physical Examination": "The neurological assessment found the patient sleepy but reactive to stimuli, with no neurologic deterioration (Glasgow coma score of 15/15).",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no history of perinatal complications or developmental delay. There was a previous episode of acute infectious otitis with somnolence, confusion, and lethargy eleven months before the current admission.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient presented with severe hyperammonemia, increased serum levels of aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT), metabolic alkalosis, and markedly reduced prothrombin activity and prolonged aPTT. Serum amino acid analysis revealed increased levels of glutamine. Urine analysis showed strikingly increased orotic acid excretion. Blood cytology showed increased proportions and counts of monocytes and atypical lymphocytes. Serum protein electrophoresis revealed low levels of total proteins, mainly due to decreased levels of the gamma globulins fraction. Reduced levels of IgG and slightly increased levels of IgM were detected. Normal brain computed tomography scan was reported. During the relapse, severe hyperammonemia was detected again, accompanied by increased serum levels of ornithine, glutamine, AST, ALT, and alkaline phosphatase (ALP). Blood cytology revealed increased proportions of lymphocytes and elevated counts of atypical lymphocytes. Serum protein electrophoresis consistently showed reduced levels of the gamma globulins fraction of serum proteins. Reduced levels of IgG and increased levels of IgM were detected again."
}"

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the emergency room on August 5, 2019, for recurrent acute otitis with vomiting, intermittent sensory disturbance, and irritability. Eleven months earlier (September 2018), she had a similar episode of acute infectious otitis with somnolence, confusion, and lethargy. During the current admission, she was sleepy but reactive to stimuli, with no neurologic deterioration (Glasgow coma score of 15/15). The patient was treated with intravenous sodium benzoate, sodium phenylacetate, and L-arginine, which rapidly normalized plasma ammonia levels in less than 24 hours. She was then put on a protein restricted diet (1.3 g/kg/day) supplemented with L-carnitine (100 mg/kg/day), L-arginine (100 mg/kg/day), and sodium benzoate (230 mg/kg/day), resulting in metabolic correction and clinical improvement. The otitis episode resolved after amoxicillin treatment (80 mg/kg/day) for 7 days.   "Physical Examination": "The neurological assessment found the patient sleepy but reactive to stimuli, with no neurologic deterioration (Glasgow coma score of 15/15).",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no history of perinatal complications or developmental delay. There was a previous episode of acute infectious otitis with somnolence, confusion, and lethargy eleven months before the current admission.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient presented with severe hyperammonemia, increased serum levels of aspartate aminotransferase (AST) and alanine aminotransferase (ALT), metabolic alkalosis, and markedly reduced prothrombin activity and prolonged aPTT. Serum amino acid analysis revealed increased levels of glutamine. Urine analysis showed strikingly increased orotic acid excretion. Blood cytology showed increased proportions and counts of monocytes and atypical lymphocytes. Serum protein electrophoresis revealed low levels of total proteins, mainly due to decreased levels of the gamma globulins fraction. Reduced levels of IgG and slightly increased levels of IgM were detected. Normal brain computed tomography scan was reported. During the relapse, severe hyperammonemia was detected again, accompanied by increased serum levels of ornithine, glutamine, AST, ALT, and alkaline phosphatase (ALP). Blood cytology revealed increased proportions of lymphocytes and elevated counts of atypical lymphocytes. Serum protein electrophoresis consistently showed reduced levels of the gamma globulins fraction of serum proteins. Reduced levels of IgG and increased levels of IgM were detected again.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Genetic analysis revealed no mutations in the OTC gene. Direct sequencing of the SLC25A15 gene identified two novel heterozygous mutations in exon 5: c.649G>A (p.Gly217Arg) and c.706A>G (p.Arg236Gly). In silico analysis of these mutations suggested they are highly detrimental for the secondary structure and function of the protein. Comprehensive phenotypic and functional analysis of cellular and humoral adaptive immune compartments was performed. Proliferative responses of peripheral blood mononuclear cells (PBMC) to various mitogens were assessed, showing significantly reduced proliferation rates in the patient. Cytokine production analysis revealed significantly reduced levels of IFNγ, IL-17A, and TNFα, and higher levels of IL-10 in the patient's PBMC culture supernatants. Flow cytometry analysis of peripheral blood showed normal counts of NK and B cells, but significantly higher counts of T cells, mainly due to an increase in the CD4+ T cell subset. Further T cell subset analysis revealed alterations in the distribution of naïve, central memory, effector memory, and terminally differentiated effector memory cells in both CD4+ and CD8+ T cell compartments. B cell subset analysis showed significantly reduced frequencies of plasmablasts, immature and memory B cells, and higher frequencies of mature B cells in the patient compared to controls."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 36-year-old woman from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the emergency department with chest pain for three hours. She was initially assessed for hypertensive emergency with blood pressure up to 220/100 mmHg. Chest pain and troponin elevation resolved after blood pressure was normalized with nitroglycerin infusion over 24 hours. The patient had a history of delayed developmental milestones, walking at age four and having delayed speech with mostly incomprehensible words. She had been previously diagnosed with bilateral lens dislocations ('ectopia lentis') five years before presentation. She had a left hip fracture and total hip replacement six years before the presentation. After discharge, she was started on vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) 10 mg/kg/day (total of 500 mg daily), folate 1 mg daily, and vitamin B12 1000 µg daily. She was then switched to a vegan, low-methionine diet with amino acid formula deficient in methionine. The introduction of betaine led to further improvement of homocysteine levels. Follow-up over two years showed improved energy level and behavior with sleep-wake cycle regulation. Before treatment, the patient had bouts of agitation and irritability at night, sometimes associated with self-harm. Most of these behaviors resolved with treatment. She could maintain longer conversations with her family, listen to music, and enjoy watching television with a longer attention span. She acquired more words in English than she used to communicate with her family.",

  "Physical Examination": "Examination showed arachnodactyly, microcephaly, and a high-arched palate. Examination of the lower extremities showed an absent posterior tibial artery, dorsalis pedis, and popliteal and femoral pulse on palpation. Ultrasound and Doppler studies showed normal flow in lower extremities arteries with smaller spectral waves on Doppler.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was born in normal vaginal delivery with an uneventful neonatal period and no history of hospitalization. She had delayed developmental milestones. Her past medical history consisted of seizure disorder and several thrombotic events (bilateral lower extremities DVT four years prior to presentation). She also had documented bilateral lens dislocations ('ectopia lentis') five years before presentation, and a left hip fracture with total hip replacement six years before the presentation. Family history was significant for the sudden death of her father at the age of 48, who had no known medical history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial workup included a normal electrocardiogram (ECG) and elevated troponin. A computerized tomography angiogram of pulmonary arteries was unremarkable. The initial routine biochemical profile was unremarkable, including comprehensive metabolic panel, blood count, and troponin I level throughout hospitalization (details provided in Table 1). Lactic acid was 0.7 mmol/l (reference range 0.5-2.2). Thrombophilia workup was unremarkable, including levels and activity of protein C, protein S, factor V Leiden, antithrombin, factor II 20210A, and antibodies to antiphospholipid syndrome. Electroencephalogram (EEG) showed a slow posterior dominant rhythm, with diffuse background slowing and occasional bursts of polymorphic delta waves with higher amplitude over the right hemisphere with independent bitemporal polymorphic slowing."
}"

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial workup included a normal electrocardiogram (ECG) and elevated troponin. A computerized tomography angiogram of pulmonary arteries was unremarkable. Electroencephalogram (EEG) showed a slow posterior dominant rhythm, with diffuse background slowing and occasional bursts of polymorphic delta waves with higher amplitude over the right hemisphere with independent bitemporal polymorphic slowing.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "CT angiogram showed part of the upper abdominal aorta with incidental finding of filling defect. The study was extended to include the aorta and lower extremities, which showed significant aortic thrombosis below the superior mesenteric artery (SMA) level with the involvement of the left renal artery with infarction of the lower and mid poles of the left kidney. The thrombus extended down to the iliac arteries, with a resumption of blood flow in the femoral arteries through two collateral blood supplies. Imaging showed diffuse osteopenia in hand radiographs and several vertebral compression fractures and osteopenia. Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DEXA) scan showed low bone mineral density (BMD), with lumbar spine Z-scores of -1.7, femoral neck Z score of -2.3, and hip Z-score of -2.2. Homocysteine levels were extremely elevated at >500 µmol/L (reference range <10 µmol/L). Fasting homocysteine levels were elevated at 106 umol/l (reference < 1 umol/L) and fasting methionine levels were elevated at 170 umol/l (reference 16-34 umol/l). Family members (sister and mother) were screened with homocysteine and methionine measurements, and both had normal levels. Serial measurements of amino acid levels showed improvement of initially low serine levels, increase in taurine and ß-aminoisobutyric acid. Amino acids from the urea cycle were affected during treatment. Levels of the myokine beta-aminoisobutyric acid increased over two years of follow-up."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "This 4-year-old female patient is of Taiwanese descent. She was born via cesarean section at 28 weeks of gestation. Her body weight is 15.3 kg (21st percentile, Z-score: −0.80) and her body height is 93.1 cm (<3rd percentile, Z-score: −2.77). She resides in Taiwan.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with multiple dysmorphic features and developmental delay. Her birth was complicated by generalized edema and fetal distress. Throughout her development, she experienced worsening facial dysmorphism and developmental delays in motor and speech skills. At age 4, she could walk independently but could not run and could say single words but not full sentences. Bilateral mild corneal clouding was observed, but there was no history of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). She had chronic lung disease of prematurity, requiring home oxygenation with nasal cannula during the day and BiPAP with a mask at night. Additional symptoms included hearing impairment, laryngomalacia type A, biliary atresia managed by a Kasai procedure, and an atrial septal defect (ASD) II. The patient exhibited facial dysmorphism with midface hypoplasia, flat nasal bridge, hypertelorism, high-arched palate, macroglossia, gum hypertrophy, and enamel hypoplasia. Other noted features included a deformity of the chest cage, prominent pigeon chest with scoliosis, hepatosplenomegaly, relatively freely movable extremities with mild limitation of the range of motion (ROM) in most large and small joints, and a widely spaced and unstable gait.",
  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed facial dysmorphism characterized by midface hypoplasia, flat nasal bridge, hypertelorism, high-arched palate, macroglossia, gum hypertrophy, and enamel hypoplasia. The patient had a deformed chest cage and prominent pigeon chest with scoliosis. Hepatosplenomegaly was observed, along with relatively freely movable extremities but with mild limitation of ROM in most large and small joints. The patient had a widely spaced and unstable gait.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother underwent gamete intrafallopian transfer during pregnancy with twins, and one of the twins experienced fetal demise at 10 weeks. The patient had four ascites aspirations during pregnancy due to hydrops fetalis. At birth, she was diagnosed with generalized hydrops. She has a history of chronic lung disease of prematurity, hearing impairment, laryngomalacia type A, biliary atresia (treated with the Kasai procedure), and an atrial septal defect (ASD) II. There is a family history of genetic variants, with her mother carrying the heterozygous variant c.1454C > T in the GUSB gene and her paternal grandmother carrying the heterozygous variant c.104C > A.",
  "Initial Test Results": "The X-ray results showed paddle ribs, dysplastic vertebral bodies, and irregularity and defect of bilateral femoral heads. The urine MPS screening of dimethylmethylene blue (DMB) ratio was 33.68 mg/mmol creatinine (normal range for 2–17 y/o: <20.98). The LC–MS/MS analysis of disaccharide units showed DS at 3.33 μg/mmol creatinine (normal range: <1.56), HS at 1.41 μg/mmol creatinine (normal range: <3.10), KS at 12.97 μg/mmol creatinine (normal range: <13.79), and CS at 8.72 μg/mmol creatinine (normal range: <59.66). Leukocyte enzymatic analyses for MPS I, MPS II, MPS IIIB, MPS IVA, and MPS VI were all normal."
}"

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed facial dysmorphism characterized by midface hypoplasia, flat nasal bridge, hypertelorism, high-arched palate, macroglossia, gum hypertrophy, and enamel hypoplasia. The patient had a deformed chest cage and prominent pigeon chest with scoliosis. Hepatosplenomegaly was observed, along with relatively freely movable extremities but with mild limitation of ROM in most large and small joints. The patient had a widely spaced and unstable gait.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother underwent gamete intrafallopian transfer during pregnancy with twins, and one of the twins experienced fetal demise at 10 weeks. The patient had four ascites aspirations during pregnancy due to hydrops fetalis. At birth, she was diagnosed with generalized hydrops. She has a history of chronic lung disease of prematurity, hearing impairment, laryngomalacia type A, biliary atresia (treated with the Kasai procedure), and an atrial septal defect (ASD) II. There is a family history of genetic variants, with her mother carrying the heterozygous variant c.1454C > T in the GUSB gene and her paternal grandmother carrying the heterozygous variant c.104C > A.",
  "Initial Test Results": "The X-ray results showed paddle ribs, dysplastic vertebral bodies, and irregularity and defect of bilateral femoral heads. The urine MPS screening of dimethylmethylene blue (DMB) ratio was 33.68 mg/mmol creatinine (normal range for 2–17 y/o: <20.98). The LC–MS/MS analysis of disaccharide units showed DS at 3.33 μg/mmol creatinine (normal range: <1.56), HS at 1.41 μg/mmol creatinine (normal range: <3.10), KS at 12.97 μg/mmol creatinine (normal range: <13.79), and CS at 8.72 μg/mmol creatinine (normal range: <59.66). Leukocyte enzymatic analyses for MPS I, MPS II, MPS IIIB, MPS IVA, and MPS VI were all normal.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Further diagnostic testing included DNA analysis via next-generation sequencing (NGS), which revealed a heterozygous genetic variant c.104C > A in the GUSB gene leading to the variant of p.Ser35Ter, and another heterozygous point variant in the GUSB gene c.1454C > T leading to the variant of p.Ser485Phe. The variant c.104C > A was deemed pathogenic in the ClinVar database and ACMG interpretation criteria while c.1454C > T was not reported in ClinVar but was likely pathogenic according to ACMG criteria."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 53-year-old woman. She has been passionate about Asian culture (Korea and Japan) since the age of 5 years old and has correspondents with whom she shares her interest. She has had lots of pets and a reborn baby to bring herself some affection and to cope with a feeling of loneliness.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "At the age of 3, she had an acute metabolic episode revealed by a right-sided hemiplegia. She had a second acute episode revealed by a left-sided hemiparesis at 9 years old. A low-protein regimen successfully controlled her condition afterward. At around 50 years old, she developed functional neurologic disorders such as dystonia, dysphonia, and abrupt loss of muscular tonus in the legs, which improved during follow-up. She continued to have rare episodes of muscular weakness. A psychiatric assessment was needed to complete the neurological evaluation. The patient attended multiple follow-ups with a child psychiatrist for behavior disorders such as clastic crises and multiple scarifications. She was hospitalized once around 25 years old for a suicide attempt (self-phlebotomy). Psychiatrists suspected bipolar disorder given cyclothymic signs and she was treated with Aripiprazole, which was later replaced by Venlafaxine after 2-3 years. She has suffered from traumatic events, including sexual abuse by her first husband and emotional and physical abuse by her second husband. She noted possible emotional neglect during childhood due to communication issues with her parents. She presented emotional dysregulation with impulsivity, affective fluctuations, and self-induced mutilations. She had alexithymia, dissociative symptoms with depersonalization, and multiple episodes of dissociative amnesia in concordance with her traumatic history. She experienced an episode of dissociative amnesia after a sexual assault, where she lost memory of the past 4 years, which spontaneously recovered after 1 week. Autistic symptoms were not clinically marked, but she had difficulties in understanding implicit sense and some sensory intolerance. She had obsessive-compulsive disorders for several years, and she systematically created detailed tables describing her symptoms day by day for the last 6 months, impacting her sleep, housekeeping, and personal hygiene. She currently presents an anxious apprehension of potential muscular weakness and systematically uses a wheelchair when going out, although she has never needed it.",
  "Physical Examination": "On examination, she was mildly disinhibited and logorrheic, but her mood was globally stable. There was no argument for a hypomanic, manic, or depressed syndrome. The neuropsychological evaluation indicated mild global intellectual disability with deficiencies in short-term memory and working memory, but intact episodic memory. Executive functions were globally preserved, but she had difficulty in planning and longer processing speed.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient experienced right-sided hemiplegia at 3 years old and left-sided hemiparesis at 9 years old due to acute metabolic episodes. These were managed with a low-protein regimen. She has a history of behavior disorders with multiple follow-ups with a child psychiatrist, self-phlebotomy at age 25, and suspected bipolar disorder treated first with Aripiprazole and then Venlafaxine. She reported traumatic events such as sexual abuse by her first husband and emotional and physical abuse by her second husband, and possible emotional neglect in childhood. She has obsessive-compulsive disorders, alexithymia, and dissociative symptoms, including depersonalization and dissociative amnesia.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Neuropsychological evaluation showed mild global intellectual disability, deficiencies in short-term memory and working memory, intact episodic memory, preserved executive functions, and difficulty in planning with longer processing speed."
}"
