Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "This female neonate, the first child of a non-consanguineous couple, was born at 38w6d gestational age via cesarean section. Her birth weight was 2.79kg, and her body length and head circumference were 47cm and 35.5cm, respectively. Geographic location information is not provided in the text.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "Five hours after birth, she was admitted to the pediatric intensive care unit due to tachypnea and dysphoria. After admission, the patient presented with convulsions and irritability. She was supported by low-flow oxygen and given symptomatic and empirical treatments including sodium bicarbonate to correct metabolic acidosis, arginine to reduce blood ammonia, vitamin C and coenzyme Q10 to nourish the myocardium, L-carnitine and vitamin B1 to regulate metabolic balance, blue light to treat jaundice, and antibiotics to fight infection. Although metabolic acidosis was initially corrected by sodium bicarbonate, it reappeared once no alkaline liquid was added. During the 13-day hospital stay, blood lactate levels remained consistently higher than normal. The girl was discharged with oral administration of L-carnitine, coenzyme Q10, and vitamin B1. Through post-discharge follow-up, the mother reported dysilthia, dyskoimesis, dysphoria, and occasional convulsion. On the 26th day of her life, the girl passed away at home.",
  "Physical Examination": "",
  "Past Medical History": "At 12 weeks of gestation, the thickness of fetal nuchal translucency was 0.7mm measured by fetal ultrasound. At 22w5d’ gestation, ultrasound images displayed small cysts in the anterior horns of the lateral ventricle and enlarged posterior horns of the lateral ventricle. Increased biparietal diameter and head circumference were detected during the entire pregnancy, which were generally above the 90th or even 95th percentile according to the NICHD Fetal Growth Curve (Asian). MRI at 22w5d’ gestation revealed long T2 signals near the anterior horns and bodies of bilateral lateral ventricles indicating subependymal cysts, and widened bilateral posterior horns of lateral ventricles. The abnormalities persisted and were more pronounced as the pregnancy progressed. Postnatally, multiple and large subependymal cysts were still visible, the largest of which exceeded 4cm in long diameter. The posterior horn of the left lateral ventricle was severely widened to more than 2 cm. Amniocentesis performed during pregnancy revealed a fetal chromosome karyotype of 46, XX, and a copy number variation analysis revealed a 0.64MB microdeletion on chromosome 10 (chr10:g.47080000_47720000del), rated as Likely Benign.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory results revealed that blood lactic acid was 24.8mM and ammonia was 294.4mM. Blood bilirubin increased progressively with a peak of 269.8μM. Blood glucose was normal. Blood myocardial enzyme levels were extremely elevated, including creatine kinase at 973U/L, creatine kinase-MB at 145U/L, lactate dehydrogenase at 769U/L, and α-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase at 581U/L. The 3-beta-hydroxybutyrate was 0.37mM and the urine ketone was 2+. Arterial blood gas analysis disclosed metabolic acidosis with pH of 7.24 and HCO3 − of 5.2mM. During the 13-day hospital stay, blood lactate levels were consistently elevated."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Inherited metabolic disease determination reported a significant increase in blood citrulline (109.4mM) and mild elevations of tyrosine (223.4mM) and alanine (408.5mM). Further, trio-whole exome sequencing (WES) detected a compound heterozygous mutation in the PC gene of the proband, specifically c.1154_1155del (p.Arg385GlnfsTer10) from the mother and c.152G>A (p.Arg51His) from the father. The maternal mutation was a frame-shift mutation not recorded in the gnomAD database and considered Likely Pathogenic. The paternal mutation is a missense mutation also considered Likely Pathogenic. Chest computed tomography showed no abnormalities, but an echocardiogram revealed mild patent ductus arteriosus, patent foramen ovale, and mitral and tricuspid regurgitation. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 31-year-old man with a history of traumatic spinal cord injury causing paraplegia. He is from central North Carolina.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient developed a fever of 103°F, diffuse myalgia, headache, and a non-productive cough five days after a fishing trip in late May at a man-made reservoir in central North Carolina. Three days after symptom onset, he sought care at a local urgent care where he received a presumptive diagnosis of an unspecified 'viral illness'. His symptoms progressively worsened, and a flat erythematous rash developed on the palms of both hands. Five days after the initial visit, he developed new bilateral lower extremity erythema and edema. The patient's condition continued to worsen with persistent fevers and worsening bilateral pain in his shoulders, wrists, and right middle finger. At discharge, 14 days after initial symptom onset, the rash and fever had resolved, and the arthralgia was improving, although the right shoulder remained painful to active movement. Six days after discharge, the patient still had persistent joint pain and weakness in his right arm. Approximately 5 weeks after symptom onset, the patient reported feeling better with energy returning to baseline levels. He still had pain in his right shoulder, elbow, and wrist, suggestive of inflammation in the axillary and radial nerve distribution. The skin on his palms had desquamated bilaterally.",

  "Physical Examination": "In the ED, the patient's vital signs included a blood pressure of 111/53 mm Hg, pulse of 86 beats per minute, temperature of 98.5°F, respiratory rate of 19 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 96%. A flat erythematous rash was observed on the palms of both hands. Bilateral lower extremity erythema and edema were also noted.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of traumatic spinal cord injury causing paraplegia.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Complete blood count (CBC) showed a white blood cell count at the upper limit of normal with lymphopenia and a normocytic anemia. A comprehensive metabolic panel (CMP) showed a slight elevation in aspartate aminotransferase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), and alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and c-reactive protein (CRP) were elevated at 79 mm/h and 342 mg/L, respectively. Urinalysis revealed moderately elevated leukocytes and trace ketones. Multiplex polymerase chain reaction (PCR) testing for influenza, respiratory syncytial virus, and SARS-CoV-2 was negative. A venous duplex exam was negative. An electrocardiogram and chest X-rays were unremarkable. Repeat laboratory testing showed a new leukocytosis, markedly elevated CRP and ESR, and more pronounced elevations in AST, ALT, and ALP."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Additional tests were performed for HIV, syphilis, gonorrhea, chlamydia, Rickettsia rickettsii, Ehrlichia chaffeensis, Lyme disease, parvovirus, toxoplasmosis, and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). All were negative, except for EBV Viral Capsid Antigen IgG and EBV Nuclear Antigen IgG antibody, likely reflective of past infection. Convalescent Ehrlichia and Rickettsia serological tests were ordered along with galactose-α-1,3-galactose (alpha-gal) IgE serology. The acute Ehrlichia serology and acute Rickettsia serology were originally non-reactive with both titers measured at < 1:64 during the hospital stay. Convalescent serology, ordered 28 days after the acute sample collection, showed a greater than four-fold increase in the Ehrlichia IgG titer (1:256)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 59-year-old woman from a geographic location where she works at a construction site. She is diabetic.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a two-year history of ulcerated rashes on the left ankle and both sides of the jaw. The skin lesions were slightly itchy and sometimes painful. She had been previously assessed at another clinic, where she received surgical treatment for a suspected cutaneous tumor. Three years prior to the presentation, the patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at a local hospital but had not received standard treatment. The patient denied a history of skin trauma. After diagnosis and treatment, there was no recurrence after three years of follow-up, and the patient is currently being treated for diabetes at a local hospital.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed three annular areas of erythematous and raised plaque with an ulcer over the left ankle and both sides of the jaw.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes three years prior to presentation. She had no history of skin trauma.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The fasting blood glucose concentration was 10.41 mmol/L (reference range: 3.90–6.10 mmol/L). The white blood cell count was 3800 cells/mm3 (reference range: 4000 to 10000 cells/mm3), with 47.7% neutrophils and 30.2% lymphocytes. Liver and renal function tests were within normal ranges. HIV serology was negative. Direct microscopy of exudate smears in either 10% of potassium hydroxide solution (KOH) or fluorescence staining displayed slender hyphae."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 59-year-old woman from a geographic location where she works at a construction site. She is diabetic.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a two-year history of ulcerated rashes on the left ankle and both sides of the jaw. The skin lesions were slightly itchy and sometimes painful. She had been previously assessed at another clinic, where she received surgical treatment for a suspected cutaneous tumor. Three years prior to the presentation, the patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at a local hospital but had not received standard treatment. The patient denied a history of skin trauma. After diagnosis and treatment, there was no recurrence after three years of follow-up, and the patient is currently being treated for diabetes at a local hospital.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed three annular areas of erythematous and raised plaque with an ulcer over the left ankle and both sides of the jaw.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes three years prior to presentation. She had no history of skin trauma.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The fasting blood glucose concentration was 10.41 mmol/L (reference range: 3.90–6.10 mmol/L). The white blood cell count was 3800 cells/mm3 (reference range: 4000 to 10000 cells/mm3), with 47.7% neutrophils and 30.2% lymphocytes. Liver and renal function tests were within normal ranges. HIV serology was negative. Direct microscopy of exudate smears in either 10% of potassium hydroxide solution (KOH) or fluorescence staining displayed slender hyphae.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Biopsies were taken from skin lesions on the left chin and left ankle. Histopathological examination showed pseudoepitheliomatous hyperplasia in the epidermis; neutrophil abscess in the superficial dermis, diffuse lymphocytes, histiocytes, plasma cells, and a few neutrophils infiltrated in the dermis; and multinucleated giant cells. Periodic acid-Schiff stain revealed dark red spores in multinucleated giant cells. Mycological culture of exudate from the three lesions and biopsied tissues from the two lesions were performed on Sabouraud dextrose agar. The growth of creamy, brownish-beige colonies typical of Sporothrix spp. was noted. Microculture showed thin septate hyphae with conidia in a dense arrangement at its extremities. The fungal culture was confirmed to be S. globosa by sequencing the ribosomal region ITS1-ITS2 of the rDNA (GenBank accession no. OP614927). Antifungal susceptibility testing was carried out, with minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) values provided for various antifungal agents."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 64-year-old woman. She is from a farming background in the mountains. She was positive for hepatitis B surface antigen for several decades.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "On October 13, 2020, the patient presented with fatigue, low blood pressure, arthralgia, and myalgia for 1 week. She had a history of untreated hydronephrosis for 4 years. She reported doing farm work in the mountain without personal protection 1 week prior to admission to a local hospital. Four days after admission, her blood pressure fell dramatically to 84/58 mmHg, jaundice appeared, and renal function deteriorated despite symptomatic treatment. Subsequently, she was transferred to another hospital and complained of generalized pain without fever and jaundice over the entire body. On days 2–4 of hospitalization, the patient's condition worsened, and noninvasive assisted ventilation under high-flow oxygen was commenced. The maximum body temperature was 37.2°C. Tracheoscopy revealed extensive hemorrhage in both airways. Plasma, thrombocytes infusion, liver protection, and relief of jaundice were offered. Additionally, meropenem was prescribed in combination with continuous renal replacement therapy. Multidisciplinary diagnosis and treatment involved the Departments of Hematology, Infectious Disease, Pneumology, and Organ Transplantation, as well as the Intensive Care Unit. Entecavir and ornithine aspartate were administered to lower the high blood ammonia level. On days 5–13 of hospitalization, the patient's liver function deteriorated further under non-invasive assisted ventilation and continuous renal replacement therapy. Considering severe jaundice and inflammatory response caused by the pulmonary infection and hepatitis B virus activation, plasmapheresis was performed on days 8, 9, and 10. The test of bone marrow puncture showed no obvious abnormality. Piperacillin-tazobactam was commenced, and further sputum cultures revealed Aspergillus fumigatus. On day 14, the patient suddenly vomited blood and lost consciousness with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3/15. Emergency brain CT revealed hematoceles in both lateral ventricles and hemorrhage in the right paraoccipital lobe. The patient died 5 hours later after discussions with family members.",
  "Physical Examination": "On initial examination, thickened wet rales were noted in both lungs, there was abdominal distention, and edema was present in both lower limbs. Neurological examination was negative with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15/15. The patient's blood pressure was 100/80 mmHg and pulse rate was 98 beats/min (on noradrenaline maintenance) in supine position.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of untreated hydronephrosis for 4 years and was positive for hepatitis B surface antigen for several decades. Two family members engaged in farm work also underwent antibody testing for leptospirosis, which revealed negative results. Chronic anemia was indicated by decreased red blood cell count and high free iron levels.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory findings on admission were as follows: WBC count 15.3 × 109/L; PLT level 10 × 109/L; albumin level 22.7 g/L; ALT 79 U/L; AST 134 U/L; TBI 105.3 μmol/L; DBI 60.6 μmol/L; creatinine 87.3 μmol/L; blood urea nitrogen 16.68 mmol/L; PT 18.6 s; APTT 41.9 s; D-dimer level 6,320 μg/L. Blood pressure was stable at 120/73 mmHg. After transfer, laboratory parameters were significantly elevated: WBC count 57.0 x 109/L; TBI 254.5 μmol/L; creatinine 263 μmol/L; procalcitonin 10.73 ng/mL; CRP 59.3 mg/L. Sputum, urine, and feces samples were tested for Leptospira IgM and IgG antibodies, both negative."
}"

The test of bone marrow puncture showed no obvious abnormality. Piperacillin-tazobactam was commenced, and further sputum cultures revealed Aspergillus fumigatus. On day 14, the patient suddenly vomited blood and lost consciousness with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 3/15. Emergency brain CT revealed hematoceles in both lateral ventricles and hemorrhage in the right paraoccipital lobe. The patient died 5 hours later after discussions with family members.",
  "Physical Examination": "On initial examination, thickened wet rales were noted in both lungs, there was abdominal distention, and edema was present in both lower limbs. Neurological examination was negative with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 15/15. The patient's blood pressure was 100/80 mmHg and pulse rate was 98 beats/min (on noradrenaline maintenance) in supine position.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of untreated hydronephrosis for 4 years and was positive for hepatitis B surface antigen for several decades. Two family members engaged in farm work also underwent antibody testing for leptospirosis, which revealed negative results. Chronic anemia was indicated by decreased red blood cell count and high free iron levels.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory findings on admission were as follows: WBC count 15.3 × 109/L; PLT level 10 × 109/L; albumin level 22.7 g/L; ALT 79 U/L; AST 134 U/L; TBI 105.3 μmol/L; DBI 60.6 μmol/L; creatinine 87.3 μmol/L; blood urea nitrogen 16.68 mmol/L; PT 18.6 s; APTT 41.9 s; D-dimer level 6,320 μg/L. Blood pressure was stable at 120/73 mmHg. After transfer, laboratory parameters were significantly elevated: WBC count 57.0 x 109/L; TBI 254.5 μmol/L; creatinine 263 μmol/L; procalcitonin 10.73 ng/mL; CRP 59.3 mg/L. Sputum, urine, and feces samples were tested for Leptospira IgM and IgG antibodies, both negative.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Chest radiography revealed obvious patchy shadows in both lungs. Brain CT showed normal findings initially. Chest CT revealed bilateral patchy shadows and diffuse infiltration with extensive consolidation in the right lung. Bone marrow puncture was performed due to abnormal blood routine examinations and showed no obvious abnormality. PCR and next-generation sequencing of blood and sputum samples were conducted. On day 14, emergency brain CT revealed hematoceles in both lateral ventricles and hemorrhage in the right paraoccipital lobe that had ruptured the lateral ventricle. Culture detected Pseudomonas aeruginosa in sputum on day 10, and later Aspergillus fumigatus was also found. Repeat chest CT indicated hydrothorax and relief of bilateral exudation initially, but later revealed new patchy shadows in the right upper lung."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 15-year-old girl from a family where her parents are second cousins. She is the first child of healthy parents. Her birth was at term with a birth weight of 3300 g (0.5 SD).",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the medical genetics department due to obesity, intellectual disability, and dysmorphism. She had no history of failure to thrive in infancy or respiratory insufficiency. Her developmental milestones included sitting independently at 6 months, walking at 18 months, and speaking first words at 30 months. Her family reported an increase in weight gain starting from 3 months of age. At 6 years and 2 months, her weight was 38.7 kg (3.4 SDS), length 116.4 cm (0.1 SDS), and BMI 24.4 kg/m2 (3.3 SDS). At 16 years and 5 months, her weight was 129.4 kg (6.38 SDS), height 156.5 cm (1.03 SDS), and BMI 52.83 kg/m2 (4.79 SDS). Her bone age was determined as 8.8 years at the age of 6 years and 2 months. A GnRH stimulation test performed due to advanced bone age and early breast development revealed prepubertal results. Menarche occurred at 12 years and 8 months, with irregular menstrual cycles. Due to progressive weight gain and clinical signs of insulin resistance, an oral glucose tolerance test was performed, revealing insulin resistance. Metformin treatment was started at 13 years and 9 months, but the patient was noncompliant and weight gain continued. High blood pressure was noted in outpatient examinations (BP: 155–75 mmHg, systolic >99p, >2.3 SDS). Psychiatric evaluation determined the patient did not have autism spectrum disorder but had attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and low school performance. Her intelligence quotient was 80.",

  "Physical Examination": "Dysmorphological examination revealed coarse face, high forehead, bitemporal narrowing, deep-set eyes, prominent nasal bridge, bulbous nasal tip, short philtrum, thin lips, prominent jaw, posteriorly rotated ears, short neck, obesity, tapering fingers, brachydactyly, and bilateral sandal gaps between the first and second toes. Physical examination also showed acanthosis nigricans on the neck and striae on the abdominal region. There were no abnormalities in other systemic evaluations.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's prenatal history was uneventful. There was no history of failure to thrive in infancy or respiratory insufficiency.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Fasting blood glucose, insulin, HbA1c, liver transaminases, thyroid function tests, and a metabolic workup were normal. Karyotype analysis showed 46, XX. Methylation analysis for Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS) was normal."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Clinical exome sequencing (CES) detected a novel heterozygous c.1732C>T (p.Gln578*) pathogenic variant in the MAGEL2 (NM_019066) gene. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 24-year-old woman who was married for eight months. She is 154cm tall and weighs 40kg.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient first visited the outpatient clinic at the Department of Family Medicine in June 2021. She presented with primary amenorrhoea, and painful and unsuccessful intercourse. This was very disturbing for the patient. There was normal body hair distribution and breast development. The vagina was 2cm short ending with a closed pouch. The physical signs of puberty including developed breasts, presence of axillary and pubic hair were present. There was a blind ending of the vagina. No severe skeletal muscle-related anomalies were observed.",

  "Physical Examination": "Upon examination, the woman was 154cm tall and weighed 40kg. The physical signs of puberty including developed breasts, presence of axillary and pubic hair were present. There was a blind ending of the vagina. Clitoris, labia majora and labia minora were noted to be normal. The vulva was normal, and the vagina was short (3cm). Normal ovaries and fallopian tubes were observed, whereas the pelvic sidewalls were displaced.",

  "Past Medical History": "No specific past medical history was provided in the given information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were provided in the given information."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 50-year-old female with a known history of hypothyroidism.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the Emergency Department with a three-month history of headaches associated with dizziness and blurry vision.   "Physical Examination": "On examination, the patient had a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 15 with no other neurological deficits.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a known history of hypothyroidism.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory investigations revealed high prolactin levels (1346 mIU/L)."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "An MRI pituitary scan was performed. The imaging showed a well-defined, completely suprasellar, homogenously enhancing mass lesion arising from the left lateral aspect of the pituitary infundibulum, abutting the left optic tract and tuber cinereum, measuring approximately 1.1 × 1.2 cm. The pituitary gland was seen separately. The lesion showed intermediate signal intensity on T1 and T2-weighted images."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 5-year-old girl from Saudi Arabia. She was delivered at term by normal vaginal delivery after an uneventful pregnancy. Her growth parameters are in the 50th percentile for height and head circumference and the 25th percentile for weight.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient had a history of uncontrolled bronchial asthma with frequent exacerbations, managed with Salbutamol and Flixotide inhaler. One month prior to presentation in March 2018, she developed fever lasting for one week, associated with throat pain and difficulty swallowing. She was initially treated for acute tonsillitis with antipyretics and oral antibiotics. Two days later, she remained febrile, became hypoactive, and had decreased appetite and oral intake. She was admitted to another hospital where blood investigations showed pancytopenia. She developed respiratory distress and was transferred to the pediatric intensive care unit with an impression of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). She was managed with oxygen supplementation via face mask and frequent nebulization. After improvement, she completed a seven-day course of IV antibiotics in the pediatric ward. At follow-up two weeks later, she appeared pale with poor appetite. One week after the follow-up, she spiked a fever after contact with a febrile person and was evaluated at Qatif Central Hospital, Qatif, Eastern Province, KSA.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had normal vital signs and good body build with no dysmorphic features. She appeared pale but not jaundiced or cyanosed. Physical examination revealed congested tonsils without exudate, no lymphadenopathy, mild hepatomegaly, and an ejection systolic murmur. Other parts of the examination were unremarkable.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was fully vaccinated according to the Saudi national vaccine schedule. There was no family history of any medical or surgical diseases. Her developmental history was normal, and she met all developmental milestones at the expected time.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Complete Blood Count (CBC) persistently showed pancytopenia. At follow-up, her CBC showed WBC: 2.6 K/µL, Hb: 8 gm/dL, Platelet: 79 × 103/uL."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a middle-aged individual. Demographics include gender information yet to be specified, of a certain race, from an unspecified geographic location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with multiple tumors located in the pancreas, spleen, and liver. Following surgical resection, several tumors were identified: a tumor of diameter 2.5 cm in the body of the pancreas, the tails of the pancreas and spleen were removed, and a tumor of approximately 1 cm in diameter in the caudate lobe of the liver was also excised in a wedge shape. The patient's spleen revealed a grayish-red and brown mass, while the liver tumor displayed gray-white nodules in the center. Pathological diagnosis during and after the operation suggested that the splenic tumors were likely benign, whereas the pancreatic tumors suggested pancreatic pseudopapillary tumors.",
  "Physical Examination": "",
  "Past Medical History": "",
  "Initial Test Results": ""
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a middle-aged individual. Demographics include gender information yet to be specified, of a certain race, from an unspecified geographic location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with multiple tumors located in the pancreas, spleen, and liver. Following surgical resection, several tumors were identified: a tumor of diameter 2.5 cm in the body of the pancreas, the tails of the pancreas and spleen were removed, and a tumor of approximately 1 cm in diameter in the caudate lobe of the liver was also excised in a wedge shape. The patient's spleen revealed a grayish-red and brown mass, while the liver tumor displayed gray-white nodules in the center. Pathological diagnosis during and after the operation suggested that the splenic tumors were likely benign, whereas the pancreatic tumors suggested pancreatic pseudopapillary tumors.",
  "Physical Examination": "",
  "Past Medical History": "",
  "Initial Test Results": "",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Microscopic examination of paraffin-embedded histopathological sections showed that the pancreatic tumor cells were mostly distributed in strips or diffuse sheets, with characteristic salt and pepper-like nuclei. Immunohistochemistry confirmed that cytokeratin (CK) and beta-catenin were positive, supporting the diagnosis of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors. The liver-associated tumor contained epithelioid cells, perivascular muscle-like cells, and adipocytes, with immunohistochemistry revealing that GPC-3 was negative and Melan A was positive, supporting the diagnosis of a perivascular epithelioid cell tumor (PEcoma). The splenic tumor was a round-shaped nodule with clear boundaries, consisting of uniformly sized oval-shaped tissue-like cells and spindle-shaped muscle-like cells. Immunohistochemistry showed positive staining for both smooth muscle actin (SMA) and cluster of differentiation 68 (CD68), leading to the diagnosis of splenic hamartoma (myoid hamartoma). Genetic mutation detection using the patient's genomic DNA revealed heterozygous variants in the BRCA1 related protein 1 (BAP1) and tuberous sclerosis complex 2 gene (TSC2), suggesting a possible tumor susceptibility syndrome."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 70-year-old individual from Hangzhou, Zhejiang, China. The patient's gender and race were not specified in the provided information.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the hospital with a 'gastric tumor' found during routine physical examination endoscopy. The patient did not complain of nausea, vomiting, or fever. There was no abdominal pain and no obvious aggravating or relieving factors. There was no hematemesis, melena, acid regurgitation, belching, chills, or any other discomforts. After initial diagnosis, the patient underwent endoscopic submucosal dissection (ESD). During the procedure, a white tumor body measuring approximately 2.5 cm was found at the cardia and the gastric bottom. The tumor body was closely connected to the muscularis propria. ESD was performed under gastroscopy, and the lesion was entirely excised. No obvious bleeding was observed on the wound surface. A purse-string suture was used, and the surgical procedure was smooth. Following pathological results, the patient was transferred to surgery for additional treatment and underwent radical gastrectomy plus lymph node dissection. The patient has kept healthy since the follow-up started two years ago.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were reported in the provided information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a ten-year history of hypertension and had been taking anti-hypertensive drugs showing effective blood pressure control. There was no family history of gastric tumors or related diseases.",

  "Initial Test Results": "After admission to the hospital, the complete blood count, blood chemistry, and tumor indices were normal. Specific biochemical test results were mentioned to be presented in a table, but the actual values were not provided in the given information. Gastroscopy examination showed a 2.0 cm × 2.0 cm hemispherical submucosal eminence at the fundus of the stomach with regular borders, a smooth surface, and a shallow central ulcer. Endoscopic ultrasonography revealed a hypoechoic mass originating from the muscularis propria of the gastric wall, which was 2.4 cm × 1.5 cm in size, round and protruding into the gastric cavity, with clear boundary, uniform internal echo, complete mucosal, submucosal, and serosal layers, and no surrounding swollen lymph nodes."
}"

Immunohistochemical results showed lymphoepithelial carcinoma, infiltrating the muscular layer, without tumor thrombus and nerve invasion in vessels, and the lesion involved the lateral incisal margin. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 17-year-old obese female with Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS). She was born in Egypt and moved to Qatar at the age of 9 years. She is the youngest of three siblings.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was born at term with a birth weight of 3.5 kg after an uneventful pregnancy. In the newborn period, she experienced feeding difficulties. On day 12 of life, she had a seizure with frothing, cyanosis, and jaw clenching, resulting in a 10-day admission to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU). There was a delay in motor milestones, with crawling starting at 1 year 8 months and walking at 2 years. Speech delay was also noted, with the patient starting to speak at 5 years. Weight gain began at 2 years, with hyperphagia and excessive weight gain noticed around puberty at 12 years. Parents had difficulty limiting her food intake due to persistent hunger, sometimes leading to vomiting after large meals. At 15 years, she sought endocrine care for an obesity workup. During the COVID-19 quarantine at 16, she gained 17 kg in 1 year. The patient exhibited symptoms suggestive of sleep apnea, including mouth breathing, night snoring, and occasional daytime sleepiness. A sleep study confirmed obstructive sleep apnea, and she was started on non-invasive ventilation. Menarche occurred at 13 years, followed by irregular menses with prolonged heavy periods. To reduce the risk of endometrial hyperplasia and carcinoma, she was prescribed medroxyprogesterone, receiving three 5-day courses since 2019. At 17 years, she presented with high blood glucose values (250-300 mg/dl) during clinic follow-ups, along with polyuria, polydipsia, and nocturia. Her blood gas did not show acidosis. She was started on both long-acting and short-acting insulin for glycemic control. The patient attended a school for children with special needs.",

  "Physical Examination": "At presentation, the patient's weight was 124.1 kg (99.54 centile), height was 138.8 cm (0.01 centile: -3.73 Z-Score), and body mass index (BMI) was 64.4 kg/m2. Acanthosis nigricans was observed on the neck, axilla, and inguinal region, suggestive of insulin resistance.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS). Her father has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM).",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests revealed an HbA1c of 8.1% with high serum insulin and C-peptide levels. Echocardiography showed normal cardiac function and anatomy."
}"

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of Prader-Willi Syndrome (PWS). Her father has Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM).",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests revealed an HbA1c of 8.1% with high serum insulin and C-peptide levels. Echocardiography showed normal cardiac function and anatomy.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Ultrasound of the liver showed multiple lesions initially thought to be areas of focal fatty sparing. An MRI of the liver revealed an enlarged liver with diffuse fat infiltration and multiple numerous focal lesions suggestive of multiple adenomas (adenomatosis). A follow-up ultrasound in 2021 showed a markedly echogenic and heterogeneous liver. The largest measured adenoma was 13 mm superficially in the left lobe (previously up to 11 mm), with others generally around 6 mm in diameter. The patient undergoes an MRI of the abdomen every 6 months for liver adenomatosis monitoring. To date, all MRI scans show no significant interval changes in the number or size of the adenomas. Genetic testing through methylation studies in 2019 revealed an absence of the paternal allele at 15q11-q13 due to abnormal methylation, suggesting a defect in imprinting as the underlying molecular mechanism of the PWS."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 50-year-old woman. She had been recognized as having a slightly large head since childhood. Her head circumference was 61 cm. She had resigned from her job to focus on her treatment.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "At age 39, bilateral breast masses were detected. At age 40, she underwent left cerebellar tumor resection. At age 41, she experienced depression and was referred to a psychiatry department where she was diagnosed with depression and started on medication, with gradual relief of her depressed mood. At age 43, she developed right upper and lower extremity incomplete hemiplegia. She subsequently underwent transvenous embolization on 3 occasions. At age 45, she changed her residence and was referred to the Departments of Breast Surgery, Neurosurgery, and Psychiatry at a new hospital for follow-up. At age 46, she underwent right lobe resection due to a mass in the thyroid gland. In October of the same year, she was diagnosed with recurrent breast cancer with left-rib metastasis, and started hormonal therapy. At age 50, she was referred to the Department of Oncology for continuous surveillance. The patient preferred to be monitored at her current hospital. The attending doctor and the patient consulted a genetic specialist at another hospital, and surveillance was carried out at the current hospital under his guidance. Surveillance for uterine cancer was requested at the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, and periodic lower gastrointestinal endoscopy, urinalysis, and abdominal ultrasound were planned to detect renal or colorectal cancer.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient's physical findings at presentation showed clear consciousness. The right lobe of her thyroid and bilateral breasts had been resected. She had multifocal oral mucosal papillomatosis.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had never been diagnosed with mental retardation. At age 39, she was diagnosed with bilateral invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. A whole-body examination revealed cerebellar tumors and hydrocephalus. Multiple polyps were found in the stomach and large intestine. At age 40, pathological results from left cerebellar tumor resection indicated hamartomas. At age 46, pathological result from thyroid gland mass resection was an adenomatous goiter. Regarding the patient's family history, her older sister had been clinically diagnosed with Cowden syndrome at another hospital. Her father was undiagnosed, but the obtained information indicated that he had macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, and multifocal oral mucosal papillomatosis, and was therefore considered likely to have Cowden syndrome, as defined by the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) diagnostic criteria. Neither the patient nor her sister had any children and there was no possibility of further inheritance because both had reached menopause.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Her blood and urine findings and abdominal ultrasound results were normal."
}"

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had never been diagnosed with mental retardation. At age 39, she was diagnosed with bilateral invasive ductal carcinoma of the breast. A whole-body examination revealed cerebellar tumors and hydrocephalus. Multiple polyps were found in the stomach and large intestine. At age 40, pathological results from left cerebellar tumor resection indicated hamartomas. At age 46, pathological result from thyroid gland mass resection was an adenomatous goiter. Regarding the patient's family history, her older sister had been clinically diagnosed with Cowden syndrome at another hospital. Her father was undiagnosed, but the obtained information indicated that he had macrocephaly, hydrocephalus, and multifocal oral mucosal papillomatosis, and was therefore considered likely to have Cowden syndrome, as defined by the National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) diagnostic criteria. Neither the patient nor her sister had any children and there was no possibility of further inheritance because both had reached menopause.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Her blood and urine findings and abdominal ultrasound results were normal.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "At age 43, close examination revealed a dural arteriovenous fistula. Analysis of the PTEN gene showed a likely pathogenic c.801 + 2T>A variant. The c.801 + 2T>A variant is considered as 'likely pathogenic' according to the American College of Medical Genetics, because it is located at the splice donor site of intron 7 (PVS1). It is a very rare variant that is not registered in The Genome Aggregation Database in the general population, including in Japanese (PM2), but is registered as 'pathogenic' in ClinVar. Primers were designed for exons 5 to 8 to cover exon 7, and splicing defects were detected by reverse transcription-polymerase chain reaction and ribonucleic acid (RNA) sequencing. Messenger RNA (mRNAs) lacking exon 7 were detected. mRNAs having a cryptic exon as part of the intron 6 sequence and mRNAs produced by splicing with a new donor site at 'GT' 74 nucleotides downstream from the mutation site were also detected. Both of these splicing aberrations cause a frameshift that stops PTEN protein synthesis. These mRNAs were degraded by nonsense-mediated mRNA decay. In addition, deletion of exons 6 and 7 results in the synthesis of proteins with deletions from glycine 165 to lysine 267. These results suggested that alleles with these variants were unlikely to produce normal PTENs."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 40-year-old woman with no smoking history and no concerning environmental exposures.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient underwent total body computed tomography (CT) as part of an initial annual executive medical assessment, which revealed a right upper lobe mass. She had no cardiopulmonary symptoms. A CT-guided biopsy was performed, revealing adenocarcinoma consistent with lung primary. No distant disease was found on brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and positron emission tomography-CT. The patient underwent right upper lobectomy and regional lymph node dissection. Pathologic evaluation identified a stage II (T2N1M0) lung adenocarcinoma harboring an EGFR exon 19 p.Glu746_Ala750 deletion. Approximately 6 weeks after surgical resection, the patient started adjuvant osimertinib. Adjuvant chemotherapy was not recommended due to concern for heightened leukemogenic potential of cytotoxic agents in the setting of a germline TP53 mutation.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were mentioned in the provided information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's family history revealed multiple relatives with cancer. Her mother, with a distant and minimal smoking history, was diagnosed with stage 1B RUL NSCLC harboring an EGFR exon 21 c.2573T>G (p.Leu858Arg) mutation at age 69 years. An identical twin sister was diagnosed with invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the sigmoid colon with well-differentiated neuroendocrine tumor features at age 31 years. The twin sister's cancer was KRAS wild type, NRAS wild type, and BRAF wild type, with immunohistochemistry for mismatch repair proteins intact. A maternal aunt had breast cancer diagnosed at age 65 years, and her son (first cousin to the patient) was diagnosed with prostate cancer at age 55 years.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No specific initial test results were mentioned in the provided information."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "An 81-year-old Black female from the United States.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the dermatology clinic for an asymptomatic 'dark line' on her right great toenail. The 'line' had been present for many years but had recently changed over the last 6 months. There was no history of trauma to the affected toe.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical exam revealed a brown-black longitudinal band with localized distal onycholysis on the right great toenail. Additionally, there was slight nail thickening or pachyonychia present where the pigment presented. Dermoscopy of the free edge was performed.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no history of skin cancer.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were reported."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "An 81-year-old Black female from the United States.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no history of skin cancer.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were reported.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A nail matrix biopsy was performed. Histopathologic examination revealed acanthosis of the nail matrix with matrical onychocytes characterized by small monomorphic nuclei, scant cytoplasm, and absence of cytologic atypia focally displaying concentric nests. A Fontana-Masson stain showed increased melanin deposition. SOX10 and MART-1 immunohistochemical stains failed to demonstrate a definitive melanocytic lesion."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is an 8-year-old girl from a family with consanguineous parents (father and mother are cousins). She has an older brother who had a similar condition and died at 16 years old, and a healthy 12-year-old sister.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with weakness in both lower limbs lasting for more than 6 years. The disease course was slow and progressively worsening. She exhibited unstable walking, frequent falls, slow walking speed, inability to squat or get up independently, reluctance to climb stairs, and inability to run. The patient occasionally complained of abdominal pain, had difficulty controlling stool, and experienced occasional bedwetting. Her developmental milestones included raising her head at 3 months, sitting at 6 months, and walking at 1.5 years old. She was born to a mother with gravida 3 para 3, had unknown birth weight, and was fed with mixed feeding.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were reported in the given information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's older brother had a similar history of weakness in both lower limbs that later progressed to general weakness. He died one year ago at the age of 16 years. No other past medical history was reported for the patient.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were reported in the given information."
}"

She was born to a mother with gravida 3 para 3, had unknown birth weight, and was fed with mixed feeding.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were reported in the given information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's older brother had a similar history of weakness in both lower limbs that later progressed to general weakness. He died one year ago at the age of 16 years. No other past medical history was reported for the patient.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were reported in the given information.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Genomic DNA was extracted from the peripheral blood using QIAamp DNA Mini Kit and quantified with Nanodrop 2000. A genomic DNA library was constructed using NEXTflex® Rapid DNA-Seq Kit. The libraries were captured by xGen Exome Research Panel v2 and sequenced by Novaseq 6000. Alignment was performed using Short Oligonucleotide Analysis Package (SOAP) aligner software. Snp_indel was called by GATK and annotated by ANNOVAR. Variants were filtered and evaluated according to the American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics (ACMG) guidelines. Total RNA was extracted from peripheral blood samples using TRIzol Reagent and reverse transcribed to cDNA. PCR was performed with specific primers designed upstream and downstream of gene c.1373+1G>A variation. PCR products were separated by 2% agarose gel electrophoresis and sequenced by ABI 3500. Brain MRI was performed on the patient at age 8 years. A muscle biopsy was also performed on the patient at age 8 years and processed with standard methods for histology and histochemistry."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 55-year-old Japanese man. He was born to a consanguineous marriage (between cousins). His parents were healthy, and he had no family history of neurological diseases.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient had normal physical and mental development until he noticed unsteadiness while walking down stairs at 36 years old. His walking disorder slowly progressed, leading him to visit a neurology department at 39 years old. He has been regularly attending the hospital for rehabilitation and neurological evaluations since then. Due to further progression of gait disturbance, he began using a walker at 51 years old. He had no episodes of loss of consciousness or epilepsy. His cognitive function, evaluated using the revised version of Hasegawa's dementia scale (HDS-R), declined with age. At 39, 50, and 55 years old, his HDS-R scores were 28, 20, and 18 out of 30 respectively (cut-off score 20/21). At 55 years old, his Japanese adaptation of the Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE-J) score was 24 out of 30 (cut-off score 26/27), and his Frontal Assessment Battery (FAB) score was 11 out of 18 (cut-off score 11/12).",

  "Physical Examination": "On neurological examination, the patient showed downbeat nystagmus, slurred speech, and limb ataxia. He also exhibited hyperreflexia in the upper and lower extremities and spasticity in the lower extremities. No muscle wasting was observed. Both Hoffman's and Babinski reflexes were negative. An ophthalmic examination revealed no tortuosity of the conjunctival vessels.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no significant past medical history reported.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The results of nerve conduction studies, needle electromyography, and electric encephalography were normal. The serum concentration of CoQ10 was 395 ng/mL (reference interval: 338-1,340 ng/mL)."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed marked atrophy of the cerebellum and mild atrophy of the frontal lobes. Single-photon emission computed tomography showed a decrease in cerebellar blood flow. Gene analysis ruled out major types of spinocerebellar ataxia (SCA) caused by nucleotide repeat expansion, including SCA1, SCA2, SCA3, SCA6, SCA7, SCA8, SCA10, SCA17, and SCA31. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) of SCA-related genes using a multi-gene exome panel revealed a novel homozygous deletion mutation in the TMEM16K (ANO10) gene (NM_018075.3:c.616delG, p.Glu206Lysfs*17), which was validated by conventional Sanger sequencing."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "The patient underwent a work-up including an NGS panel and copy number analysis of 536 genes associated with ataxia/episodic ataxia, performed on an Illumina instrument using Agilent Sure Select capture reagent. A study of mitochondrial DNA was added, which consisted of sequencing and copy number variant assessment of an mtDNA PCR product of approximately 16,476 base pairs encompassing all known pathogenic variants in the mtDNA. Analysis of triplet expansion of Friedreich's ataxia was also performed. The analysis detected a homozygous likely pathogenic variant in the SYNE1 gene: NM_182961.4(SYNE1): c.9625A > T (p.Lys3209Ter), Chr6:152690632, reference GRCh37. This variant generates a substitution of a thymine for an adenine at nucleotide position 9625, which is predicted to result in the change of a lysine at position 3209 to a stop codon. There is no information available on whether this variant was confirmed by Sanger sequencing or not."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 19-year-old man from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient first experienced a generalized seizure attack without any apparent cause at 8 years of age. He sometimes complained of bright or colorful flashing lights, blurry vision, and distance changes in both visual fields before seizures, especially on the right side. These visual auras usually lasted several minutes and sometimes occurred alone. At 17 years of age, he experienced transient nodding attacks, frequently without an aura. At 18 years of age, dropping attacks occurred frequently, with accompanying gripped hands and slight forearm flexion. After these attacks, he could stand by himself without an aura or a memory. The nodding and dropping attacks could occur 2–10 times in 4–5 days and in a series. He was diagnosed with refractory epilepsy and underwent presurgical evaluation at another hospital. He underwent vagal nerve stimulation (VNS) using five types of antiepileptic drugs, but there was no significant improvement. He was subsequently admitted to the current hospital for further treatment.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination results were normal.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's family, perinatal, and growth history were normal.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Wakeful background on video electroencephalography showed 9–10 Hz alpha rhythm in bilateral occipital regions. Interictal EEG showed generalized 2–2.5 Hz slow spike waves (SSWs) during wakefulness and generalized paroxysmal fast activities (GPFAs) during sleep. There were also multifocal independent spikes, especially in the bilateral occipital and posterior temporal regions where the left side was more predominant than the right. Compared with SSWs and occipital discharges, GPFA was more prominent, followed by occipital discharges. Epileptic spasms, tonic seizures, and atypical absence were recorded, which showed EEG onsets with a little localization value. Neuropsychological tests showed moderate cognitive impairment. No abnormalities were found on genetic testing and perimetry."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient was over 70 years of age and from a BoDV-1-endemic region of southern Germany.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the department of neurology with a 2-week history of confusion, dizziness, memory impairment, and recurrent vomiting. On the day after admission, the patient was found unconscious and was intubated due to suspected severe aspiration pneumonia. The patient remained in a deep coma after stopping light sedation on day 5. By day 12, the patient was in a deep coma, showing no motor responses, with multiple brainstem reflexes absent. The patient died on day 15 after admission. BoDV-1 infection was diagnosed by a positive qRT-PCR result from CSF collected on day 8 after admission. The first CSF obtained on day 1 after admission yielded positive results for BoDV-1 RNA ranging between 515 and 1,850 copies/mL, whereas a CSF obtained on day 4 tested negative. Seroconversion was detected on day 13 using iIFA (titer 320). BoDV-1-specific antibodies were not detected in serum or CSF samples obtained earlier. ELISA tests showed seroconversion on day 13, mainly based on reactivity against BoDV-1 X protein, with anti-BoDV-1-P-IgG just above the cutoff in the last plasma sample obtained, and anti-BoDV-1-N-IgG not detectable.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient was found unconscious on the day after admission. The patient remained in a deep coma after day 5, showing no motor responses by day 12. Multiple brainstem reflexes were absent.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's medical history was insignificant, especially without immunosuppression or organ transplantation.",

  "Initial Test Results": "An electroencephalogram (EEG) displayed mild diffuse slowing. CSF parameters on the day after admission showed normal cell count (2 leucocytes/μL), lactate 1.98 mmol/L, and protein 925 mg/L, indicating a blood-brain barrier disruption. CSF analysis on day 8 showed a CSF leucocyte count of 41 μL. PCR results for herpes simplex virus, varicella-zoster virus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and enterovirus were negative. Serological indicators of Lyme disease, tick-borne encephalitis, or autoimmune encephalitis were not detectable."
}"

The first CSF obtained on day 1 after admission yielded positive results for BoDV-1 RNA ranging between 515 and 1,850 copies/mL, whereas a CSF obtained on day 4 tested negative. Seroconversion was detected on day 13 using iIFA (titer 320). BoDV-1-specific antibodies were not detected in serum or CSF samples obtained earlier. ELISA tests showed seroconversion on day 13, mainly based on reactivity against BoDV-1 X protein, with anti-BoDV-1-P-IgG just above the cutoff in the last plasma sample obtained, and anti-BoDV-1-N-IgG not detectable.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient was found unconscious on the day after admission. The patient remained in a deep coma after day 5, showing no motor responses by day 12. Multiple brainstem reflexes were absent.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's medical history was insignificant, especially without immunosuppression or organ transplantation.",

  "Initial Test Results": "An electroencephalogram (EEG) displayed mild diffuse slowing. CSF parameters on the day after admission showed normal cell count (2 leucocytes/μL), lactate 1.98 mmol/L, and protein 925 mg/L, indicating a blood-brain barrier disruption. CSF analysis on day 8 showed a CSF leucocyte count of 41 μL. PCR results for herpes simplex virus, varicella-zoster virus, cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, and enterovirus were negative. Serological indicators of Lyme disease, tick-borne encephalitis, or autoimmune encephalitis were not detectable.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Two brain magnetic resonance images (MRIs) on days 4 and 11 remained unremarkable. Post mortem, all samples from non-neuronal tissue tested negative for BoDV-1 RNA, while samples from the frontal cortex as well as from the optical nerve and peripheral nerve tissue contained a high RNA load. Histological work-up showed marked necrotizing lymphocytic neuritis of the peripheral femoral and small visceral nerves. Western blot using recombinant BoDV-1 proteins showed at least two reactive bands. ELISA tests were performed using recombinant BoDV-1 nucleoprotein (N), accessory protein X (X), and phosphoprotein (P) proteins. BoDV-1-specific IgM antibodies were also tested."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a female named Taliah. Her current age is not specified, but she is described as being in adulthood.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "Taliah had her first prolonged generalized tonic clonic seizure (GTCS) at 2 months of age, 12 hours after her first immunization. At 3 months, she experienced another prolonged GTCS following her second immunization. Shortly after, she began experiencing habitual, unprovoked seizures including myoclonic jerks, unclassified unresponsive episodes (possibly absence or atypical absence seizures), and GTCS. Her seizures were drug-resistant, and she experienced several episodes of status epilepticus. At 4 years of age, Taliah experienced a severe and prolonged GTCS which led to developmental regression and subsequent intellectual disability. Currently, as an adult, she continues to have clusters of GTCS occurring every 1-2 months. Taliah has also been diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).",

  "Physical Examination": "Taliah has thoracolumbar scoliosis, which was surgically corrected at 13 years of age.",

  "Past Medical History": "Taliah was born following an uneventful pregnancy. Her early development was normal until the age of 4 when she experienced developmental regression following a severe and prolonged GTCS. At 10 years of age, Taliah was diagnosed following genetic testing which identified a pathogenic stopgain variant in SCN1A (NM_001353948:c.G3991T:p.E1331*).",

  "Initial Test Results": ""
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male child born at term via elective Cesarean section. He is the second child of consanguineous (first cousin) parents from Pakistan.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The child was noted to have a right-sided facial palsy at birth, with additional concerns later raised about the left side. He exhibited an anomaly of his left upper limb with symbrachydactyly, a chest wall deformity, apparent absence of pectoralis major, and an absent nipple areolar complex. He experienced an episode of milk aspiration and was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit for 20 days. Oral intake remained poorly coordinated, and feeding was supported using a nasogastric tube. Flexible nasal largyngoscopy revealed mild to moderate laryngomalacia and a deep inter-arytenoid groove with salivary pooling. The child exhibited generalized hypotonia. A contrast study for persistent gastro-esophageal reflux revealed an anatomically normal alimentary canal. Due to persistent reflux and a further aspiration, he underwent insertion of a gastric tube with fundoplication. Within the first 12 months of life, he was examined by plastic surgeons specializing in facial palsy and congenital limb anomalies. Facial examination revealed bilateral, asymmetric facial palsies (worse on the right), bilateral failure of ocular abduction, and bilateral blepharoptosis with no skeletal facial dysmorphism. A high arched but intact hard palate was noted. He exhibited good masseteric contractions bilaterally. Examination of the upper limbs and chest revealed a complete absence of pectoralis major and the nipple areolar complex on the left with significant axillary hollowing. Hypoplasia of left upper limb, particularly forearm and hand were noted. Symbrachydactyly was observed, with a reasonable thumb including thenar musculature. Flexion was observed at the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints. The index, middle and ring fingers were hypoplastic, biphalangeal and syndactylized. Active movement was exhibited at the elbow and shoulder. At 18 months of age, he underwent release of the 1st and 4th web space syndactyly. He remains a candidate for bilateral facial reanimation. Based on these findings, a diagnosis of Poland-Möbius syndrome was made.",

  "Physical Examination": "Facial examination revealed bilateral, asymmetric facial palsies (worse on the right), bilateral failure of ocular abduction, and bilateral blepharoptosis with no skeletal facial dysmorphism. A high arched but intact hard palate was noted. The child exhibited good masseteric contractions bilaterally. Examination of the upper limbs and chest revealed a complete absence of pectoralis major and the nipple areolar complex on the left with significant axillary hollowing. Hypoplasia of left upper limb, particularly forearm and hand were noted. Symbrachydactyly was observed, with a reasonable thumb including thenar musculature. Flexion was observed at the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints. The index, middle and ring fingers were hypoplastic, biphalangeal and syndactylized. Active movement was exhibited at the elbow and shoulder.",

  "Past Medical History": "The prenatal history was uneventful and there was no maternal history of medical or recreational drug use.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Echocardiography revealed a patent ductus arteriosus and a moderate atrial septal defect which was treated expectantly. Flexible nasal largyngoscopy revealed mild to moderate laryngomalacia and a deep inter-arytenoid groove with salivary pooling. A contrast study for persistent gastro-esophageal reflux revealed an anatomically normal alimentary canal."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The proband is a nine-year-old girl from a consanguineous union (f = 1/64) residing in a geographic location not specified. She was born from an uneventful pregnancy and delivery, with a birth weight of 2800 g. Her family comprises her parents and four other siblings.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with progressively declining vision associated with limb malformations and dermatologic anomalies. She had surgery at the age of 4 years to liberate the right-hand syndactyly between the 1st-2nd fingers and 4th-5th fingers. Her psychomotor development was normal. She complained of severe photophobia, progressive visual loss, and was diagnosed with bilateral horizontal and conjugate nystagmus. There was a notable absence of hearing loss or intellectual disability. Her 13-year-old sister also complained of progressively declining vision and was diagnosed with congenital cone dystrophy, but did not present with limb anomalies or dermatologic issues. The sister had intermittent exotropia with bilateral, horizontal, and conjugate nystagmus noticed since the age of 3 months.",
  "Physical Examination": "At the age of 9 years, the proband was found to have short stature at −2.7 DS, with weight and head circumference within normal ranges (−1.9 DS and +1 DS respectively). Dysmorphic features included a large protruding forehead, hypoplastic alae nasi, prominent columella, micrognathia, hypoplastic mandible, and down slanting ears. The patient had hypodontia with small teeth and enamel dysplasia. Upper limb anomalies comprised an absent third digital ray at the right hand with scars of repaired cutaneous syndactyly between the first and second digits, and the fourth and fifth digits. The left hand lacked the second and third digital rays with cutaneous syndactyly between the fourth and fifth fingers. Feet malformations consisted of a bilateral central cleft with absent second and third digital rays and syndactyly between the fourth and fifth toes in the left foot. Dermatologic examination revealed dry and hypopigmented skin without palmoplantar keratoderma. She had blond thin and sparse hair, hypotrichosis included eyebrows, eyelashes, and temporoparietal scalp. Trichoscopy for her scalp hair and eyelashes revealed inter and perifollicular scales, sparse hair, miniaturization, and pili torti. She had brittle nails and nail pits on the left thumb and reported reduced sweating. Hypoplastic nipples were also noticed.",
  "Past Medical History": "The proband's birth and early development were uneventful except for the tetramelic SHFM noticed at birth and surgically addressed at age 4. Family history revealed a brother deceased at the age of 2 months from congenital heart malformation. A 13-year-old sister presented with nystagmus since the age of 3 months and progressive decrease in visual acuity. Neither parent had limb anomalies or ophthalmic problems.",
  "Initial Test Results": "The ophthalmic evaluation included slit-lamp examination showing severe blepharitis with mucopurulent discharge, epiphoria, and absent Meibomian glands in both eyes. Cycloplegic objective refraction was +6.25/-2×180° in the right eye and +6.75/-2×10 in the left eye, with best-corrected visual acuity of 20/200 in both eyes. Schirmer test with anesthetics was normal. The mean fluorescein tear-film break-up time was 4 seconds in the right eye and 5 seconds in the left eye, indicating rapid tear evaporation. Anterior segment examination showed bilateral superficial punctuate keratitis. Fundoscopy was unremarkable in both eyes."
}"

}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 7-year-old male. He was born from a pregnancy with ovodonation, fertilized with paternal sperm, and was part of a twin birth. At birth, he weighed 2,150 g with a length of 45.5 cm. His general state of health is good, with a slight difference in development compared to his twin. He has bilateral mild-to-moderate hearing loss.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient's psychomotor and cognitive development is regular. Primary teeth replacement is delayed and incomplete. On the frontal plane, the face appears elongated and asymmetrical with a chin deviation to the right. The middle and upper third are balanced, while on the lateral plane there is a reduction of the lower third (micrognathia). Lip competence is present. The head is slightly tilted. The eyelid rims are tilted downwards and outwards (slanting), the interpupillary distance is normal, and there are no signs of iris or pupillary coloboma. The tongue's mobility appears to be reduced due to a short frenulum, which does not compromise its extrusion but only its elevation. This anomaly is also found in the twin brother.",

  "Physical Examination": "Deciduous central and lateral incisors in the upper arch are slightly discolored. Bilateral agenesis of the deciduous canines is present, although the permanent canines are touchable under the gums. Distally, there are four deciduous molar-like teeth with disproportionate and irregular crowns. The presence of abundant plaque and dental malposition causes erythematous areas and gingivitis. The lateral frenula have a very low insertion, while the central one does not interfere with the incisors. The palate is narrow and ogival. The lower arch appears very similar to the upper one. Globodontia affects molars and canines, with the left canine being semi-included. There are only two incisors in the lower arch. The ophthalmologic examination did not show any vision abnormalities.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's pregnancy involved ovodonation and fertilization with paternal sperm, resulting in a twin birth without complications. Cow's milk protein allergy is noted in the history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Cephalometric analysis shows a skeletal Class I in a hyperdivergent, biretrused patient with growth pattern of clockwise mandibular rotation."
}"

There are erupted teeth similar to molars with large cubic crowns. The buds of the second and third molars are present. In the lower arch, there is substantial anterior crowding; the lateral incisors are included due to lack of adequate space for eruption. The buds of the premolars and of the first molars are absent bilaterally. The buds of the second and third molars are present distally."

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 7-year-old boy from South Korea. He was born at 38 weeks gestation with a birth weight of 3.35 kg. He is the first child of nonconsanguineous parents.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient visited the hospital with uncorrected vision. He had been wearing glasses for several years, but his best-corrected visual acuity was 20/200 in both eyes. He had a mild hyperopic refractive error of +1.5 diopters. Photophobia and slow pendular nystagmus were observed. Fundus examination revealed a normal-looking optic disc and macula. Widefield fundus photography and fundus autofluorescence did not reveal any definite abnormalities, but blurring of ellipsoid zone was noted on optical coherence tomography. A full-field electroretinogram showed severely reduced responses in the cone and rod systems in both eyes. On subsequent dental evaluation, the patient had brown discolorations in his permanent maxillary central incisors and enamel hypoplasia in his permanent first molars. A panoramic radiograph showed pulp obliteration of the remaining primary teeth. Enamel hypoplasia, which is a variant of amelogenesis imperfecta, was diagnosed.",

  "Physical Examination": "Fundus examination revealed a normal-looking optic disc and macula. The patient had brown discolorations in his permanent maxillary central incisors and enamel hypoplasia in his permanent first molars.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no previous family history of ocular, systemic, or chromosomal disorders.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Widefield fundus photography and fundus autofluorescence did not reveal any definite abnormalities. Optical coherence tomography showed blurring of ellipsoid zone. A full-field electroretinogram showed severely reduced responses in the cone and rod systems in both eyes. A panoramic radiograph showed pulp obliteration of the remaining primary teeth."
}"
