  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 7-year-old boy from South Korea. He was born at 38 weeks gestation with a birth weight of 3.35 kg. He is the first child of nonconsanguineous parents.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient visited the hospital with uncorrected vision. He had been wearing glasses for several years, but his best-corrected visual acuity was 20/200 in both eyes. He had a mild hyperopic refractive error of +1.5 diopters. Photophobia and slow pendular nystagmus were observed. Fundus examination revealed a normal-looking optic disc and macula. Widefield fundus photography and fundus autofluorescence did not reveal any definite abnormalities, but blurring of ellipsoid zone was noted on optical coherence tomography. A full-field electroretinogram showed severely reduced responses in the cone and rod systems in both eyes. On subsequent dental evaluation, the patient had brown discolorations in his permanent maxillary central incisors and enamel hypoplasia in his permanent first molars. A panoramic radiograph showed pulp obliteration of the remaining primary teeth. Enamel hypoplasia, which is a variant of amelogenesis imperfecta, was diagnosed.",

  "Physical Examination": "Fundus examination revealed a normal-looking optic disc and macula. The patient had brown discolorations in his permanent maxillary central incisors and enamel hypoplasia in his permanent first molars.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no previous family history of ocular, systemic, or chromosomal disorders.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Widefield fundus photography and fundus autofluorescence did not reveal any definite abnormalities. Optical coherence tomography showed blurring of ellipsoid zone. A full-field electroretinogram showed severely reduced responses in the cone and rod systems in both eyes. A panoramic radiograph showed pulp obliteration of the remaining primary teeth.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Next-generation sequencing (NGS) was performed for genetic analysis. Targeted panel sequencing was done with 439 genes related to inherited retinal dystrophy. Compound heterozygous missense variants of c.1511T>G, p.(Ile504Ser), and c.344T>C, p.(Leu115Pro) in the CNNM4 gene were identified. The c.1511T>G variant was classified as likely pathogenic according to the American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics guidelines. The c.344T>C variant has never been reported in a population database. Parental testing, performed only for the patient's mother due to circumstances, revealed one heterozygous variant (c.1511T>G) from the mother."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a Chinese male infant born to healthy non-consanguineous parents. He was delivered by caesarean section after 38 weeks of gestation due to oligohydramnios, premature rupture of membranes, and intrauterine hypoxia. He is the second child in the family.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "At 1 month old, the patient developed increasingly restricted movement of his limbs. From 2.5 months, he began crying when moved and presented with feeding problems and diarrhoea. At 4 months, he showed hypoactivity, hypotonia, and sensitivity to passive movement. He had frontal bossing, a short nose, a depressed nasal bridge, and a papular skin rash on his hands. At 6 months, he developed flexion contractures in the elbow, hip, knee, and ankle with swollen joints and body pain. One month later, hyperpigmentation over the bony prominences was observed. He experienced recurrent respiratory infections and episodes of diarrhoea. At 8 months, he failed to thrive with a weight of 7.0 kg (<2 SD), could not raise his head or sit up unaided, and gingival hypertrophy was observed. His intelligence was similar to that of healthy children. At 2 years, he experienced recurrent acute bronchitis or pneumonia 3-5 times every year and persistent diarrhoea. At 3 years, he suffered from diarrhoea with severe dehydration, seizure, and a coma, but recovered after treatment with intravenous gamma globulin. At 4 years, his gingival hyperplasia led to facial deformity. He had pearly papules around his neck, cutaneous nodules at his chest, back and right ear, hyperpigmentation at his abdomen and back with recurrent skin infections, and perianal plaques. His joint contractures had not progressed after 1 year of age. His weight was 7.2 kg (<4 SD).",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient presented with hypoactivity, hypotonia, and sensitivity to passive movement. He had frontal bossing, a short nose, a depressed nasal bridge, and a papular skin rash on his hands. Flexion contractures were observed in the elbow, hip, knee, and ankle with swollen joints. Hyperpigmentation over the bony prominences, gingival hypertrophy, pearly papules around the neck, cutaneous nodules at the chest, back and right ear, hyperpigmentation at the abdomen and back, and perianal plaques were noted during follow-up examinations.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother was threatened with preterm labour at 3 months of gestation and was treated with medication. Decreased foetal movement was observed during pregnancy. Foetal hydronephrosis was diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound screening. The patient had no family history of ISH. His healthy older brother was 5 years old, and his mother had experienced two induced abortions.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient had an increased serum alanine aminotransferase level (61 U/L, normal range: 0-40 U/L) and mild hyperkalaemia (5.57 mmol/L, normal range: 3.5-5.5 mmol/L). Tests for anti-dsDNA antibodies (dsDNA) were positive. The creatine kinase, serum creatinine, blood glucose, thyroid function, blood gas, coagulation function, syphilis antibody, and blood tandem mass spectrometry data were normal. The patient's IgG level was 3.0 g/L (normal range: 3.7-8.3 g/L), CD3+% was 57% (normal range: 64%-73%), CD8+% was 23% (normal range: 24%-34%), and CD19+% was 22% (normal range: 14%-21%). Ultrasound detected hydronephrosis on the left side, separation of the renal pelvis, splenomegaly, and patent ductus arteriosus."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a Chinese male infant born to healthy non-consanguineous parents. He was delivered by caesarean section after 38 weeks of gestation due to oligohydramnios, premature rupture of membranes, and intrauterine hypoxia. He is the second child in the family.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "At 1 month old, the patient developed increasingly restricted movement of his limbs. From 2.5 months, he began crying when moved and presented with feeding problems and diarrhoea. At 4 months, he showed hypoactivity, hypotonia, and sensitivity to passive movement. He had frontal bossing, a short nose, a depressed nasal bridge, and a papular skin rash on his hands. At 6 months, he developed flexion contractures in the elbow, hip, knee, and ankle with swollen joints and body pain. One month later, hyperpigmentation over the bony prominences was observed. He experienced recurrent respiratory infections and episodes of diarrhoea. At 8 months, he failed to thrive with a weight of 7.0 kg (<2 SD), could not raise his head or sit up unaided, and gingival hypertrophy was observed. His intelligence was similar to that of healthy children. At 2 years, he experienced recurrent acute bronchitis or pneumonia 3-5 times every year and persistent diarrhoea. At 3 years, he suffered from diarrhoea with severe dehydration, seizure, and a coma, but recovered after treatment with intravenous gamma globulin. At 4 years, his gingival hyperplasia led to facial deformity. He had pearly papules around his neck, cutaneous nodules at his chest, back and right ear, hyperpigmentation at his abdomen and back with recurrent skin infections, and perianal plaques. His joint contractures had not progressed after 1 year of age. His weight was 7.2 kg (<4 SD).",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient presented with hypoactivity, hypotonia, and sensitivity to passive movement. He had frontal bossing, a short nose, a depressed nasal bridge, and a papular skin rash on his hands. Flexion contractures were observed in the elbow, hip, knee, and ankle with swollen joints. Hyperpigmentation over the bony prominences, gingival hypertrophy, pearly papules around the neck, cutaneous nodules at the chest, back and right ear, hyperpigmentation at the abdomen and back, and perianal plaques were noted during follow-up examinations.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother was threatened with preterm labour at 3 months of gestation and was treated with medication. Decreased foetal movement was observed during pregnancy. Foetal hydronephrosis was diagnosed by prenatal ultrasound screening. The patient had no family history of ISH. His healthy older brother was 5 years old, and his mother had experienced two induced abortions.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient had an increased serum alanine aminotransferase level (61 U/L, normal range: 0-40 U/L) and mild hyperkalaemia (5.57 mmol/L, normal range: 3.5-5.5 mmol/L). Tests for anti-dsDNA antibodies (dsDNA) were positive. The creatine kinase, serum creatinine, blood glucose, thyroid function, blood gas, coagulation function, syphilis antibody, and blood tandem mass spectrometry data were normal. The patient's IgG level was 3.0 g/L (normal range: 3.7-8.3 g/L), CD3+% was 57% (normal range: 64%-73%), CD8+% was 23% (normal range: 24%-34%), and CD19+% was 22% (normal range: 14%-21%). Ultrasound detected hydronephrosis on the left side, separation of the renal pelvis, splenomegaly, and patent ductus arteriosus.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Electromyography and magnetic resonance imaging of the head and lumbosacral vertebrae produced normal results. SMA gene was excluded. Radiography revealed bilateral periosteal hyperplasia in the humerus, ulna, femur, and tibia; a thickened cortex in the left clavicle; and a bony process at the upper end of the left radius. Trio-exome sequencing (ES) was performed, revealing a NM:058172.5:c.1294C > T p.(R432X) nonsense mutation in exon 15 of the ANTXR2 gene from the mother and a 4.41-kb deletion in 4q21.21 from the father. Sanger sequencing confirmed the missense mutation, and quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR) identified the gross deletion. The patient was diagnosed with a compound heterozygous mutation in ANTXR2, confirming the diagnosis of ISH."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 49-year-old Caucasian male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the outpatient clinic due to deterioration of vision in both eyes (OU) over the last few months. He had been reporting problems with clarity of vision for 5 years, but in recent months he noticed a significant decrease in visual acuity. The best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was 0.4 in the right eye (RE) and 1.0 in the left eye (LE), whereas Snellen test was 3.0 and 1.5, respectively. The Ishihara test was within normal limits in OU. The patient did not complain about night blindness.",

  "Physical Examination": "The anterior segment examination did not disclose any significant abnormality. Fundus examination revealed an atrophic area around the optic discs, macular degenerations, and retinal thinning in OU. Enhanced depth imaging optical coherence tomography (EDI-OCT) pictures revealed foveal thinning with distortion and loss of the outer nuclear layer (ONL), external limiting membrane (ELM), ellipsoid zone (EZ), and retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) bilaterally. The central foveal thickness was 175 µm for the RE and 170 µm for the LE, whereas the choroid thickness (CT) was 275 µm and 276 µm, respectively. Static perimetry demonstrated a deepening central scotoma with saving peripheral vision in OU.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no previous history of eye disease, trauma, or family history of inherited diseases.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Fundus autofluorescence (FAF) showed a centrally located area with irregular borders showing hypoautofluorescence because of RPE atrophy with a surrounding rim of hyperautofluorescence consistent with RPE damage. There was an area of hypoautofluorescence around the optic discs at the site of atrophy as well. Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) revealed granular hyperfluorescence in the macula and concomitant areas of fenestrated loss with visible choriocapillaris. The contrast flow through the main vessels did not show any obvious abnormalities. Flash full-field electroretinography (ffERG) were performed using the RETeval portable unit (LKC, USA) and sensor strip electrodes. There was lowering of a and b waves in light-adapted (LA) 3 ERG and LA 30 Hz ERG as well as prolonged peak times of a and b waves under photopic adaptation conditions (significantly worse in the RE). However, dark-adapted (DA) 0.01 ERG and DA3 were normal."
}"

There was an area of hypoautofluorescence around the optic discs at the site of atrophy as well. Fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA) revealed granular hyperfluorescence in the macula and concomitant areas of fenestrated loss with visible choriocapillaris. However, dark-adapted (DA) 0.01 ERG and DA3 were normal.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "The patient underwent next-generation sequencing (NGS) of a panel of 317 macular, cone/cone–rod dystrophy, retinitis pigmentosa and other IRD-related genes. Enrichment was conducted using the Roche/NibleGen (Madison, WI, USA) sequence capture technology, and NGS was carried out on an Illumina HiSeq 1500 system (San Diego, CA, USA). Verification of identified variant and segregation analyses were carried out by PCR amplification of the corresponding exon, followed by Sanger sequencing. Genetic testing showed a homozygous mutation in CDHR1 (NM_033100.4:c.783G>A(;)(783G>A). This splice region variant is classified in the Human Gene Mutation Database as pathogenic."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 56-year-old female with cutaneous albinism. She has golden hair and a light skin complexion.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient had complaints of photophobia and decreased vision since birth. Her best-corrected visual acuity was 20/120 in both eyes (OU). Ocular examination revealed alternating exo tropia with horizontal nystagmus. Vortex veins drain the choroidal vasculature. Their ampullae can be identified ophthalmoscopically with their location often serving as a landmark for the equator. Rarely, they can be anomalous and located at the posterior pole. In the literature, there are a few cases of macular vortex vein reported in individuals with high myopia.",

  "Physical Examination": "Anterior-segment examination showed iris transillumination defects. On fundus examination in both eyes, choroidal vessels and posterior staphyloma were easily visualized. In addition, macular vortex veins were noted in the macula of each eye.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had photophobia and decreased vision since birth.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were reported."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 9-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented with fever, chills, myalgias, right eye conjunctivitis, cracked edematous lips, abdominal pain, macular rash on back and knees, and lower extremity edema. He was diagnosed with MIS-C secondary to SARS-CoV-2. During hospitalization, his condition worsened, developing anasarca, pulmonary edema, bilateral pleural effusion, respiratory distress, acute kidney injury, and mild ectasia of 2 coronary arteries. He required admission to the pediatric intensive care unit for high flow nasal canula oxygen. He was admitted for a total of 11 days and recovered well with resolution of his anasarca, pulmonary edema, acute kidney injury, and ectasia of his coronary arteries. One month after discharge, he developed left eye redness and photophobia after self-discontinuing prednisone. A few days later, he complained of photophobia in the right eye. Three weeks later, at the Proctor Foundation, he was diagnosed with bilateral anterior uveitis. Throughout his treatment course, he developed mild ocular hypertension in both eyes. At 9 months after initial presentation, he had experienced multiple recurrences (3 total) of inflammation in both eyes with complications including ocular hypertension and posterior subcapsular cataracts.",

  "Physical Examination": "Initial ophthalmology exam showed vision 20/20 in the right eye and 20/50 in the left eye with normal intraocular pressures in both eyes. The right eye had a normal anterior segment, while the left eye showed 2+ conjunctival injection with 2+ anterior chamber cell and posterior synechiae. A few days later, the right eye showed 1+ conjunctival injection, 2+ anterior chamber cell and flare, and posterior synechiae. At the Proctor Foundation, visual acuity was 20/20 and 20/25 in the right and left eye respectively, with normal intraocular pressure in both eyes. Anterior segment exam showed white conjunctiva and 3+ anterior chamber cell, and 1+ cell in the anterior vitreous in both eyes. At 9 months follow-up, vision was 20/20 in the right eye and 20/25 in the left eye with normal intraocular pressure. Right eye exam showed 2+ anterior chamber cell, with broken posterior synechiae, a small posterior subcapsular cataract, and rare anterior vitreous cell. The left eye exam revealed 1+ anterior chamber cell exam broken posterior synechiae, a small posterior subcapsular cataract and rare anterior vitreous cell. Posterior segment exam was normal.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of obesity, asthma, and coronavirus (COVID-19) infection one-month prior requiring hospitalization. Antibody testing to the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 was detected with no prior history of vaccination.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory evaluation revealed anemia (Hemoglobin 8.0 gm/dl, Hematocrit 25%), thrombocytopenia (103 Thousand/µL), and elevated c-reactive protein (185.4 mg/L), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (20 mm/hr), fibrin d-dimer (1.44), functional fibrinogen (412 mg/dl), activated partial thromboplastin time (56.7 s), and prothrombin time (17.2 s). Initial imaging studies included a normal chest x-ray and a normal echocardiogram. CT of the abdomen displayed right lower quadrant lymphadenopathy. Repeat echocardiogram showed mild ectasia of 2 coronary arteries."
}"

Repeat FA at 9 months showed resolution of disc and vascular leakage."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 74-year-old man with a height of 160 cm and a body weight of 51.5 kg. He is from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with swelling and pain in the right leg. He had been diagnosed with Klippel-Trenaunay-Weber Syndrome (KTWS) with arteriovenous fistula in the right leg 10 years prior. In the past year, the patient's abdominal aorta had enlarged to a size indicated for surgery. The patient complained of continuous pain in the abdominal region. Endovascular aortic repair was considered but deemed inappropriate due to poor vascular characteristics. A decision was made to re-open the abdomen for vascular replacement of the abdominal aorta.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed swelling of the right leg and significant development and tortuosity of superficial vessels in the right neck and right forehead. Vessels in the upper limbs, left lower limb, left neck, and left forehead were somewhat tortuous but otherwise generally normal.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had undergone an open total gastrectomy for gastric cancer three years previously. He had a history of abdominal surgery.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Preoperative laboratory test results showed low levels of haemoglobin (9.7 g/dL) and cholinesterase (109 units/L). No coagulation abnormalities were detected. A preoperative electrocardiogram showed atrial fibrillation. Transthoracic echocardiography showed enlargement of the right atrium and ventricle with moderate tricuspid regurgitation and mild mitral regurgitation due to an arteriovenous fistula in the right leg. The left ventricular ejection fraction was 57%. The patient's ejection fraction had decreased."
}"

Vessels in the upper limbs, left lower limb, left neck, and left forehead were somewhat tortuous but otherwise generally normal.",

A remarkably observed arteriovenous fistula had developed between the aneurysm and peripheral artery, which had dilated towards the popliteal artery. The distal popliteal artery was occluded. No obvious cerebrovascular malformations were noted on preoperative examination."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 76-year-old woman from the geographic area served by Shimane University Hospital.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient fell onto concrete and suffered a stroke that affected the left side of her face. On the same day, she was referred to her local ophthalmologist and presented to the ophthalmology department of a university hospital immediately due to a suspected left global rupture. At the initial visit, the best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA) measured by decimal visual acuity chart was 1.2 in her right eye (OD) and hand motions in her left eye (OS). The intraocular pressures (IOPs) were 13 mmHg OD and 38 mmHg OS. The presence of a relative afferent pupillary reflex was unknown due to dense hyphema OS. The patient underwent an exploratory surgery on the same day. Postoperatively, topical antibiotics (1.5% levofloxacin) 4 times daily were prescribed for 1 month and stopped; topical steroids (0.1% betamethasone) 4 times daily were prescribed for 2 months, followed by twice daily for another 2 months, and then stopped. At the final visit 4 months postoperatively, the BCVA was 1.2 bilaterally and the right and left IOPs were 16 and 13 mmHg, respectively. No evidence of sympathetic ophthalmia was observed during the follow-up period.",

  "Physical Examination": "Slit-lamp examination showed a blood clot in the well-formed anterior chamber; the iris and IOL were not observable. Brown-colored tissue was seen beneath the conjunctiva. Intraoperatively, a circumferential peritomy showed no evidence of scleral laceration other than the previous sclerocorneal tunnel. After hyphema removal by bimanual irrigation and aspiration, total aniridia was seen. Iris tissue beneath the conjunctiva was removed by excising Tenon's capsule. A postoperative slit-lamp examination showed complete iris loss and an intact intracapsular-fixed lens position.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of uncomplicated bilateral phacoemulsification cataract surgeries and intraocular lens (IOL) implantations more than 10 years previously, but the surgical details were unavailable.",

  "Initial Test Results": "B-mode echography showed neither dense vitreous hemorrhage nor retinal detachment."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 7-year-old female, born at 38 weeks' gestation with a birth weight of 3,010 g by elective cesarean section. Her head circumference increased from 25th centile at birth to around 50th centile at 7 years old.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "An antenatal ultrasound scan at 20 weeks' gestation detected an occipital meningocele sized 14 mm × 11 mm × 11 mm, which later showed interval increase in size. Fetal MRI at 36 weeks' gestation confirmed an occipital meningocele measuring 11 mm × 27 mm × 16 mm. Ventriculomegaly was noted throughout the pregnancy. Postnatally, the patient was stable at birth and did not require mechanical ventilation. At 1 year of age, she had another cystic lesion at the retrocerebellar region as shown on a follow-up MRI scan without other clinical signs. She has no further intracranial cystic lesions developed and no hydrocephalus with generally normal development. The patient has bilateral severe myopia since infancy requiring corrective glasses. Currently, the severity of myopia is around −14.00D bilaterally. Retina on both eyes are thinning with indirect barrier laser treatment performed while no retinal detachment was noted so far. She can read at close proximity and write down her name in Chinese and English properly. The patient's parents reported her daily function was adjusted despite severe myopia. Her development and cognitive assessment were normal at 7 years old.",

  "Physical Examination": "Apgar score was 9 at 1 min and 10 at 5 min of life. After the initial meningocele surgery, she had no sign of raised intracranial pressure.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient underwent excision of the occipital meningocele on day 6 of life. There was a small bony defect (<5 mm) with narrow pedicle connecting the lesion. The content of the meningocele was gel-like and no normal brain tissue. At 16 months of age, she underwent posterior fossa craniotomy for cyst fenestration without any complications.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Antenatal karyotyping and array comparative genomic hybridization (aCGH) of amniotic cells were normal."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a female born in October 1964, weighing 3230 g at birth. She is the only child of non-consanguineous parents. Her final height was 151 cm, which is at the lower limit of normal, on the 3rd centile.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was noted to have multiple congenital abnormalities at birth. At the age of three years, she was diagnosed with Oral-Facial-Digital Syndrome Type I (OFD I). She had a cleft soft palate requiring plastic surgery and a partial cleft of the hard palate. There was a hypertrophic irregular lingual frenum and thick fibrous bands between the buccal mucosa and alveolar ridges. The tongue was partially cleft into lobes with a typical nodule on the left margin. She had clinodactyly affecting the fingers and toes, and syndactyly of the fingers of both hands requiring surgical correction. Patchy alopecia of the scalp and dry hair were also present. She had the typical facies with short upper lip and broad nasal root. She grew along the 25th centile for height until she was 12 years of age, but thereafter the height velocity diminished, possibly due to the development of renal failure. Significant mental retardation was a major feature with an IQ of around 70. She had marked dysarthria and a clumsy gait from early childhood. By the age of 17 years, she had established chronic renal failure and bilaterally palpable renal masses. Ultrasound and intravenous urography showed polycystic kidneys. No cysts were seen in the liver or pancreas. She initially received conservative treatment, but after four months, she required dialysis. She was established on continuous ambulatory peritoneal dialysis and later transferred to maintenance haemodialysis. She is awaiting renal transplantation.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had a cleft soft palate and a partial cleft of the hard palate. There was a hypertrophic irregular lingual frenum and thick fibrous bands between the buccal mucosa and alveolar ridges. The tongue was partially cleft into lobes with a typical nodule on the left margin. She had clinodactyly affecting the fingers and toes, and syndactyly of the fingers of both hands. Patchy alopecia of the scalp and dry hair were present. She had the typical facies with short upper lip and broad nasal root. She had bilaterally palpable renal masses.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother also suffers from OFD I of lesser severity. The mother had operative correction of oral malformations and syndactyly affecting the fingers of her right hand. She has clinodactyly and tongue malformations similar to the daughter. Ultrasound examination revealed polycystic kidneys in the mother, but her renal function is normal at 44 years of age. The mother is of normal intelligence with no neurological dysfunction. There is no known history of congenital malformation or renal disease in the mother's three brothers and three sisters, in the maternal grandmother, or in the maternal great grandmother. The patient's mother had no spontaneous abortions.",

  "Initial Test Results": "At six years of age, an electroencephalogram showed non-specific diffuse abnormalities. At the time dialysis was required, the patient's serum urea was 45 mmol/l, creatinine 1130 μmol/l, bicarbonate 9 mmol/l, and haemoglobin 6 g/dl. The mother's serum creatinine was 88 μmol/l and urea was 5.8 mmol/l at 44 years of age. Chromosomal studies of both the patient and her mother showed normal female 46,XX karyotypes on analysis of banding patterns after trypsin-Giemsa staining. Both had a large heterochromatic band on chromosome 1 visible on C banding, which is usually considered to be a normal population variant."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A man in his 70s.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with dizziness for the last 1.5 years. Initially, the dizziness was rotatory, episodic, moderate to severe in intensity, and aggravated by postural changes. Over the following weeks, it developed into a near-continuous symptom, with episodic postural and positional aggravation, relieved by lying down. This was associated with swaying, 'turning of his vision,' and blurring upon walking or moving his head, presumably oscillopsia. There were no associated aural, cardiac, or other neurological symptoms initially. After an evaluation by an otolaryngologist and a course of labyrinthine sedatives, the patient experienced slight transient relief in symptoms. However, his unsteadiness progressed to the point where he could not stand or walk. Three months prior to this presentation, the patient developed additional slowness of activity, taking a long time to bathe, eat, and walk to and from the bathroom. There was no history of stiffness, tremors, freezing, frequent falls, sleep disturbance, hallucination, urinary symptoms, or erectile dysfunction.",
  "Physical Examination": "The patient presented as well-groomed with a cheerful personality and a Montreal Cognitive Assessment score of 27. Ocular examination showed square wave jerks during fixation, restricted up-gaze with im-persistent gaze-evoked horizontal nystagmus bilaterally, broken pursuit, slow dysmetric horizontal saccades, and abnormal optokinetic nystagmus bilaterally. Extrapyramidal examination revealed mild asymmetrical cog-wheeling and rigidity of both upper limbs (right more than left) and bradykinesia (right more than left). Cerebellar examination showed dysmetria and dysdiadochokinesia (right more than left), with impaired tandem walk and swaying towards the right side. The patient exhibited a broad-based cautious gait. Vestibular examination disclosed abnormal dynamic visual acuity and head impulse tests on both sides. Other cranial, sensory, and motor examinations were normal for his age with no postural drop in both systolic and diastolic blood pressures.",
  "Past Medical History": "There is no documented past medical history or family history provided in the case.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Initial investigations included MRI of the brain showing age-related cerebral atrophy. Blood routines including haemogram, renal and liver profiles, electrolytes, vitamin B12 levels, glycaemic status, and thyroid levels were normal. Neck vessel imaging, echocardiogram, and 24-hour Holter monitoring were normal. Cervical and ocular vestibular evoked myogenic potential (VEMP) test showed right more than left dysfunction with bilateral prolonged P13 latency. Brainstem evoked response auditory was normal. Pure-tone audiogram indicated bilateral moderate to severe sensorineural hearing loss."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "To investigate the subacute progressive nature of symptoms, a lumbar puncture was performed revealing protein level of 80.8 (N<45g/dL), no cells, and glucose level of 93. Cerebrospinal fluid infective and immune workup including cytology and antineuronal antibody panels were negative. Viral markers were non-reactive. A repeat gadolinium-enhanced MRI of the brain remained normal. Whole-body positron emission tomography-CT revealed only age-related cortical atrophy. The patient was treated with intravenous immunoglobulin 2g/kg body weight divided over five days due to albumin cytological dissociation. Despite treatment, symptoms persisted and insidiously progressed. BVP was confirmed with reduced caloric response bilaterally (sum of bithermal max. peak slow phase velocity at 2.65°/s)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 30-year-old female from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the neurology department with a recurrence of symmetrical weakness proximally in the lower extremities. Seven years ago, at the age of 23, she experienced a sudden onset of persistent weakness in the bilateral proximal lower extremities. At that time, she was able to stand with assistance and walk on her own. She visited a local medical clinic and was diagnosed with Guillain-Barre syndrome, largely recovering after high-dose glucocorticoid therapy. The current admission was due to a recurrence of neurological symptoms in the past 1 month.",

  "Physical Examination": "Neurological examination revealed muscle weakness and hypotonia of extremities, muscle weakness of neck flexion (Medical Research Council (MRC) grade 4), elbow flexion (MRC grade 3), and knee extension (MRC grade 4). No tendon reflexes of the biceps brachii and triceps were found. No significant abnormalities were observed in cranial nerve examination, sensory system, autonomic nervous system, and meningeal irritation sign.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a previous episode of bilateral proximal lower extremity weakness at age 23, which was diagnosed as Guillain-Barre syndrome and treated with high-dose glucocorticoid therapy.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory analysis showed elevated creatinine kinase (CK) at 246 U/L (previously 236 U/L) and alpha-hydroxybutyrate dehydrogenase (alpha-HBDH) at 232 U/L. Other routine serologic investigations, cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis, and autoimmune antibody titers, including peripheral neuropathy antibody spectrum in both serum and cerebrospinal fluid, were within normal limits. Electrocardiography revealed sinus tachycardia and left ventricular high voltage. Electromyography (EMG) and evoked potential (EP) suggested peripheral neurogenic damage of upper and lower extremities with myogenic damage. Blood lactic acid was slightly increased at 8.7 mmol/L in resting state."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Myositis autoantibody analysis was completed with no myositis autoantibody found. Muscle magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed no remarkable characteristics of muscle lesions and no obvious specific change in muscle group, but there was edema in short-tau inversion recovery (STIR) sequences. A muscle biopsy was performed, and the results suggested pathological changes in mitochondrial inherited disorders (MIDs) and neuronal damage. Mitochondrial DNA analysis on the involved muscles revealed a heteroplasmic m3271 T>C mutation in the mitochondrial tRNA-Leu gene (UUR), with the proportion of mutant mtDNA reaching 87.4%."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 13-year-old boy. His body mass index is 14.17 (138 cm tall and 27 kg weight), which is significantly lower than that of healthy children his age.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with progressive vision loss and difficulty opening his eyes. He complained of dizziness and fatigue, and had missed school for a long time. From birth, his height and weight had been lower than his peers. He had been diagnosed with growth retardation and received growth hormone therapy. Best-corrected visual acuity was LogMAR 0.3 in both eyes. Approximately 5° exotropia was found based on the Hirschberg test, and movements of both eyes were restricted in all gaze directions. Bilateral ptosis was slight, with the upper eyelid always covering the upper third of the pupil when looking ahead. The parents denied a history of preterm birth. Family history was negative for individuals with similar symptoms or early-onset vision loss.",

  "Physical Examination": "Intraocular pressure was approximately 18 mmHg in the right eye and 17 mmHg in the left eye. Color fundus photography showed hyperpigmentation of both eyes. Binocular perimetric examination revealed a superior temporal visual field defect and centripetal reduction in both eyes. Macular spectral-domain optical coherence tomography revealed an interruption in the ellipsoid band, and several hyperreflective deposits above the retinal pigment epithelium were remarkable. The average subfoveal choroidal thickness in both eyes was 223 μm (left eye) and 224 μm (right eye). Optical coherence tomography angiography showed that the deep retinal capillary density decreased and the choroid microvessels atrophied greatly, but foveal area zone and superficial retinal capillary changed insignificantly.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had been diagnosed with growth retardation and received growth hormone therapy.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Cycloplegic refraction revealed + 0.50 + − 1.50 × 180 in the right eye and + 1.00 × 95 in the left eye. Echocardiography findings were unremarkable. 24-h ambulatory electrocardiogram revealed intermittent first-degree atrioventricular block and partial second-degree type I atrioventricular block."
}"

The long-range PCR of the blood samples revealed a deletion of 7652 bp in the mitochondrial DNA, starting at nucleotide position 6341 and ending at 13993. No abnormality was noted in the mother's genes."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 29-year-old Japanese woman.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient slowly developed foot edema, proteinuria (2.9 g/gCr) and hematuria (20-29/high-power field) at 28 years old. Her Crohn's disease was in remission at this time, without skin symptoms such as erythema nodosum or joint symptoms. No antibodies or symptoms of SLE, such as butterfly rash, were detected, and the patient had no history of infection. After diagnosis, the patient was started on oral steroids (prednisolone, 30 mg/day), after which her proteinuria improved to 0.6 g/gCr.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient presented with foot edema.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was diagnosed with Crohn's disease at 19 years old. She had been treated with mesalazine and salazosulfapyridine for Crohn's disease. Since the age of 21, she had been treated with adalimumab (40 mg subcutaneously every 2 weeks). The patient had no personal or family history of renal disease.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial tests revealed proteinuria (2.9 g/gCr) and hematuria (20-29/high-power field). C3 and C4 complement levels were not low. Serum creatinine was 0.8 mg/dL."
}"

Since the age of 21, she had been treated with adalimumab (40 mg subcutaneously every 2 weeks). The patient had no personal or family history of renal disease.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial tests revealed proteinuria (2.9 g/gCr) and hematuria (20-29/high-power field). C3 and C4 complement levels were not low. Serum creatinine was 0.8 mg/dL.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A kidney biopsy was performed. Light microscopy revealed 19 glomeruli, of which 5 exhibited global glomerulosclerosis, and 1 was a crescentic glomerulus. Approximately two-thirds of the glomeruli had mesangial proliferation and subendothelial deposits. In the interstitium, lymphocytic aggregation was found around the sclerotic glomeruli, and fibrosis was observed in approximately 40% of the interstitium. Immunofluorescence microscopy showed diffuse, global and granular staining of the glomerular tuft mesangial region with IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q and C3. Electron microscopy revealed electron-deposits in the mesangial region."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 3-year-old girl. The geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was initially diagnosed with a cystic tumor on the left kidney by abdominal ultrasound in another hospital 2 weeks prior, after experiencing occasional abdominal pain. When she presented to the current clinic, she had no abdominal pain. A reexamined ultrasound showed a cystic tumor inside the left kidney, with a size of 4.6 × 3.9 cm, with a clear boundary, thin wall, and uniform internal sound transmission. The patient was initially diagnosed with a simple left renal cyst and underwent a laparoscopic decortication of the renal cyst. During the operation, a unicystic tumor in the middle and upper pole of the left kidney was revealed. The inner wall of the cyst was smooth, the cystic fluid was clear, and there was no obvious connection between the cyst and the renal pelvis. The cyst wall with an area of 3 × 3 cm was resected. After the initial diagnosis of CPDN (Cystic Partially Differentiated Nephroblastoma), a second operation was performed, involving a radical nephrectomy on the left kidney. The operated area was rinsed with distilled water. No abnormal lymph nodes were found.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were reported.",

  "Past Medical History": "No past medical history was reported.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Abdominal ultrasound showed a cystic tumor inside the left kidney, with a size of 4.6 × 3.9 cm, with a clear boundary, thin wall, and uniform internal sound transmission. An abdominal enhanced CT showed a cystic low-density lesion inside the left kidney with a clear boundary, about 4.0 × 3.8 × 3.5 cm in size, and without contrast filling. The adjacent renal pelvis was dilated with a diameter of about 1.9 cm, and there was contrast filling in the renal pelvis. Kidney function tests showed a creatinine level of 33 µmol/L and a urea nitrogen level of 4.6 mmol/L. Tumor marker tests showed carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) <0.30 ng/ml, alpha fetoprotein (AFP) 2.15 IU/ml, carbohydrate antigen 125 (CA-125) 17.0 U/ml, carbohydrate antigen 19-9 (CA19-9) 9.42 U/ml, β-human chorionic gonadotropin (βHCG) < 0.20 mIU/ml, neuron-specific enolase (NSE) 11.6 ng/ml, and cytokeratin 19 fragment (CK-19) 1.8 ng/ml. The patient's routine blood test and urinalysis were normal."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 35-year-old G2P0 woman at the gestational age of 11 + 6 weeks. She is in her second pregnancy after an ectopic pregnancy in 2019. The couple is not consanguineous.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the prenatal diagnosis center due to an enlarged fetal bladder. At 11+6 weeks, ultrasound showed a normal nuchal translucency (NT = 1.3 mm) and an enlarged bladder with a diameter of 12 mm. After 1 week, a repeated ultrasound showed a slightly reduced bladder with a diameter of 10 mm. At 15 weeks of gestation, non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) was conducted, and the result was negative. At 17 weeks, the woman accepted amniocentesis and chromosome microarray analysis (CMA) as the first-line genetic testing. At 22 weeks, the routine fetal anomaly scan showed multiple structural abnormalities including the right multicystic kidney, left hydronephrosis, and cleft lip and palate. The parents opted to terminate the pregnancy via induction. Amniocentesis was performed to obtain the amniotic fluid prior to the intra-amniotic injection of rivanol solution after signing the informed consent, and they accepted the trio whole-exome sequencing (trio-WES) to identify the underlying etiology.",

  "Physical Examination": "External examination showed no ectrodactyly or lobster-claw deformity.   "Basic Information": "The patient is a 35-year-old G2P0 woman at the gestational age of 11 + 6 weeks. She is in her second pregnancy after an ectopic pregnancy in 2019. The couple is not consanguineous.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the prenatal diagnosis center due to an enlarged fetal bladder. After 1 week, a repeated ultrasound showed a slightly reduced bladder with a diameter of 10 mm. At 15 weeks of gestation, non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) was conducted, and the result was negative. At 17 weeks, the woman accepted amniocentesis and chromosome microarray analysis (CMA) as the first-line genetic testing.   "Physical Examination": "External examination showed no ectrodactyly or lobster-claw deformity. The autopsy confirmed bilateral cleft lip and palate (bilateral cleft lip, alveolar cleft, and complete cleft palate), right renal dysplasia, and hydronephrosis of the left kidney.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had an ectopic pregnancy in 2019. The family history was unremarkable for any other known congenital anomalies or otherwise.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Ultrasound at 11+6 weeks showed a normal nuchal translucency (NT = 1.3 mm) and an enlarged bladder with a diameter of 12 mm. A repeated ultrasound after 1 week showed a slightly reduced bladder with a diameter of 10 mm. Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) at 15 weeks of gestation was negative. At 17 weeks, chromosome microarray analysis (CMA) and karyotyping results were both normal. The routine fetal anomaly scan at 22 weeks showed multiple structural abnormalities including the right multicystic kidney, left hydronephrosis, and cleft lip and palate.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Trio whole-exome sequencing (WES) was performed, and a de novo missense mutation (c.1027C > T R304W) was detected in exon 8 of the TP63 gene. Sanger sequencing confirmed this conclusion. No mutation at this site was found in the parents."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 79-year-old South Asian male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with chief complaints of bilateral headaches, facial pain, bilateral neck and upper limb pain, complete loss of vision in the right eye, and acute partial loss of vision in the left eye. The headache was of sudden onset in the temporal region, while the left-sided peri-auricular pain and the neck pain radiating to the arms were of slow onset. The bilateral headache was in the temporal region; the facial pain sites were peri-auricular and temporomandibular joint (TMJ) areas bilaterally (right > left). The arm pains were along the entire length of both arms. The bilateral neck pain radiated to the arms ipsilaterally. The temporal pain and vision loss were acute, while the neck pain and the pain radiating to the arms were chronic. The temporal pain was continuous with an intensity of 5 to 6 on a visual analog scale (VAS) of 0 to 10, and had a throbbing quality. The TMJ and ear pain were intermittent (provoked) with an intensity of 4 to 5, while the neck pain radiating to arms occurred intermittently, multiple times a day, with an intensity of 3 to 4. Both had a 'dull-aching' quality. The temporal pain was chronic progressive; the TMJ, ear, and neck pain were non-progressive; the visual symptoms were rapidly progressing. The temporal, TMJ, and ear pain were aggravated by chewing, and the neck and arm pain by neck movements. The temporal pain was unrelenting, while the TMJ, ear, neck, and arm pain were relieved by rest. None of the chief complaints was responsive to any of the past attempted therapies. The patient complained of claudication upon chewing, paresthesia in the neck and arm with neck movements, complete/partial loss of vision, and scalp tenderness. The jaw pain radiated to the neck, arms, and the side of the head ipsilaterally. The neck pain radiated to ipsilateral arm. The patient reported poor quality of sleep.",

  "Physical Examination": "All mandibular movements were within normal limits, but with pain. Cervical range of motion was restricted by approximately 30–40% with moderate pain. Palpation of the temporalis and masseter muscles elicited intense pain, reproducing the patient's familiar pain and chief complaints of facial/jaw pain bilaterally, by approximately 70%. Temporal artery appeared tortuous on the right, and its pulse was nonpalpable on the right, and feeble on the left. Palpation of the bilateral sternocleidomastoid muscles reproduced the patient's familiar pain and chief complaints by approximately 50–60%. Fibromyalgia screening was positive. TMJ palpation elicited mild pain of 3 on VAS bilaterally.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient is a known diabetic, hypertensive, and hyperlipidemic, all being managed adequately by medications. The patient takes olmesartan 40 mg OD, sitagliptin 50 mg BD, and rosuvastatin 5 mg OD.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory investigations revealed: HbA1c = 7.4 (normal value: 4.0–5.6), Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) = 94 mm/h (normal value: 0–15), C-reactive protein (CRP) = 131.8 mg/L (normal value: 0.0–10.0). Total leukocyte count (TLC) and polymorphonuclear leukocyte count were markedly high with reduction in lymphocyte count."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 34-year-old woman was referred to genetic counselling at the beginning of the second trimester of her second pregnancy, conceived by IVF because of idiopathic infertility. She resides in an unspecified geographic location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "Upon prenatal screening in the first trimester of the current pregnancy, the shortening of long bones was observed. The shortening of the long bones, narrowing of the chest with short ribs, bowing of the femur, excess soft tissues on the thighs and lower legs, suspicion of retrognathia, and ulnar deviation of the wrist were noted on an ultrasound at 14 weeks of gestation plus 6 days. Skeletal dysplasia with poor prognosis was suspected, with a probable diagnosis of type 1 thanatophoric dysplasia. Amniocentesis and FGFR3 gene sequencing or next-generation sequencing using a panel for skeletal dysplasias were proposed. After obtaining the patient’s informed consent, the amniocentesis under ultrasound guidance was performed at 15 weeks of gestation. At the 17th week of gestation, another ultrasound scan was performed to visualize the abnormal sulcation of the temporal lobes and further detail the phenotype. The observed sulcation pattern was normal. The ultrasound findings from the previous scan were generally confirmed; additional findings included bilateral brachydactyly of the hands, mild polyhydramnios, moderate pericardial effusion, a small hydrothorax, and mild retrognathia without signs of the Pierre–Robin sequence. The shortening of the ribs was severe with high probability of pulmonary hypoplasia. Other noted features included a protuberant abdomen and a relative excess of soft tissues of the lower and upper extremities attributable to the limb shortening. The shortening of the long bones was assessed as severe (e.g., measured femur length vs. expected: 14.2 mm vs. 25 mm, respectively—three standard deviations below the median; fibula length: 9.2 mm—more than three standard deviations below the median). No other abnormalities were noticed.",
  "Physical Examination": "",
  "Past Medical History": "The first pregnancy ended with spontaneous abortion at 8 weeks. The family history was negative.",
  "Initial Test Results": ""
}"

Cases.Final Name: Pneumonia caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa infection
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 53-year-old man from Italy.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "On 12 March 2022, the patient presented to the Emergency Department with right subscapular pain lasting for six hours, not relieved by paracetamol and ketoprofen. This was followed by dyspnea, fever, cough, and hemoptysis. The patient had experienced a paucisymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection approximately two months prior. Upon arrival, vital signs showed a temperature of 36 °C, blood pressure of 120/60 mmHg, heart rate of 120 bpm, oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 90% at room air, and a slightly increased respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Oxygen therapy via a Venturi mask FiO2 35% was implemented, achieving SpO2 95%. Six hours after admission, the patient experienced acute neurological deterioration with a stuporous state and mottled skin. He was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit where endotracheal intubation was complicated by cardiac arrest. Cardiopulmonary resuscitation was performed, followed by pneumothorax, requiring chest drain placement. The clinical picture evolved into irreversible metabolic acidosis and multi-organ failure. The patient died 36 hours after admission.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient presented with right subscapular pain, dyspnea, fever, cough, and hemoptysis. Six hours after admission, he developed a stuporous state and mottled skin. Autopsy findings revealed a cavitated lesion (2.5 cm) at the right upper lung lobe, surrounded by parenchyma of increased consistency and covered by fibrinous induration, with pleural involvement. The left lung parenchyma showed increased consistency at the lower lobe and was covered by fibrinous induration at the upper lobe. There was also bilateral diffuse alveolar hemorrhage and pulmonary edema.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's past medical history was unremarkable, except for a paucisymptomatic SARS-CoV-2 infection experienced approximately two months prior to admission. The patient had a reported penicillin allergy.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Electrocardiogram documented a sinus rhythm. Blood exams showed hyponatremia (132 mEq/L), slightly high levels of C-reactive protein (2 mg/dL), elevated D-dimer (3608 ng/mL), significant elevation of procalcitonin level (51 microg/L), and normal lactates value (1.2 mmol/L). Arterial blood gas analysis documented hypoxia (pO2 52 mmHg, SpO2 90%). Chest X-ray displayed a right upper lobe opacification. Six hours after admission, arterial blood gas analysis showed respiratory and lactic acidosis (pH 7.1 mmHg, PaO2 45 mmHg, PaCO2 42 mmHg, HCO2- 16.5 mmol/L, BE −15.8 mmol/L, SpO2 73.3% in oxygen therapy FiO2 100%, lactates 9.7 mmol/L). A repeat chest X-ray 24 hours after admission revealed complete right upper lobe, right lower and left mid-basal opacification, with diffuse thickening of the bilateral lower-middle lung."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "CT angiography confirmed the right upper lobe opacification with a suspected air bubble inside, excluding pulmonary embolism or aortic dissection. Bronchoalveolar lavage was performed. Microbiological investigations revealed that blood and bronchoalveolar lavage cultures were positive for Pseudomonas aeruginosa (PA) with a good sensitivity profile. The whole genome of the isolated PA strain was sequenced, revealing it belonged to ST1184, a rare ST. The strain carried the exoenzyme gene exoS, while exoU was absent. The wild type form of the ladS gene was confirmed. Exolysin genes exlA and exlB were absent. Analysis of the plasmid content showed absence of plasmids."

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is an 82-year-old female from a region with a university hospital.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the emergency department with complaints of shortness of breath and back pain. The patient had a history of trauma 20 days prior to the presentation. The patient was referred to the radiology department for initial imaging as part of the trauma protocol. A posteroanterior chest X-ray was performed, which showed a round lesion with sclerotic and regular margins in the lower zone of the left lung, adjacent to the lower pole of the scapula. This finding necessitated further investigation with a chest CT.",

Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 36-year-old man.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a right neck level-V mass measuring 1 × 1 cm for 1 week with mild tenderness. He also reported bilateral aural fullness for months.",

  "Physical Examination": "A right neck level-V mass measuring 1 × 1 cm was noted.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no significant medical or family history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were reported in the given information.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Computed tomography (CT) scan revealed ill-defined enhancing mass lesions at the right nasopharyngeal roof, causing Rosenmuller fossa obliteration and nasopharyngeal narrowing. Enlarged lymph nodes at the right jugular chain were also noted. A biopsy was performed for microscopic evaluation. Microscopically, the tumor was composed of two components: non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and large cell neuroendocrine carcinoma (LCNEC). LCNEC showed a nested and trabecular pattern in the background of the desmoplastic stroma. Focal rosette formation was observed. Tumor cells had a moderate amount of cytoplasm, large pleomorphic nuclei, and 1–2 conspicuous nucleoli. Immunohistochemical studies were performed. The SCC part was positive for p63 and negative for neuroendocrine markers (synaptophysin, chromogranin-A, CD56, and insulinoma-associated protein 1 [INSM1]). The LCNEC part was focally reactive with synaptophysin, CD56, and INSM1, but negative for p63 and chromogranin-A. Both SCC and LCNEC parts were diffusely positive for Epstein–Barr encoding region in-situ hybridization."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 52-year-old woman from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented with locally advanced non-small-cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) with a PD-L1 expression level of 5%. She was treated with radiochemotherapy. After 2 years, she experienced an adrenal relapse, which was treated with stereotactic radiotherapy and pembrolizumab. She achieved a complete response (CR) after 15 months of treatment (20 cycles). During treatment, she developed immune-induced hypothyroidism (CTCAE 5.0 grade 2) which was treated with supplementation. After six cycles of pembrolizumab, evaluation showed persistence of CR but revealed subcutaneous and fascial hypermetabolism without morphological or clinical translation, except for a transitory elevation of eosinophil count. After four more cycles of pembrolizumab, the patient complained of CTCAE 5.0 grade 2 asthenia, inflammatory muscle and joint pain, subcutaneous nodules, and symmetrical edema of the lower limbs.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient presented with subcutaneous nodules and symmetrical edema of the lower limbs.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of locally advanced non-small-cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) treated with radiochemotherapy. She later developed an adrenal relapse.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Blood tests revealed a slightly elevated CRP of 20.5 mg/L, with normal levels of cortisol and TSH. Autoantibody assays (antinuclear antibodies, rheumatoid factors, anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide, and anti-Scl70) were negative. Electroneuromyogram was also negative."
}"

After six cycles of pembrolizumab, evaluation showed persistence of CR but revealed subcutaneous and fascial hypermetabolism without morphological or clinical translation, except for a transitory elevation of eosinophil count. After four more cycles of pembrolizumab, the patient complained of CTCAE 5.0 grade 2 asthenia, inflammatory muscle and joint pain, subcutaneous nodules, and symmetrical edema of the lower limbs.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of locally advanced non-small-cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC) treated with radiochemotherapy. She later developed an adrenal relapse.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "18F-FDG-PET/CT evaluation showed persistence of complete response to cancer treatment but revealed the appearance and subsequent increase of subcutaneous and fascial hypermetabolism. The SUVmax on fascia was 12.3 and on subcutaneous nodules was 9.5. The scan also showed diffuse tracer uptake on the synovial walls of both knees. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male with a diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder. He was living in supported accommodation prior to admission.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to an acute in-patient ward under the Mental Health Act due to disinhibited behavior. This was his second admission within a month, representing a typical relapse pattern. Staff at his supported accommodation had become concerned about overfamiliarity. He exhibited clear psychotic features including auditory hallucinations, bizarre ideas that he had died and was communicating with the deceased country singer Glen Campbell, grandiose proposals, and delusional misidentification. Settling the patient's mental state with psychotropic medication proved difficult. Overfamiliarity and chaotic behavior continued to be core presenting features. On day 16 following clozapine initiation, he developed a fever with low blood oxygen saturation, not commensurate with his mild shortness of breath. Twenty-two days after clozapine initiation, a rash appeared, initially as papules on his upper arms then becoming more widespread. The rash had a maculopapular appearance and was pruritic and generalised, with confluent erythematous areas over the arms and trunk. Much of the rash was desquamating, with some plaques showing a punctum, and no obvious vesicles or blistering. The patient experienced a second relapse of his rash 4-5 weeks following the first episode, showing a more widespread eruption associated with varying degrees of limb oedema. During the second course of steroid treatment, the rash showed improvement but with persisting itch and papules. Two weeks into the clozapine-tapering regimen, the patient's rash improved markedly and had completely resolved within a month. Following the reintroduction of amisulpride, his mental state also recovered significantly with no further delusional beliefs. Once his mental state was stable, plans for discharge were made, with phased reintroduction to supported accommodation. His social functioning and interaction recovered well. Following discharge into the community, his mental state remained stable.",

Much of the rash was desquamating, with some plaques showing a punctum, and no obvious vesicles or blistering. During the second episode, the rash showed a more widespread eruption, associated with varying degrees of limb oedema.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Inflammatory markers were elevated (white cell count 17.7 × 109/L, C-reactive protein 92 mg/L). A normal chest x-ray was reported during the initial bronchitis diagnosis. "{

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to an acute in-patient ward under the Mental Health Act due to disinhibited behavior. This was his second admission within a month, representing a typical relapse pattern. Staff at his supported accommodation had become concerned about overfamiliarity. He exhibited clear psychotic features including auditory hallucinations, bizarre ideas that he had died and was communicating with the deceased country singer Glen Campbell, grandiose proposals, and delusional misidentification. Settling the patient's mental state with psychotropic medication proved difficult. Overfamiliarity and chaotic behavior continued to be core presenting features. The rash had a maculopapular appearance and was pruritic and generalised, with confluent erythematous areas over the arms and trunk. Much of the rash was desquamating, with some plaques showing a punctum, and no obvious vesicles or blistering. The patient experienced a second relapse of his rash 4-5 weeks following the first episode, showing a more widespread eruption associated with varying degrees of limb oedema. Following the reintroduction of amisulpride, his mental state also recovered significantly with no further delusional beliefs. Once his mental state was stable, plans for discharge were made, with phased reintroduction to supported accommodation. His social functioning and interaction recovered well. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 26-year-old female from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the rheumatology department in 2015 after recent cardiology management of an anterior myocardial infarction with ST segment elevation (STEMI). She underwent an angioplasty with bare-metal stent (BMS) placement for a 90% stenosis of the anterior descending coronary artery (LAD). Four months later, she developed angina due to a 70% intrastent restenosis, which was treated with a drug-eluting stent (DES) implantation. A year later, the DES was reoccluded, necessitating a balloon angioplasty. Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) was recommended after testing for aspirin and clopidogrel response. At age 13, the patient was admitted for fatigue, weight loss, and persistent headache. She had no pulse in her axillary, brachial, and radial arteries, a blood pressure difference of over 30 mmHg between upper limbs, and vascular bruits confirmed during auscultation of her carotid, subclavian, and renal arteries. She displayed no inflammatory syndrome. After ruling out infectious, congenital, or miscellaneous diseases, the diagnosis of Takayasu was established according to pediatric TA classification criteria. Due to the severity of vessel involvement, an aortic bicarotid bypass with Gore-Tex was performed at her juvenile age. Corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide (six cycles of intravenous treatment followed by oral administration) were initiated but later disrupted because of apparent disease remission.",

  "Physical Examination": "At age 13, the patient had no pulse in her axillary, brachial, and radial arteries. There was a blood pressure difference of over 30 mmHg between upper limbs. Vascular bruits were confirmed during auscultation of her carotid, subclavian, and renal arteries.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no evocative family history or prior medical events before her diagnosis at age 13. She was diagnosed with Takayasu arteritis at age 13 and underwent an aortic bicarotid bypass with Gore-Tex at that time. She was treated with corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide, which were later discontinued due to apparent disease remission.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The initial electrocardiogram showed suspected ST segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). Repeated venous Doppler ultrasound showed no abnormal findings."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 13-year-old girl from an unspecified geographic location. She is the eldest daughter in her family, and her parents are non-consanguineous.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the Pediatric Nephrology Clinic with a chief complaint of recurrent fevers. She reported recurrent fevers due to UTIs since 5 years old. Her first febrile episode at age 5 included a 5-day high-grade fever associated with loss of appetite. After 45 days, she experienced another episode of fever and loss of appetite. The patient's periodic fevers were repeated every 45 days during the past 8 years. In the intervals between her febrile episodes, the patient was healthy and laboratory tests were normal. She had multiple referrals to different doctors, including infectious specialists, pediatricians, nephrologists and urologists with the same complaints. During her final visits to the nephrology clinic, the patient was on antibiotics as prophylaxy for UTI and was given Fosfomycin for her fevers. After 20 days from her visit, the patient was admitted to a hospital and was treated for pyelonephritis. During her last visit to the nephrology clinic, she had an axillary temperature of 39.5 degrees. The patient was ill and mentioned difficulty in swallowing. The patient was instructed to take 1.5 tablets (2 mg/kg) of prednisolone forte (50 mg) in a single dose at time of her fever onset. To date, the patient has experienced 5 other febrile episodes, during which all the symptoms have been relieved within 24 h from their onset. Gradually the intervals between the episodes also became longer (3–4 months).",

  "Physical Examination": "During her first febrile episode at age 5, her physical examination was unremarkable. During her final visits to the nephrology clinic, physical examination was unremarkable. During her last visit to the nephrology clinic, a thorough physical examination revealed 3 cervical lymph nodes, exudative tonsillitis and painful aphthous stomatitis.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was born through natural vaginal delivery and did not have any significant medical history before the age of 5 years old.",

  "Initial Test Results": "During her first febrile episode at age 5, blood tests showed leukocytosis with a shift to the left and urine examination was in favor of pyuria. The urine culture was positive for bacterial growth. During her second episode, her urine examination was in favor of pyuria. In her blood tests she had leukocytosis with rise in polymorphonuclear leukocytes (PMN) and had an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 95 mm/hr. and a 3+ C-reactive protein. Her kidney function, including blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and serum creatinine levels were normal. During her last visit to the nephrology clinic, urine dipstick was positive for leukocytes and nitrite. The patient had an elevated ESR plus pyuria in urine tests and a positive urine culture. Throat cultures were sent and were negative."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 12-year-old boy from Sri Lanka who was admitted to the hospital.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with fever (38–39 °C) lasting 4 days and bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. Five years earlier, while in Sri Lanka, he had experienced intermittent fever for 12 days, mild cough, abdominal pain, and significant bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. During the current admission, the patient developed a diffuse erythematous and itchy rash on the trunk, arms, and legs. The patient had a painful lymphadenopathy (3 cm in diameter) in the right side of the neck.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient's physical development was normal. He was febrile and had a painful lymphadenopathy (3 cm in diameter) in the right side of the neck.",

  "Past Medical History": "Five years prior, the patient had been admitted to a local hospital in Sri Lanka for intermittent fever, mild cough, abdominal pain, and significant bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. At that time, blood tests revealed very high LDH levels (2360 IU/L) and positive cytomegalovirus (CMV) antibodies (IgG and IgM).",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial investigations revealed a mild increase in CRP (1.79 mg/dL) and hepatic enzymes (AST 51 IU, ALT 81 IU). Viral markers showed a past CMV infection. Markers for Epstein Barr Virus (EBV), Toxoplasma gondii, Adenovirus, and Parvovirus were negative. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) levels were normal. A chest X-ray was normal. A neck ultrasound showed the presence of two hypoechoic and slightly inhomogeneous lymph nodes, with rich vascularized hilum and no evidence of colliquative phenomena. Some other small lymph nodes were found in the submandibular region. Five years earlier, an abdominal ultrasound scan was normal, but a subsequent scan showed severe steatosis. Hepatitis B and C and HIV viral markers were negative. Hepatic autoantibodies and LKM were negative. ANA and ASMA were mildly positive (ANA 1:80 homogeneous pattern, ASMA 1:80 vascular pattern). Anti ds-DNA and complement fractions (C3 and C4) were normal. Thyroid function, cholesterol (LDL and HDL), and A and B apolipoprotein were normal. Blood and urine copper and serum ceruloplasmin levels were normal. Urine galactose and fructose were normal. A tuberculin intradermal reaction was negative."
}"

}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 67-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer and thymectomy.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to rheumatology with pain in thighs and biceps. This pain started after she began aromatase inhibitor therapy and continued even after stopping the therapy. Initially, there was no proximal muscle weakness or tenderness. An impression of polymyalgia was made on initial review. After a stable course for 3 years, the patient started deteriorating over 1 month. She developed proximal muscle weakness to the extent where she was unable to walk without support. She also developed bilateral ptosis and difficulty in swallowing towards the end of her meals.",

  "Physical Examination": "Initially, there was no proximal muscle weakness or tenderness. After 3 years, the patient developed proximal muscle weakness to the extent where she was unable to walk without support. She also presented with bilateral ptosis.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of breast cancer and thymectomy. She had previously been on aromatase inhibitor therapy.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Blood tests showed elevated serum levels of creatinine kinase. Extended myositis spectrum antibody screen showed positive antinuclear antibodies and transcription intermediary factor 1-gamma antibodies. Electromyography didn't show any evidence of neuropathy."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 61-year-old Caucasian woman from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to her family physician with generalized fatigue, pain and stiffness around both hips and shoulders. She had difficulty standing from a seated position and raising her arms above her shoulders. She denied fever or visual impairment but reported some headaches. The patient was prescribed a 7-day course of prednisone 20 mg daily. Her symptoms significantly improved thereafter but she deteriorated after stopping steroids. As the clinical presentation was suspicious, prednisone was restarted and a temporal artery biopsy was performed, with the results confirming the diagnosis. Steroids were gradually tapered and the patient was prescribed the steroid-sparing medication tocilizumab which has controlled her symptoms very well.",

  "Physical Examination": "Upon initial evaluation, she was haemodynamically stable and afebrile and was saturating well on ambient air. Her physical examination was significant for proximal myopathy involving both upper and lower extremities. The temporal artery was not palpable. Sensation, coordination and reflexes were intact during neurological examination.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was without a significant medical history. She had never smoked cigarettes, drank alcohol occasionally and had no history of illicit drug use.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Extensive work-up was done including a complete blood count (CBC), complete metabolic panel (CMP), creatine kinase (CK), antinuclear antibodies (ANA), antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) and rheumatoid factor (RF); results were all unremarkable. Inflammatory markers showed CRP of 6.0 mg/l (normal range 0–10 mg/l) and ESR of 30 mm/hr (normal range 0–30 mm/hr). The platelet count was normal at 325 K/μl (normal range 130–430 K/μl)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 60-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with multiple cutaneous nodules, primarily affecting the upper extremities. These nodules first appeared 4 years ago and had been gradually increasing in size over the last 3 months. He reported morning stiffness lasting 1 hour and pain in the small joints of the hands. Seven soft, palpable, non-tender nodules were observed with a maximum diameter of 40 mm on both elbows, extensor surface of wrists, and knees. Painful swelling of both third metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP) and wrists was noted. The patient did not have skin thickenings, sclerodactyly, finger contractures, or Raynaud's phenomenon. After receiving pre-treatment with methylprednisolone (32 mg given as one dose 12 hours and a second dose 2 hours before a total body CT scan), a remarkable reduction in tenosynovitis was observed, and his symptoms of pain and morning stiffness subsided. However, his skin nodules remained stable. The patient was discharged without any prescribed medication while awaiting biopsy results.",

  "Physical Examination": "Clinical examination revealed seven soft, palpable, non-tender nodules with a maximum diameter of 40 mm on both elbows, extensor surface of wrists, and knees. Painful swelling of both third metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP) and wrists was noted. No skin thickenings, sclerodactyly, finger contractures, or Raynaud's phenomenon were detected.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's past medical history was unremarkable except for an allergy to streptomycin.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests were normal. Antinuclear antibodies (ANA), rheumatoid factor (RF), anti-Citrullinated Protein Antibodies (ACPA), complement components C3/C4, serum angiotensin converting enzyme (SACE), erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), C-reactive protein (CRP), and viral serology were within normal ranges or negative. X-rays of hands showed cystic lesions in the third to fifth metacarpal and in the carpal bones bilaterally, as well as below the left ulnar styloid process. Musculoskeletal ultrasound showed synovitis of third MCPs and tenosynovitis of extensor tendons of both wrists. Synovial fluid analysis showed mild inflammation (white blood cells 3402/μl—56% polymorphonuclear cells), while gram stain was negative."
}"
