Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 36-year-old man with a smoking history of more than 20 packs per year.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the hospital with osteomyelitis after surgery for an ingrown nail of the right first toe at another hospital. At the Department of Orthopedics, the patient underwent disarticulation of the interphalangeal joint of the right first toe. After disarticulation, the wound was dressed using ordinary methods and closely monitored. However, wound healing was delayed for over a month, and wound disruption and skin necrosis occurred. Subsequently, a consultation for plastic surgery was requested, and the patient was transferred. Debridement and wound repair of the right first toe was performed with antibiotic treatment. Despite persistent negative findings in the wound culture and no signs of wound infection, the wound healed very slowly.",

  "Physical Examination": "Upon physical examination, the dorsalis pedis artery was hardly palpable, and poor blood flow was confirmed through handheld Doppler examination.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a smoking history of more than 20 packs per year.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory findings showed erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) = 5 mm/h, C-reactive protein (CRP) = 0.1 mg/dL (normal range 0.1–0.5 mg/dL), and HbA1C 5.4%. Other typical laboratory test results were also within a normal range. Chest X-ray and standard Electrocardiogram findings were normal. Immunologic tests showed negative results with anti-phospholipid antibody <1.0 U/mL and anti-cardiolipin antibody <3.0 immunoglobulin G [IgG] phospholipid U/mL."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 36-year-old man with a smoking history of more than 20 packs per year.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the hospital with osteomyelitis after surgery for an ingrown nail of the right first toe at another hospital. At the Department of Orthopedics, the patient underwent disarticulation of the interphalangeal joint of the right first toe. After disarticulation, the wound was dressed using ordinary methods and closely monitored. However, wound healing was delayed for over a month, and wound disruption and skin necrosis occurred. Subsequently, a consultation for plastic surgery was requested, and the patient was transferred. Debridement and wound repair of the right first toe was performed with antibiotic treatment. Despite persistent negative findings in the wound culture and no signs of wound infection, the wound healed very slowly.",

  "Physical Examination": "Upon physical examination, the dorsalis pedis artery was hardly palpable, and poor blood flow was confirmed through handheld Doppler examination.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a smoking history of more than 20 packs per year.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory findings showed erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) = 5 mm/h, C-reactive protein (CRP) = 0.1 mg/dL (normal range 0.1–0.5 mg/dL), and HbA1C 5.4%. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 69-year-old man from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a 1-year history of red papules and plaques with severe itching. He had a 20-year history of oral LP. The skin lesions started 3 days after receiving the second dose of COVID-19 vaccination, initially manifesting as isolated papules on both lower extremities, which quickly coalesced and spread throughout the entire body. Prior treatments included compound glycyrrhizin, antihistamine agent, tripterysium glycosides, fluticasone propionate, and fluoconodimethyl sulfoxide, resulting in an unsatisfactory response.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed widespread red papules, edematous erythema, and multiple crusts on the scalp, face, neck, trunk, and extremities. Violet plaques with white stripes were observed on the bilateral buccal mucosa and soft palate. There were no nail or scalp lesions.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a 20-year history of oral LP. Other medical history included hypertension (well-controlled by nifedipine, bisoprolol fumarate, and losartan potassium tablets for about 20 years) and diabetes mellitus type 2 (poorly controlled by acarbose and isophane protamine biosynthetic human insulin, with a fast blood glucose of 9.8 mmol/L).",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory investigation showed eosinophilia (eosinophil percentage, 11.4%) and an elevated serum total IgE production (150 kU/L, normal range, 0–60 kU/L). IgG autoantibody targeting NC16A domain of bullous pemphigoid (BP) 180 by enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) was weakly positive (12 U/ml, normal range, <9 U/ml)."
}"

The skin lesions started 3 days after receiving the second dose of COVID-19 vaccination, initially manifesting as isolated papules on both lower extremities, which quickly coalesced and spread throughout the entire body. Prior treatments included compound glycyrrhizin, antihistamine agent, tripterysium glycosides, fluticasone propionate, and fluoconodimethyl sulfoxide, resulting in an unsatisfactory response.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed widespread red papules, edematous erythema, and multiple crusts on the scalp, face, neck, trunk, and extremities. Violet plaques with white stripes were observed on the bilateral buccal mucosa and soft palate. There were no nail or scalp lesions.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a 20-year history of oral LP. Other medical history included hypertension (well-controlled by nifedipine, bisoprolol fumarate, and losartan potassium tablets for about 20 years) and diabetes mellitus type 2 (poorly controlled by acarbose and isophane protamine biosynthetic human insulin, with a fast blood glucose of 9.8 mmol/L).",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory investigation showed eosinophilia (eosinophil percentage, 11.4%) and an elevated serum total IgE production (150 kU/L, normal range, 0–60 kU/L). IgG autoantibody targeting NC16A domain of bullous pemphigoid (BP) 180 by enzyme linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) was weakly positive (12 U/ml, normal range, <9 U/ml).",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Histopathology demonstrated intercellular epidermal edema, a subepidermal blister with an underlying sparse dermal perivascular infiltrate consisting of lymphocytes and eosinophils. Direct immunofluorescence showed linear depositions of IgG and complement component 3 at the BMZ. Indirect immunofluorescence utilizing monkey esophagus substrate demonstrated serum anti-BMZ autoantibodies of IgG at 1:40 dilution. Based on the clinical features, histopathological and immunofluorescent findings, as well as an ELISA result, a diagnosis of BP was made, with an evaluation of BP disease area index (BPDAI) score of 104."
}"

Cases.Final Name: Porokeratotic eccrine ostial and dermal duct nevus
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 14-month-old orphan male infant. He was born at 38 weeks via caesarean section, weighing 3080 g. The patient's geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The infant was consulted in 2016 due to bilateral corneal masses. Corneal opacities were present at admission to the orphanage. On ocular examination, bilateral vascularized dome-shaped corneal tumors were observed, distinctly larger on the right side, protruding through the right palpebral fissure. The tumors were opaque salmon-colored, soft and cystic on palpation, without intralesional hair. The rest of the conjunctival surfaces were normal, and the limbus was spared in both eyes. Ocular fundi could not be visualized. The diagnosis of grade III corneal dermoids was made. A conservative approach was adopted, prescribing lubricants. Follow-up visits in 2017 and 2019 showed no progression in corneal tumors. However, in June 2021, significant regression of both corneal dermoids was observed, particularly in the right corneal tumor.",

  "Physical Examination": "The infant presented with trigonocephaly, flat nose bridge, small upturned nose, cleft palate and lip, micrognathia, bilateral radial defects, club hands, pes equinovarus, and hypospadias.",

  "Past Medical History": "The infant received a diagnosis of Fetal Valproate Syndrome (FVSD) a few weeks after birth due to several congenital anomalies. Limited prenatal history indicated that the mother had epilepsy and regularly took Valproic Acid (VPA) throughout her pregnancy. The baby was abandoned to an orphanage after being discharged from the maternity ward.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Cytogenetic analyses were normal. B-mode ocular ultrasonography revealed bilateral dense vitreal opacities, probably representing a developmental vitreoretinal abnormality, which was more pronounced in the left eye."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 26-year-old primigravida woman. The geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was assessed by the Prenatal Diagnosis Unit for a morphological ultrasound at week 21 of pregnancy. The ultrasound examination revealed biometry not in accordance with gestational age, indicating an early diagnosis of severe intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) (according to 17 + 4 weeks, estimated fetal weight: 208 g). The fetal morphological study showed several abnormalities. After the discovery of fetal abnormalities, the patient was informed about the findings and fetal prognosis, as well as possible causes (mainly genetic and infectious). She was offered and accepted the possibility of performing an invasive technique (amniocentesis) at 21 weeks to refine the diagnosis. After receiving the genetic results and being informed of the known prognosis for the identified syndrome, the patient opted for legal termination of pregnancy with the help of the Obstetrics team and psychological support.",

  "Physical Examination": "The fetal morphological study revealed several abnormalities. At the intracranial level, the cavum septum pellucidum (CSP) was absent and there was an abnormal bridge of tissue across the midline at the level of the CSP, with direct visualization of the columns of the fornix. The prefrontal area showed an open midline in three lines in the sagittal section with an elevation of the third ventricle. The corpus callosum was not identified in the sagittal section. In the posterior fossa, the cerebellum was hypoplastic with a transverse diameter of 14 mm (corresponding to 15 + 2 weeks) and thin thickness. Ventriculomegaly was not observed. The fetal profile showed a present nasal bone, slightly flattened frontal area with prefrontal edema, and subjective micrognathia. Mild ocular proptosis was observed bilaterally. The cardiac study was within normal limits, except for slight levocardia. The vertebral column showed no apparent anomalies. Normal male genitalia were observed. Regarding the extremities, the fetus presented hands with normal fingers and phalanges, as well as preserved mobility. However, the wrist joint seemed fixed, and the feet were located in hyperflexion with little mobility. No amniotic fluid alterations were found.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no personal or family history of interest. Both parents are healthy, without apparent consanguinity between them. The pregnancy had a normal evolution to date.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The first-trimester ultrasound and combined screening for chromosomal abnormalities in the first trimester showed low risk for Down, Edward's, and Patau syndromes. Blood tests from the first and second trimesters showed no pathological findings. Quantitative Fluorescence-Polymerase Chain Reaction (QF-PCR) results were Diploid 13, 18, 21, XY. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) and toxoplasma PCR in amniotic fluid were negative. Toxoplasmosis, rubella, cytomegalovirus, herpes simplex (TORCH virus) serology was negative."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 33-year-old Chinese male.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a 7-year history of itching brown papules and plaques on the gluteal cleft and the buttocks. The lesion began as a small brown scaly papule and increasingly coalesced to form larger plaques. There was no discernable history or underlying cutaneous diseases. The patient did not respond to treatment with topical glucocorticoid and antihistamine drugs. Treatment with the administration of oral acitretin and application of topical retinoid creams daily was prescribed, but the rash showed no significant improvement during 4-month follow up.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed a large well-defined reddish brown verrucous plaque located on both buttocks, and satellite papules were found at the inner thigh. A reddish-brown, well-demarcated, hypertrophic and invasive verrucous plaque was presented bilaterally and symmetrically on the buttocks. Numerous well-defined reddish brown discrete papules were found symmetrically at the inner thigh. Demoscopy showed a sharply demarcated annular lesion with a thick, peripheral light brown rim, limiting an erythematous non-atrophic center with regular dotted vessels.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no discernable history or underlying cutaneous diseases.",

  "Initial Test Results": ""
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 47-year-old female from Kyiv, Ukraine.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was hospitalized on April 14, 2021, presenting with weakness, fever up to 37.6°C, edema on the lower limbs, painful ulcers on the legs, aphthae on the lower lip and buccal mucosa, and liquid bloody stool 3–4 times a day. The onset of clinical manifestations was in January 2021 after receiving the third dose of the IndiRab rabies vaccine following a domestic dog bite. Initial symptoms included pain in the joints and muscles, bloating, loose stools 3–4 times a day with mucus and blood, and elevated temperature of 37.4°C. Esophagogastroscopy revealed erythematous gastropathy. Ileocolonoscopy showed round ulcers with focal distribution, less than 6 ulcers, and absence of cobblestone appearance. The patient was initially prescribed mesalazine, which led to the development of nodular erythema of the lower limbs. Oral methylprednisolone was then prescribed with a positive effect. However, from April 10, there was a significant deterioration in the patient's condition: increased number of painful erythematous nodes in lower limbs bilaterally, ulceration and bleeding from nodes, high temperature (37.8°C), and defecation up to 4–5 times a day with blood and mucous stool, and tenesmus.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient's skin and visible mucous membranes were pale. Several small, rounded aphthous ulcers were present on the mucous membrane of the lips and the buccal mucosa, covered with a grayish-white settling and surrounded by an erythematous crown. On both shins, there were nodes up to 6 cm in diameter, hyperemic, painful, with necrosis in the center and bleeding. Peripheral edema was observed in the shin and on the dorsal surface of the right foot. Pathergy syndrome was negative.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was previously healthy. She received the third dose of the IndiRab rabies vaccine (Bharat Biotech International Limited, India) following a domestic dog bite in January 2021.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory examination revealed: hemoglobin 86 g/l, MCV 72.6 fl, MCH 25.3 pg, erythrocytes 3.4 × 10^12/l, leukocytes 10.6 × 10^9/l, platelets 442 × 10^9/l, C-reactive protein 293 mg/l, fibrinogen 606 mg/dl, fecal calprotectin 417 mcg/g, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) 51 mm/h. The serological test for H. pylori was negative."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 29-year-old Caucasian woman from an unspecified geographic location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred and admitted for the management of fetal growth restriction (FGR) and oligohydramnios at 33 weeks and 6 days of gestation. She reported smoking five cigarettes per day, consuming four glasses of wine per day during the pregnancy, and using cocaine during the first two months of pregnancy. The first ultrasound at 12 weeks of gestation described a crown-rump length (CRL) corresponding to the anamnestic gestational age. The combined test in the first trimester resulted in low risk for the main aneuploidies, and a second trimester screening at 20 weeks of gestation described normal fetal anatomy. According to the Truffle Study, the patient was monitored every three days with an ultrasound fetal Doppler and cardiotocographic examination twice a day. A urine screen test for amphetamine, benzodiazepines, cocaine, methadone, opiates, and cannabinoids was conducted, with all tests resulting negative. Additionally, hair and urine samples were collected to evaluate the use of alcohol, smoking, and cocaine during pregnancy. The rapid test for the diagnosis of premature rupture of membranes also resulted negative.",
  "Physical Examination": "Upon admission, an ultrasound exam showed evidence of reduced amniotic fluid (amniotic fluid index—AFI: 73 mm) and an estimated fetal weight of 1559 g, equal to the first percentile (z-score −3.303) for gestational age. Fetal Doppler showed an umbilical artery pulsatility index (PI) of 1.23, equal to the 96th percentile (z-score 1.697), middle cerebral artery PI of 1.62, equal to the 16th percentile (z-score −0.995), with the cerebroplacental ratio of 1.32, equal to the 3rd percentile (z-score −2.004) for gestational age. Another ultrasound exam after seven days of hospitalization (34 weeks and 6 days of gestational age) confirmed reduced amniotic fluid (AFI: 70 mm) and showed umbilical artery PI of 1.27, equal to the 98th percentile (z-score 2.005), middle cerebral artery PI of 1.21, equal to the 1st percentile (z-score −2.813), with cerebroplacental ratio of 0.95, equal to the 1st percentile (z-score −3.507) for gestational age. Cardiotocographic examinations always showed normal baseline heart rate, presence of accelerations, absence of decelerations, and no uterine contractions, and the short-term variability was always >4.5 ms.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient has iatrogenic hypothyroidism, treated with Levotiroxine 75 mcg, due to a hemithyroidectomy for a benign thyroid nodule in 2016.",
  "Initial Test Results": "In the first trimester, the combined test resulted in low risk for the main aneuploidies, and in the second trimester, a screening at 20 weeks of gestation described normal fetal anatomy. Upon admission, a urine screen test for amphetamine, benzodiazepines, cocaine, methadone, opiates, and cannabinoids was conducted, with all tests resulting negative. A rapid test for the diagnosis of premature rupture of membranes resulted negative. Cardiotocographic examinations always showed normal baseline heart rate, presence of accelerations, absence of decelerations, and no uterine contractions, and the short-term variability was always >4.5 ms."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 33-year-old pregnant woman, at 36 and 2/7 weeks’ gestation, in her first pregnancy. Geographic location information is not provided.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the Pregnancy Pathology Ward for fetal well-being assessment and induction of labor. She was diagnosed with grade 1 Fetal Growth Restriction (FGR) based on the recommendations of the International Society of Ultrasound in Obstetrics and Gynecology (ISUOG) and the Polish Society of Gynecologists and Obstetricians. On the day of admission, fetal well-being was assessed with the following results: estimated fetal weight 0 percentile, cerebral–placental ratio 1.77 (26th percentile), and mean pulsatility index in the uterine artery of 0.65 (40th percentile). From the 30th week of pregnancy, the patient took methyldopa (2 × 250 mg) to manage pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH), which was optimally controlled. Throughout her pregnancy, the patient did not report any complaints or complications, and it progressed without any issues. She underwent six standard pregnancy ultrasound examinations, as per the Standards of the Polish Society of Gynecologists and Obstetricians, and four additional ultrasound examinations along with fetal echocardiography at a tertiary center for prenatal diagnostics. The first-trimester prenatal examination revealed normal fetal anatomy and a low risk of trisomy, preeclampsia, and preterm delivery. The combined test values were: free subunit of β-hCG 0.87 MoM, PAPP-A 0.701 MoM, and AFP 7.12 IU/l. All ultrasound examinations showed no structural defects in the fetus. There were no ultrasonographic features of placental mesenchymal dysplasia or other identifiable placental pathologies. The fetus exhibited slow weight gain starting from the 20th week of gestation, assessed using Hadlock’s formula 3 and The World Health Organization Fetal Growth Charts. Grade 1 FGR was diagnosed in the 30th week of pregnancy, in accordance with the recommendations. Following the diagnosis of FGR, weekly assessments of the cerebroplacental index and amniotic fluid volume, using the largest fluid pocket, were performed. Additionally, from the 34th week of pregnancy, a 40–60 min cardiotocographic record with short-term variation assessment was conducted once a week. At 36 + 3 weeks of gestation, the patient started labor pre-induction. Before the pre-induction of labor, fetal well-being was determined by CTG and Doppler ultrasonography and biophysical profile. Labor pre-induction involved the use of a Foley catheter, which was removed after 24 h. Subsequently, an insert containing dinoprostone was utilized, and it was removed after 8 h due to the onset of regular contractile actions of the uterus. A permanent cardiotocographic record was then connected and Group B streptococcal prophylaxis was started. The amniotic fluid drained 20 min before delivery and the patient gave birth to a male newborn weighing 1830 g (<3%), with dimensions of 47 cm in length (50%) and a head circumference of 30 cm (<3%). He received 6, 8, 9, and 10 points on the Apgar scale at 1, 3, 5, and 10 min, respectively, and the umbilical blood was pH 7.1.",

Physical findings related to labor progression and delivery processes are described in the Clinical Presentation. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 28-year-old woman with spontaneous conception, admitted to the University Hospital of Patras at 29 weeks of gestation.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented with fever, fatigue, pharyngitis, and cough. During the first 5 days of hospitalization, she was under observation and in good clinical condition. On the 6th day, she experienced acute chest pain and shortness of breath. On the 10th day, she developed progressive dyspnea, fever, and shallow breathing. Her clinical condition deteriorated with increasing oxygen needs and respiratory failure (acute respiratory distress syndrome), necessitating intubation. A preterm emergency cesarean section was performed at 30 weeks of gestation.",

  "Physical Examination": "The upper abdominal ultrasound showed splenomegaly. The obstetric ultrasonography did not show any fetal abnormalities.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was seronegative for CMV through the first and second trimester of pregnancy.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Nasopharyngeal swab for SARS-CoV-2, Influenza virus antigen and RSV antigen were negative. Maternal serum revealed elevated CRP (C-reactive protein) (7.18 mg/dl, normal values: < 0.5 mg/dl), as well as positive both CMV IgM and IgG with low IgG avidity test (< 10%). The patient was seronegative for both ΗΙV I&II, HSV and EBV. Maternal whole blood test was strongly positive for CMV DNA (40,917 iu/mL, positive > 178 iu/mL) by real-time polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR). Serological immune control tests were not indicative of autoimmune disorder (ANA, p-ANCA, ASMA, RF, complement system and control for the major immunoglobulin classes). On the 6th day, a chest x-ray revealed a reticular pattern indicative of pneumonia. Bronco-alveolar lavage fluid was negative for bacterial superinfection. CRP further increased to 15.5 mg/dl."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 33-year-old healthy Palestinian female who completed her bachelor's degree in education. She is part of a couple married for 10 years, with her husband being a 35-year-old male who completed his bachelor's degree in science.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The couple presented to a genetic clinic with a history of recurrent pregnancy losses. They had two previous pregnancies resulting in early miscarriages and two pregnancies resulting in neonatal deaths. The neonatal deaths were associated with congenital heart disease due to hypoplastic left heart syndrome, microcephaly, and respiratory distress. They have one living offspring, a 6-year-old son, with mild intellectual impairment, behavioral issues, and autism spectrum disorder. The son was evaluated by neurology and genetic services, with unremarkable metabolic and genetic testing results. His brain MRI and CT scans were normal.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination of the patient was unremarkable. There were no dysmorphic features or typical physical characteristics of PKU such as fair skin, blond hair, blue eyes, and eczema. Her head circumference was 54.5 cm (57th centile). Full neurological and psychological assessments were entirely normal with no abnormalities in intellectual and neuropsychological function.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no history of learning difficulty or behavioral problems at school. Family history revealed that the patient has one brother with classical PKU, diagnosed early and well-controlled on medical formula and Kuvan. The patient's niece, 2 years old, was diagnosed with PKU through newborn screening and is doing well on treatment.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial assessment included parental chromosomal analysis and maternal hematological and autoimmune work up. Chromosomal analyses performed on the parents and the neonate from the second affected pregnancy were unremarkable. Plasma amino acid testing showed a Phe level in the classic range at 1642 μmol/L and a second level of 1492 μmol/L obtained a few days later."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 33-year-old healthy Palestinian female who completed her bachelor's degree in education. She is part of a couple married for 10 years, with her husband being a 35-year-old male who completed his bachelor's degree in science.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The couple presented to a genetic clinic with a history of recurrent pregnancy losses. They had two previous pregnancies resulting in early miscarriages and two pregnancies resulting in neonatal deaths. The neonatal deaths were associated with congenital heart disease due to hypoplastic left heart syndrome, microcephaly, and respiratory distress. They have one living offspring, a 6-year-old son, with mild intellectual impairment, behavioral issues, and autism spectrum disorder. The son was evaluated by neurology and genetic services, with unremarkable metabolic and genetic testing results. His brain MRI and CT scans were normal.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination of the patient was unremarkable. There were no dysmorphic features or typical physical characteristics of PKU such as fair skin, blond hair, blue eyes, and eczema. Her head circumference was 54.5 cm (57th centile). Full neurological and psychological assessments were entirely normal with no abnormalities in intellectual and neuropsychological function.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no history of learning difficulty or behavioral problems at school. Family history revealed that the patient has one brother with classical PKU, diagnosed early and well-controlled on medical formula and Kuvan. The patient's niece, 2 years old, was diagnosed with PKU through newborn screening and is doing well on treatment.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial assessment included parental chromosomal analysis and maternal hematological and autoimmune work up. Chromosomal analyses performed on the parents and the neonate from the second affected pregnancy were unremarkable. Plasma amino acid testing showed a Phe level in the classic range at 1642 μmol/L and a second level of 1492 μmol/L obtained a few days later.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Exome sequencing was performed on both parents. The patient was found to be homozygous for a three-basepair in-frame deletion variant c.169_171del, p.Glu57del in the PAH gene, consistent with the genetic diagnosis of autosomal recessive PKU. No other clinically relevant sequencing variants or copy number variations related to the described phenotype were identified. Exome sequencing in their son disclosed no clinically relevant variant, but his carrier status was not reported. The patient's brother and niece were each found to be homozygous for the same pathogenic variant and affected with PKU."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 5-day-old male weighing 3250 g, transferred to the neonatal ICU. The patient is from a location where the use of valproic acid during pregnancy was advised by a physician.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient had been intubated due to respiratory distress and was later extubated. Tachypnea was observed following extubation. During antibiotic therapy, respiratory distress persisted. The mother of the patient used valproic acid for epilepsy treatment before and during pregnancy. The first-born child of the mother had autism. No consanguinity was reported between the parents. During the follow-up, an echocardiographic evaluation revealed an 8-mm atrial septal defect with dilation of the right atrium and ventricle. Further echocardiography showed the left main coronary artery enlarged and a marked colour Doppler flow from the left coronary region to the right atrium. Angiography showed a coronary AV fistula from the left coronary artery to the right atrium, which was then closed with the AMPLATZER Duct Occluder II Additional Sizes (ADO-II AS) device. After the transcatheter closure, symptoms improved significantly, leading to the patient's discharge. The clinical exome sequencing test and peripheral blood genetic analysis did not detect any chromosomal abnormalities or mutations related to Holt-Oram syndrome and Fanconi anaemia.",
  "Physical Examination": "The physical examination revealed a 1x1.5 cm diameter capillary haemangioma on the forehead, frontal bossing and broad forehead, hypertelorism, posteriorly rotated low-set ears, long philtrum, micrognathia, anteverted nares, pectus excavatum deformity, right thumb agenesis, wrist contractures, clinodactyly, lumbosacral hypertrichosis, and a sacral dimple. Auscultation revealed a 2/6 systolic murmur on the left sternal border. Other systemic examinations suggested no abnormalities.",
  "Past Medical History": "The mother was treated with valproic acid for epilepsy and continued its use during pregnancy as advised by her physician. Her first-born child had autism. No family history of consanguinity was reported.",
  "Initial Test Results": "ECG showed sinus rhythm with significant p waves. X-ray revealed prominent pulmonary vascular shadows, cardiomegaly, absence of the radius bone in the right forearm, and the presence of spina bifida. Initial laboratory findings suggested no abnormalities."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 45-year-old Japanese woman. She was born preterm with a low birth weight of 1,980 g and was the second child of non-consanguineous parents.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient experienced repetitive episodes of skin lacerations and subcutaneous hemorrhage after minor trauma. She had marked joint laxity with repetitive sprains caused by unstable ankle joints. Intractable hair loss has been her major physical concern since childhood. At age 36, she developed massive intraabdominal hemorrhages caused by rupture of the superior mesenteric artery, associated with multiple aneurysms, which were treated with catheter embolization. At age 45, she exhibited hair with a kinky texture and generalized thinning, a high palate and multiple dental caries, hyperextensible and translucent skin, skin striae in the lower extremities with atrophic scars, soft soles, an umbilical hernia, pes planus, and generalized joint hypermobility (Beighton score 8/9). She had high myopia but no hearing impairment. There had been no episodes of dislocations or musculoskeletal pain.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed hyperextensible and translucent skin, skin striae in the lower extremities with atrophic scars, soft soles, an umbilical hernia, pes planus, and generalized joint hypermobility (Beighton score 8/9). Radiological examination showed no spinal deformities. No aortic root dilatation or valve abnormalities were detected on echocardiography.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had bilateral congenital hip dislocation for which she underwent fixation with a brace. She also had spinal disc herniation. No skin hyperextensibility, fragility, or joint hypermobility were noted in her mother, elder sister, or two daughters.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Hematoxylin and eosin staining of a skin specimen obtained at age 36 showed increased spaces between collagen fibers and disorganized orientations of these fibers in the lower and middle layer of the dermis. Masson's trichrome staining revealed decreased collagen fibers. Elastica van Gieson staining showed prominent elastic fibers due to the decreased numbers of collagen fibers."
}"

At age 45, she exhibited hair with a kinky texture and generalized thinning, a high palate and multiple dental caries, hyperextensible and translucent skin, skin striae in the lower extremities with atrophic scars, soft soles, an umbilical hernia, pes planus, and generalized joint hypermobility (Beighton score 8/9). She had high myopia but no hearing impairment. There had been no episodes of dislocations or musculoskeletal pain.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed hyperextensible and translucent skin, skin striae in the lower extremities with atrophic scars, soft soles, an umbilical hernia, pes planus, and generalized joint hypermobility (Beighton score 8/9). Radiological examination showed no spinal deformities. No aortic root dilatation or valve abnormalities were detected on echocardiography.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Hematoxylin and eosin staining of a skin specimen obtained at age 36 showed increased spaces between collagen fibers and disorganized orientations of these fibers in the lower and middle layer of the dermis. Masson's trichrome staining revealed decreased collagen fibers. Elastica van Gieson staining showed prominent elastic fibers due to the decreased numbers of collagen fibers.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Next-generation sequencing (NGS) panel-based analysis revealed a non-sense variant c.2296G>T,p.(Glu766*) and a frameshift variant c.2383dup,p.(Glu795Glyfs*3) in AEBP1 (NM_001129.5), which were confirmed by Sanger sequencing. Ultrastructural analysis using transmission electron microscopy of the skin specimen revealed the presence of collagen fibrils with irregular contours (flower-like appearance) and small size under the cross-sectional view. Measurement of procollagen production from cultured skin fibroblasts showed that amounts of type I and type III procollagen were both reduced compared with an age- and sex-matched control."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a two-day-old female neonate born at full term to healthy parents with a history of third-degree consanguinity. The infant's birth weight was 1500 g, birth length was 44 cm, head circumference was 30.8 cm, chest circumference was 29.7 cm, and ponderal index was 1.88.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The infant was referred to the pediatrics department with complaints of skin laxity, thin body stature, progeroid features, bilateral claw-like hands, and mild respiratory distress. The child did not cry immediately after birth. The appearance of the child is progeroid with frontal bossing, dysmorphic facies, micropthalmia with strabismus, and a long philtrum. The anterior and posterior fontanels were wide. The ears were low-set with large ear lobes. There were excessive skin folds over the limbs and generalized hypotonia. The upper limbs showed flexion deformity of the wrists and hyper-extensible metacarpophalangeal joints associated with clawing of the hands. The chest wall showed marked pectus excavatum. The skin over the abdomen and thorax was very thin and transparent with visible veins over the chest and abdomen. Examination of the external genitalia revealed mild clitoromegaly. The eyes showed hypotelorism, bilateral corneal opacities, and cataract formation. Rooting and sucking reflexes were normal with incomplete Moro's reflexes. The skin was wrinkled, thin, and atrophic with reduced subcutaneous fat.",

  "Physical Examination": "The vital signs of the patient were within normal limits. The appearance was progeroid with frontal bossing, dysmorphic facies, micropthalmia with strabismus, and a long philtrum. The anterior and posterior fontanels were wide. The ears were low-set with large ear lobes. There were excessive skin folds over the limbs and generalized hypotonia. The upper limbs showed flexion deformity of the wrists and hyper-extensible metacarpophalangeal joints associated with clawing of the hands. The chest wall showed marked pectus excavatum. The skin over the abdomen and thorax was very thin and transparent with visible veins. Examination of the external genitalia revealed mild clitoromegaly. The eyes showed hypotelorism, bilateral corneal opacities, and cataract formation. Rooting and sucking reflexes were normal with incomplete Moro's reflexes.",

  "Past Medical History": "The mother, aged 22 years, had regular ante-natal check-ups, consisting of three doctor visits in the first trimester and six doctor visits in the third trimester. There was no history of fever or rash in the first trimester. She was not on any medication for other conditions. Her thyroid function tests were normal. Iron and folic acid (IFA) prophylaxis and two doses of tetanus toxoid were administered in the second trimester. The mother had a history of first-trimester abortion one year ago. There was no history of anemia, pregnancy-induced hypertension (PIH), or exposure to radiation or chemicals during pregnancy. Intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) was noted in the third trimester. The mother underwent a normal vaginal delivery at full term of gestational age. There was no significant history of congenital abnormalities in the family.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No specific initial test results were provided in the given information."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A male, naturally conceived, third-born child of a non-consanguineous couple with an unremarkable family history and healthy siblings. Born in a secondary-care hospital at 38 + 1 weeks of gestation after a dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy. The geographic location is unspecified.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The mother noticed significant differences between the fetal movements of the two twins, with one being barely noticeable. At birth, the patient had an Apgar score of 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes of life, respectively, due to persistence of hypotonia. The newborn’s weight was 2560 g (10th percentile), length was 49 cm (25–50th percentile), and head circumference was 35 cm (50–75th percentile). The female twin had similar measurements but was not hypotonic and had an Apgar score of 9 and 10. The infant was referred to the Department of Neonatology at 5 days of life for further evaluations. Axial hypotonia, poor head control, poor sucking, and a peculiar senile appearance were noted. Facial dysmorphisms included hypertelorism, down-slanting palpebral fissures, ocular exotropia, arched nose with a bulbous nasal tip, high-vaulted palate, short philtrum, down-turned mouth with thin upper lip, micrognathia, and low set ears with evident lobes. Skin appeared lax and translucent. The patient showed arachnodactyly, contracted finger joints, adduction deformity of the right thumb, clinodactyly and ulnar deviation of all hand fingers, camptodactyly of the feet with a tendency for toe flexion. Nails appeared dystrophic. The patient also had a patent foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus with a hemodynamically not significant left-to-right shunt. Despite physiotherapy, finger motility remained limited.",
  "Physical Examination": "Initial neonatal visit confirmed axial hypotonia, joint hypermobility, right congenital genu recurvatum (resolved spontaneously within 12 hours), arachnodactyly, and finger joint contractures. At 5 days, axial hypotonia, poor head control, poor sucking, peculiar senile appearance, facial dysmorphisms (hypertelorism, down-slanting palpebral fissures, ocular exotropia, arched nose with bulbous nasal tip, high-vaulted palate, short philtrum, down-turned mouth with thin upper lip, micrognathia, low set ears with enlarged lobes), lax and translucent skin, arachnodactyly, contracted finger joints, adduction deformity of the right thumb, clinodactyly, ulnar deviation of hand fingers, camptodactyly of the feet, dystrophic nails, and no pterygia. Heart rhythm was regular without audible murmurs, and femoral pulses were palpable and symmetrical.",
  "Past Medical History": "No remarkable family history. The male child was born following a dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy. Routine fetal ultrasound showed intrauterine growth restriction in both fetuses.",
  "Initial Test Results": "At birth, the patient had an Apgar score of 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Newborn screening tests (hearing, pulse oximetry, and inborn error of metabolism screening) were normal. Ophthalmic evaluation confirmed exotropia with no other abnormalities. Abdominal ultrasound was normal. Echocardiography revealed aortic root dilation at the aortic sinus of 13 mm (Z score + 3) without aortic insufficiency. Remaining segments of the aorta were within limits. Patent foramen ovale and ductus arteriosus were also present with a hemodynamically not significant left-to-right shunt. Follow-up echocardiography at 5 months showed aortic dilation progressing to 18 mm. Evaluation at 7 months showed aortic dilation stabilizing at 20 mm. The latest evaluation at 13 months showed dilation progressing to 24.5 mm."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 9-year-old girl from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a persistent wet cough that had begun immediately after birth. Three months prior to her visit to the respiratory outpatient clinic, she had received empirical treatment with antibiotics and antihistamines, but her symptoms did not improve. She was able to expectorate sputum on her own and noticed that it had a bright yellow, serous quality.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were reported in the given information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no history of trauma, and her past medical history was unremarkable.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were reported in the given information."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 9-year-old girl from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a persistent wet cough that had begun immediately after birth. Three months prior to her visit to the respiratory outpatient clinic, she had received empirical treatment with antibiotics and antihistamines, but her symptoms did not improve. She was able to expectorate sputum on her own and noticed that it had a bright yellow, serous quality.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were reported in the given information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no history of trauma, and her past medical history was unremarkable.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were reported in the given information.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Chest computed tomography scan revealed abnormal bronchial bifurcation originating in the right main bronchus. Bronchoscopy showed yellow, serous secretions from an anomalous orifice in the medial side of the right intermediate bronchus. Fistulography revealed contrast material slowly proceeding to the hepatic region. An immediate follow-up computed tomography scan revealed a small amount of air and contrast material remaining in the liver. Technetium-99m scintigraphy showed that most of the radionuclide had accumulated in the normal biliary pathway and a small amount had accumulated in the fistula."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 14-month-old orphan male infant. He was delivered by caesarian section at 38 weeks and weighed 3080 g. The patient's geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The infant was consulted in 2016 due to bilateral corneal masses. Corneal opacities were present at admission to the orphanage. The patient was diagnosed with Fetal Valproate Syndrome (FVSD) a few weeks after birth due to several congenital anomalies. The patient had bilateral vascularized dome-shaped corneal tumors, distinctly larger on the right side, protruding through the right palpebral fissure. The tumors were opaque salmon-colored and felt soft and cystic on palpation. There was no intralesional hair, and the rest of the conjunctival surfaces were normal. The limbus was spared in both eyes. The ocular fundi could not be visualized. The diagnosis of grade III corneal dermoids was made. A conservative approach was adopted by prescribing lubricants due to high risks associated with general anesthesia and no potential for useful vision. The patient was seen twice in 2017 and 2019 without any progression in corneal tumors. At the most recent visit in June 2021, both corneal dermoids, particularly the right corneal tumor, had regressed significantly. The posterior segment findings were stable.",

  "Physical Examination": "The newborn had trigonocephaly, flat nose bridge and small upturned nose, cleft palate and lip, micrognathia, bilateral radial defects and club hands, pes equinovarus, and hypospadias. On ocular examination, there were bilateral vascularized dome-shaped corneal tumors, distinctly larger on the right side, protruding through the right palpebral fissure. The tumors were opaque salmon-colored and felt soft and cystic on palpation. There was no intralesional hair, and the rest of the conjunctival surfaces were normal. The limbus was spared in both eyes.",

  "Past Medical History": "Based on the limited information available on the prenatal history, the mother had epilepsy and regularly took Valproic Acid (VPA) throughout her pregnancy. The baby was abandoned to an orphanage after being discharged from the maternity ward.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Cytogenetic analyses were normal. B-mode ocular ultrasonography revealed bilateral dense vitreal opacities, probably representing a developmental vitreoretinal abnormality, which was more pronounced in the left eye."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient was a 56-year-old man. Notable demographic details include a history of working as a fisherman and a geographic location consistent with a drug dealing district. The environmental temperature at the time of discovery was 16.5°C.",

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 17-year-old female weighing 65.5 kg. She is from a community with access to both a community emergency department and a tertiary pediatric center.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented via ambulance to a community emergency department (ED) one hour after ingesting some drug with suicidal intent. Initially, she was asymptomatic with normal mental status. She denied co-ingestions. No symptoms nor signs of salicylism were observed. A sodium bicarbonate infusion was initiated given the salicylate concentration, and she was transferred to a tertiary pediatric center. At the tertiary ED, she developed dizziness and blurry vision. Bicarbonate therapy was stopped and the patient was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). Eleven hours after ingestion, the patient became agitated and developed 20 minutes of sustained wide complex tachycardia (WCT) with intact perfusion. She had 30 seconds of rigidity to her bilateral upper extremities and leftward gaze preference that spontaneously resolved. Calcium gluconate (2 g) was administered due to the known low ionized calcium. Lipid emulsion therapy (LET; Intralipid 20%) was administered empirically (0.25 mg/kg) as prophylaxis against recurrent toxicity. By about 13 hours post-ingestion, her mental status, arterial-venous oxygen difference and lactic acidosis improved. Her EKG showed normal sinus rhythm.",

  "Physical Examination": "At the community ED, the patient had normal vital signs and a normal physical exam. Later, she developed 20 minutes of sustained wide complex tachycardia (WCT) with intact perfusion. She also experienced 30 seconds of rigidity to her bilateral upper extremities and leftward gaze preference that spontaneously resolved.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of depression.",

  "Initial Test Results": "At the community ED, serum studies reported hyperchloremia (132 mmol/L), normal bicarbonate (28 mmol/L), an anion gap of 20, and an elevated salicylate concentration (115 mg/dL). At the tertiary ED, repeat testing showed a whole blood (WB) chloride of 145 mmol/L, a serum chloride of 110 mmol/L, and undetectable salicylates. Her ionized calcium (iCa) was low at 0.9 mmol/L. Later laboratory testing demonstrated elevated venous oxygen saturation (92%) and serum lactate (5.9 mmol/L), and narrowed arterial-venous oxygen difference (5%)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male infant born at 35+1 weeks of gestational age by Cesarean section delivery. His birth weight was 2,000 g (between the 3rd and 10th percentiles), indicating he was small for gestational age. The patient's parents and elder brother are healthy, and his parents are not close relatives.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "Prenatal oligohydramnios was discovered at 28+4 weeks of gestational age. Three days before delivery, the amniotic fluid index and the maximum depth reduced to 47 and 28 mm, respectively. The infant presented with dysmorphic facial features, including a characteristic triangular appearance, a broad forehead, a pointed chin, and a bulbous tip of the nose. His hair and eyebrows were extremely sparse. The infant failed to thrive and had poor sucking and weight gain. He was admitted to a local hospital at 1 month and placed on an amino acid formula, which failed to improve weight gain. At 3 months, he was admitted to another hospital and placed on a high calorific formula, which improved weight gain from 4 to 6 months. However, from 7 months, his appetite and weight gain deteriorated again. At 9 months, his weight was 7.4 kg (8%, between 3rd and 10th percentiles), body length 67.5 cm (8%, between 3rd and 10th percentiles), and head circumference 43 cm (11%, 10th percentiles). At 1.5 years, his weight was 8.2 kg (less than 3rd percentile) with a body length of 76 cm (less than 3rd percentile). The infant showed impaired motor development. At 9 months (corrected gestational age: 8 months), he could turn over confidently and sit steady but could not climb. At 1.5 years, he could only take a few steps on his own and pronounce 'baba, mama' but not other words or sentences. The baby could not regulate his body temperature well and could not sweat before 7 months of age. He presented with fever in outdoor summer environments, which normalized in the shade. This phenomenon stopped after a sudden sweat at about 7 months, after which he could regulate his body temperature normally.",

  "Physical Examination": "The infant had dysmorphic facial features, including a characteristic triangular appearance, a broad forehead, a pointed chin, and a bulbous tip of the nose. His hair and eyebrows were extremely sparse.",

  "Past Medical History": "The infant's mother received regular antepartum examinations during pregnancy. The infant suffered from chronic renal function damage since birth, initially characterized by elevated serum levels of creatinine. He had stage 5 CKD at birth, which improved to stage 3 from 9 months to 1.5 years.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The Apgar score was 10 at 1, 5, and 10 min after birth. At 3 months (corrected gestational age: 2 months), the Bayley Scales of Infant Development II (BSID-II) Motor Scale and the Peabody Developmental Motor Scale II (PDMS-2) showed mildly low scores: Gross Motor Quotient (GMQ) of 87, Fine Motor Quotient (FMQ) of 82, Total Motor Quotient (TMQ) of 83, and Psychomotor Development Index (PDI) of 84. On day 3 after birth, liver function tests showed increased total bilirubin (131.2 µmol/L), direct bilirubin (22.2 µmol/L), glutamyl transpeptidase (598 U/L), and alkaline phosphatase (324 U/L). At 1 month, elevated levels of alanine transaminase (61 U/L), aspartate aminotransferase (86 U/L), total bile acid (109 µmol/L), and phosphorus (3.22 mmol/L) were evident. At 3 months, elevated triglycerides (2.21 mmol/L) were noted. At 6 months, elevated cholesterol (8.88 mmol/L) was observed. Blood routine tests, TORCH, viral hepatitis tests, autoantibody tests, plasma amino acids, and urine organic acid profile were normal. Abdominal ultrasound revealed bilateral hypodysplastic kidneys. Cardiac ultrasound showed no obvious abnormalities."
}"

Family genetic testing confirmed this as a de novo mutation. Transcriptomic sequencing verified that the c.5930-2A > G variant led to the skipping of exon 33, altering NOTCH2 mRNA splicing. Whole exome sequencing (WES) found no other genetic mutations matching the patient's phenotype beyond the NOTCH2 mutation."

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 40-year-old female.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with complaints of abdominal pain for one month. She also experienced several episodes of non-projectile vomiting. Following the initial diagnosis and imaging, the patient underwent a diagnostic hepatic vein venography procedure, which confirmed the imaging findings. Subsequently, hepatic vein stenting was performed successfully. The right internal jugular vein was used for gaining venous access. A balloon-expanding stent of size 8 x 37 mm was used for the procedure.",

  "Physical Examination": "On examination, there was mild tenderness in the epigastric and right hypochondriac region. The liver was palpable below the subcostal margin, indicative of hepatomegaly.",

  "Past Medical History": "",

  "Initial Test Results": "On grayscale ultrasound examination, heterogeneous echotexture was seen in the liver and a fibrous cord was noted replacing the middle hepatic vein along with the presence of mild ascites. On color Doppler, no color flow was noted in hepatic veins."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "On contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) scan, no contrast opacification was noted in the middle and left hepatic veins and partial opacification was noted in the right hepatic vein, indicative of complete thrombosis of middle and left hepatic veins and partial thrombosis of the right hepatic vein associated with slit-like visualization of the hepatic part of IVC. A slight enlargement of the caudate lobe was noted. The liver showed a heterogeneous mottled appearance (nutmeg liver). The patient underwent a diagnostic hepatic vein venography procedure, which confirmed the imaging findings."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a two-month-old male infant from a mixed family (Romanian mother and Syrian father). He was born at 38 weeks of pregnancy via cesarean section due to intrauterine growth restriction. His birth weight was 2260 g (−2.4 SD, <p1%), length was 43 cm (−3.5 SD, <p1%), and head circumference was 30 cm (−3.5 SD, <p1%). The Apgar scores were nine at 1 minute and ten at 5 minutes.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The infant was admitted to the Pediatrics Department for feeding difficulties and growth failure. He had been fed with a special milk formula for premature infants since birth, but the daily intake was poor (only 300 mL), resulting in below-normal weight gain (600 g in six weeks). At two months old, the infant was dystrophic with a weight of 2710 g (Z score −3.12). The infant presented with facial dysmorphism including hypertelorism, microphthalmia, eyelid ptosis, mongoloid slant and bilateral blepharophimosis, anteverted nostrils, long philtrum, micrognathia, and low-set dysplastic posteriorly rotated ears. Other constitutional anomalies included presacral fossa, cleft palate, clinodactyly of the fifth finger of both hands, abnormally implanted toes, and syndactyly of the third and fourth toes of the left foot. Umbilical and right inguinoscrotal hernias were also observed. Neurologic examination indicated global developmental delay.",

  "Physical Examination": "Clinical examination at birth revealed dysmorphic facial features (hypertelorism, microphthalmia, mongoloid palpebral fissures, microretrognathia, and long philtrum), membranous partial cleft palate, low-set ears, and prominent occiput. The infant also had an umbilical and inguinal hernia, syndactyly of the third and fourth digits of the feet, fifth digit clinodactyly, floating testicles, axial hypotonia, and limb hypertonia.",

  "Past Medical History": "During pregnancy, intrauterine growth restriction, oligohydramnios, and ventriculomegaly were diagnosed. The mother was monitored for these conditions. In the first trimester, combined screening for aneuploidy and preeclampsia indicated a low risk of their development. A fetal MRI was performed, which also indicated suspicion of a cleft palate.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The cardiological evaluation revealed an atrial septal defect with a small left-to-right shunt without hemodynamic impact. Ophthalmologic examination established the diagnosis of severe bilateral eyelid ptosis that required surgical treatment and hypermetropia that required postoperative optical correction."
}"

In the first trimester, combined screening for aneuploidy and preeclampsia indicated a low risk of their development. A fetal MRI was performed, which also indicated suspicion of a cleft palate.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The cardiological evaluation revealed an atrial septal defect with a small left-to-right shunt without hemodynamic impact. Ophthalmologic examination established the diagnosis of severe bilateral eyelid ptosis that required surgical treatment and hypermetropia that required postoperative optical correction.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A cerebral CT scan was conducted and revealed asymmetric lateral ventricles. Blood samples for microarray testing were obtained, with results being normal and without any significant copy number variations identified. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "Two brothers, aged 18 and 8 years, with Pediatric Intestinal Pseudo-obstruction (PIPO) were referred to a medical facility. They are from a country where introducing solid foods around 2 years of age is a common practice.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The older brother had normal prenatal history and development. He developed chronic constipation upon introducing solid foods around age 2. He preferred milk and resisted oral food. His condition worsened over time, leading to growth failure, although he remained active and participated in swimming. At 14 years, he experienced acute volvulus of the large intestine requiring right hemicolectomy. Shortly after, he had a small bowel obstruction requiring partial resection and ileostomy. He became mostly intolerant of oral food intake and dependent on exclusive total parenteral nutrition (TPN) via a central line. He would place a nasogastric tube as needed for decompression. Over time, he has been able to tolerate some oral food while still receiving the majority of his caloric intake parenterally. The younger brother developed PIPO at age 6, with a similar infantile course. He also experienced acute volvulus of the large intestine requiring right hemicolectomy, followed by small bowel obstruction requiring partial small bowel resection and ileostomy, becoming TPN-dependent around age 14. He develops enuresis when receiving too much fluid and suffers from vitamin D deficiency and osteopenia. While able to consume food, most of his nutrition is provided by TPN. Both brothers were treated with pyridostigmine, starting at low doses (10 mg daily) and increasing to 80 mg TID. Initially, both seemed to benefit from it, experiencing less abdominal distension, increased oral intake, and higher ostomy output.",

  "Physical Examination": "Antroduodenal manometry performed on the older brother at age 18 revealed a mixed myopathic and neuropathic motility disorder, with low amplitude contractions and a lack of motor migrating complexes. The younger brother underwent antroduodenal manometry at age 8, which revealed a very similar motility pattern to that of his older brother.",

  "Past Medical History": "The mother, maternal aunts, and maternal grandmother have had severe childhood-onset constipation requiring large amounts of laxatives. The father reportedly had chronic diarrhea and nephrolithiasis and died at age 50 due to lung cancer. The younger brother has been on anticoagulant therapy due to a history of central-line-related thrombosis.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Biopsies performed on the older brother at an outside hospital showed hypertrophy of the muscularis mucosa and lamina propria, mucosal atrophy, and normal ganglion cells in the small and remnant large intestine."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "Two brothers, aged 18 and 8 years, with Pediatric Intestinal Pseudo-obstruction (PIPO) were referred to a medical facility. They are from a country where introducing solid foods around 2 years of age is a common practice.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The older brother had normal prenatal history and development. He developed chronic constipation upon introducing solid foods around age 2. He preferred milk and resisted oral food. His condition worsened over time, leading to growth failure, although he remained active and participated in swimming. At 14 years, he experienced acute volvulus of the large intestine requiring right hemicolectomy. Shortly after, he had a small bowel obstruction requiring partial resection and ileostomy. He became mostly intolerant of oral food intake and dependent on exclusive total parenteral nutrition (TPN) via a central line. He would place a nasogastric tube as needed for decompression. Over time, he has been able to tolerate some oral food while still receiving the majority of his caloric intake parenterally. The younger brother developed PIPO at age 6, with a similar infantile course. He also experienced acute volvulus of the large intestine requiring right hemicolectomy, followed by small bowel obstruction requiring partial small bowel resection and ileostomy, becoming TPN-dependent around age 14. He develops enuresis when receiving too much fluid and suffers from vitamin D deficiency and osteopenia. While able to consume food, most of his nutrition is provided by TPN. Both brothers were treated with pyridostigmine, starting at low doses (10 mg daily) and increasing to 80 mg TID. Initially, both seemed to benefit from it, experiencing less abdominal distension, increased oral intake, and higher ostomy output.",

  "Physical Examination": "Antroduodenal manometry performed on the older brother at age 18 revealed a mixed myopathic and neuropathic motility disorder, with low amplitude contractions and a lack of motor migrating complexes. The younger brother underwent antroduodenal manometry at age 8, which revealed a very similar motility pattern to that of his older brother.",

  "Past Medical History": "The mother, maternal aunts, and maternal grandmother have had severe childhood-onset constipation requiring large amounts of laxatives. The father reportedly had chronic diarrhea and nephrolithiasis and died at age 50 due to lung cancer. The younger brother has been on anticoagulant therapy due to a history of central-line-related thrombosis.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Biopsies performed on the older brother at an outside hospital showed hypertrophy of the muscularis mucosa and lamina propria, mucosal atrophy, and normal ganglion cells in the small and remnant large intestine.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Genome sequencing (GS) was performed on DNA extracted from whole-blood samples collected from the mother and the two brothers. The data were aligned according to the Human Reference Genome (GRCh37/hg19) and analyzed using the Strelka caller for single nucleotide variants and Canvas caller for copy number variants. Expansions of short tandem repeats were identified using ExpansionHunter. Immunohistochemistry was performed on paraffin-embedded intestinal tissues from the brothers, using specific antibodies against ACTG2, neurofilament, and smooth muscle actin α2 (ACTA2). All sections were counterstained with hematoxylin. Images were taken with the NanoZoomer 2.0-HT and analyzed with the NanoZoomer Digital Pathology viewer software."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is an 11-year-old girl who presented to a paediatric ophthalmology clinic in November 2018. She had undergone kidney transplantation at age 5 in another country.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented for an ophthalmic evaluation. She had nystagmus since birth and bilateral high myopia (-7 -2 *180). At age 2, she had undergone cataract extraction with posterior chamber IOL implantation. Initially, her vision was 20/200 unaided in both eyes. After 16 months, she was referred from the emergency department with a complaint of pain in her left eye. Visual acuity examination showed no light perception in the left eye. The left eye had spontaneous subtotal hyphaemia and intraocular pressure of 25mmHg. Despite treatment, her intraocular pressure increased to 55mmHg. An anterior chamber wash was performed, and the intraocular pressure decreased to the 24–26 mmHg range, but without any improvement in the visual acuity. She experienced another episode of hyphema, but the intraocular pressure remained stable.",

  "Physical Examination": "Bilateral ocular findings were as follows: nystagmus, full ocular motility, posterior chamber IOL, band keratopathy, normal pupillary reflex, tessellated fundus with macular hypoplasia and retinal thinning, optic nerve atrophy, and intraocular pressure of 18mmHg. Cycloplegic refraction values were − 1.75*25 for the right eye and + 1.25*155 for the left eye. Later examination of the left eye showed spontaneous subtotal hyphaemia and intraocular pressure of 25mmHg. The iris showed neovascularisation.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of nephrotic syndrome diagnosed at 16 months of age. She had undergone kidney transplantation at age 5. She had been receiving dual immunosuppression with mycophenolate and tacrolimus (250 and 500 mg and 2 mg, in the morning and evening, respectively) along with vitamin B complex, folic acid, and thyroxin for her hypothyroidism. She had no history of trauma to the left eye.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Intraocular pressure was initially 18mmHg in both eyes, later increasing to 25mmHg and then 55mmHg in the left eye. Bloodwork-up showed a coagulation profile of INR 1.06, APTT 29.4 s, and PT 15.7 s. Other blood test results included: tacrolimus level of 5.3 µg/L, Urea 4.6 mmol/L, Creatinine 114 mol/l, Albumin 41 g/L, TSH 7.1 mU/L, and Glomerular Filtration Rate 49 ml/min/1.73m2."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 75-year-old woman from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the hospital with progressive right knee pain and severe genu valgum. Her ambulation was limited due to right knee pain and instability, requiring bilateral knee braces and T-canes. The appearance of her lower extremities revealed severe genu valgum, which was uncorrected by manual stress. She was unaware of her bilateral dislocation condition. Total knee arthroplasty (TKA) was planned to treat severe osteoarthritis (OA), and both proximal and distal realignments were planned to treat patellar dislocation with permanence (PDP). The operation was performed under general anesthesia. Rehabilitation involved the same protocol as conventional TKA with progressive continuous passive motion, weight-bearing as tolerated, ambulation, and isometric quadriceps exercises on postoperative day 1. On postoperative day 2, she walked on full weight-bearing as tolerated and performed passive range of motion (ROM) exercises. The patient was discharged for further rehabilitation on postoperative day 21. At 1-year follow-up, annual follow-up, and the latest follow-up (5 years), her condition and ROM were reassessed. At the 5-year follow-up, her ambulation had improved without a knee brace.",

  "Physical Examination": "Manual muscle testing showed grade 3/4 on the right and left knees. The range of motion (ROM) was 20°-150°, and the patella was laterally dislocated during knee flexion. On long-leg anteroposterior weight-bearing radiographs, she demonstrated severe genu valgum of the right knee with a hip-knee-ankle angle (HKAa) of valgus 29.0°, grade IV osteoarthritic changes in the lateral femorotibial compartment according to the Kellgren-Lawrence classification, and laterally dislocated patella. The lateral radiograph demonstrated dysplasia of the lateral femoral condyle. Radiographs on the skyline view at 30°, 60°, and 90° demonstrated the dysplasia of the trochlea with a sulcus angle of 150° and laterally located patella. Computed tomography of the knee revealed a tibial tuberosity to trochlear groove distance of 41.3 mm. The preoperative knee score was 20/30, and the functional score was 60/60 on the right and left knees, respectively. During the operation, the patella was found to be very small (10 mm) and thin (6 mm), with little articular cartilage.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient underwent orthotic treatment for left congenital dislocation of the hip at birth, total hip arthroplasty for ipsilateral hip OA at the age of 55 years, and revision surgery for aseptic loosening of the cup at the age of 69 years. She had no history of trauma or knee surgery.",

  "Initial Test Results": "There were no remarkable laboratory tests, suggesting the absence of rheumatoid arthritis. On postoperative day 21, the ROM was 10°-110°, and the long-leg anteroposterior radiograph exhibited HKAa of valgus 16° and valgus 16° on the right and left knees, respectively."
}"

At the latest follow-up (5 years), the ROM of the affected knee was 10°-135°, with an extension lag of 10°. Radiographs showed no evidence of loosening or fracture and HKAa of valgus 11° and valgus 17° on the right and left knees, respectively. The postoperative Knee Society Knee score and Function score improved to 60/50 and 85/85 on the right and left knees, respectively."
}"

Cases.Final Name: Congenital primary megaureter, refluxing and obstructed form
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 2-year-old girl from Indonesia, as the case mentions Hasan Sadikin Hospital, which is located in Indonesia.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a lump in her stomach that has been getting bigger since birth, accompanied by pain, especially in the left side of the abdomen. The abdomen was found to be enlarged, particularly on the left side. The patient underwent multiple radiological examinations over the course of several months. These included Abdominal Ultrasonography (US), CT urography, MRI, and Voiding Cystoureterography (VCUG). The US revealed a cystic mass with septation in the abdomen, accompanied by pelvocalyectasis of the left kidney. CT urography showed multiple cystic masses in the upper to lower abdomen with pelvocalyectasis of the left kidney. The CT Scan 3D Urography did not visualize the normal structure of the kidney and left ureter. The T2WI MRI sequence showed a thick-walled cystic mass resembling a tortuous tubular structure connected with the pelvicalyceal system without any distal obstruction. VCUG examination found no reflux. The patient underwent surgery at the age of 4 years old, which included cystoscopy followed by nephroureterectomy. Cystoscopy revealed a normal right ureteral opening and no left ureteral opening. Nephroureterectomy showed an enlarged, tortuous left ureter with the smallest diameter of approximately 1 cm and the largest diameter of approximately 5 cm.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination at the pediatric clinic revealed an enlarged abdomen, especially on the left side.",

  "Past Medical History": "No specific past medical history was provided in the given information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory examinations in the form of routine blood tests were performed, but specific results were not provided in the given information. After surgery, a urine culture was performed, and the results showed no bacteria."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 14-year-old boy under foster care. His height is 146 cm (<3rd percentile) and BMI is 15.5 kg/m2. He has normal blood pressure.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the genetics clinic due to hypospadia, cryptorchidism, aortic coarctation, and short stature. He has a webbed neck, posteriorly rotated ears, low-set hairline, multiple facial nevi, Blaschko lines on his back, anterior hypospadia, hyperpigmented scrotum, and scarring tissue on genitals. A palpable right testicle was noted. The patient had undergone multiple surgical procedures previously, but no medical records were available. The case was taken up by the Development and Sexual Differentiation Disorders Clinic at a university hospital where the possibility of the presence of testicular tissue was discussed.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient has a height of 146 cm (<3rd percentile) and a BMI of 15.5 kg/m2. Normal blood pressure was recorded. Physical examination revealed a webbed neck, posteriorly rotated ears, low-set hairline, multiple facial nevi, Blaschko lines on the back, anterior hypospadia, hyperpigmented scrotum, scarring tissue on genitals, and a palpable right testicle.",

  "Past Medical History": "There is no information available regarding the patient's familial or prenatal history due to his foster care status. The patient had undergone multiple surgical procedures previously, but no medical records were available.",

  "Initial Test Results": "A previous karyotype (25 metaphases analyzed) with a resolution <400 bands was reported as normal. A new G banding karyotype with 600 bands was performed (20 metaphases analyzed), showing a mosaicism 45,X [13]/46,XY [7]. A complete spinal X-ray showed a lumbar scoliosis of 4°. An audiometry and a kidney-ureter-bladder ultrasound showed no abnormal findings. A testicular ultrasound revealed a 2.1 × 1 × 0.9 cm right testicle (volume 1.7 cm3) without focal lesions, and a cyst in the spermatic cord."
}"

Intraoral examination reveals early mixed dentition, anterior and bilateral cross bite, centred midlines, and anterior crowding in the upper arch.",

Intraoral examination reveals early mixed dentition, anterior and bilateral cross bite, centred midlines, and anterior crowding in the upper arch.",

  "Past Medical History": "The anamnesis is negative for congenital heart defects and neurocognitive disabilities. No ocular problems such as strabismus and ophthalmoplegia are evident. No food or drug allergies are reported.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient's orthopanoramic X-ray shows all buds of permanent teeth are present. In the upper arch, there is a risk of canine inclusion due to lack of adequate space for their eruption.
