  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient's general state of health is good with regular psychomotor development. He presents with some clinical characteristics such as a round face with broad forehead, low set ears, and ocular hypertelorism. The patient has broad and short hands with short, stubby fingers. Intraoral examination reveals early mixed dentition, anterior and bilateral cross bite, centred midlines, and anterior crowding in the upper arch.",

  "Physical Examination": "Extraoral examination shows short stature, a round face with broad forehead, low set ears, and ocular hypertelorism. The patient has broad and short hands with short, stubby fingers. Intraoral examination reveals early mixed dentition, anterior and bilateral cross bite, centred midlines, and anterior crowding in the upper arch.",

  "Past Medical History": "The anamnesis is negative for congenital heart defects and neurocognitive disabilities. No ocular problems such as strabismus and ophthalmoplegia are evident. No food or drug allergies are reported.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient's orthopanoramic X-ray shows all buds of permanent teeth are present. In the upper arch, there is a risk of canine inclusion due to lack of adequate space for their eruption. The radiological investigation also reveals an undefined dental anatomy and dimension of the superior lateral incisors. Cephalometry analysis diagnoses a skeletal class III in a hyperdivergent, biretrused patient with a growth pattern of clockwise mandibular rotation and mandibular asymmetry.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": ""
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 4-year-old individual assigned female at birth. The patient's parents are non-consanguineous.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient visited the genetic outpatient clinic for ambiguous genitalia and skeletal dysplasia. The patient was born via cesarean delivery and had a cleft palate, which was corrected at 4 months. The patient exhibited moderate developmental delay, characterized by being able to stand at 1 year of age and walk at 3 years of age after constant physiotherapy. At birth, the physicians described the appearance of external female genitalia. The patient had moderate conductive bilateral hearing loss, which was corrected with hearing aids.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination of the head revealed trigonocephaly, a protruding frontal region, almond-shaped eyes with antimongoloid deviation, a flat nasal bridge, a long philtrum, retromicrognathia, and a short neck. Limb malformations were observed, including prominent hips, shortening of the right lower limb, valgus knees, and rhizomelic arms.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a cleft palate, which was corrected at 4 months of age. The patient underwent constant physiotherapy for developmental delay.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Radiography of the head revealed a vertebral fusion between C5 and C6. Radiography of the limbs revealed femur bowing, an underdeveloped acetabulum, and a femoral head. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed ovaries, a small uterus, and shortened vagina. Hormone analysis showed increased testosterone, luteinizing hormone, and follicle-stimulating hormone levels. A peripheral blood karyotype reported a 46XY with a positive SRY gene."
}"

The patient was born via cesarean delivery and had a cleft palate, which was corrected at 4 months. The patient exhibited moderate developmental delay, characterized by being able to stand at 1 year of age and walk at 3 years of age after constant physiotherapy. At birth, the physicians described the appearance of external female genitalia. The patient had moderate conductive bilateral hearing loss, which was corrected with hearing aids.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination of the head revealed trigonocephaly, a protruding frontal region, almond-shaped eyes with antimongoloid deviation, a flat nasal bridge, a long philtrum, retromicrognathia, and a short neck. Limb malformations were observed, including prominent hips, shortening of the right lower limb, valgus knees, and rhizomelic arms.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a cleft palate, which was corrected at 4 months of age. The patient underwent constant physiotherapy for developmental delay.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Radiography of the head revealed a vertebral fusion between C5 and C6. Radiography of the limbs revealed femur bowing, an underdeveloped acetabulum, and a femoral head. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed ovaries, a small uterus, and shortened vagina. Hormone analysis showed increased testosterone, luteinizing hormone, and follicle-stimulating hormone levels. A peripheral blood karyotype reported a 46XY with a positive SRY gene.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Brain magnetic resonance imaging showed Arnold–Chiari malformation type 1. Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) was performed on the mother, father, and patient. The sequencing identified 1,582 variants causing non-synonymous, stop-gain, and frameshift changes. After filtering, one nonsense heterozygote variant in the SOX9 gene of the patient was detected. The pathogenic variant was caused by a guanine to adenine change at the 344 bp (c.G344A), resulting in a tryptophan to a premature stop codon change at position 115 (p.Trp115*) of the HMG domain. The frequency of this variant was 0 in the Genome Aggregation Database and Exome Aggregation Consortium databases and was not reported in the Ensembl genome and ClinVar databases. The parents did not have the nonsense variant and were homozygous for the reference allele (G)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "This female patient was born at term (37 weeks and 5 days gestational age) with a birth weight of 2550 g by Cesarean section for breech presentation. The pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. Family history was unremarkable, and parents denied consanguinity.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "At birth, the patient was noted to have multiple congenital abnormalities, including syndactyly of the right and left 3rd, 4th, and 5th toes, telecanthus, anteriorly displaced and imperforate anus, bilateral hydronephrosis, ano-vaginal fistula, tethered spinal cord, left sensorineural hearing loss, clitoromegaly, accessory nipple, and bilateral club feet. Additional diagnostic studies revealed a ventricular septal defect and patent ductus arteriosus which closed without intervention. She was also found to have hydrocephalus but did not require a shunt placement. The patient underwent the following surgical procedures: release of tethered spinal cord at 3 months, repair of ano-vaginal fistula at 4 months, laparoscopic Ladd's procedure with appendectomy for intestinal malrotation noted at 6 months, and ileostomy and multiple surgical revisions for neurogenic bladder and bowel at 4 years of age. An ophthalmological examination at age 7 months noted mild telecanthus and pigment mottling in the macula of both eyes. Follow-up examinations at 1 year and 2 years of age, observed similar bilateral pigmentary changes in the macula. The patient presented at our institution at 5 years of age for ophthalmological examination with visual acuity of 20/200 in the right eye and 20/160 in the left eye with correction. Cycloplegic refraction was −3.50 + 4.50 × 095 in the right eye and −3.25 + 3.75 × 080 in the left eye. Microarray analysis revealed a likely pathogenic 150 kilobase deletion of chromosome Xq28 (arr[hg19] Xq28(152,834,159–152,984,574)x1) containing 6 genes including FAM58A, which established the diagnosis of STAR syndrome. The parents did not have the same mutation.",
  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination during the 5-year ophthalmological visit showed an external examination revealing mild telecanthus, and an anterior segment examination that was normal in both eyes. Intraocular pressure was 14 mmHg in the right eye and 15 mmHg in the left eye. On posterior segment examination, the optic nerves were normal without evidence of optic nerve hypoplasia.",
  "Past Medical History": "Family history was unremarkable, and the parents denied consanguinity. The patient has had multiple congenital abnormalities since birth and various surgeries to address these issues.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Initial tests included an ophthalmological examination at age 7 months which noted mild telecanthus and pigment mottling in the macula of both eyes. Follow-up examinations at 1 year and 2 years of age showed similar bilateral pigmentary changes in the macula. At the 5-year visit: Cycloplegic refraction revealed −3.50 + 4.50 × 095 in the right eye and −3.25 + 3.75 × 080 in the left eye. Intraocular pressure was 14 mmHg in the right eye and 15 mmHg in the left eye."
}"

OCT angiography showed normal vessel density and normal foveal avascular zone in both eyes. Oral fluorescein angiography exhibited staining in areas of atrophy in both eyes. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a woman in her 50s from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented to the emergency department with urinary retention and perianal pain. She had a history of faecal incontinence since childhood. Three months after neurostimulator removal, she returned to the ED with intense perineal pain lasting 24 hours. Two weeks later, she presented with abdominal pain for 2 days without associated symptoms like fever, nausea, vomiting, or change in bowel habits. Three days after discharge, she returned to the ED with abdominal pain and urinary retention. Following surgery, the patient's symptoms disappeared. She no longer complained of abdominal or perianal pain, and there were no more episodes of urinary retention. After 6 months of follow-up, she remained asymptomatic.",

  "Physical Examination": "Initial perineal inspection revealed induration of the perianal skin at 07:00 hours in lithotomy position. Digital rectal examination showed anal stenosis without tenderness or bulging. Pelvic examination showed posterior vaginal wall tenderness and a small opening draining purulent exudate. Three months later, examination revealed a perianal orifice at 07:00 hours in the lithotomy position, compatible with the external opening of a fistula-in-ano. Two weeks after that, she showed hypogastric tenderness. Three days later, apart from hypogastric tenderness, physical examination was unremarkable.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of imperforate anus repaired during the neonatal period. In her 40s, after failure of multiple conservative treatments for incontinence, she underwent a dynamic graciloplasty. Due to anal pain, she stopped using the electrostimulatory system 3 years after the surgery. Both imperforate anus repair and dynamic graciloplasty took place in another institution.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Complete blood count and blood chemistry tests were normal on multiple occasions. An initial abdominal CT scan revealed a fluid collection extending from the electrostimulator to the left side of the rectouterine pouch. A subsequent CT scan showed a pelvic fluid collection posterior to the vagina and the uterus measuring 13×9 cm. Two weeks later, another CT scan showed recurrence of the fluid collection posterior to the vagina and the uterus, now measuring 11.5×8×7 cm."
}"

A diagnostic laparoscopy was performed, revealing a cystic lesion in the pelvis. The cyst was filled with serous fluid and its internal surface was lined with what appeared to be colonic mucosa. Histopathological analysis of the surgical specimen confirmed the diagnosis, though the specific diagnosis was not mentioned in the provided information."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male who was first evaluated at 11 months of age, and then again at 4 years and 16 years. He was brought from an orphanage for consultation.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was initially referred for evaluation and testing for growth retardation and hypotonia at 11 months. At 4 years, he was assessed for development, walking defects, and absence of language. There is severe delay of postnatal development and microcephaly is present. Postnatal growth and development are far behind for his age. The patient achieved independent walking by 26 months of age and presented mild hypotonia during infancy. He pronounced his first word at the age of 4. At 16, his language is very poor, limited to only six simple words. He communicates with non-verbal gestures and vocalizations. He can assist with dressing and feeding himself but otherwise depends on his maternal assistant's support. The patient had an episode of unprovoked, generalized tonic-clonic seizures at 6 months, which were controlled with anticonvulsants (phenobarbital). EEGs at 4 years of age were normal, in both the awake and drowsy states, and no seizure activity was present. Cognitive abilities were deficient with a developmental quotient (IQ) of 21, with the major delay occurring in speech. He could not attend school due to lack of language but followed cognitive stimulation therapies.",

  "Physical Examination": "Facial features include high forehead, frontal bossing, high frontal hairline, hypertelorism, high arched eyebrows, a wide nasal bridge, short philtrum, micro-retrognathia, and low set ears. Skeletal anomalies include scoliosis, small hands and feet, brachydactyly, clinodactyly, and tapering fingers. There is slight cutaneous syndactyly between the second and third toe. The dermatoglyphic pattern shows absent thenar crease and a short hypoplastic mid-palmar crease. The fifth finger has a single flexion crease on its volar surface. Dental oral anomalies include downturned corners of the large mouth, a high-arched palate, delayed dental eruption, multiple caries, residual roots, enamel hypoplasia, and gingivitis. The right superior central incisor is insufficiently erupted and rotated mesially, both incisors have slight palatoversion, and there is transposition between the left lateral incisor and canine. The patient has an open bite and the median line is deviated to the right. Agenesis of third inferior molars is present. Clinical and ultrasound examinations of other organs and systems were normal.",

  "Past Medical History": "No family history is available as the patient was brought from an orphanage. The patient had an episode of unprovoked, generalized tonic-clonic seizures at 6 months, which were controlled with anticonvulsants (phenobarbital).",

  "Initial Test Results": "Growth parameters at 11 months: G=5700g, T=65cm PC=42cm (SD: −3.54 for waist, −4.4 for weight, −3.25 for cranial perimeter). At 4 years: G=12.3kg, T=91cm PC=47cm (SD: −2.68 for waist, −2.46 for weight, −2.27 for PC). At 16 years: G=47kg, T=148cm PC=51 (SD: −2.94 for waist, −1.54 for weight, −2.75 for PC). EEGs at 4 years of age were normal. X-ray examination of hands at 11 months and 16 years revealed the relative shortness of tubular bones, especially of distal and middle phalanges. The Simon–Binnet test determined a severe intellectual disability with a developmental quotient (IQ) of 21."
}"

  "Initial Test Results": "Growth parameters at 11 months: G=5700g, T=65cm PC=42cm (SD: −3.54 for waist, −4.4 for weight, −3.25 for cranial perimeter).   "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Chromosome Analysis and Fluorescent In Situ Hybridization (FISH) were performed. At 11 months, cytogenetic evaluation revealed a mosaic karyotype: 46,XY,del (4)(p16.3) [6.6%]/46,XY[93.4%]. At 4 years, FISH analysis on 200 interphase cells revealed a 65% percent mosaic 4p16.3 deletion with the nuclear in situ hybridization (nuc ish) p16.3(WHSx1)[130]/(WHSx2)[70]. FISH analysis ruled out Williams syndrome. Orthopantomography and profile teleradiography were performed, revealing CS5 stage of maturation of the cervical vertebrae. Cephalometric analysis was conducted using the Heb.Uni. software program, providing detailed information on facial typology, mandibular growth and shape, skeletal relationships, and dental report."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 28-year-old man from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented in November 2022 with constipation and abdominal pain. Despite being sent home with a bowel regimen, his pain persisted, leading to a repeat evaluation. In January 2023, he was admitted with pelvic pain, nausea, vomiting, and suicidal ideation. He underwent a colectomy with end-ileostomy due to colonic obstruction secondary to a mass. His hospital course was complicated by abdominal wound dehiscence and evisceration, requiring a return to the operating room for closure. He was started on total parenteral nutrition (TPN) due to poor appetite following multiple abdominal surgeries and peritoneal carcinomatosis. The patient began chemotherapy with reduced dose carboplatin and paclitaxel on 14/02/2023 and received supportive growth factor on 16/02/23. After NGS results revealed a t(11;22) EWSR-WT1 translocation, carboplatin and paclitaxel were discontinued. The patient is currently on palliative vincristine (2 mg), doxorubicin (37.5 mg/m2), and cyclophosphosphamide (1200 mg/m2) (VAC) every 3 weeks and has completed five cycles of treatment.",

  "Physical Examination": "A colonoscopy revealed a mass extending 3 cm from the anus to 10 cm, causing a partial obstruction.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of schizophrenia and depression.",

  "Initial Test Results": "An initial abdominal X-ray was negative for obstruction. CT A/P revealed numerous pelvic masses with severe colitis, bilateral moderate hydronephrosis, and metastatic disease in the liver. Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA) was 2.4 ng/mL, alpha fetoprotein (AFP) was 2.5 ng/mL, and prostate-specific antigen (PSA) was 0.6 ng/mL. A repeat staging CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis (CT C/A/P) showed a large rectal mass with peritoneal carcinomatosis and liver metastatic disease, extensive lymphadenopathy, and a sclerotic bone lesion in the right iliac. Initial biopsy pathology was read as squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). A subsequent review by the institution's pathology department indicated basaloid SCC with neuroendocrine features, and a Ki67 of 70%."
}"

}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 59-year-old female, 162 cm tall, weighing 59 kg. She is from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was scheduled for total laparoscopic hysterectomy. She had been using 100 mg of danazol once a week for long-term symptom control of hereditary angioedema (HAE). The patient was treated with danazol 200 mg the day before surgery. During the surgery, 3 pints of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) were transfused as recommended by the allergy department. The total fluid intake during the surgery was 1,310 ml including 3 pints of FFP, and the output was 680 ml including blood loss. The patient stayed at the sub-intensive care unit for 1 day to monitor possible late-onset airway edema after surgery. No special events were detected until discharge, and the patient took danazol as usual and was discharged 4 days after the operation. The patient visited the outpatient clinic a week after discharge and reported no significant event. However, four weeks later, during her second visit, she complained that edema alternated between her left and right feet every 10 days. The patient no longer experienced edema by week 8 of outpatient follow-up.",

  "Physical Examination": "Before induction, the blood pressure was 135/78 mmHg, and the pulse rate was 82 beats/min. The endotracheal intubation was performed smoothly using a video laryngoscope, and no abnormalities such as edema of the epiglottis or vocal cords were detected. At the end of the surgery, video laryngoscopy confirmed the absence of edema in the patient's epiglottis and vocal cord. Further, no edema was detected in the trachea and carina with a fiberoptic bronchoscope. After the operation, the patient did not have any particular complaints and the vital signs were stable.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was diagnosed with type I hereditary angioedema (HAE) at the age of 49 years, based on genetic testing. She experienced recurrent episodes of angioedema involving legs or hands once every 2–3 months. However, she had not experienced an edema attack for the past one year prior to the surgery.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Preoperative blood tests revealed normal range of biochemical parameters except for total cholesterol (216 mg/dl, normal range: 0–200 mg/dl). Protein immunoassay revealed a C4 level of 14 mg/dl (normal range: 10–40 mg/dl). The patient's C1-INH antigen level was 9.70 mg/dl (normal range: 21.0–39.0 mg/dl) and the C1-INH activity was 33% (normal range: 70–130%). Chest X-ray and electrocardiography findings were normal."
}"

No special events were detected until discharge, and the patient took danazol as usual and was discharged 4 days after the operation. The patient visited the outpatient clinic a week after discharge and reported no significant event. However, four weeks later, during her second visit, she complained that edema alternated between her left and right feet every 10 days. The patient no longer experienced edema by week 8 of outpatient follow-up.",

  "Physical Examination": "Before induction, the blood pressure was 135/78 mmHg, and the pulse rate was 82 beats/min. The endotracheal intubation was performed smoothly using a video laryngoscope, and no abnormalities such as edema of the epiglottis or vocal cords were detected. At the end of the surgery, video laryngoscopy confirmed the absence of edema in the patient's epiglottis and vocal cord. Further, no edema was detected in the trachea and carina with a fiberoptic bronchoscope. After the operation, the patient did not have any particular complaints and the vital signs were stable.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was diagnosed with type I hereditary angioedema (HAE) at the age of 49 years, based on genetic testing. She experienced recurrent episodes of angioedema involving legs or hands once every 2–3 months. However, she had not experienced an edema attack for the past one year prior to the surgery.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Preoperative blood tests revealed normal range of biochemical parameters except for total cholesterol (216 mg/dl, normal range: 0–200 mg/dl). Protein immunoassay revealed a C4 level of 14 mg/dl (normal range: 10–40 mg/dl). The patient's C1-INH antigen level was 9.70 mg/dl (normal range: 21.0–39.0 mg/dl) and the C1-INH activity was 33% (normal range: 70–130%). Chest X-ray and electrocardiography findings were normal.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "The patient was diagnosed with type I HAE based on genetic testing at the age of 49 years. No other advanced diagnostic tests were mentioned in the provided information."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 27-year-old man, active military. He is an ex-smoker with a history of two-five packs per year.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted for increasing dyspnea, cough, and wheezing that had been present for a few weeks. He had been diagnosed with asthma one year earlier. After initial treatment and diagnosis of Idiopathic Chronic Eosinophilic Pneumonia (ICEP), the patient responded well to therapy with rapid resolution of symptoms. However, attempts at tapering the corticosteroids below 35 mg were met with three relapses in 16 months, associated with clinical worsening, reascension of eosinophil count, recurrence of pulmonary lesions, and multiple hospital admissions. A high glucose level due to chronic steroid use was noted. Subcutaneous mepolizumab 100 mg monthly was initiated, allowing for a gradual decrease of oral steroids. At four months of overlap of anti-IL5 and tapering doses of corticosteroids, with a current dose of 20 mg of prednisone, no relapse has occurred.",

  "Physical Examination": "",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had been diagnosed with asthma one year earlier.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Tests showed blood eosinophilia (2G/L, 15%). The C-reactive protein level was 10 mg/L. The serum Immunoglobulin E level was 502 IU/mL. ANCA were negative."
}"

Cases.Final Name: Pruritic urticarial papules and plaques of pregnancy
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 36-year-old primiparous pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation. She has gained 15 kg during the first two trimesters of pregnancy.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred with an extensive pruritic rash that initially appeared as erythematous papules on the abdomen. The rash rapidly spread to the trunk, thighs, buttocks, calves, legs, and arms, and was unresponsive to topical corticosteroids. The patient had a body temperature of 38 °C. Ultrasound evaluation showed a 32-week fetus with normal morphology, estimated weight of 2350 g (above 90th percentile), and slightly tachycardic (fetal heart rate: 180–200 bpm). The amniotic fluid index (AFI) was within the normal range. The patient was transferred to an infectious diseases ward, where an infectious cause was excluded. Upon return to the obstetrics-gynecology ward, the patient received intravenous hydration and intravenous treatment with high doses of hydrocortisone hemisuccinate. The fever subsided from the first day of treatment and did not relapse. Fetal tachycardia remitted in less than 6 h, and the rash gradually remitted under the corticosteroid treatment. The patient was discharged after 12 days and had an uneventful pregnancy course until 36 weeks of gestation, when she gave birth via cesarean section to a 2650 g baby girl due to premature membrane rupture. The maternal dermatological condition did not influence the onset of birth. The evolution of the newborn was favorable, and the postnatal adaptation was appropriate, without dermatological lesions or other diseases. At 3-month follow-up, the patient did not report any skin lesion.",

  "Physical Examination": "Clinical examination showed a body temperature of 38 °C. The patient presented with an extensive pruritic rash that appeared as erythematous papules on the abdomen, trunk, thighs, buttocks, calves, legs, and arms.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient denied other illnesses.",

  "Initial Test Results": "All paraclinical investigations were within normal limits, including additional immune tests for anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA), perinuclear ANCA (p-ANCA), circulating immune complexes, and rheumatoid factor. Procalcitonin and c-reactive protein were negative. ELISA test showed anti BP-180 antibodies: 12 U/mL (normal values < 20 U/mL)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 55-year-old well-fit male with a distinguished career in military service.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "He first noted symptoms approximately a year ago, with the onset of swelling and discomfort in his right leg. It was an unexpected development, as he had no prior history of trauma or similar conditions to the affected leg. Initially, the symptoms were subtle and intermittent; however, over the course of the year, they progressed, compelling him to seek medical attention. The patient faced constraints in accessing certain diagnostic and treatment options in a context with limited resources. The challenge of obtaining CT or MRI scans in a timely manner in our setting led the multidisciplinary team to opt for an excisional biopsy of the leg lesion. Upon diagnosis, the patient was promptly connected with an oncology team experienced in orthopedic cancers. The X-ray findings clearly displayed extensive involvement of the proximal tibia beyond the bone cortex. Taking into account the patient’s overall health, the aggressive nature of adamantinoma, and its specific location, the team concluded that amputation was the most viable treatment option, given the limited availability of alternative treatment methods. Following the amputation, the patient’s wound healed effectively with no evidence of either distant metastasis or local recurrence. Subsequently, the patient was discharged and scheduled for a follow-up appointment.",
  "Physical Examination": "The physical examination revealed a swelling in the right proximal leg. Notably, the overlying skin appeared intact, with no observable signs of inflammation or infection such as redness, heat, or pus. The pain, although not severe, was consistent, disrupting his daily activities.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no prior history of trauma or similar conditions to the affected leg.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Prompt diagnostic tests were performed, beginning with an AP and lateral X-ray of the affected leg. The radiographic images showed a right anterior tibial, mid diaphyseal lytic expansile lesion with internal trabeculations. The lesion has a narrow zone of transition with associated solid type of periosteal reaction. There are also small adjacent lytic satellite lesions (Figure 1A and B). An abdominal ultrasound was further conducted, which was nonrevealing. Additional tests, such as a chest X-ray, were also carried out to exclude any potential systemic issues which was unremarkable."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 17-year-old adolescent male. No specific geographic location is mentioned.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient consulted for a painful swelling above his right ankle, present for two years and progressively increasing in size. The patient had no other symptoms. Postoperatively, the patient was placed in partial weight-bearing for an initial three weeks, then resumed full weight-bearing after five weeks. At the last follow-up visit, 12 months after surgery, the patient was asymptomatic and showed no recurrence.",

  "Physical Examination": "On physical examination, the patient presented with a hard, fixed and tender bony swelling on the distal part of the right tibia. The lesion was not adherent to the skin and was not associated with ulceration or elevated temperature. The swelling was diffuse and extensive. Neurovascular status of the right lower limb was normal. The systemic physical examination revealed no abnormal findings.",

  "Past Medical History": "No medical, family, allergic, drug or social history was relevant.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory investigations, including blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP), were within normal limits. Conventional radiographs of the right ankle and tibia in anteroposterior and lateral projection revealed a lytic image at the level of the tibial pilon, presenting a polylobed aspect of type IA according to Lodwick's classification."
}"

  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 17-year-old adolescent male. No specific geographic location is mentioned.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient consulted for a painful swelling above his right ankle, present for two years and progressively increasing in size. The patient had no other symptoms. Postoperatively, the patient was placed in partial weight-bearing for an initial three weeks, then resumed full weight-bearing after five weeks. At the last follow-up visit, 12 months after surgery, the patient was asymptomatic and showed no recurrence.",

  "Physical Examination": "On physical examination, the patient presented with a hard, fixed and tender bony swelling on the distal part of the right tibia. The lesion was not adherent to the skin and was not associated with ulceration or elevated temperature. The swelling was diffuse and extensive. Neurovascular status of the right lower limb was normal. The systemic physical examination revealed no abnormal findings.",

  "Past Medical History": "No medical, family, allergic, drug or social history was relevant.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory investigations, including blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) and C-reactive protein (CRP), were within normal limits. Conventional radiographs of the right ankle and tibia in anteroposterior and lateral projection revealed a lytic image at the level of the tibial pilon, presenting a polylobed aspect of type IA according to Lodwick's classification.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "The patient underwent a surgical procedure involving en bloc biopsy-exeresis of the tumor with the interposition of surgical cement. After four months, the cement was replaced by a cancellous bone graft. The histological study revealed a benign tumor proliferation of lobulated architecture, with hypercellular central zones, made up of stellate cells with ovoid to fusiform nuclei, devoid of cytonuclear atypia, and surrounded by abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, presenting bipolar or multipolar cytoplasmic extensions. The latter are arranged within a myxoid background. The periphery of the lobule is hypercellular, with spindle-shaped cells, non-atypical ovoid nuclei and abundant cytoplasm. No malignancy was found."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 32-year-old White British female who was born prematurely at 32 gestational weeks.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient had normal perinatal and neurodevelopmental history. At age 5, she began experiencing running difficulty, followed by gait difficulty with unsteadiness and progressive dysarthria. At age 6, she took longer to swallow food and experienced painful spasms of her left lower limb. By age 10, she developed mild kyphoscoliosis and rapidly progressive visual impairment, with corneal opacities detected on ophthalmological assessment. She subsequently developed progressive generalized dystonia with prominent oromandibular involvement and intermittent facial grimacing, which evolved into akinetic–rigid parkinsonism. Her speech progressively deteriorated, becoming anarthric by age 16. She has been PEG-fed since age 20. At age 20, her verbal IQ was 90, and her performance IQ was 92 (WAIS test). The patient is currently anarthric and communicates using a tablet. She receives baclofen 25 mg three times daily, gabapentin 300 mg three times daily, and botulinum toxin injections with benefit. Miglustat and levodopa were not tolerated due to intractable diarrhea and sinus tachycardia, respectively.",

  "Physical Examination": "On examination at age 32, pursuit and saccades were unremarkable. The patient had generalized dystonia, with blepharospasm, facial grimacing, tongue involvement, left torticollis, hand deformities with cubital deviation of her fingers, and bilateral foot inversion. There was severe generalized bradykinesia. Tendon reflexes were brisk throughout. There were no cerebellar signs.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's past medical history was otherwise unremarkable. The patient's unrelated parents, one older sister and one half-brother were in good health.",

  "Initial Test Results": "At age 20, her verbal IQ was 90, and her performance IQ was 92 (WAIS test). Biochemical analyses detected very low β-galactosidase activity in leukocytes of 5.0 nmol/hr/mg protein (range in GM1 homozygotes: 0.78–8.0) and galactose-containing oligosaccharides in urine."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Brain and spine MRI showed mild global cerebral white matter atrophy, faint bilateral putaminal clefts, mild cervicothoracic scoliosis, and abnormal cervical vertebral body morphology with irregularity of the endplates and intervertebral discs. Single-gene testing and segregation analysis revealed the patient was compound heterozygote for a paternally inherited pathogenic variant NM_000404.4(GLB1):c.245C>T p.(Thr82Met) and maternally inherited pathogenic variant NM_000404.4(GLB1):c.335A>C p.(His112Pro)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 30-year-old female with a height of 146 cm and weight of 47 kg. She is gravida 3, para 0, and was admitted at 33 weeks of gestation.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient's chief complaint was headache and upper abdominal pain. On admission, her blood pressure was 194/120 mmHg. She was diagnosed with preeclampsia and partial hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, and low platelet count (HELLP) syndrome by the obstetrician. Despite continuous administration of magnesium sulfate and nicardipine, the systolic blood pressure remained above 180 mmHg. The continuation of the pregnancy was considered dangerous for the patient, and a decision was made to terminate the pregnancy via cesarean section. Combined spinal epidural anesthesia was planned. In the operating room, an epidural catheter was placed at the L1/2 interspace, and a mixture of 2.4 mL of 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine and 0.15 mg of morphine was administered into the subarachnoid space from the L4/5 interspace. After spinal anesthesia, her blood pressure stabilized at a systolic pressure of around 120 mmHg. Magnesium sulfate was administered continuously during the surgery. Continuous epidural anesthesia with 0.2% ropivacaine was started at 5 mL/hr after the start of the surgery. A male neonate weighing 1.528 kg was delivered successfully 14 minutes after the start of the surgery. The total operation time was 87 minutes. Postoperatively, the patient complained of a postdural puncture headache, but the symptoms resolved within a few days. No severe complications related to neuraxial anesthesia were observed.",

  "Physical Examination": "Cold hypoesthesia below the level of the Th4 dermatome area was confirmed five minutes after spinal anesthesia administration.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of amblyopia and hearing loss. She also had a history of postnatal respiratory distress that required tracheal intubation for two months. During pregnancy, fetal echography showed findings suggestive of a cleft palate. A previous computed tomography scan showed only mild scoliosis and no abnormalities in the spinal canal.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests showed a serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST) level of 103 U/L, a lactate dehydrogenase (LD) level of 484 U/L, and a platelet count of 16×10４/μL. Urinalysis indicated proteinuria grade 3. The patient's platelet count was within the normal range on admission, and she had no history of bleeding tendency."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The proband is a 12-year-old girl from a non-consanguineous Italian couple.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "Pregnancy was uneventful except for a dysplastic multicystic right kidney and femur length at the upper limits during the morphology scan. She was born at 40 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 3.250 kg (50-75th centile) and length of 52 cm (50th centile). Her length became >97th centile since the first months of life, and the right dysplastic kidney atrophied over time. At the age of 10 years, bilateral pantonal sensorineural hearing loss was diagnosed. At 12 years of age, her weight was 74.8 kg (+2.04 SD), height was 185.5 cm (+4.35 SD), and she had relative microcephaly with an occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) of 52.2 cm (−0.95 SD). Her body mass index (BMI) was 21.7 (+0.44 SD), and her arm-span was 182 cm with a normal arm span/height ratio (0.98). Her intellectual and social development was normal. Mild dysmorphic features included a high frontal hairline, slight asymmetric face, deeply set eyes, slight prognathism, small ears, bifid uvula, and peg-shaped incisors. She had long and thin fingers, prominent phalanx epiphyses, camptodactyly of fingers and toes, first and second fingers clinodactyly on the left hand, and second and third fingers clinodactyly on the right hand. She also had clinodactyly and proximal placement of the fifth toes bilaterally. She exhibited mild joint hyperextensibility with a Beighton score of 5/9. The proband's father was tall (201 cm, +3.96 SD), had camptodactyly and hypoplasia of the left second finger, bilateral clinodactyly of the second and third right fingers with prominent interphalangeal epiphyses, and thoracic scoliosis requiring spinal surgery at 23 years of age. During childhood, he also showed progressive bilateral pantonal sensorineural hearing loss without dental anomalies. Other family members were reported with normal stature and in good health.",
  "Physical Examination": "Thyroid and pelvic US scan were normal. Carpal x-ray revealed a bone age 4 years older than chronological age. Spine x-ray revealed left-convex lumbar rotoscoliosis with moderate right-convex compensatory curvature. She also had valgus knees and flat feet. Mild dysmorphic features included a high frontal hairline, slight asymmetric face, deeply set eyes, slight prognathism, small ears, bifid uvula, and peg-shaped incisors. She had long and thin fingers, prominent phalanx epiphyses, camptodactyly of fingers and toes, first and second fingers clinodactyly on the left hand, and second and third fingers clinodactyly on the right hand. She also had clinodactyly and proximal placement of the fifth toes bilaterally. Mild joint hyperextensibility was noted with a Beighton score of 5/9. Skin examination revealed no striae distensae, bruising, atrophic scars, or pigmentation disorders.",
  "Past Medical History": "The proband had a dysplastic multicystic right kidney identified during pregnancy which subsequently atrophied over time. At the age of 10, bilateral pantonal sensorineural hearing loss was diagnosed. The proband’s father had thoracic scoliosis requiring spinal surgery at the age of 23 and progressive bilateral pantonal sensorineural hearing loss during childhood. Other family members were reported to have normal stature and were in good health.",
  "Initial Test Results": "The birth weight was 3.250 kg (50-75th centile) and length was 52 cm (50th centile). At 12 years of age: weight 74.8 kg (+2.04 SD), height 185.5 cm (+4.35 SD), occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) 52.2 cm (−0.95 SD), body mass index (BMI) 21.7 (+0.44 SD), arm-span 182 cm with normal arm span/height ratio (0.98). Thyroid and pelvic US scans were normal. Carpal x-ray revealed a bone age 4 years older than chronological age. }"

At 12 years of age, her weight was 74.8 kg (+2.04 SD), height was 185.5 cm (+4.35 SD), and she had relative microcephaly with an occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) of 52.2 cm (−0.95 SD). Her body mass index (BMI) was 21.7 (+0.44 SD), and her arm-span was 182 cm with a normal arm span/height ratio (0.98). Her intellectual and social development was normal. Mild dysmorphic features included a high frontal hairline, slight asymmetric face, deeply set eyes, slight prognathism, small ears, bifid uvula, and peg-shaped incisors. She had long and thin fingers, prominent phalanx epiphyses, camptodactyly of fingers and toes, first and second fingers clinodactyly on the left hand, and second and third fingers clinodactyly on the right hand. She also had clinodactyly and proximal placement of the fifth toes bilaterally. She exhibited mild joint hyperextensibility with a Beighton score of 5/9. The proband's father was tall (201 cm, +3.96 SD), had camptodactyly and hypoplasia of the left second finger, bilateral clinodactyly of the second and third right fingers with prominent interphalangeal epiphyses, and thoracic scoliosis requiring spinal surgery at 23 years of age. During childhood, he also showed progressive bilateral pantonal sensorineural hearing loss without dental anomalies. Other family members were reported with normal stature and in good health.",
  "Physical Examination": "Thyroid and pelvic US scan were normal. Carpal x-ray revealed a bone age 4 years older than chronological age. Spine x-ray revealed left-convex lumbar rotoscoliosis with moderate right-convex compensatory curvature. She also had valgus knees and flat feet. Mild dysmorphic features included a high frontal hairline, slight asymmetric face, deeply set eyes, slight prognathism, small ears, bifid uvula, and peg-shaped incisors. She had long and thin fingers, prominent phalanx epiphyses, camptodactyly of fingers and toes, first and second fingers clinodactyly on the left hand, and second and third fingers clinodactyly on the right hand. She also had clinodactyly and proximal placement of the fifth toes bilaterally. Mild joint hyperextensibility was noted with a Beighton score of 5/9. Skin examination revealed no striae distensae, bruising, atrophic scars, or pigmentation disorders.",
  "Past Medical History": "The proband had a dysplastic multicystic right kidney identified during pregnancy which subsequently atrophied over time. At the age of 10, bilateral pantonal sensorineural hearing loss was diagnosed. The proband’s father had thoracic scoliosis requiring spinal surgery at the age of 23 and progressive bilateral pantonal sensorineural hearing loss during childhood. Other family members were reported to have normal stature and were in good health.",
  "Initial Test Results": "The birth weight was 3.250 kg (50-75th centile) and length was 52 cm (50th centile). At 12 years of age: weight 74.8 kg (+2.04 SD), height 185.5 cm (+4.35 SD), occipitofrontal circumference (OFC) 52.2 cm (−0.95 SD), body mass index (BMI) 21.7 (+0.44 SD), arm-span 182 cm with normal arm span/height ratio (0.98). Thyroid and pelvic US scans were normal. Carpal x-ray revealed a bone age 4 years older than chronological age. Spine x-ray showed left-convex lumbar rotoscoliosis with moderate right-convex compensatory curvature.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Exon 14 and flanking exons of the FGFR3 gene sequencing revealed a heterozygous likely pathogenic variant c.1861C>T, p.(Arg621Cys) in both the proband and her father. The study was approved by the relevant Ethical Committee and Scientific Board, with written informed consent obtained from the patients. DNA was extracted from peripheral blood leukocytes by an automated DNA extractor, followed by PCR amplification of the FGFR3 gene. The sequencing was performed using the Genetic Analyzer 3500 and described according to the HGVS nomenclature."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "This case involves a 37-year-old Latino woman, gravida 2 para 0-0-1-0, at 13 weeks of gestation.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred at 13 weeks of gestation to genetic counseling due to a positive first trimester screen with increased NT thickness. Her first trimester screen was positive for trisomy 21 and 18 with risks of 1/6 and 1/24, respectively. Fetal NT measured 6.44 mm; pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) was 0.53 multiples of median (MOM) and human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) was 0.70 MOM. The patient's noninvasive prenatal screen was low risk for trisomy 21, 18, 13, and sex chromosome aneuploidy. The patient was counseled on invasive diagnostic testing via chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis. She was also advised to consider an early anatomical ultrasound at 16 weeks of gestation and complete anatomical ultrasound at 20 weeks of gestation as well as a fetal echocardiogram. The patient underwent amniocentesis at 17 weeks. Her anatomy ultrasound at 20 weeks showed early onset growth restriction with the fetus measuring 18 weeks and multiple anomalies including shortened long bones, clenched fists, bilateral clubfeet with high suspicion of polydactyly, cerebellar hypoplasia, abnormal calvarium, micrognathia, low-set ears, single umbilical artery, and possible ventral septal defect (VSD). The patient was offered WES testing and counseled on options for continuation versus termination of pregnancy given the anomalies seen on ultrasound. The patient ultimately decided to terminate the pregnancy.",

  "Physical Examination": "",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a past medical history of hypertension on labetalol and low-dose daily aspirin for preeclampsia prevention. She has a history of an uncomplicated first trimester pregnancy loss.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The first trimester screen was positive for trisomy 21 and 18 with risks of 1/6 and 1/24, respectively. Fetal NT measured 6.44 mm; pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) was 0.53 multiples of median (MOM) and human chorionic gonadotropin (HCG) was 0.70 MOM. The patient's noninvasive prenatal screen was low risk for trisomy 21, 18, 13, and sex chromosome aneuploidy. The anatomy ultrasound at 20 weeks showed early onset growth restriction with the fetus measuring 18 weeks and multiple anomalies including shortened long bones, clenched fists, bilateral clubfeet with high suspicion of polydactyly, cerebellar hypoplasia, abnormal calvarium, micrognathia, low-set ears, single umbilical artery, and possible ventral septal defect (VSD)."

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 13-month-old female child from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The child was admitted to the hospital with retching for 1 week and worsening condition for 2 days. She had no vomiting, fever, rash, cough, expectoration, jaundice, diarrhea, or trauma. During the illness, the child had poor appetite, poor sleep, fair mental status, and reduced urine output, but no abnormal exhaust and defecation. There were no signs of upper respiratory tract infection. The child had been previously hospitalized in the neonatology unit 1 year ago with diagnoses of neonatal hyperbilirubinemia (NHB), neonatal bilirubin encephalopathy (NBE), congenital hepatic cyst (CHC), and congenital bilateral renal multiple cysts (CRMCs). NHB and NBE recovered favorably after active treatment. CHC and CRMC were treated with conservative observation, with color ultrasonography of the liver and kidneys conducted every other year. Anemia was detected at 8 months of age, with a minimum hemoglobin (HGB) of about 34 g/L. After treatment with oral medication and dietary therapy, the maximum HGB was about 80 g/L.",

  "Physical Examination": "The child was 74 cm tall and weighed 9.5 kg. Her body temperature was 36.4 °C, pulse rate 150/min, respiration rate 68/min, and blood pressure 77/64 mmHg. She had poor general status, tachypnea, and anemic appearance. Physical examination showed coarse breath sounds in both lungs, low and dull heart sounds, heart rate 150/min, galloping rhythm, a pansystolic grade 3 murmur in the precardiac area, and the lower border of the liver reaching the right pelvic inlet.",

  "Past Medical History": "The child was born of a gravida 1, parity 1 mother. She was delivered vaginally at 38+2 weeks of gestation, with a birth weight of 2750 g. She was breastfed, with normal growth and developmental milestones. The child had no previous history of surgery or blood transfusion, and no significant history of medication or food allergies. The child's parents were healthy, and there was no abnormality in the family history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Blood tests showed decreased levels of hemoglobin (HGB), mean corpuscular volume, mean corpuscular hemoglobin, mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration, and ferritin concentration. Biomarkers of heart failure, such as N-Terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide, were remarkably elevated. No abnormal results were found in urine and stool analyses. Chest X-ray demonstrated enhanced texture in both lungs and enlarged heart shadow, with a cardiothoracic ratio of about 0.62. Electrocardiogram (ECG) suggested left axis deviation, paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia with a heart rate of 150/min and ST-T segment changes."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Color doppler echocardiography (CDE) displayed enlarged left heart, thickening of the posterior wall of the left ventricle, minor amounts of mitral regurgitation, ventricular wall hypokinesis and decreased left heart function. Cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) revealed slight endocardial thickening of the left ventricle, minor thickening of the myocardium, and diffuse motion reduction of the ventricular wall with no apparent delayed enhancement abnormalities. Color ultrasonography of the abdomen showed hepatic cyst (size: 0.93 cm × 0.75 cm), bilateral renal multiple cysts (the largest one size: 1.1 cm × 1.7 cm) and a markedly enlarged liver with a right oblique diameter of 8.25 cm and an inferior hepatic border 6.32 cm from the right inferior costal arch border of the midclavicular line."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "77-year-old Japanese male.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient had a past medical history of acute cardiac infarction and was diagnosed with right carotid artery stenosis which progressed over three years. The carotid plaque showed high signal intensity on the T1-weighted image, suggesting a vulnerable plaque with intraplaque hemorrhage. A digital subtraction angiogram revealed 93% internal carotid artery stenosis starting at the carotid bifurcation. Considering the surgical risks associated with the presumed vulnerable plaque, the patient elected for carotid endarterectomy rather than carotid artery stenting. During the presurgical assessment, an echocardiogram showed a decreased left ventricular ejection fraction accompanied by bright myocardium and left atrial dilatation, suspicious of cardiac amyloidosis. Myocardial pathological examination by a myocardial biopsy eventually diagnosed the patient with ATTRwt amyloidosis.",
  "Physical Examination": "",
  "Past Medical History": "Past medical history includes acute cardiac infarction.",
  "Initial Test Results": "An echocardiogram showed a decreased left ventricular ejection fraction accompanied by bright myocardium and left atrial dilatation."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "77-year-old Japanese male.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient had a past medical history of acute cardiac infarction and was diagnosed with right carotid artery stenosis which progressed over three years. The carotid plaque showed high signal intensity on the T1-weighted image, suggesting a vulnerable plaque with intraplaque hemorrhage. A digital subtraction angiogram revealed 93% internal carotid artery stenosis starting at the carotid bifurcation. Considering the surgical risks associated with the presumed vulnerable plaque, the patient elected for carotid endarterectomy rather than carotid artery stenting. During the presurgical assessment, an echocardiogram showed a decreased left ventricular ejection fraction accompanied by bright myocardium and left atrial dilatation, suspicious of cardiac amyloidosis. Myocardial pathological examination by a myocardial biopsy eventually diagnosed the patient with ATTRwt amyloidosis.",
  "Physical Examination": "",
  "Past Medical History": "Past medical history includes acute cardiac infarction.",
  "Initial Test Results": "An echocardiogram showed a decreased left ventricular ejection fraction accompanied by bright myocardium and left atrial dilatation.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A T1-weighted image suggested a vulnerable plaque containing intraplaque hemorrhage. A digital subtraction angiogram showed 93% internal carotid artery stenosis. Myocardial biopsy confirmed the diagnosis of ATTRwt amyloidosis. Pathological findings from the hematoxylin and eosin-stained specimen of the carotid artery revealed carotid intima’s eccentric fibrosis, compatible with arteriosclerotic change. Masson’s trichrome staining showed that the plaque consisted of fibers surrounding scattered smooth muscle cells and neovascularization. Positive staining on potassium permanganate-DFS stain and apple-green birefringence confirmed non-AA amyloid deposition at the carotid artery."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 51-year-old Japanese man with a body mass index of 17.8. His parents were born in the same small village in the Kyushu island, Japan, but consanguinity was denied.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to hospital for first-time heart failure with dilated cardiomyopathy-like morphology. He complained of orthopnea. Echocardiography and cardiac magnetic resonance imaging revealed diffuse hypokinesis of the left ventricle. The left ventricular ejection fraction was 20%. The patient had mild hearing loss as an extra-cardiac symptom. No skin lesions or fatty liver were observed.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's parents have been free from heart diseases.",

Echocardiography and cardiac magnetic resonance imaging revealed diffuse hypokinesis of the left ventricle. The left ventricular ejection fraction was 20%. In scintigraphy, the myocardial washout (WR) of 123I-β-iodophenyl-p-pentadecanoic acid (BMIPP) was −7.4%. A peripheral blood smear showed Jordans' anomaly in the polymorphonuclear leukocytes. The patient had mild hearing loss as an extra-cardiac symptom. No skin lesions or fatty liver were observed.",

  "Physical Examination": "Neurological examination revealed normal manual muscle test results.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's parents have been free from heart diseases.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Echocardiography showed diffuse hypokinesis of the left ventricle. The left ventricular ejection fraction was 20%. In scintigraphy, the myocardial washout (WR) of 123I-β-iodophenyl-p-pentadecanoic acid (BMIPP) was −7.4%. A peripheral blood smear showed Jordans' anomaly in the polymorphonuclear leukocytes.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging was performed (data not shown). Detailed analyses of paraffin-embedded endomyocardial biopsy specimens showed multiple vacuoles in cardiomyocytes positive for PLIN2, which is a marker for lipid droplets. Immunostaining for ATGL was positive on the rim and surrounding area of lipid droplets. Genetic analyses revealed that this patient was homozygous for a novel point mutation in exon 4 (c.446C > G, P149R) of PNPLA2 (LC705680). The amino acid residue P149, located in the catalytic domain of ATGL, is conserved between species. In vitro experiments using HeLa cells stably expressing this mutant ATGL showed more lipid droplets when treated with oleic acid, compared with those expressing wild-type ATGL, suggesting reduced lipolytic activity."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 46-year-old female. Her geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the hospital complaining of sudden weakness of both legs for 2 days. The right leg was markedly swollen and painful. After treatment with intravenous injection of urokinase and subcutaneous injection of low molecular weight heparin for 7 days, followed by oral administration of rivaroxaban, the muscle myodynamia of the lower limbs returned to grade 5 without edema after 50 days. The patient's father died of a slow heart rate at 36 years old. Her elder sister (48 years old) and younger brother (41 years old) were diagnosed with Atrial Standstill (AS) and had pacemakers implanted. The patient's younger sister and son do not currently have the disease.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination showed that the myodynamia of the distal muscle strength of the right lower limb was level 3, and the distal muscle strength of the right lower limb was level 1 by Lovett's scale. On fluoroscopy, no atrial contraction was observed.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a previous history of old cerebral infarction for 6 years and old myocardial infarction for 4 years. She did not have hypertension or diabetes mellitus.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The ECG showed a regular junctional rhythm of 43 beats/min. Laboratory test results, including liver function, D-dimer, brain natriuretic peptide (BNP), and white blood cell count, were obviously elevated. Transthoracic echocardiography (TTE) showed 49 mm for the left ventricular end-diastolic diameter, 40 mm for the left atrial diameter, 44 mm for the RA diameter, 37 mm for the right ventricular diameter, left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) 33%, and no atrial mechanical contraction. Atrial and ventricular systolic spectra and tissue Doppler imaging (TDI) at the mitral valve annulus showed the absence of a' at the annulus."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Double lower-limb arterial computed tomography (CT) angiography showed diffuse embolus and stenosis of both the left iliac artery and right femoral artery, and occlusion of the left popliteal artery. Coronary artery–enhanced CT revealed no stenosis in the coronary artery. However, thrombosis was seen in the left atrial appendage. Electrophysiological examination (EPS) showed a basal rhythm of slow junctional rhythm, approximately 43 times/min. No A-wave appeared in the high RA, the middle RA, the Koch triangular, or all CS domain. Electrical stimulation (10 V) at a frequency of 60 times/min was performed on the high RA, the middle RA, the Koch triangular domain, and the CS, but the right and left atria were not captured. Genetic testing with whole-exon sequencing of arrhythmia disorders analyzed 721 genes associated with 1475 diseases. A frameshift mutation in LMNA (c.1567dupG) was revealed, resulting in an amino acid frameshift insert mutation of asparagine to glutamic acid at the 524 locus and early termination after the latter 28 amino acids (p.Asn524Glufs*28). The heterozygous mutation of the LMNA gene was also detected in the patient's younger brother and her older sister. The patient's younger sister and son did not carry the gene mutation."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 32-year-old male originally from Cuba.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the hospital with fever, night sweats, cough, hemoptysis, and 20-25 pounds of weight loss over 2 to 3 months. Acid-fast bacillus smear and culture revealed Mycobacterium tuberculosis. He was initiated on rifamycin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol (RIPE). During his hospital stay, it was revealed that as a child in Cuba, the patient was told of an underlying heart condition but was unaware of a formal diagnosis; he had no further workup at the time. The patient denied chest pain, lower extremity swelling, orthopnea, or palpitations. He continued to show improvement in his underlying pulmonary symptoms and was discharged from the hospital on RIPE therapy with outpatient cardiology follow-up recommended.",

  "Physical Examination": "Vital signs on admission revealed a temperature of 37.7 degrees Celsius, a heart rate of 135 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 18 respirations per minute, a blood pressure of 142/99 mmHg, and saturating 99% on room air. On physical exam, he was tachycardic with a regular rhythm, no murmur, no jugular venous distention, and no lower extremity edema.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no known past medical history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "On initial labs, his electrolytes, kidney function, and hepatic function were within normal limits, but leukocytosis was present with a white blood cell count of 15,100 per microliter. Serial high-sensitivity troponins were negative. An electrocardiogram revealed sinus tachycardia with evidence of left atrial and left ventricular (LV) enlargement. LV ejection fraction was 40-45% with moderately decreased global LV systolic function. LV fractional shortening was decreased at 18%. The aortic root and ascending aorta were without dilatation. The right and left atria, as well as the right ventricle, were normal. The mitral and pulmonic valves had normal anatomy and function; however, the tricuspid valve had trace regurgitation. Pulmonary artery systolic pressure was normal with an estimated right ventricular systolic pressure of 21 mmHg."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian woman. She is normoponderal with a body mass index of 23.1 kg/m2 and an active smoker.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the cardiology department for worsening dyspnoea and lower limb oedema. The symptomatology had progressed slowly over the past few months. Her home medications included nebivolol (5 mg o.d.), furosemide (40 mg o.d.), spironolactone (25 mg o.d.), and acenocumarol (2 mg o.d.). Upon admission, her vital signs were stable, with blood pressure ranging between 100 and 110/60–70 mmHg, a heart rate of 110–115 b.p.m., and an oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 95% on room air. The patient underwent standard pre-operative protocol and was referred for cardiac surgery. During surgery, a tricuspid valve replacement with a biological prosthesis Medtronic Hancock no. 31 was performed with extracorporeal circulation. The cardiopulmonary bypass time was 145 min and ischaemic time was 81 min. Upon bypass cessation, the patient presented ventricular fibrillation, which was converted to atrial fibrillation after low-energy electrical cardioversion (a single shock of 10 J). At the 3-month follow-up consultation, the patient reported a significant alleviation of heart failure symptoms (New York Heart Association functional Class II).",

  "Physical Examination": "A physical examination revealed the presence of a 4/6 holosystolic murmur heard loudest at the right left sternal border, prominent bilateral jugular turgescence, moderate lower peripheral oedema, and hepatomegaly. Auscultation revealed normal lung sounds. Intra-operatively, upon inspection of the tricuspid valve, it was found that the posterior tricuspid valve leaflet and its subvalvular apparatus were completely absent.",

Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 62-year-old Caucasian woman. She is normoponderal with a body mass index of 23.1 kg/m2 and an active smoker.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the cardiology department for worsening dyspnoea and lower limb oedema. The symptomatology had progressed slowly over the past few months. Her home medications included nebivolol (5 mg o.d.), furosemide (40 mg o.d.), spironolactone (25 mg o.d.), and acenocumarol (2 mg o.d.). Upon admission, her vital signs were stable, with blood pressure ranging between 100 and 110/60–70 mmHg, a heart rate of 110–115 b.p.m., and an oxygen saturation (SpO2) of 95% on room air. The patient underwent standard pre-operative protocol and was referred for cardiac surgery. During surgery, a tricuspid valve replacement with a biological prosthesis Medtronic Hancock no. 31 was performed with extracorporeal circulation. The cardiopulmonary bypass time was 145 min and ischaemic time was 81 min. Upon bypass cessation, the patient presented ventricular fibrillation, which was converted to atrial fibrillation after low-energy electrical cardioversion (a single shock of 10 J). At the 3-month follow-up consultation, the patient reported a significant alleviation of heart failure symptoms (New York Heart Association functional Class II).",

  "Physical Examination": "A physical examination revealed the presence of a 4/6 holosystolic murmur heard loudest at the right left sternal border, prominent bilateral jugular turgescence, moderate lower peripheral oedema, and hepatomegaly. Auscultation revealed normal lung sounds. Intra-operatively, upon inspection of the tricuspid valve, it was found that the posterior tricuspid valve leaflet and its subvalvular apparatus were completely absent.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of heart failure, severe tricuspid regurgitation (TR) with unknown aetiology, and permanent atrial fibrillation. She did not take regular cardiological examinations.",

  "Initial Test Results": "An electrocardiogram showed atrial fibrillation, 115 b.p.m., incomplete right bundle branch block, and non-specific repolarization abnormalities. A chest X-ray showed normal lung fields and mild cardiomegaly. A biochemical analysis showed a mild increase in the total bilirubin level (1.28 mg/dL) and serum aminotransferase (40 U/I) and a slightly lower serum K concentration (3.4 mmol/L). A transthoracic echocardiogram revealed severe dilatation of the right ventricle at end diastole (56 mm) and of the right atrium at end systole (74 mm, area of 43 cm2), and paradoxical ventricular septal motion. The tricuspid annular plane systolic excursion (TAPSE) was 16 mm. Severe TR (vena contracta = 11 mm) secondary to the lack of leaflet co-optation was observed. The left ventricular ejection fraction was normal (65%), and no abnormal intra-cardiac shunts were observed. The main pulmonary artery diameter was 32 mm. No additional significant valvular disease was observed.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A transthoracic three-dimensional echocardiogram showed the total absence of the posterior tricuspid leaflet, generating a large regurgitant orifice, a slightly hypoplastic anterior leaflet, and a normal septal leaflet. A transoesophageal echocardiography confirmed these findings. A coronary angiogram showed normal coronary arteries. Right heart catheterization revealed a normal pulmonary arterial pressure of 26/6 mmHg and a Qp/Qs ratio of 1. An early post-operative evaluation demonstrated a normally functioning prosthesis with normal transvalvular gradients (maximum/medium = 7/4 mmHg). A mild (Grade I) TR was present. RV function was found moderately impaired (TAPSE = 7–8 mm). At the 3-month follow-up, the transthoracic echocardiogram showed a normal functioning prosthesis, absence of peri-prosthetic regurgitation, and transvalvular gradients similar to those measured immediately post-surgery. A partial recovery of RV function was observed, with a calculated TAPSE of 12 mm and a fractional area change of 35%."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 28-year-old male patient from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the hospital outpatient department with complaints of cough, chest pain, and upper respiratory tract symptoms including runny nose and sore throat. He has been taking three antihypertensive medications for his blood pressure: almondine 10 mg daily, hydrochlorothiazide 25, and enalapril 10 mg BID. Upon re-evaluation, a significant discrepancy in blood pressure was observed between the upper and lower extremities. The upper extremities registered a blood pressure of 150/100 mmHg, while the lower extremities registered 90/65 mmHg. The pulses in the lower extremities at the popliteal arteries and dorsalis pedis were feeble compared to the pulses felt in the bilateral radial arteries. After being informed about his condition and treatment options, the patient decided to defer surgery and continue with conservative medical treatment.",

  "Physical Examination": "Blood pressure measurements were taken from both upper and lower extremities. Pulse examination was conducted on bilateral radial arteries, popliteal arteries, and dorsalis pedis.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has had systemic hypertension for the past 13 years, being followed at different healthcare facilities.",

  "Initial Test Results": "A complete blood count (CBC) was performed, which showed lymphocytosis. A chest X-ray (CXR) was also conducted, which revealed normal lung fields with no signs of pneumonia. However, examination of the osseous structures in the chest showed multiple subtle irregularities involving the bilateral inferior ribs, suggestive of inferior rib notching."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "57-year-old male renal transplant recipient.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted for evaluation of recurrent presyncope. Despite appropriate resting bradycardia, pre-myectomy resting echocardiogram demonstrated severe dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction and significant mitral valve systolic anterior motion resulting in moderate-to-severe mitral regurgitation. One year earlier, the patient had undergone surgical myectomy for hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy (HOCM) with persistent class II–III dyspnoea, and presyncope on medical therapy. Surgical myectomy reduced septal thickness and decreased the resting peak LVOT pressure gradient. Six months after surgery, the patient reported progressive exertional dyspnoea and orthostatic presyncope. A new left bundle branch block was noted. Given the known residual post-surgical LVOT gradient and occasional postural hypotension, repeat resting and stress echocardiography was arranged. Exercise stress echocardiogram did not induce ischaemia, arrhythmia, or a significant LVOT gradient, but an apparent shunt across the ventricular septum was noted. Computed tomography coronary angiography (CTCA) demonstrated a large calibre first septal perforating artery extending to the endocardial border of the LVOT, with probable communication with the LV cavity, and a ventricular septal defect was excluded. Invasive angiography confirmed a fistula between an unroofed first septal perforator and the LV cavity. Adenosine myocardial perfusion scan demonstrated septal post-surgical wall motion changes and an ejection fraction (EF) of 59%, with no evidence of myocardial ischaemia to suggest a steal phenomenon. Inpatient telemetry demonstrated incidental runs of asymptomatic non-sustained ventricular tachycardia. Given the lack of symptom-rhythm correlation between ventricular tachycardia and presyncope, fludrocortisone was initiated for recurrent presyncope due to orthostatic hypotension, resulting in symptomatic improvement.",
  "Physical Examination": "Heart rate was 63 b.p.m. and blood pressure 106/70 mmHg, with evidence of orthostatic hypotension (standing blood pressure 86/57 mmHg). There was a loud systolic murmur heard at the left sternal edge, radiating to the carotid arteries, with no significant augmentation with dynamic manoeuvres and no clinical signs of heart failure.",
  "Past Medical History": "History of surgical myectomy for HOCM, renal transplant for end-stage renal failure secondary to reflux nephropathy, hypertension, and dyslipidaemia.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Pre-myectomy resting echocardiogram demonstrated severe dynamic left ventricular outflow tract (LVOT) obstruction (85 mmHg at rest and 140 mmHg on Valsalva) associated with increased septal thickness (18 mm) and significant mitral valve systolic anterior motion resulting in moderate-to-severe mitral regurgitation. Left and right ventricular volumes and ejection fraction (EF 55%) were normal. Pre-myectomy exercise stress echocardiography was electrically and symptomatically negative for inducible ischaemia, but showed evidence of severe dynamic intracavity obstruction post-exercise and moderate-severe dynamic mitral regurgitation. Coronary angiography revealed a right-dominant coronary system with type II left anterior descending artery and non-obstructive coronary artery disease. Post-surgical resting echocardiography demonstrated a significant reduction in LVOT gradient (now 5 mmHg)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 73-year-old man from Ibaraki, Japan. His height is 167.8 cm and weight is 64.8 kg. He has a history of smoking 10 cigarettes per day for 60 years but no history of drinking alcohol.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the hospital in July 2017 with complaints of a cough and shortness of breath. He had noticed thickening, yellowing, and poor growth of his nails approximately 5 years earlier. The cough and dyspnea gradually worsened, prompting him to visit a nearby clinic. Chest radiography at a previous hospital indicated bilateral pleural effusion. The patient's fingernails and toenails were yellow and thickened. Non-pitting edema was observed in both lower extremities. Despite anti-tuberculosis drug therapy for 6 weeks and antibiotic treatment, the pleural effusion showed an increasing tendency and the patient's general condition worsened due to inadequate dietary intake caused as a side effect of the anti-tuberculosis treatment. Based on the results and the yellowing and growth retardation of the toenails, the patient was diagnosed with a specific condition (name omitted). Treatment with prednisolone was initiated, starting at 30 mg/day and gradually tapered to 15 mg/day over 5 weeks. This treatment led to a consistent decrease in bilateral pleural effusion and improvement in general condition and respiratory symptoms. The patient was subsequently transferred to another hospital for rehabilitation, and the prednisolone dose was further reduced to 7.5 mg/day with good disease control.",

  "Physical Examination": "At admission, the patient's blood pressure was 140/63 mmHg, pulse rate was 117 beats/min, body temperature was 37.1˚C, respiratory rate was 24 breaths/min, and blood oxygen level was 92% while breathing 3 l/min oxygen via a nasal cannula. Breath sounds were attenuated in both lower lungs. There were no palpable lymph nodes in the neck, axilla or groin.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no reported history of significant past medical conditions or family medical history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Hematological evaluation showed: WBC count 8,700/µl (Neu 77%, Lym 12%, Eos 2%), hemoglobin 17.9 g/dl, total proteins 6.4 g/dl, albumin 2.9 g/dl, aspartate aminotransferase 21 U/l, alanine transaminase 10 U/l, LDH 289 U/l, blood urea nitrogen 8.9 mg/dl, creatinine 0.87 mg/dl, C-reactive protein 1.87 mg/dl, thyroid-stimulating hormone 1.48 µIU/ml, triiodothyronine 1.9 pg/ml, and thyroxine 1.2 mg/dl. Rheumatoid factor and anti-nuclear antibodies were negative, but sIL-2R was elevated at 845 U/ml. Pleural fluid analysis showed: protein 3.9 g/dl, LDH 120 U/l, WBC 3,000/µl (Neu 17%, Lym 83%, Eos 2%), and adenosine deaminase level 12.9 U/l. The pleural effusion was diagnosed as exudative according to Light's criteria. Evaluation for Mycobacterium tuberculosis was negative on smear, PCR, and culture tests. Cytological examination of the pleural fluid showed no atypical cells. The tuberculosis-specific enzyme-linked immunospot assay (T-SPOT.TB) was positive."
}"
