Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 20-year-old female from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient had noticed redness in the palmar region for several years. She sought medical attention due to the onset of pain and was referred to the dermatology department. The patient experienced palmar redness and pain, especially when gripping objects. There was no restriction in finger mobility and no similar findings in other regions of the body. After initial assessment, the patient underwent wide local excision of the soft tissue tumor. During the first surgery, the tumor was found to be adherent to the digital nerve but could be excised en bloc. A part of the nerve was in contact with the tumor, and its superficial membranous tissue was removed. The defect was covered with artificial dermis and negative pressure wound therapy (NPWT). Although pathology results indicated positive margins near the nerve area, no additional excision was done after consultation with the patient and her family. Instead, skin reconstruction was opted for. Two weeks post-surgery, skin grafting was performed using a graft from the sole of the foot to cover the palmar defect. Five years post-operatively, the patient shows no signs of recurrence, pain, or restriction in finger mobility.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient presented with a hand tumor, specifically redness in the palmar region. There was no restriction in finger mobility observed.",

  "Past Medical History": "No specific past medical history was provided in the given information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were provided in the given information."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 29-year-old male with a body mass index of 30. He is from a location where he was initially evaluated at an outside hospital before being referred to the current medical center.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient complained of dyspnea with minimal exertion and lower extremity edema for six months before presentation. He was initially evaluated at an outside hospital, where he was treated with diuretics and had a transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) and a heart catheterization with an initial diagnosis of a ventricular septal defect (VSD). On the first visit to the current medical center, he was not considered an adequate surgical candidate due to decompensated heart failure and biventricular systolic dysfunction. He was started on medical therapy with diuretics, beta-blockers, and angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs). He had significant improvement in his symptoms with resolution of his edema, improvement in his shortness of breath, as well as normalization of his left ventricular (LV) and right ventricular (RV) systolic function. Eight months after his initial presentation to the center, he underwent surgical repair. His postoperative echocardiogram showed no evidence of residual shunting lesions with preserved LV and RV systolic function and no significant valvular disease. Outpatient cardiology follow-up at one, three, and six months after hospital discharge showed good results with no residual shunting, normal ventricular function, and no active cardiac symptoms.",

  "Physical Examination": "On physical examination, his heart rate was 126 beats per minute, his blood pressure was 150/80 mmHg, and his oxygen saturation was 100% on room air. Cardiac examination revealed a III/VI continuous murmur best heard at the mid-sternal border. No rubs or gallops were noted. He had mild edema in the lower extremities. The rest of the examination was normal.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no significant past medical history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "An electrocardiogram (ECG) at the institution showed sinus tachycardia with a normal axis and non-specific repolarization changes. Transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) showed a mildly dilated LV with moderately to severely decreased LV systolic function (ejection fraction (EF) 25%-35%) and a moderate-size defect communicating the aortic root and the right ventricle. The presence of continuous flow on Doppler interrogation of the jet between the aortic root and the RV was observed."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 44-year-old male.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain and chronic recurrent urticarial skin rash for nine months. He had oral mucosal ulcerations and diffuse purpuric and urticarial lesions on multiple locations in the body. During hospitalization, eosinophilia persisted. The patient underwent a biopsy of the skin rash that came back positive for leukocytoclastic vasculitis. He was started on methylprednisone 60 mg daily with improvement in his symptoms. He was also initiated on famotidine and cetirizine given the urticarial picture of his rashes. In addition to steroids, dapsone was added to his regimen with folic acid. Finally, hydroxychloroquine was added at the time of discharge. On a two-month follow-up, his rash was resolved.",

Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 44-year-old male.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain and chronic recurrent urticarial skin rash for nine months. He had oral mucosal ulcerations and diffuse purpuric and urticarial lesions on multiple locations in the body. During hospitalization, eosinophilia persisted. The patient underwent a biopsy of the skin rash that came back positive for leukocytoclastic vasculitis. He was started on methylprednisone 60 mg daily with improvement in his symptoms. He was also initiated on famotidine and cetirizine given the urticarial picture of his rashes. In addition to steroids, dapsone was added to his regimen with folic acid. Finally, hydroxychloroquine was added at the time of discharge. On a two-month follow-up, his rash was resolved.",

  "Physical Examination": "On arrival, his blood pressure was 135/78 mmHg, pulse of 75 beats per minute, and saturating 99% on room air. Physical examination showed oral mucosal ulcerations and diffuse purpuric and urticarial lesions on multiple locations in the body.",

  "Past Medical History": "His past medical history was significant for seropositive rheumatoid arthritis, and venous thromboembolism for which he was anticoagulated with apixaban.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory workup showed eosinophilia. Initial inflammatory markers revealed elevated C-reactive protein and erythrocyte sedimentation rate. His inflammatory/rheumatological evaluation showed low complement levels C3 and C4. Anti-double stranded and anti-smith antibodies, c-ANCA, p-ANCA, human immunodeficiency virus, and cryoglobulin tests were negative.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "He underwent computed tomography that showed extensive mural thickening throughout the ileum, ascending colon, hepatic flexure, and duodenum suggestive of intestinal angioedema. Workup from an infectious and hematologic standpoint including bone marrow biopsy was unremarkable for parasitic infection or primary hematologic malignancy. The patient underwent a biopsy of the skin rash that came back positive for leukocytoclastic vasculitis. Anti-C1q antibody test was positive."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 38-year-old Caucasian female from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the emergency provider with confusion, aphasia, and headache. She was diagnosed with an unspecified condition about four months prior to this visit. Initially, she had presented with persistent vomiting and headaches. She continued to have ongoing headaches along with periods of confusion and was subsequently brought back to the hospital. She was noted to have new expressive aphasia which did not improve despite being started on IV pulse dose steroids for 3 days. The patient underwent treatment with high-dose methylprednisolone (IV of 1 g daily) and was transitioned to oral prednisone with an outpatient taper regimen. Due to subsequent deterioration, the IV methylprednisolone course was repeated and she was started on mycophenolate mofetil, along with IVIG every 2 weeks. A decision was made to initiate TPE using Spectra Optia continuous-flow centrifugal apheresis system using 5% albumin as replacement every other day for five sessions with a centrifugal device, achieving resolution of aphasia and headache. The patient was then discharged home with an outpatient regimen of prednisone and MMF.",

  "Physical Examination": "Funduscopic examination was notable for a cotton wool spot on the left eye.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of anxiety and depression.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Brainstem auditory evoked response showed dysfunction of the distal auditory nerve on the right. Lumbar puncture was unremarkable except for lymphocytic pleocytosis with positive serum GAD65."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 23-year-old pregnant woman referred to a fetal medicine center due to fetal hydrops. The gestational age at the time of examination was 22 weeks.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the fetal medicine center due to fetal hydrops. Ultrasound examination at 22 weeks of gestation revealed generalized skin edema, bilateral pleural effusions, and peritoneal effusions in the fetus. The patient had a previous pregnancy at 20 weeks with a fetus showing nonimmune fetal hydrops. In the current pregnancy, after genetic testing revealed the cause, the parents opted to terminate the pregnancy at 27 weeks and 4 days.",

  "Physical Examination": "A thorough systematic ultrasound examination of the fetus was performed at 22 weeks of gestation. The examination revealed generalized skin edema, bilateral pleural effusions, and peritoneal effusions in the fetus. A normal Doppler, normal placenta, and amniotic fluid were found, without any structural anomalies or signs of fetal anemia.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a previous pregnancy with a fetus showing nonimmune fetal hydrops at 20 weeks of gestation. Amniocentesis sampling of the first fetus demonstrated a normal male karyotype and no alterations in the copy number variations (CNVs) test. Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) was not performed during the first pregnancy.",

  "Initial Test Results": "TORCH screening, blood routine examinations, hepatorenal function tests, and maternal serum indirect Coombs test showed no abnormal changes. Amniocentesis was performed, which indicated no abnormalities in chromosome karyotype analysis or in copy number variations (CNVs)."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 23-year-old pregnant woman referred to a fetal medicine center due to fetal hydrops. The gestational age at the time of examination was 22 weeks.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the fetal medicine center due to fetal hydrops. Ultrasound examination at 22 weeks of gestation revealed generalized skin edema, bilateral pleural effusions, and peritoneal effusions in the fetus. The patient had a previous pregnancy at 20 weeks with a fetus showing nonimmune fetal hydrops. In the current pregnancy, after genetic testing revealed the cause, the parents opted to terminate the pregnancy at 27 weeks and 4 days.",

  "Physical Examination": "A thorough systematic ultrasound examination of the fetus was performed at 22 weeks of gestation. The examination revealed generalized skin edema, bilateral pleural effusions, and peritoneal effusions in the fetus. A normal Doppler, normal placenta, and amniotic fluid were found, without any structural anomalies or signs of fetal anemia.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a previous pregnancy with a fetus showing nonimmune fetal hydrops at 20 weeks of gestation. Amniocentesis sampling of the first fetus demonstrated a normal male karyotype and no alterations in the copy number variations (CNVs) test. Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) was not performed during the first pregnancy.",

  "Initial Test Results": "TORCH screening, blood routine examinations, hepatorenal function tests, and maternal serum indirect Coombs test showed no abnormal changes. Amniocentesis was performed, which indicated no abnormalities in chromosome karyotype analysis or in copy number variations (CNVs).",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A trio-based Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) targeted to the fetal hydrops phenotype was performed. DNA samples were collected from the amniotic fluid and the peripheral blood of the pregnant patient. The WES revealed two homozygous variants in the GUSB gene and one in the CHD7 gene. Further analysis identified a homozygous missense variant c.1324G > A in exon 8 of the GUSB gene on chromosome 7, causing a single amino acid substitution (p. Ala442Thr). This variant was not included in the HGMD, Clinvar, ExAC, gnomAD, or the 1000 Genomes database. Bioinformatics analysis predicted the variant to be deleterious. Both parents were found to be heterozygous carriers of this GUSB gene variant. Sanger sequencing of DNA from the previous edema fetus also revealed the presence of this mutation."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The mother is a 26-year-old female, gravida 2 para 1 living 1, with no significant medical or obstetric history, residing in an unspecified geographic location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The mother presented at 32 weeks of gestation with an ultrasound suggestive of a cystic lesion on the umbilical cord at the fetal end, initially measuring 3.6 * 1.9 cm, and increased to 4.3 * 5.7 cm at 34 weeks. Color Doppler confirmed normal flow through the umbilical vessels, showing no vascularity around the cyst and no fetal abdominal herniation. A subsequent scan at 35 weeks revealed a further increase in cyst size to 5.5 * 6.0 cm with the fetus in good condition. Genetic testing for the fetus was offered but refused by the patient. Due to increasing cyst size, close monitoring ensued. At 36 weeks, the patient presented with decreased fetal monitoring. A Cardiac tocogram was done, and CTG was non-reassuring, leading to an emergency LSCS. A male child with an APGAR score of 10 at 1 and 5 minutes was delivered. The baby was kept in the ICU for observation and discharged with the mother on the third day. During a subsequent visit, the mother reported persistent umbilical wetness in the baby, confirmed on examination, and a micturating cystourethrogram was performed revealing specifics of the condition. The baby had no fever, excessive crying, and urine microscopy was negative for infection. A thorough review found no other congenital anomalies. On Day 7, the baby underwent laparotomy and extraperitoneal excision of the tract. A catheter was kept for 4 days and the baby was covered with a single antibiotic. Gradual feeds were started under observation and he was discharged on day 7 post-surgery and followed up in the OPD.",
  "Physical Examination": "On examination, the baby presented with persistent umbilical wetness. There were no signs of fever or excessive crying, and the urine microscopy was negative for infection. A thorough review of all systems did not reveal any other congenital anomaly.",
  "Past Medical History": "There is no significant medical or obstetric history noted for the mother.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Initial ultrasound at 32 weeks of gestation showed a cystic lesion on the umbilical cord at the fetal end, with dimensions of 3.6 * 1.9 cm, which increased in size to 4.3 * 5.7 cm at 34 weeks. Color Doppler confirmed normal flow through the umbilical vessels with no vascularity around the cyst and no fetal abdominal herniation. A subsequent scan at 35 weeks revealed further increase in cyst size to 5.5 * 6.0 cm with good fetal condition. A Cardiac tocogram was performed at 36 weeks due to decreased fetal monitoring, which was non-reassuring."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male infant born to healthy non-consanguineous Caucasian parents (31-year-old mother, 33-year-old father) as their second child. He was born via caesarean section at 39 weeks of pregnancy due to pathological cardiotocography (CTG) trace. The pregnancy was complicated by maternal hypothyroidism and gestational diabetes. The patient was hypotrophic, weighing 2400 g at birth, with a length of 48 cm, head circumference of 32 cm, and chest circumference of 31 cm.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "During labor, there was a leakage of greenish amniotic fluid. The Apgar score was 7/8/8/8, and the patient required continuous positive airway pressure ventilation (CPAP) for 2 hours before achieving stable respiration. The patient exhibited dysmorphic features including ocular hypotelorism, gothic palate, retrognathism, low-set ears and hairline, hypertrichosis, broad and flat nasal bridge, wrinkled facial skin, and pectus excavatum. Developmental defects in the extremities included arachnodactyly and clubfoot. The patient was hospitalized for 27 days at the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit. Neurological, orthopaedic, and ophthalmological consultations led to the diagnosis of axial hypotonia and limbal retinal immaturity. The patient experienced recurring infections of the upper and lower respiratory tract. At 6 weeks, he was admitted to the hospital due to an upper airway infection after 2 days of enteroviral rhinitis. Subtle intercostal retractions were noted. At 12 weeks, the patient presented with fever, cough, and suspected pneumonia, with left-sided crackles present in auscultation. After 3 days of hospitalization, the patient developed tachypnoea, severe dyspnoea, wheezing in the lung fields, and extended inspiration phase. The patient's condition worsened over time, leading to his death at 10 months due to respiratory failure in the course of a respiratory tract infection.",

  "Physical Examination": "The physical examination revealed dysmorphic features including ocular hypotelorism, gothic palate, retrognathism, low-set ears and hairline, hypertrichosis, broad and flat nasal bridge, wrinkled facial skin, and pectus excavatum. Developmental defects in the extremities included arachnodactyly and clubfoot. Axial hypotonia was also noted. During respiratory infections, left-sided crackles were present in auscultation, and the patient later developed tachypnoea, severe dyspnoea, wheezing in the lung fields, and extended inspiration phase.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother had hypothyroidism and gestational diabetes during pregnancy. There was no other significant family medical history reported.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial tests showed elevated levels of cardiac insufficiency markers (NT-proBNP: 10,569.0 pg/ml; Troponin T: 72.2 ng/L). Chest x-ray imaging revealed an enlarged cardiac silhouette. Electrocardiographic findings at 14 weeks included partial right bundle branch block and low voltage of QRS complexes in limb leads. First-day measurements showed significantly elevated γ-glutamyltransferase (GGT) values (1264 U/L), which gradually lowered in the following days. On the 5th day, direct bilirubin was elevated to 2.2 mg%. Biochemical examination during a respiratory infection showed increased levels of inflammatory markers and microcytic anaemia."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Whole exome sequencing (WES) identified a hemizygous variant on chromosome X in the NAA10 gene - p(Ser37Pro). This variant was inherited from the unaffected mother. Echocardiography confirmed the presence of patent foramen ovale (PFO) and ventricular septum defect (VSD), resulting in a mild left-right shunt. Ultrasound imaging of the abdomen did not detect any abnormalities in the size of the organs or signs of inflammation. Imaging of the scrotum ruled out cryptorchidism but confirmed the presence of a left-sided epidydimal cyst (12 × 5 mm). Transfontanellar ultrasonography and subsequent magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) discovered the evolution of the ventricular system from physiological size to middle-grade hydrocephalus."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a newborn female, born via cesarean section at 40 weeks and 4 days gestation. Her birth weight was 3430 g, and she had an Apgar score of 9-9-9. The patient's geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the hospital with a diagnosis of 'high-risk delivery'. During pregnancy, fetal examinations revealed severe hydronephrosis, pericardial effusion, and cauda equina cysts. The patient had difficulty with early feeding due to a weak sucking reflex. She was able to be fully fed orally before discharge, but her sucking power remained poor. The patient was treated with nasal catheter oxygen and anti-infection therapy during hospitalization. She was discharged 13 days after birth when her parents decided to abandon treatment. At an 8-month follow-up, the patient showed delayed gross motor development without seizures.",

  "Physical Examination": "Upon admission, the patient had stable vital signs and breathing. Unique facial features included midface retraction, frontal bossing, and low-set ears. The anterior fontanelle was flat and soft, measuring 3.0 cm x 3.0 cm. There was no flaring of nares, perioral cyanosis, or fingertip cyanosis. Pulmonary examination showed no abnormalities. Heart rate was 125 beats/min with a regular rhythm, and a class II/6 systolic murmur was heard in the precordial region. The abdomen was significantly enlarged with an abdominal circumference of 38 cm and 2-3 bowel sounds/min. The patient had increased muscle tone in the limbs, limited abduction of both upper and lower limbs, bilateral varus, syndactyly of the 4th and 5th toes, and vulvar malformation (dysplasia of the labia majora).",

  "Past Medical History": "This was the mother's first pregnancy. The patient's parents were healthy, not consanguineous, and had no family history of specific diseases. During pregnancy, the mother was diagnosed with gallbladder polyps and hypothyroidism.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Full biochemistry profile, routine blood, urine, and stool examinations, and thyroid function tests were all normal. Tandem mass spectrometry screening of blood and urine samples showed normal results. Chest radiographs revealed broad bones. Color Doppler echocardiography showed atrial septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, and right atrial and right ventricular enlargement. Color Doppler ultrasonography of the urinary system detected bilateral severe hydronephrosis. Cranial color Doppler ultrasonography showed grade II-IVH on the left side and moderate enlargement of bilateral lateral cerebral ventricles. Video electroencephalogram (EEG) showed normal results. No ocular fundus abnormalities were observed. Both ears did not respond to the rapid auditory brainstem response test."
}"

She was able to be fully fed orally before discharge, but her sucking power remained poor. The patient was treated with nasal catheter oxygen and anti-infection therapy during hospitalization. She was discharged 13 days after birth when her parents decided to abandon treatment. At an 8-month follow-up, the patient showed delayed gross motor development without seizures.",

The anterior fontanelle was flat and soft, measuring 3.0 cm x 3.0 cm. There was no flaring of nares, perioral cyanosis, or fingertip cyanosis. Pulmonary examination showed no abnormalities. Heart rate was 125 beats/min with a regular rhythm, and a class II/6 systolic murmur was heard in the precordial region. The patient had increased muscle tone in the limbs, limited abduction of both upper and lower limbs, bilateral varus, syndactyly of the 4th and 5th toes, and vulvar malformation (dysplasia of the labia majora).",

  "Past Medical History": "This was the mother's first pregnancy. The patient's parents were healthy, not consanguineous, and had no family history of specific diseases. During pregnancy, the mother was diagnosed with gallbladder polyps and hypothyroidism.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Full biochemistry profile, routine blood, urine, and stool examinations, and thyroid function tests were all normal. Tandem mass spectrometry screening of blood and urine samples showed normal results. Chest radiographs revealed broad bones. Color Doppler echocardiography showed atrial septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, and right atrial and right ventricular enlargement. Color Doppler ultrasonography of the urinary system detected bilateral severe hydronephrosis. Cranial color Doppler ultrasonography showed grade II-IVH on the left side and moderate enlargement of bilateral lateral cerebral ventricles. Video electroencephalogram (EEG) showed normal results. No ocular fundus abnormalities were observed. Both ears did not respond to the rapid auditory brainstem response test.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Abdominal CT showed a significant increase in the size of both kidneys and signs of severe hydronephrosis in both kidneys. Whole-Exome Sequencing revealed a heterozygous variant (c.2621 A > T, p.Asp874Val) in exon 4 of SETBP1 (NM_015559). This variant was not found in databases including the 1,000 Genomes Project, ExAC gnomAD, and dbSNP. Sanger sequencing confirmed that this was a de novo variant. In silico predictions suggested deleterious effects of this variant on protein function. The variant was classified as likely pathogenic according to American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics guidelines. Protein-DNA/RNA docking analysis suggested that this variant may affect the binding of SETBP1 protein to E3 ubiquitin ligase, potentially impacting SETBP1 protein ubiquitination. Alignment of SETBP1 sequences showed that the amino acid residue at position 874 was strictly conserved."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 27-year-old male patient admitted to our institution for an early postoperative appointment with the cardiovascular surgery group. The patient is located in a geographic region served by the institution.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was initially admitted due to hypovolemic shock secondary to open thoracic trauma caused by a sharp weapon wound in the precordial region. Post-trauma, he required basic life support, a sternotomy, and neurorrhaphy of the superior right lobe and cardiorrhaphy of the right atrium. Postoperative evolution was adequate. During an initial follow-up, an echocardiogram revealed an aorto-atrial fistula with a suspected posttraumatic interventricular communication, leading to his referral to our institution. The patient's functional class declined, presenting with a New York Heart Association (NYHA) class type III/V. The patient had a previous history of myocarditis of unknown origin untreated in 2010, and an intracardiac conduction block with a recommendation for a definitive artificial cardiac pacemaker implantation, which he had previously declined. He also had a history of daily cannabis consumption.",
  "Physical Examination": "During initial evaluation in the Cardiovascular Intensive Care Unit (CICU), bradycardic cardiac rhythms with a grade III/IV holosystolic murmur were auscultated. There was an effacement of the first heart sound, reduced right vesicular murmur extending to the middle third of the right hemithorax, and a third-grade atrioventricular block.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of myocarditis of unknown origin in 2010, which was untreated. He also had an intracardiac conduction block with an indication for definitive pacemaker implantation, which was previously declined. Additionally, he had a history of daily cannabis use.",
  "Initial Test Results": "An electrocardiogram showed a third-grade atrioventricular block. A chest X-ray evidenced a poorly defined opacity in the basal right lung, signs of reduced volume secondary to lobar atelectasis, effacement of the ipsilateral costophrenic angle due to a moderate pleural effusion, and elevation of the right diaphragm due to a right thoracostomy tube. A transthoracic echocardiogram reported biatrial enlargement (left atrium 44 m1/m2, right atrium 35 m1/m2), left ventricle of usual size and morphology without segmental contractility disorders, and preserved systolic function (LVEF 65%). The right cardiac chambers were enlarged with preserved right ventricle systolic function and signs of volume overload, and there was massive functional tricuspid insufficiency (ERO 0.72 cm2, 70 ml regurgitating volume) with an eccentric jet directed towards the right atrium's lateral wall. A Gerbode type defect was observed using shaken saline solution as contrast fluid."
}"

The right cardiac chambers were enlarged with preserved right ventricle systolic function and signs of volume overload, and there was massive functional tricuspid insufficiency (ERO 0.72 cm2, 70 ml regurgitating volume) with an eccentric jet directed towards the right atrium's lateral wall. A Gerbode type defect was observed using shaken saline solution as contrast fluid.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "During surgery, structural changes in the right cardiac chambers, previous extra-institutional atrial cardiorrhaphy, tricuspid ring dilation, and a defect communicating the left ventricle with the right atrium above the tricuspid valve were identified. A surgical closure of Gerbode's defect was performed. Intraoperative findings included structural changes in the right chambers, previous atrial cardiorrhaphy, and a defect communicating the left ventricle with the right atrium above the tricuspid valve. A follow-up transesophageal echocardiogram reported satisfactory closure of the tricuspid valve and Gerbode's defect. On the eighth postoperative day, a definitive cardiac resynchronization therapy pacemaker with coronary sinus stimulation was implanted. The patient was discharged on postoperative day 10."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 5-day-old male neonate, born at 39-week gestation by spontaneous vaginal delivery with normal Apgar scores. He is the third child of non-consanguineous parents.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with core phenotypes of ARCND (auriculo-condylar syndrome), including decreased mouth opening, micrognathia, microstomia, prominent cheeks, glossoptosis, and postauricular tags. He suffered from respiratory distress within 4 days after birth, requiring referral to the hospital. The patient had poor feeding. At 17 days after birth, the patient underwent bilateral mandibular osteotomy and distraction osteogenesis. A second procedure was performed at 16 months old to improve mandibular growth. At 10 months old, his primary teeth erupted but were crowded with fragile enamel. At the age of 2 years, the patient had normal developmental milestones; however, his speech articulation difficulties persisted and required gesturing or pointing for communication.",

  "Physical Examination": "Clinical examination showed normal heart and limb function. Hearing was normal in the patient.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has an unremarkable family history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Bloodwork, liver/kidney function, electrolytes, cardiomyopathy markers, and urine/stool analysis were unremarkable."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 5-day-old male neonate, born at 39-week gestation by spontaneous vaginal delivery with normal Apgar scores. He is the third child of non-consanguineous parents.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with core phenotypes of ARCND (auriculo-condylar syndrome), including decreased mouth opening, micrognathia, microstomia, prominent cheeks, glossoptosis, and postauricular tags. He suffered from respiratory distress within 4 days after birth, requiring referral to the hospital. The patient had poor feeding. At 17 days after birth, the patient underwent bilateral mandibular osteotomy and distraction osteogenesis. A second procedure was performed at 16 months old to improve mandibular growth. At 10 months old, his primary teeth erupted but were crowded with fragile enamel. At the age of 2 years, the patient had normal developmental milestones; however, his speech articulation difficulties persisted and required gesturing or pointing for communication.",

  "Physical Examination": "Clinical examination showed normal heart and limb function. Hearing was normal in the patient.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has an unremarkable family history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Bloodwork, liver/kidney function, electrolytes, cardiomyopathy markers, and urine/stool analysis were unremarkable.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Computed tomography (CT) revealed a narrowed oropharynx airway and absent condylar fossae, shortened mandibular rami, and obtuse mandibular angles. Fibrobronchoscopy showed a sagging root tongue, enlarged lingual tubercle, and left bronchomalacia. Trio whole-exome sequencing (WES) was performed to identify the molecular etiology of the child's medical condition. Peripheral blood was collected from the child and his parents. Leukocyte DNA was extracted and sequenced using a MiSeq sequencer. The sequenced reads were aligned to the human reference genome. Candidate variants were verified by Sanger sequencing. Various online analysis tools were used to predict potentially harmful biological variants. Public SNP databases were searched for annotation of variants. The output was curated based on ACMG guidelines. Conservative analysis of the variant sites was conducted using GERP++, PhyloP, and PhastCons. The crystal structure of human PLCB4 was used to predict the structures of the wild-type and mutated PLCB4."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 66-year-old woman from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the emergency department with complaints of daily watery diarrhea for the previous 18 months. The diarrhea episodes were progressively becoming more frequent over time (up to 15 times a day, even during the night) and did not improve with fasting. She also reported anorexia, unquantified weight loss and night sweats, but denied episodes of flushing. The patient was started on ocreotide LAR with marked symptom improvement and stability of the lesions on 68-Ga DOTATOC PET/CT scan. However, she eventually developed progression of the disease with liver failure and passed away after 2 years of follow-up.",

  "Physical Examination": "On admission, the patient was described as dehydrated, hypertensive (BP 190/90 mmHg) and tachycardic (HR 110 bpm). A palpable painful hepatomegaly and marked confluent telangiectasias of the nose and malar regions were also evident.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of smoking and uncontrolled hypertension.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial laboratory tests revealed elevated inflammatory markers, mild hyponatremia and hypokalemia with normal kidney function, hypoalbuminemia, direct hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated cholestatic liver enzymes. Abdominal ultrasonography confirmed hepatomegaly with multiple space-occupying lesions consistent with diffuse liver metastasis. A transthoracic echocardiogram exhibited thickening and retraction of the tricuspid valve leaflets, as well as moderate to severe regurgitation, coherent with carcinoid heart disease."
}"

She also reported anorexia, unquantified weight loss and night sweats, but denied episodes of flushing. However, she eventually developed progression of the disease with liver failure and passed away after 2 years of follow-up.",

  "Physical Examination": "On admission, the patient was described as dehydrated, hypertensive (BP 190/90 mmHg) and tachycardic (HR 110 bpm). A palpable painful hepatomegaly and marked confluent telangiectasias of the nose and malar regions were also evident.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of smoking and uncontrolled hypertension.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial laboratory tests revealed elevated inflammatory markers, mild hyponatremia and hypokalemia with normal kidney function, hypoalbuminemia, direct hyperbilirubinemia, and elevated cholestatic liver enzymes. Abdominal ultrasonography confirmed hepatomegaly with multiple space-occupying lesions consistent with diffuse liver metastasis. A transthoracic echocardiogram exhibited thickening and retraction of the tricuspid valve leaflets, as well as moderate to severe regurgitation, coherent with carcinoid heart disease.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Computed tomography scan of the chest, abdomen and pelvis was remarkable for a hypervascular intraluminal mass in the terminal ileum, hepatomegaly (207 mm) with more than 10 solid hypervascular lesions with necrotic/cystic areas, the largest measuring 108 mm, as well as bilateral ovarian metastatic nodules. Further laboratory tests documented high blood levels of chromogranin A (441.7 ng/mL) and elevated 24-h urinary 5-hydrocyindoleacetic acid (5-HIAA) concentration (>75 mg/day). A liver biopsy was performed, establishing the diagnosis of well differentiated NET G1. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 28-day-old girl born after a full-term, uneventful pregnancy. The mother was infected with SARS-CoV-2 during the third trimester. There is no family history of epilepsy, neurological, or other metabolic disorders, including hypocalcemia.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The parents noted abnormal movements from birth, initially 1–3 episodes/day that increased to 4–5 seizures/hour lasting 1–2 minutes one day prior to admission. Seizures were controlled through a combination of antiepileptic medications, initiating with a loading dose of phenobarbital followed by oral administration and the subsequent addition of intravenous levetiracetam. Seizures persisted until topiramate was introduced. Following antiepileptic treatment, the seizures ceased, and treatments for hypocalcemia were initiated. Over the next 5-month follow-up, serum calcium levels were monitored monthly, and calcitriol doses were adjusted. The infant developed normally but experienced two short febrile seizures at 7 and 10 months, leading to a decision against resuming antiepileptic medication.",
  "Physical Examination": "The ictal recording during v-EEG showed right focal to bilateral clonic seizures with hemifacial clonic movements spreading to the superior and inferior right limbs, ending with an opisthotonic posture. Interictal v-EEG revealed normal background activity with rare spike and wave discharges in the left frontocentral brain regions. An ophthalmological examination showed no abnormalities.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient received oral cholecalciferol for rickets prophylaxis before admission, which was switched to oral calcitriol upon the diagnosis of hypoparathyroidism. There was no relevant family history of epilepsy, neurological disorders, or metabolic disorders, including hypocalcemia.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Routine blood tests revealed hypocalcemia (total serum calcium 5.94 mg/dL), hypomagnesemia (1.41 mg/dL), and hyperphosphatemia (10.48 mg/dL). Liver and kidney function tests were normal, with no inflammation markers. Hypercalciuria and hypophosphaturia were present. Parathyroid hormone levels were low at 2.3 pg/mL. Serum Na, K, and Cl levels were within normal ranges. ECG showed a prolonged QT interval secondary to hypocalcemia."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "12-year-old male, height 141 cm (25th-50th percentile), weight 31 kg (25th percentile), head circumference 54 cm (>97th percentile), testicular volumes 12 ml (borderline enlargement), appropriate social interactions and good eye contact, school performance below average particularly in language and mathematics, IQ of 75 (verbal = 79, performance = 75). Geographic location not specified.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred for genetic testing because his younger brother was diagnosed with a full mutation of a genetic condition. The patient had normal prenatal and postnatal development. He achieved early developmental milestones late, specifically walking at approximately 2 years of age. His face did not present notable genetic features, such as a long, narrow face or prominent jaw, nor did he have prominent ears. His physical appearance was shy, but he showed good cooperation during social interactions. His younger brother, diagnosed at 6 years of age, showed full features of the same genetic condition, including macrocephaly, a long and narrow face, prominent ears, attention deficit and hyperactivity, flat feet, hyperextensible joints, and macroorchidism.",
  "Physical Examination": "At 12 years of age, the patient had a height of 141 cm (25th-50th percentile) and a weight of 31 kg (25th percentile). His head circumference was 54 cm (>97th percentile). Testicular volumes were borderline enlarged at 12 ml. His face did not have notable features such as a long, narrow face, prominent jaw, or prominent ears.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no medical complications during his prenatal and postnatal periods. His early developmental milestones were unremarkable except for walking, which was delayed until approximately 2 years of age. The patient’s mother is a premutation carrier as indicated by her genetic test results. There is no additional family medical history provided.",
  "Initial Test Results": "The patient, his parents, and unaffected brother underwent genetic testing. Fluorescent PCR testing of the patient’s FMR1 gene showed approximately 101 CGG repeats. His mother's results showed a premutation carrier status with 37/∼140 CGG repeats. Southern blot analysis revealed that the mother also carried the full mutation allele. Test results demonstrated that the patient carried both unmethylated and methylated FMR1 alleles likely due to random X-inactivation of the premutation allele."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 15-year-old boy of unspecified race and geographic location. He has a 46, XY karyotype.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the hospital with complaints of delayed secondary sexual characteristics and bilateral non-palpable testes. He had a history of ear anomalies, hearing loss, mental retardation, short stature, posterior nasal atresia, and patent ductus arteriosus. At 3 and 7 years old, he was diagnosed with bilateral migrating testes, but follow-up visits were interrupted until he was 15 years old. At 7 years old, his height was 105 cm, which was 2.5 standard deviations below the age-appropriate mean. Genitourinary abnormalities included delayed development of pubic hair (Tanner Stage 1) and micropenis (Tanner Stage 2). Testes were not palpable bilaterally in the scrotum or inguinal canal and were not detectable on ultrasonography. Laparoscopic exploration revealed testicular vessels leading into the inguinal canals on both sides. Further laparoscopic groin exploration identified atrophic testes in the groin canals, which were pulled into the abdominal cavity. Due to absent testosterone secretory function, bilateral orchiectomy was performed. The patient has been receiving testosterone replacement therapy since the orchiectomy.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed short stature, delayed development of pubic hair (Tanner Stage 1), micropenis (Tanner Stage 2), and bilateral non-palpable testes in the scrotum or inguinal canal. Ear anomalies were also noted.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's medical history included ear anomalies, hearing loss, mental retardation, short stature, posterior nasal atresia, and patent ductus arteriosus. He was diagnosed with bilateral migrating testes at 3 and 7 years old.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Ultrasonography failed to detect either testis. Blood tests revealed low serum concentrations of FSH (0.33 mIU/mL), LH (0.10 mIU/mL), and total testosterone (<0.03 ng/mL). Serum ACTH, PRL, and GH levels were within the reference ranges. FSH and LH were hyporesponsive to GnRH stimulation. The hCG stimulation test did not increase the serum testosterone concentration. These findings indicated both primary and secondary hypogonadism."
}"

He had a history of ear anomalies, hearing loss, mental retardation, short stature, posterior nasal atresia, and patent ductus arteriosus. At 3 and 7 years old, he was diagnosed with bilateral migrating testes, but follow-up visits were interrupted until he was 15 years old. At 7 years old, his height was 105 cm, which was 2.5 standard deviations below the age-appropriate mean. Genitourinary abnormalities included delayed development of pubic hair (Tanner Stage 1) and micropenis (Tanner Stage 2). Testes were not palpable bilaterally in the scrotum or inguinal canal and were not detectable on ultrasonography.   "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed short stature, delayed development of pubic hair (Tanner Stage 1), micropenis (Tanner Stage 2), and bilateral non-palpable testes in the scrotum or inguinal canal. Ear anomalies were also noted.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's medical history included ear anomalies, hearing loss, mental retardation, short stature, posterior nasal atresia, and patent ductus arteriosus. He was diagnosed with bilateral migrating testes at 3 and 7 years old.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Ultrasonography failed to detect either testis. Blood tests revealed low serum concentrations of FSH (0.33 mIU/mL), LH (0.10 mIU/mL), and total testosterone (<0.03 ng/mL). Serum ACTH, PRL, and GH levels were within the reference ranges. FSH and LH were hyporesponsive to GnRH stimulation. The hCG stimulation test did not increase the serum testosterone concentration. These findings indicated both primary and secondary hypogonadism.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "CT of the head showed no abnormalities in the brain, including the hypothalamus and pituitary gland. Chromosomal G-banding analysis showed a 46, XY karyotype. Sequence analysis of the CHD7 gene revealed an 8-nucleotide deletion in exon 4 (c.2099_2106delAATAAGAA) of CHD7. Histological examination of the excised testes showed atrophic seminiferous tubules with only Sertoli cells apparent. Germ cells were large and atypical with nuclear atypia and clear cytoplasm. Immunohistochemical staining of germ cells showed weak positivity for CD117 and SALL4, indicating maturation arrest of spermatogenesis and germ cell neoplasia in situ (GCNIS) in bilateral testes. Immunohistochemical staining for testosterone-synthesizing enzymes (P450scc, P45017α, 3β-HSD, and 17β-HSD) in Leydig cells was negative, while staining for the transcription factor Ad4BP/SF-1 was positive. These results suggested that testosterone synthesis was impaired at the enzymatic level, not at the transcriptional level."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 24-year-old female from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the hospital in December 2009 with complaints of right hip pain and limited mobility for over a year following a fall. The pain limited movement but was slightly relieved with rest, allowing her to walk. She had multiple skin pigmentations at birth and was diagnosed with a facial bone deformity at the age of 14. The patient had normal menstruation and secondary sexual characteristics and delivered a child naturally at the age of 24. She received 5 mg of zoledronic acid through intravenous infusion four times between 2009 and 2013, along with oral calcium supplementation. Total hip replacement (THA) was performed on the right side in July 2010. In December 2013, the patient underwent orthopedic surgery and a right supracondylar osteotomy. In May 2015, the patient sustained a left femoral shaft fracture due to a fall and underwent internal fixation with plates and screws. In December 2015, the right femoral plate was removed to prevent stress concentration and subsequent fracture in the femoral shaft. The patient was treated for submaxillary infection and mandibular osteonecrosis at another hospital in 2017 and 2018.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had multiple untreated skeletal abnormalities, including double hip varus deformity, flexion contracture, and adduction deformity of the right hip and bilateral knee valgus deformity. Multiple skin pigmentations were present at birth.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a 10-year history of multiple untreated skeletal abnormalities. She was diagnosed with a facial bone deformity at the age of 14. The patient had normal menstruation and secondary sexual characteristics and delivered a child naturally at the age of 24.",

  "Initial Test Results": "X-ray on admission revealed multiple cystic areas of bone densification and ground glass density in both the lower limb long bones and skull, thinning of the bone cortex and deformation of the bilateral femoral shaft and cervical trunk angle. Blood biochemistry findings showed markedly increased levels of serum alkaline phosphatase (670 IU/L, normal value: 40–160 IU/L) and osteocalcin (219.6 ng/ml, normal value: 11–43 ng/ml). Serum calcium concentration was within the reference range, and other endocrine indices were not abnormal. In July 2010, postoperative alkaline phosphatase and osteocalcin levels were 538 IU/L and 192.5 ng/ml, respectively. In December 2013, alkaline phosphatase and osteocalcin levels were 403 IU/L and 246.30 ng/ml, respectively."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "Male infant, term born vaginally, weighing 3065 grams. He was the fourth child of consanguineous parents (first degree cousins). Geographic information is not specified.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "He developed watery, urine-like diarrhea on the 3rd day of his life. When he was 1 month old, he weighed 2700 grams (Z score: -4.3) and was 53 cm (Z score: -1.8) tall. He was defecating 14-18 times a day. He was fed only with TPN and was receiving aggressive intravenous fluid replacement. He developed cholestasis which regressed at 5 months of age. By the age of 2 months, he started to have abdominal distension and pseudo obstructions. His stool volume was above 250 ml/kg per day, and he was defecating 2-6 times a day. He was still fed only with total parenteral nutrition and was receiving aggressive intravenous fluid replacement. On the postnatal 6th day, he weighed 2750 grams, became dehydrated, and had metabolic acidosis. He was hospitalized throughout his life due to dependence on TPN and aggressive intravenous fluid replacement. He developed complications such as catheter-related sepsis, iron deficiency anemia, catheter-related thrombosis, vitamin D deficiency, hepatosteatosis, and non-selective proteinuria. His psychomotor development was below expectations for his age. He started walking at 18 months, and at the age of 3, he could only use a few words. He never started oral feeding. He died at 3 years and 4 months old.",
  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination details directly provided other than the association with psychomotor delay and his physical growth parameters.",
  "Past Medical History": "Complications throughout his life included catheter-related sepsis, iron deficiency anemia, catheter-related thrombosis, vitamin D deficiency, hepatosteatosis, and non-selective proteinuria. He never initiated oral feeding and was dependent on TPN. He developed cholestasis which regressed at 5 months of age. His psychomotor development was delayed, starting walking at 18 months and using only a few words by age 3.",
  "Initial Test Results": "On the postnatal 6th day, he weighed 2750 grams, became dehydrated, and had metabolic acidosis. His mean fecal volume was 1100 cc/day (400 cc/kg/day). In his stool: Potassium was 20 mEq/L, sodium was 84 mEq/L, and chlorine was below 20 mEq/L. Stool osmotic gap: 82 mOsm/kg. Diarrhea continued in the fasting state. On the postnatal 20th day, upper GI endoscopy had a normal appearance. Light microscopic examination of the duodenal biopsy showed moderate villous blunting with mildly increased inflammatory cells in the lamina propria and intraepithelial lymphocytosis. Enterocytes at the villous tips showed an irregular vacuolated appearance in the apical cytoplasm with patchy absence of the brush border. Surface epithelial brush border exhibited an abnormal pattern of PAS and CD10 staining instead of the normal linear pattern. Electron microscopy revealed intracytoplasmic inclusions lined by intact microvilli in the apical cytoplasm of enterocytes, associated with poorly developed surface brush border microvilli."
}"

He was still fed only with total parenteral nutrition and was receiving aggressive intravenous fluid replacement. On the postnatal 6th day, he weighed 2750 grams, became dehydrated, and had metabolic acidosis. He was hospitalized throughout his life due to dependence on TPN and aggressive intravenous fluid replacement. He developed complications such as catheter-related sepsis, iron deficiency anemia, catheter-related thrombosis, vitamin D deficiency, hepatosteatosis, and non-selective proteinuria. His psychomotor development was below expectations for his age. He started walking at 18 months, and at the age of 3, he could only use a few words. He never started oral feeding. He died at 3 years and 4 months old.",
  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination details directly provided other than the association with psychomotor delay and his physical growth parameters.",
  "Past Medical History": "Complications throughout his life included catheter-related sepsis, iron deficiency anemia, catheter-related thrombosis, vitamin D deficiency, hepatosteatosis, and non-selective proteinuria. He never initiated oral feeding and was dependent on TPN. He developed cholestasis which regressed at 5 months of age. His psychomotor development was delayed, starting walking at 18 months and using only a few words by age 3.",
  "Initial Test Results": "On the postnatal 6th day, he weighed 2750 grams, became dehydrated, and had metabolic acidosis. His mean fecal volume was 1100 cc/day (400 cc/kg/day). In his stool: Potassium was 20 mEq/L, sodium was 84 mEq/L, and chlorine was below 20 mEq/L. Stool osmotic gap: 82 mOsm/kg. Diarrhea continued in the fasting state. On the postnatal 20th day, upper GI endoscopy had a normal appearance. Light microscopic examination of the duodenal biopsy showed moderate villous blunting with mildly increased inflammatory cells in the lamina propria and intraepithelial lymphocytosis. Enterocytes at the villous tips showed an irregular vacuolated appearance in the apical cytoplasm with patchy absence of the brush border. Surface epithelial brush border exhibited an abnormal pattern of PAS and CD10 staining instead of the normal linear pattern. Electron microscopy revealed intracytoplasmic inclusions lined by intact microvilli in the apical cytoplasm of enterocytes, associated with poorly developed surface brush border microvilli.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Surgical full thickness ileal and colonic biopsies were taken. Histopathological features of ileal biopsy showed no muscular or neurologic abnormality. Microvillus inclusions were detected by electron microscopy. Colonic biopsies were normal with no epithelial abnormality. Genetic analysis detected Homozygous c.1323-2A>G mutation of the MYO5B gene."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 54-year-old male seeking treatment in the digestive department. His body mass index is 22.9 kg/m2.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient has experienced recurrent diarrhea for the past 10 years, accompanied by abdominal distension, weight loss, and occasional abdominal pain. Recently, he has had frequent diarrhea, occurring five to six times per day, with yellow, loose, or watery stools. He also reports perianal pain and dull pain in the posterior lateral muscle group of the left thigh, which affects his walking. The day before seeking medical attention, he developed a fever. The patient has undergone multiple surgeries at other hospitals during this period.",

  "Physical Examination": "The physical examination revealed swollen perianal skin, but no obvious external opening was observed.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a 10-year history of recurrent diarrhea and has undergone multiple surgeries at other hospitals.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The three-dimensional computed tomography (CT) imaging of the patient's small intestine and blood vessels showed segmental inflammation of the ileum, inflammatory thickening of the rectal and anal walls, narrowing and obstruction of the intestinal lumen, and secondary colon dilation and fluid accumulation. Widespread inflammation and fistula formation were found in the lower segment of the rectum and perianal space, sacral anterior space, bilateral ischiorectal fossa, and gluteus maximus muscle space."
}"

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient has experienced recurrent diarrhea for the past 10 years, accompanied by abdominal distension, weight loss, and occasional abdominal pain. Recently, he has had frequent diarrhea, occurring five to six times per day, with yellow, loose, or watery stools. He also reports perianal pain and dull pain in the posterior lateral muscle group of the left thigh, which affects his walking. The day before seeking medical attention, he developed a fever. The patient has undergone multiple surgeries at other hospitals during this period.",

  "Physical Examination": "The physical examination revealed swollen perianal skin, but no obvious external opening was observed.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a 10-year history of recurrent diarrhea and has undergone multiple surgeries at other hospitals.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The three-dimensional computed tomography (CT) imaging of the patient's small intestine and blood vessels showed segmental inflammation of the ileum, inflammatory thickening of the rectal and anal walls, narrowing and obstruction of the intestinal lumen, and secondary colon dilation and fluid accumulation. Widespread inflammation and fistula formation were found in the lower segment of the rectum and perianal space, sacral anterior space, bilateral ischiorectal fossa, and gluteus maximus muscle space.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Colonoscopy revealed black-speckled changes throughout the entire colonic mucosa. Biopsies were performed in multiple locations of the colon. The pathological results indicated mild inflammation of the intestinal mucosa, with aggregation of tissue cells that phagocytose pigments in the lamina propria. The colon lesion was consistent with changes in colonic melanosis. No crypt deformation or non-caseating granuloma was observed in the biopsy specimens. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) results showed extensive inflammation and fistula formation in the lower rectal segment and the perianal space, sacral anterior space, bilateral ischiorectal fossa, and gluteus maximus space, as well as the formation of perianal abscess. A biopsy of three skin tissue samples was performed, and the pathological results indicated perianal mucinous adenocarcinoma."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 40-year-old female patient from an unspecified geographic location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with left abdominal pain accompanied by diarrhea for one week on August 9, 2023. She did not have hematochezia. She had consulted with a vascular interventionalist before admission and was given oral rivaroxaban. After her admission, she continued to receive oral rivaroxaban. On August 11, 2023, upper gastrointestinal endoscopy showed superficial gastritis without gastroesophageal varices (Figure 2A and 2B). On August 14, 2023, CECT scans were performed again, still showing low-density lesions in the proximal splenic vein (Figure 1B). At this time, abdominal pain alleviated, but ISVT remained. She was informed about the efficacy and safety of thrombolysis and agreed to receive systemic thrombolysis with continuous intravenous injection of urokinase 500000u every 12 hours for a duration of 7 days. During this period, she did not develop any bleeding event. On August 22, 2023, abdominal pain disappeared, and CECT scans showed a slight decrease in thrombus extension (Figure 1C). She was discharged with long-term use of oral rivaroxaban. On September 26, 2023, D-dimer level was 0.19 mg/L, and CECT scans showed that the splenic vein became a fibrotic cord.",
  "Physical Examination": "",
  "Past Medical History": "She had no history of serious comorbidities or pancreatic diseases. She had no history of smoking. She took oral contraceptives (drospirenone 3mg and ethinylestradiol 0.03mg) daily during the past three months.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests on initial admission showed a D-dimer level of 2.02 mg/L (reference range: 0.00–0.55 mg/L). Other tests such as antithrombin III, plasma protein C activity, plasma protein S activity, kappa chain, lambda chain, antiphospholipid syndrome antibody, and thrombelastography (TEG) profile were within their reference ranges."
}"

  "Physical Examination": "",

Other tests such as antithrombin III, plasma protein C activity, plasma protein S activity, kappa chain, lambda chain, antiphospholipid syndrome antibody, and thrombelastography (TEG) profile were within their reference ranges.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Contrast-enhanced computer tomography (CECT) scans on initial admission showed unenhanced lesions in the splenic vein suggesting ISVT (Figure 1A). On August 14, 2023, CECT scans still showed low-density lesions in the proximal splenic vein (Figure 1B). Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a man in his 40s from an urban area. He is married, never smoked, and had an alcohol intake of 70–80 g weekly. He travels to underdeveloped and tropical countries once or twice yearly for work, staying in rural areas.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient's symptoms began 4-5 years prior to admission with intermittent back and migratory peripheral joint pain, mainly in small joints of hands and feet, but also in large joints like knees and shoulders. The pain was described as a mild ache with inflammatory features, severe at night and on waking, improving with mobility. Nine months before admission, his arthralgia worsened, particularly in the lower back and sacroiliac joints. He was diagnosed with ankylosing spondylitis and treated with secukinumab for 4-5 months without improvement. Two months before admission, he started adalimumab, which paradoxically worsened his joint pain and led to new symptoms including low-grade fever, night sweats, lethargy, and anorexia. On admission, he reported a 15 kg weight loss over 4 months, low-grade fever, drenching night sweats for 2-4 weeks, and a 6-week cough productive of minimal white-yellow sputum. He did not have abdominal pain, change in bowel habits, or other gastrointestinal symptoms.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient appeared unwell and cachectic with generalized muscle wasting and a fever of 38°C. Other vital signs were within normal limits. There were no rashes or lymphadenopathy. Cardiac examination revealed no murmur or stigmata of endocarditis. Abdominal examination was unremarkable, with no organomegaly and normal bowel sounds. There was no joint swelling or erythema.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no chronic medical issues, allergies, or use of medications before this illness. He had no family history of auto-immune, malignant, or other illnesses. He owned a dog for a long time with no other exposure to animals and never used intravenous or other illicit substances.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial blood tests showed normocytic anemia, neutrophilia, lymphopenia, elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate, and C-reactive protein (CRP), with negative HLA-B27 test. On admission, blood tests showed worsening anemia, ongoing neutrophilia, and further elevation of inflammatory markers. Faecal calprotectin level was mildly elevated at 73 μg/g. Transthoracic echocardiography showed normal biventricular function, normal valvular structure, and function with no features of endocarditis. Extensive workup for uncommon infectious causes of fever was within normal or negative range."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "MRI of the spine and sacrum showed bilateral sacro-ileitis and active bilateral sacro-ileitis with chronic changes on repeat. FDG-PET scan showed diffuse uptake throughout the stomach, mild focal uptake in the caecum and ascending colon, avid 21 × 16 mm enlarged para-aortic lymph node uptake, and multiple mildly to moderately avid enlarged mesenteric nodes. Endoscopic examinations revealed severe nodular gastritis throughout the stomach, a 2 cm punched-out ulcer in the gastric body, and normal duodenal and jejunal mucosa. Biopsies showed non-specific inflammatory changes throughout the gastrointestinal tract, with scattered and focally clustered foamy histiocytes containing granular periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) and diastase PAS-positive material. Tropheryma whipplei PCR was positive in the jejunum and serum. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) Tropheryma Whipplei PCR was also positive. MRI of the Brain showed small hyperintense FLAIR/T2 signal foci in the subcortical white matter of the frontal lobes bilaterally."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 12-day-old male of Chinese origin was born to unaffected non-consanguineous parents by spontaneous vaginal delivery at 37 weeks +3 of gestation with a birthweight of 1.99 kg (<3rd centile).",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the ENT Department of a general hospital in Beijing, China. The initial hearing screen was performed within 72 hours using transiently evoked otoacoustic emission (TEOAE) testing. Auditory brainstem response (ABR), auditory steady state response (ASSR), distortion product otoacoustic emission (DPOAE), and acoustic immittance were performed by the age of 23 months to evaluate hearing loss. The child had mild facial dysmorphic features including short palpebral fissures and a short philtrum. Deformed digits were noted on the left hand. At 38 days old, a definitive molecular diagnosis was reached consistent with the clinical presentation. Physical examination at 23 months showed severe growth retardation with a length of 72 cm (<3rd centile), weight of 8.5 kg (<3rd centile), and head circumference of 46 cm (<3rd centile). Psychomotor development was normal for age. Multiple facial dysmorphic features included short palpebral fissures, short philtrum, a narrow mouth with a thin upper lip, maxillary hypoplasia, and prognathism. The patient walked independently on his tiptoes, with walking instability related to knee flexion and popliteal ligament tightness. Complete syndactyly of fingers 3-4 with fusion of the bones in the left hand was identified. The boy's right testicle had descended into the scrotum, and his left testicle had not. Although the patient did not pass the hearing screening, a systematic auditory functional evaluation showed normal hearing; therefore, follow-up is needed.",
  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination at birth showed the child had mild facial dysmorphic features including short palpebral fissures and a short philtrum. Deformed digits were noted on the left hand. At 23 months, severe growth retardation was observed with a length of 72 cm (<3rd centile), weight of 8.5 kg (<3rd centile), and head circumference of 46 cm (<3rd centile). Multiple facial dysmorphic features included short palpebral fissures, short philtrum, a narrow mouth with a thin upper lip, maxillary hypoplasia, and prognathism. The patient was walking independently on his tiptoes, with walking instability related to knee flexion and popliteal ligament tightness. Complete syndactyly of fingers 3-4 with fusion of the bones in the left hand was identified. The boy's right testicle had descended into the scrotum, and his left testicle had not.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother suffered from gestational hypertension and gestational diabetes during pregnancy. The parents reported no history of stillbirth or miscarriage.",
  "Initial Test Results": "An initial hearing screen was performed using TEOAE testing within 72 hours. Cardiac structure and function were evaluated by electrocardiography (ECG) and color Doppler echocardiography."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 51-year-old female from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was brought to the emergency department (ED) by her son due to a first-time episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizure. The seizure was associated with tongue-biting and eye-rolling. A family member who witnessed the event reported that the patient was confused for more than 20 minutes after the episode before returning to her baseline. In the ED, the patient received levetiracetam. The neurologist on call requested to admit the patient and advised stopping levetiracetam. The patient's hospital course was uneventful, and she was discharged after 2 days with future follow-up scheduled in the neurology clinic. However, the patient lost follow-up.",

  "Physical Examination": "In the emergency department, the patient's vital signs were within normal limits. Neurological examination was unremarkable except for a tongue laceration. Cranial nerves, sensation, and motor functions in both upper and lower extremities were all intact. Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs were negative. The examination of other systems was unremarkable.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of diabetes, hypertension, and neuroendocrine malignancy of the rectum treated with chemotherapy and radiotherapy.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The results of the lab workup, including electrolytes and glucose levels, were all within normal ranges. A non-contrast computed tomography (CT) was performed, which showed no acute intracranial lesions or bleeding. No epileptiform waves were detected in EEG studies."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 28-year-old female patient with an obstetric score of G2P1A0 L1 presented in her third trimester. She is located in the USA.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient complained of progressive visual loss for 6 months. She was a known case of an unspecified autosomal dominant condition with secondary glaucoma in both eyes (OU), diagnosed in 2018. She was taking dorzolamide hydrochloride 2%, timolol maleate 0.5%, and bimatoprost 0.02% to control IOPs. Her clinical status remained stable on maximal medical therapy until 2018 when she conceived. In early 2019, during her second pregnancy, the patient noticed a drop in visual acuity in OU as pregnancy progressed. Bimatoprost eye drops were stopped after conception. The progressive nature of glaucoma with useful vision in one eye necessitated immediate surgical intervention. Consultation and risk weighing led to the implantation of a valved glaucoma drainage device (GDD) in the right eye (OD) under sub-tenon's anesthesia with fetal monitoring. Post-surgery, the IOP was controlled with a regimen of topical antibiotic, steroid, brinzolamide, and timolol. After the child was delivered, the refractory nature of the glaucoma resolved. In the postpartum period, the left eye (OS) was operated on with a modified trabeculectomy and managed with brinzolamide/timolol fixed combination and bimatoprost due to bleb scarring. Her newborn son was affected by the same autosomal dominant condition without features of glaucoma.",
  "Physical Examination": "At presentation in 2019, best corrected visual acuity was 20/80 in the right eye (OD) and 20/400 in the left eye (OS). IOP by applanation was 38 mm Hg in OD and 32 mm Hg in OS despite maximal medical therapy. The lids, conjunctiva, and lens appeared normal. The cornea had posterior embryotoxon with iris features showing corectopia and pseudopolycoria OU. There was evidence of advanced glaucomatous damage and advanced visual field loss. Facial examination revealed mild craniofacial dysmorphism.",
  "Past Medical History": "Past medical history includes gestational diabetes mellitus. There is a family history of an unspecified autosomal dominant condition. The patient’s 5-year-old daughter does not have this condition, but her newborn son is affected without any features of glaucoma.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Initial test results included visual acuity tests (20/80 in OD and 20/400 in OS), IOP measurements (38 mm Hg in OD and 32 mm Hg in OS), and intraoperative fetal monitoring. The lids, conjunctiva, and lens were normal on examination, and the cornea examination revealed posterior embryotoxon with iris abnormalities."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 47-day-old female infant from Maharashtra, India.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The infant presented with complete bilateral cleft lip and palate, congenital depression on the forehead of the skull, polydactyly of hands and feet, camptodactyly of hands and feet, prominent prolabium, collapsed nasal structure, abnormal or incomplete formation of the pelvic region, transient abdominal telangiectasia (also known as venous geography), club foot, and triphalangeal thumb on both limbs.",

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 3-day-old female Asian neonate. She was born to a 23-year-old primigravida mother through institutionalized c-section delivery. She resides in a geographic location represented by typical Asian demographic settings.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The chief complaint is the absence of an eyelid in the right eye. The neonate was admitted to the NICU for 2 days due to respiratory difficulty. The mother reported mild oligohydramnios, high blood glucose levels during 6 to 7 months of pregnancy, and a history of cord looping around the neck of the fetus at 33 weeks of gestation. No history of toxoplasma, rubella, radiation exposure, drug use, fever, or genitourinary infections during the pregnancy. There were no other developmental abnormalities reported. There is no history of cryptophthalmos or other significant abnormalities in immediate or distant families.",
  "Physical Examination": "On inspection, there is an absence of the eyelid, eyebrow, and eyelashes in the right eye, collectively known as adnexal structures. The left eye was apparently normal. The head circumference, anterior fontanelle, and nasal bridge were normal. There were no significant findings in the head-to-toe examination. No other congenital defects of the ears, respiratory system, or fingers existed. The auditory and motor examinations were found to be normal.",
  "Past Medical History": "The neonate's past medical history includes a 2-day NICU admission for respiratory difficulty immediately after birth. The mother reported a bad obstetric history but no history of abortions. There is no history of cryptophthalmos or other significant abnormalities in immediate or distant families. No maternal history of fever or genitourinary infections during the pregnancy.",
  "Initial Test Results": "B-scan ultrasonography for both eyes was performed. The right eye B scan revealed the absence of a posterior chamber and membranous lens, a shallow anterior chamber, and a posterior staphyloma. The scan of the left eye revealed a central flat anterior chamber and the presence of a posterior chamber. The Chest X-ray was normal. USG revealed mild hydronephrosis in the right kidney and irregular urinary bladder walls."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 36-year-old woman (gravida 2, para 1) who conceived naturally. She is from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient's initial visit was at 12 weeks of gestation. At 16 weeks of gestation, her blood pressure was slightly elevated at 123/76 mmHg. Self-monitoring of blood pressure and low-dose aspirin were initiated due to the risk of preeclampsia. Her blood pressure continued to increase and reached approximately 160/110 mmHg at the end of 17 weeks of gestation. At 18 weeks and 4 days of gestation, she had an unplanned visit to the hospital with complaints of headache, nausea, and severe hypertension, as high as 198/110 mmHg. On admission, her blood pressure was 172/116 mmHg. Intravenous nifedipine and magnesium sulfate were immediately initiated to control blood pressure and to prevent eclampsia, respectively. On the third day, the criteria for preeclampsia were met based on the 2.5 g/day of proteinuria. On the fifth day, fetal ultrasound screening was performed. A thickened, multicystic placenta and multiple fetal anomalies were detected, including cleft lip and palate, short nasal bone, pericardial effusion, and syndactyly of the third and fourth fingers. Fetal growth and amniotic fluid volume were normal. The maternal ovaries were symmetrically enlarged to 7 cm in diameter with a 'spoke-wheel' pattern. Medical termination of the pregnancy was decided upon as her dyspnea deteriorated due to pulmonary edema and her liver enzymes were elevated. On the sixth day, a 224 g baby and a notably large, 400 g placenta with partial cystic changes were vaginally delivered at 19 weeks and 2 days of gestation. The patient's hypertension and proteinuria returned to normal at 2 weeks after delivery. The values of her serum hCG quickly declined. Her ovaries continued to enlarge to 12 cm in diameter at 5 weeks after delivery, but had spontaneously shrunk to normal size at 16 weeks after delivery.",

  "Physical Examination": "At 12 weeks of gestation, her blood pressure was 103/65 mmHg. At 16 weeks of gestation, her blood pressure was 123/76 mmHg. At 18 weeks and 4 days of gestation, her blood pressure was 172/116 mmHg on admission.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's medical history was unremarkable.",

  "Initial Test Results": "At 12 weeks of gestation, her urinalysis was normal. At the first-trimester ultrasound screening, the thickness of the fetal nuchal translucency was 3.1 mm. The estimated risk of trisomy 21 was 1 in 31. On admission at 18 weeks and 4 days of gestation, laboratory data were as follows: serum creatinine 46 uM/L, platelet count 178,000/μL, aspartate aminotransferase (AST) 33 U/L, alanine aminotransferase (ALT) 27 U/L, albumin 21 g/L. Her dipstick urinalysis showed 1+ proteinuria. On the fifth day, the serum human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) value was 512,652 IU/L. On the sixth day, AST was 92 U/L and ALT was 63 U/L."
}"

Placental immunostaining showed P57Kip2 positive cells, suggesting the presence of the maternal allele. XXX (69, XXX) was confirmed by genetic testing of skin tissue of the affected baby."
