Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a three-month-old male of Chinese descent.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The three-month-old boy presented with nystagmus and his parents noticed whitish pupils at birth. The proband was born to non-consanguineous unaffected Chinese parents after a full-term pregnancy. No cataract-causing event occurred during pregnancy, including cytomegalovirus, herpes simplex, rubella, or toxoplasmosis infection, toxin or X-ray exposure, and relevant medication usage. Developmental delay was also diagnosed because the boy could not lift his head at three months old. After genetic screening, the patient was referred to a pediatric clinic for further examination and diagnosis. Magnetic resonance imaging showed corpus callosum hypoplasia, and a transcranial doppler suggested high blood pressure in the intracranial artery. The patient also had a patent foramen ovale and cryptorchidism. The cataracts were removed when the boy was three months old. At the three-month follow-up, severe posterior capsular opacification was noticed in his right eye, and a second surgery was prescribed to remove the opacities. Twice yearly follow-up was scheduled.",
  "Physical Examination": "No facial dysmorphia was detected. Head circumference was 35.5 cm, indicating microcephaly, and height was 56 cm (<97% of boys at the same age). Ocular examinations revealed bilateral microcornea, microphthalmos, congenital membranous cataracts, and persistent pupillary membranes. The corneal diameter of both eyes was 8 mm. The axial lens (AL) was 16.93 mm in the right eye and 16.68 mm in the left eye. The intraocular pressure (IOP) was 16 mmHg in the right eye and 12 mmHg in the left eye. The P2 latency of visual evoked potential was delayed in both eyes.",
  "Past Medical History": "No relevant family medical history or history of cataract-causing events during pregnancy.",
  "Initial Test Results": "A comprehensive ocular examination was performed including slit-lamp photography, Pentacam scheimpflug system, Tono-Pen measurements, visual evoked potential, and A-scan and B-scan ultrasound. Genetic screening revealed the presence of corpus callosum hypoplasia via MRI and increased blood pressure in the intracranial artery via transcranial Doppler. The boy also had a patent foramen ovale and cryptorchidism."
}"

The boy also had a patent foramen ovale and cryptorchidism.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Whole-exome sequencing (WES) was performed, followed by bioinformatics analysis to identify potential pathogenic variants. A c.178_182del variant in RAB3GAP1 (of paternal origin), resulting in premature termination (p.Glu60IlefsTer3), was identified and classified as likely pathogenic. Further CNV analysis identified a deletion in chromosome 2q21.3 (hg19)2:135890449-135893557del (maternal origin). WGS confirmed the deletion around chromosome (hg19)2:135888415-135895985del, removing exons 14–17 of RAB3GAP1. The combined genetic findings classified the variants under the ACMG/AMP guidelines as likely pathogenic."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 25-year-old man from an unspecified geographic location. He is right-hand dominant.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was hospitalized on October 27, 2023, due to enduring headaches that had begun abruptly 20 days prior. The headache is characterized by continuous swelling pain predominantly in the left frontal-temporal area and does not subside with rest. There are no accompanying symptoms such as dizziness, nausea, vomiting, or limb convulsions. Urination and defecation are normal. Conservative treatment at a local hospital failed to alleviate the headache. The patient has a history of epileptic episodes starting over ten years ago, manifesting as periods of staring blankly with loss of consciousness, resolving spontaneously after approximately 3–5 minutes. Initially, these episodes occurred every two days. After starting treatment with Carbamazepine, the frequency reduced to about once per month. Two years ago, his medication regimen was adjusted, maintaining the seizure frequency at roughly once per month. Upon discharge, his medication doses were again adjusted to Sodium Valproate Sustained Release Tablets 500 mg/dose, twice daily, and Topiramate Tablets 50 mg/dose, twice daily, yet this did not fully control the seizure frequency. After surgery, the patient experienced significant alleviation in symptoms of head discomfort from the second day after anesthesia recovery. At 3 and 5 months post-surgery follow-ups, no pathological symptoms such as headache, nausea and vomiting, unsteady walking, and urinary incontinence were observed. The frequency and form of seizures did not change significantly from before surgery.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination upon admission showed a normal head circumference, clear consciousness, coherent speech, and slight cognitive and intellectual decline, with no psychiatric abnormalities and no other anomalies noted. The neuropsychological assessment indicated a mild decline in cognition and intelligence. At 3 and 5 months post-surgery follow-ups, the results of physical examination and neuropsychological evaluation were similar to those before surgery.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has no history of surgery. There were no abnormalities in the perinatal period. He was born full-term via normal delivery, from a non-consanguineous marriage. There is no family history of epilepsy. Imaging studies conducted at two months of age indicated underdevelopment of the right cerebral hemisphere, though detailed specifics remain unclear.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Preoperative routine blood tests, liver function, kidney function, and electrolytes revealed no notable abnormalities. Electrocardiogram, chest CT, and ultrasound examinations of the liver, gallbladder, pancreas, and spleen showed no significant abnormalities. Initial lumbar puncture pressures were approximately 220 mmH2O, with final pressures around 90 mmH2O. Routine, biochemical, and cytological analyses of the CSF showed no significant abnormalities."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Cranial MRI plain scan, CSF flow sequence, and cranial CT examination suggested extensive softening lesions and developmental abnormalities in the right cerebral hemisphere, accompanied by POR. Electroencephalogram (EEG) examination showed asymmetry in the background activity of both brain regions, epileptic discharges in the left temporal region during interictal periods, and slow wave activity with medium amplitude starting in the left temporal region during ictal periods. Two clinical seizure events were recorded via video monitoring: the patient exhibited unconscious autonomous activities in the right hand, followed by muscle tone disorders in the left upper limb. Postoperative cranial CT confirmed the good placement of the drainage tube."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 38-year-old woman with a 32-week zero-day pregnancy. She has a history of two successful cesarean deliveries. The patient's geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the emergency department with epigastric pain of 24 hours duration and five episodes of vomiting. Upon arrival at the emergency room, her vital signs were: blood pressure 145/94, oxygen saturation 94%, temperature 36.9°C, and heart rate 92. An obstetric ultrasound revealed polyhydramnios and a living fetus with a heart rate of 151 beats per minute (bpm) with an omphalocele. The patient was immediately transferred to the operating room for a cesarean surgery and an exploratory laparotomy. The obstetrics team performed the cesarean section with a midline infraumbilical incision, and a live female infant weighing 1796 grams was delivered with an omphalocele. The surgical team found a ruptured hepatic hematoma affecting the right lobe and part of the left lobe with a hemoperitoneum of approximately 1000 mL. Hemorrhage was managed by liver packaging and ligation of the round ligament and the falciform ligament. It was planned to operate on the fourth day to remove the packaging. A subhepatic drainage was placed, and the abdominal wall was closed. The patient was transferred to the intensive care unit (ICU) where she received 5 units of packed red blood cells, mechanical ventilation, and ionotropic agents. On the fourth day, the patient was operated again to remove the surgical pads from the previous packaging and aspiration of 600 mL of remaining hemoperitoneum. The patient was discharged on the seventh day with stable vital signs, normalizing hepatic enzymes, and mild anemia. The newborn died on the fifth day due to respiratory failure.",

  "Physical Examination": "An upper abdomen ultrasound showed a sub-hepatic hematoma on the right hepatic lobe.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has an obstetric history of two successful cesarean deliveries. The first cesarean section was performed for presentation dystocia and the second because of the previous cesarean section.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory parameters at the presentation showed elevated liver enzymes, including alanine transaminase (ALT), aspartate transaminase (AST), alkaline phosphatase (ALP), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). A complete blood count showed leukocytosis with neutrophilia. No other values were abnormal. Mild hyperkalemia and high lactate were also present. Blood gas studies revealed metabolic acidosis with a blood pH of 7.20 (normal value is 7.35-7.45). The histopathological result of the placenta demonstrated a mature placenta with microcalcifications, intervillous hemorrhage, vascular congestion, and edema. On the third day in the ICU, the laboratory studies showed no anemia and elevated hepatic enzymes. On discharge, the patient's hepatic enzymes were normalizing with ALT at 285 U/L and AST at 65 U/L (normal values: ≤ 35 U/L for ALT and ≤ 35 U/L for AST)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 64-year-old woman who has been in menopause for 9 years. She is from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with 4 months of vaginal discharge. Gynecological examination revealed watery discharge from the vagina, thickening of the cervix with a diameter of approximately 4.5 cm, hardness, and positive blood on palpation. The uterine body was the size of a two-month pregnancy, and thickening was noted in the left adnexal area. Trimanual examination showed bilateral paracervical ligaments without palpable nodules or contractures, elastic, and smooth rectal mucosa. Cervical biopsy suggested adenocarcinoma. The patient underwent extensive transabdominal hysterectomy, bilateral ovariectomy, bilateral salpingectomy, pelvic lymphatic dissection, abdominal para-aortic lymphadenectomy, and pelvic adhesion lysis. Intraoperatively, the uterine body was enlarged and soft, similar to the size of a 3-month pregnancy, with regular shape. The cervix was enlarged, about 5 cm in diameter, involving the bladder. Bilateral appendages appeared normal, and there was no obvious enlargement of bilateral iliac vascular lymph nodes. The right common iliac lymph nodes were slightly enlarged, and some intestines were adhered to bilateral pelvic walls. Dissection of the uterus revealed a 6 cm × 5 cm cervical canal mass invading the plasma membrane layer with blood in the uterine cavity. Despite receiving additional radiation and chemotherapy immediately after surgery, the patient died one year later.",

  "Physical Examination": "Gynecological examination showed watery discharge from the vagina, thickening of the cervix with a diameter of approximately 4.5 cm, hardness, and positive blood on palpation. The uterine body was the size of a two-month pregnancy, and thickening was noted in the left adnexal area. Trimanual examination revealed bilateral paracervical ligaments without palpable nodules or contractures, elastic, and smooth rectal mucosa.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had been in menopause for 9 years.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Ultrasound showed that the endometrial line of the uterine cavity was poorly displayed, and a liquid dark area was detected in the uterine cavity, which was about 88 mm × 63 mm × 86 mm in extent, with fair translucency and a few punctate echoes visible."
}"

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had been in menopause for 9 years.",

}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 40-year-old Indonesian female patient.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with intensely itchy and coalescing papules and plaques overlying lichenified plaques on the labia majora. The itching worsened when she was angry or anxious. Her vulvar skin condition started 2 months before consultation, initially presenting as dark spots in the labia majora. One month before the consultation, the spots became thickened plaques and soon felt more itchy, which prompted consultation with a physician at a primary health-care facility. She was prescribed vaginal nystatin and oral antibiotics. Two weeks before consultation, coalescing papules and plaques began to appear. The patient was then referred to secondary and tertiary dermatology and venereology health-care facilities. The patient had a history of hormonal contraceptive use, frequent wearing of tight clothing, and smoking. In the 4 weeks of follow-up after treatment, clinical improvement was observed as the lesions became hyperpigmented macules without itching. There was no recurrence after 3 years of follow-up.",

  "Physical Examination": "Intensely itchy and coalescing papules and plaques overlying lichenified plaques were observed on the labia majora.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a personal and familial history of allergic rhinitis from her mother. Her ex-husband was a promiscuous man with some histories of warts and urethral discharge in his genitals.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were mentioned in the provided information."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "An excision biopsy was performed on the papules overlying the lichenified plaque on her vulva for histopathological examination and HPV genotyping. Cases.Final Name: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia due to 17-alpha-hydroxylase deficiency
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 24-year-old female, 170 cm in height, weighing 70 kg, with upper body length of 76 cm and lower body length of 94 cm (lower/upper ratio 1.236). The patient is from Lanzhou, China.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was initially admitted to a local hospital due to limb weakness. After 5 days of potassium supplementation treatment without improvement, she was transferred to the emergency department of a university hospital. The patient complained of no menarche and no secondary sex characteristics. Blood pressure was 133/93 mmHg, and the heart rate was 95 beats/min. The patient had no axillary and pubic hairs, thoracic deformity, scoliosis, breast stage Tanner I, and the vulva was of the female infantilism type. No beard was present, but vellus hair growth was increased. After diagnosis and treatment, the limb weakness completely recovered. Three months after discharge, the patient showed increased levels of blood potassium, estradiol (E2), and 24h-UFC. One year later, the patient developed regular vaginal bleeding with a menstrual cycle of 28–30 days and periods lasting 5-6 days. The uterine size had increased compared to pre-treatment measurements.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had no axillary and pubic hairs, thoracic deformity, scoliosis, breast stage Tanner I, and the vulva was of the female infantilism type. No beard was present, but vellus hair growth was increased.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no history of menarche or development of secondary sex characteristics.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Blood biochemistry indicated hypokalemia. Androstenedione was less than 0.3 ng/ml and serum dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA) was less than 15.0 μg/dL. The 24-h urinary free cortisol (24h-UFC) was less than 10 μg/24h. Primary aldehyde screening showed 0.24 pg/ml of renin. The horizontal position test showed that renin levels were 0.19 pg/ml in the supine position and 0.29 pg/ml in the standing position. Cor rhythm demonstrated Cor(8-16-24) <1.00-<1.00-<1.00 μg/dL. ACTH rhythms showed ACTH(8-16-24) 71.8-85.0 pg/ml-59 pg/ml. X-ray of chest indicated the thoracic vertebra bent slightly to the right. X-ray of hand showed the epiphyseal of the distal ulna appeared and the epiphyseal and distal radius were not closed and wrist bones with 13-year-old bone age was observed. Gynecology B ultrasound showed uterine body size was about 22x8x4mm and bilateral ovaries were not detected. B ultrasound showed diffuse lesions of left thyroid lobe, with hypoechoic TI-RADS III nodules on both sides of the thyroid lobe. Chromosome analysis showed chromosome karyotype 46, XX."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Abdominal computerized tomography (CT) results indicated abdominal occupation due to left adrenal area and prerenal space tumors. Abdominal enhancement CT revealed bilateral abnormal adrenal enhancement of nodules and mass shadow, internal fat density shadow and uneven enhancement scan, with the right size of about 17 × 12mm and the left size of about 98 × 83mm. Pituitary magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) horizontal sweep showed the pituitary form is slightly full and the height was about 0.9 cm. Using the Illumina second-generation sequencing platform, exon sequencing of CHA related genes CYP17A1 was performed, and patient samples had a homozygous mutation of c.987del in the 17-OHD lease-related gene CYP17A1. Pedigree verification confirmed that the mutation was a heterozygous mutation of c.987delC from both parents. The genetic map of 7α-OHD was mapped by sequencing. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 2.2-month-old Chinese girl. She is the third child of healthy non-consanguineous parents. She was born at 38-week gestation via vaginal delivery. Her birth weight was 3.05 kg (25–50th percentile), birth length was 49 cm (50th percentile), and head circumference 33 cm (50th percentile).",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the hospital with complaints of diarrhea, fever, and poor feeding. She developed severe malnutrition which manifested as marasmus. She had a less rosy complexion, pale lips, thin subcutaneous fat, poor skin stretch, and petechiae. No abnormalities were found on her facial appearance, muscular tone, or psychomotor development. Initially, the patient received routine treatment including rehydration, correction of acidosis, and related symptomatic treatment. Antibiotics were also applied, but the symptoms did not improve. When an inborn error of cobalamin metabolism was suspected, hydroxocobalamin (1 mg) was given by intramuscular injection twice a week. All symptoms disappeared during her stay in the hospital. At the patient's last outpatient visit (2 years and 7 months old), neurological examinations revealed normal results. Personal-social, fine motor-adaptive, language-speech, and gross motor skills showed no significant differences compared with peers.",

  "Physical Examination": "At 2.2 months old, the patient's weight was 2.57 kg (<3rd percentile) and her length was 54 cm (3rd-10th percentile).",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother had two previous pregnancies that resulted in spontaneous miscarriages. The pregnancy with the patient was unremarkable. No family history of associated diseases was reported, especially of the hematologic system.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Complete blood count revealed pancytopenia: Red Blood Cell Count (RBC) 2.25×1012/L (3.2–4.9), Hemoglobin (Hb) 73 g/L (90–140), White Blood Cell Count (WBC) 2.48×109/L (5.0–12), platelets count 3×109/L (100–378). Biochemical examinations showed elevated urine methylmalonic acid level (23.87 μmol/L [0.2–3.6]) and increased plasma homocysteine level (21.85 umol/l [<15]). Serum VB12 and folate levels were 275.60 pmol/L (139.4–651.5) and 17.86 nmol/L (7.0–46.4), respectively. Blood gas analysis revealed metabolic acidosis. The ratio of propionyl carnitine to acetylcarnitine was slightly increased (0.319 [0.04–0.25]). Other biochemical tests were normal."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 79-year-old Japanese woman from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the hospital with chief complaints of dyspnea and cyanosis. Two hours before arrival, she reported dyspnea and her usual oxygen dosage of 2 L/min was increased to 5 L/min. Her dyspnea did not improve, and her SpO2 decreased to as low as 80%, prompting her to seek emergency care. At the time of examination, her vital signs were: blood pressure 134/62 mmHg, pulse 60 beats per minute, respiratory rate 23 breaths per minute, SpO2 80% (while receiving 5 L/min of oxygen via a mask), and body temperature 37.3 °C. The patient had been on home oxygen therapy for 6 months due to chronic respiratory failure. Despite oxygen administration and noninvasive positive pressure ventilation, her SpO2 remained low. Gram staining of the sputum revealed the presence of Gram-negative bacilli. Pseudomonas aeruginosa had been detected previously in sputum culture tests. Antimicrobial therapy with ceftazidime (1 g administered every 12 h) was initiated. After diagnosis and treatment with 8 mL methylene blue (0.2 mL/kg), the SpO2 increased to 99% within approximately 10 minutes, with resolution of cyanosis. The color of the blood samples changed from dark red to red. After starting ascorbic acid therapy (750 mg/day), the methemoglobin level remained in the range of 6–8% and SpO2 remained above 90%, allowing for the discontinuation of home oxygen therapy. In this instance, the presence of Pseudomonas aeruginosa was confirmed through sputum culture, and the patient received a 5-day regimen of ceftazidime.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed cyanosis of the lips and extremities. Auscultation revealed diminished breath sounds, but no wheezes or crackles were noted.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of pulmonary tuberculosis, lung cancer (following partial right lobe resection and radiotherapy), and bronchiectasis. She had been on home oxygen therapy for 6 months due to chronic respiratory failure. A review of her medical records revealed that her methemoglobin level had been elevated for some time (10% and 20% at 5 and 2 years prior to the latest visit, respectively). There was no history of drug use that would potentially induce methemoglobinemia.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Chest radiography revealed no infiltrative shadows. Arterial blood gas analysis revealed a high PaO2 (325.4 mmHg) and elevated methemoglobin (36.9%). After treatment, the methemoglobin level decreased to 2.0%."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Genetic testing was performed. Genomic DNA was extracted from the patient. All exons of CYB5R3 were examined using Sanger sequencing. A rare homozygous nonsynonymous variant in exon 3 (NM_000398.7:c.173G>A [p.Arg58Gln], rs121965007) was observed. The nucleotide variant has a CADD score of 27.5. No other sequence variants were observed in the other eight exons examined in CYB5R3. The resulting amino acid substitution, Arg58Gln, was predicted to be probably damaging by PolyPhen2 and damaging by SIFT software. The variant is located in the flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD)-binding domain."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 53-year-old male farmer residing in Morang, eastern Nepal.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with abdominal fullness for 15 years, which had increased in the last week, and easy fatigability for two months. He had undergone multiple blood transfusions in the past 5 years, with the most recent transfusion being 20 weeks ago.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient's vitals were stable, and he had pallor. Abdominal examination revealed a palpable spleen 9 cm below the left costal margin, suggesting splenomegaly. There was no lymphadenopathy or hepatomegaly. The rest of the systemic examinations were unremarkable.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's family history revealed a history of multiple blood transfusions and traumatic splenic injury to his younger brother after an accidental injury by a cricket ball. There was no history of consanguineous marriage in his family and no history of any drug allergies.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory investigations showed pancytopenia, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, and decreased reticulocyte count. Direct Coombs test and ANA were negative. A peripheral blood smear suggested a hemolytic picture. An osmotic fragility test showed decreased fragility. Ultrasound abdomen showed massive splenomegaly with multiple well-defined echogenic lesions throughout the splenic parenchyma. No features suggested vesicular lithiasis or signs of portal hypertension."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Bone marrow aspiration and biopsy were performed. The bone marrow report showed grade 4 iron stores on Perl's stain. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 34-year-old man. His geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the hospital for frank hematuria, described as pure blood, and recurrent epistaxis that would not subside. The patient stated his symptoms began while recovering from a severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2/COVID-19) infection that did not require treatment. He experienced massive hematuria and epistaxis that continued despite initial treatment. The patient received 10 units of blood and 35 units of fresh frozen plasma (FFP) during his hospital stay. His clinical symptoms of bleeding slowly improved over the course of his stay with resolution on day 22. The patient was then discharged with a close follow-up with hematology, steroid tapper, and continuation of rituximab for an additional week. The results of PT, aPTT, and FX assays from his biweekly follow-up appointments for three months remained stable and steadily improved to normalcy.",

  "Physical Examination": "On presentation, physical examination revealed multiple areas of ecchymosis, conjunctival hemorrhage, epistaxis, mucosal bleeding, and massive hematuria. He was febrile to 39.1 °C, tachycardic to 120/min, with normal blood pressure and oxygen saturation.",

  "Past Medical History": "According to the patient, he did not have any hereditary hemorrhagic conditions or any prior episodes of hemorrhage.",

  "Initial Test Results": "His hemoglobin on admission was 56 g/L (138–172 g/dL). Other laboratory tests did not reveal any significant abnormalities, including his platelet count of 240 × 109/L (150–450 109/L). Coagulation testing revealed both a prolonged prothrombin time (PT) of 190.2 s (11–13.5 s) and an activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) of 144.9 s (21–35 s). A fibrin degradation product of 3.1 mg/L (<10 mg/L), and D-dimer of 0.22 mg/L (<0.50 mg/L) indicated that the patient was not in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The fibrinogen level was increased to 5.6 g/L (2.0–4.0 g/L). Computer tomography (CT) of the chest and abdomen/pelvis was unremarkable in terms of any acute findings."
}"

The patient was then discharged with a close follow-up with hematology, steroid tapper, and continuation of rituximab for an additional week. The results of PT, aPTT, and FX assays from his biweekly follow-up appointments for three months remained stable and steadily improved to normalcy.",

  "Physical Examination": "On presentation, physical examination revealed multiple areas of ecchymosis, conjunctival hemorrhage, epistaxis, mucosal bleeding, and massive hematuria. He was febrile to 39.1 °C, tachycardic to 120/min, with normal blood pressure and oxygen saturation.",

  "Past Medical History": "According to the patient, he did not have any hereditary hemorrhagic conditions or any prior episodes of hemorrhage.",

  "Initial Test Results": "His hemoglobin on admission was 56 g/L (138–172 g/dL). Other laboratory tests did not reveal any significant abnormalities, including his platelet count of 240 × 109/L (150–450 109/L). Coagulation testing revealed both a prolonged prothrombin time (PT) of 190.2 s (11–13.5 s) and an activated partial thromboplastin time (APTT) of 144.9 s (21–35 s). A fibrin degradation product of 3.1 mg/L (<10 mg/L), and D-dimer of 0.22 mg/L (<0.50 mg/L) indicated that the patient was not in disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The fibrinogen level was increased to 5.6 g/L (2.0–4.0 g/L). Computer tomography (CT) of the chest and abdomen/pelvis was unremarkable in terms of any acute findings.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Mixing studies with pooled plasma revealed the correction of the patient's PT and aPTT. Thromboelastography (TEG) showed an increase in the R-value. Factor tests revealed markedly reduced factor X levels to 4.7%. A Bethesda factor X inhibitor titer assay was performed, which was negative. The M-protein was not detected in the serum or urine by immunofixation. Immunological tests did not show any other abnormalities."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 63-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the hospital on November 18, 2020, due to needle-like pain in the upper abdomen for at least 15 days. The pain was transient and was relieved shortly, but he experienced serious pain and vomiting occasionally. Gastroscopy showed reflux esophagitis and chronic atrophic gastritis. The patient reported persistent needle-like pain in the upper abdomen after initial treatment. He experienced recurrence of abdominal pain lasting for 2 weeks after discharge. Enteroscopic examination indicated multiple ulcers in the distal jejunum, which were deeper in site with an irregular margin covering them with white pus moss. The patient underwent laparoscopic exploration and partial enterectomy, which revealed multiple ulcers and narrowing in the small intestine. The intestinal wall was narrow and there was a mass at the position about 100 cm from the Treitz. A part of the intestine including the narrow lesion and the mass (2.5 cm × 1.0 cm × 0.5 cm) was excised. A narrowing site in the intestinal wall was observed at a distance of 2.5 cm from the mass. There was an ulcer in the lesion with a length and a diameter of 2.0 cm and 0.5 cm, respectively. Intestinal edema was noticed between the mass and the narrowed intestinal wall.",

  "Physical Examination": "Upon physical examination, the patient showed bilateral inguinal lymphadenectasis.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a smoking history of about 20 years (50 cigarettes per day) but had not smoked for 20 years. He had a history of drinking alcohol (about 150 g per day) for 40 years.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Routine blood examination results were as follows: white blood cell, 17.9 × 109/L (normal range: 4–10 × 109/L); lymphocyte ratio, 62.5% (normal range: 20%–40%); lymphocyte, 11.0 × 109/L (normal range: 1–3 × 109/L); erythrocyte, 4.7 × 1012/L (normal range: 3.5–5.5 × 1012/L); hemoglobin, 87 g/L (normal range: 110–160 g/L); mean corpuscular volume (MCV), 67 fL (normal range: 82–92 fl); corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH), 19 pg (normal range: 27–31 pg); mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration (MCHC), 284 g/L (normal range: 320–360 g/L); and ferritin, 8.21 ng/ml (normal range: ≥ 20 ng/ml). Doppler ultrasonography of the abdomen showed no abnormalities. Peripheral blood smear showed scattered, small to medium sized lymphoma cells with irregular nuclear contour. Flow cytometry on BM aspirate demonstrated the presence of kappa restricted B cells, together with positive staining for CD19, CD20, CD22, CD5, and CD23. No CCND1 gene break or P53 gene deletion was identified by FISH, while no mutation was identified in MYD 88 gene after Sanger sequencing. Thoracic and abdominal CT showed lymphadenopathy in mediastinum, bilateral neck, axillary area, enterocoelia, retroperitoneal and pelvic cavity, as well as splenomegaly. CT scan indicated partial thickening in the small intestine. Colonoscopy indicated three polyps with sizes of 0.8 cm, 0.7 cm, and 0.4 cm, respectively. Pathological analysis indicated tubular adenoma with low-grade dysplasia."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Bone marrow (BM) biopsy showed a markedly hypercellular marrow (85%), which was diffusely involved by a small lymphocytic infiltration (80%). The infiltration consisted of numerous small lymphocytes and scattered paraimmunoblasts. The tumor cells were positive for CD20, CD5, and CD23, and were negative for CD3, CD10, TdT, and cyclin D1. For the aspirate smear, the majority (80%) were small lymphocytes with coarse chromatin. CT enterography showed thickening in the small intestinal wall, together with multiple lymphadenopathies in the abdominal cavity and retroperitoneum. Immunohistochemistry of the intestinal mass showed tumor cells positive for CD3, CD7, CD8, CD43, CD56, TIA1, Granzyme B, and Bcl-2, and negative for CD20, CD79a, CD10, Bcl-6, MUM-1, CD23, cyclin D1, CD2, CD4, CD5, and CD30. The Ki-67 index was in a range of 70%–80%. Tumor cells near the blood vessels were positive for CD20, CD79a, CD5, CD23, CD43, and Bcl-2, with a Ki-67 index in a range of 5%–10%. The expression of EBV was negative in the tumor mass and the cells in the peripheral vessels. There was clonal rearrangement for the IG detection using specific BIOMED-2 primers based on peripheral blood sample. Sanger sequence confirmed that it was IGHV3-33_06. The homologous degree was 100% compared with the germline sequence. PCR-based TCR assay revealed a small monoclonal T-cell population in a background of oligoclonal T-cells. Next-generation sequencing (NGS) was performed using haematopoietic and lymphoid specific panels covering the coding sequence (CDS) of 143 Hematological Disease genes. The NGS results showed pathogenic hotspot mutations of STAT5B (c.1924A>C, p.N642H) and DNMT3A (c.2678G>A, p.W893*), as well as several likely pathogenic mutations and variants of uncertain clinical significance in various genes."
}"

Cases.Final Name: Nodular regenerative hyperplasia of the liver
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 77-year-old female with late-onset Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID).",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with severe multi-organ immune dysregulation, including splenomegaly, polyclonal lymphoproliferation, granulomatous-lymphocytic interstitial lung disease (GLILD), and recurrent leuko- and thrombocytopenia. She developed new onset ascites (grade 3), which led to a diagnosis of non-cirrhotic portal hypertension (NCPH) secondary to histologically proven nodular regenerative hyperplasia (NRH). Initial treatment for ascites included a transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS), which was later reduced due to hepatic encephalopathy, large volume paracenteses every 3 to 4 weeks, and diuretics (spironolactone 200 mg and furosemide 40 mg daily). Three years later, the patient received rituximab (375 mg/m2 weekly for 4 weeks) preceded by a short course of dexamethasone (20 mg daily for 4 days) for immune thrombocytopenia relapse. Following this treatment, a complete regression of ascites was noted, and diuretic treatment was discontinued. Platelet counts were quasi-normalized and remained steady after a single cycle of rituximab. Pulmonary findings and patient-reported exercise capacity were stable over a 5-year follow-up period, yet without significant radiological or spirometric improvement. The radiological disappearance of ascites persisted for up to 5 years post-treatment, indicating a sustained decrease in portal hypertension.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had splenomegaly and ascites (grade 3) before treatment.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of late-onset Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID), severe multi-organ immune dysregulation, splenomegaly, polyclonal lymphoproliferation, granulomatous-lymphocytic interstitial lung disease (GLILD), and recurrent leuko- and thrombocytopenia.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Panel-based exome sequencing revealed a heterozygous variant in TNFRSF13B (c.290C>G, p.Pro97Arg), encoding the transmembrane activator and calcium modulator and cyclophilin ligand interactor (TACI)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a two-day-old male neonate born at 33 weeks gestation, with a birth weight of 2053 grams, to a 33-year-old G6P1 (gravidity and parity) mother via C-section.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was prenatally diagnosed with oligohydramnios, bilateral enlarged ventricles in the brain, and bilateral cystic kidney disease. In the neonatal ICU, the patient was intubated on a ventilator for one day and stable on room air by day six of life. During the initial 22 hours of life in the neonatal ICU, the patient developed oliguria that required to be given furosemide in a total of eight doses over three days. Urine output was improved by day four of life without requiring furosemide anymore. He developed severe hypertension starting at eight weeks of age, requiring multiple antihypertensive medications, and a ventriculoperitoneal shunt was placed at seven months of age.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had no acute distress, edema, fluid overload, or abdominal mass on physical examination. There were no other abnormal findings, such as bone deformities and polydactyly.",

  "Past Medical History": "Toxoplasmosis, rubella, cytomegalovirus, and herpes were negative. There is no family history of cystic kidney disease. The mother's previous pregnancies resulted in one spontaneous abortion at 10 weeks, two ectopic pregnancies at five weeks, a therapeutic abortion at 10 weeks, and an emergency C-section at 35 weeks due to severe pre-eclampsia.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory results on day seven of life showed serum creatinine (Cr) of 0.7 mg/dL (normal value, 0.2-0.8 mg/dL), blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 7 mg/dL (normal value, 7-20 mg/dL), sodium of 131 mmol/L (normal value, 135-145 mmol/L), and potassium of 4.7 mmol/L (normal value, 3.5-5.5 mmol/L). Urinalysis demonstrated no blood or protein in the urine. His serum creatinine was 0.3 mg/dL at one year of age."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a White American male with known Ashkenazi Jewish ancestry. He initially presented at age 51.4 years and was formally diagnosed with Adult Polyglucosan Body Disease (APBD) at age 54.6 years.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented at age 51.4 years due to fecal incontinence and urinary retention. He reported to the emergency department due to an episode of sudden, forceful loss of fecal contents. At age 52.6 years, he experienced multiple subsequent episodes of fecal incontinence. Evaluation by the neurology department at age 53.3 years disclosed a history of bladder dysfunction and erectile dysfunction from age 44.5 years, as well as gait abnormalities starting at age 49.6 years. Bladder dysfunction was initially diagnosed as benign prostatic hypertrophy, although a review of records showed resistance to multiple medications. At age 53.5 years, he underwent cystoscopy, showing urethral obstruction, and had a prostatic urethral lift procedure at age 54.0 years. Despite this procedure, he continued to develop symptoms of urinary retention and elevated post void residuals. At age 54.7 years, he began clean intermittent catheterizations due to urinary retention. At age 55.5 years, he reported ongoing symptoms of bladder dysfunction and gait instability, as well as intermittent episodes of fecal incontinence at least once every 6 months. He reported an overall improvement of bladder control with clean intermittent catheterizations and has not had any resultant infections. However, he disclosed experiencing increased fatigue, noting that he was no longer able to walk distances greater than a mile due to sensation of muscle weakness as well as profound tiredness following meals.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient was noted to have bilateral pes cavus, ataxic gait, and abnormal reflexes (increased knee jerk, decreased ankle jerk, and upgoing plantar reflex bilaterally). Muscle weakness was further evaluated using muscle ultrasound, with findings suggestive of myopathy in conjunction with an elevated creatine kinase level (516 U/L).",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has no known liver or cardiac manifestations of GSD IV. Routine echocardiograms and electrocardiograms performed between ages 47.6 and 54.7 years were normal.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Preliminary abdominal X-ray imaging returned benign. Anorectal manometry was performed at age 52.6 years, revealing sphincter dysfunction. Alanine transaminase (ALT) levels have always been within normal limits, most recently measured at age 56.0 years."
}"

MRI of the brain without contrast, followed by MRA (magnetic resonance angiography) of the head and, subsequently, MRI of the brain with and without contrast and of the cervical, thoracic, and lumbar spine were performed together, revealing evidence of leukodystrophy with findings of white matter abnormalities, cerebral and cerebellar volume loss, spinal cord atrophy, and vascular anomalies. A leukodystrophy gene panel initially returned without notable findings. At age 54.4 years, he underwent electromyography and nerve conduction velocity test (EMG/NCS), showing a length-dependent sensorimotor axonal neuropathy in the right lower extremity. At age 54.6 years, research reanalysis of the prior leukodystrophy panel identified NM_000158.4(GBE1):c.760A>G (p.Thr254Ala; p.T254A)—a variant with conflicting interpretations of pathogenicity—and an identified deep intronic variant. At age 54.7 years, he underwent repeat EMG, confirming length-dependent, axonal, sensorimotor peripheral neuropathy."

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 12-year-old female from South India was born preterm to healthy consanguineous parents. Her birth weight was 2,500 g.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "Since birth, she presented generalized hypotonia. The average tone of the muscle motor sensor, an inaccurate gait pattern, and a bilateral flexed knee was observed. Since an early age, she presented inadequate speech and language, learning difficulties with mild mental retardation, dependence on several activities of daily life, psychomotor and developmental delay, and inability to walk. No history of hearing difficulties was reported. The ophthalmological analysis showed squint vision. Blood samples were collected from the patient and her family members by a Phlebotomist. Genomic DNA was extracted from peripheral blood by using PureLink Genomic DNA Mini Kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, United States) according to the manufacturer's instructions. Whole-exome sequencing (WES) was performed for the proband. The exome libraries were constructed using the Ion Ampliseq exome RDY kit (Thermo Fisher Scientific, United States) and sequenced on the Ion Proton sequencing platform (Life Technologies, United States). Variants were called using the Torrent Variant Caller plug-in using the software console of the Torrent server. Variants were annotated using Ion Reporter (Thermo Fisher Scientific, United States) using the human reference genome (hg19). Pathogenicity of candidate variants was evaluated using Genome Aggregation Database and ClinVar. Sanger sequencing was performed for variant validation of the proband and the parents by amplifying the PMM2 region (rs80338708) using specific primers.",
  "Physical Examination": "Generalized hypotonia was observed. The average tone of the muscle motor sensor, an inaccurate gait pattern, and a bilateral flexed knee was observed. No ataxia or cerebellar syndrome was observed. The ophthalmological analysis showed squint vision.",
  "Past Medical History": "No history of neonatal jaundice, neonatal hypoxia, or hearing difficulties was reported.",
  "Initial Test Results": ""
}"

Variants were annotated using Ion Reporter (Thermo Fisher Scientific, United States) using the human reference genome (hg19). Pathogenicity of candidate variants was evaluated using Genome Aggregation Database and ClinVar. Sanger sequencing was performed for variant validation of the proband and the parents by amplifying the PMM2 region (rs80338708) using specific primers. An initial denaturation step at 95°C for 2 minutes was followed by 35 cycles of 98°C for 25 seconds, 67°C for 45 seconds for annealing, 72°C for 30 seconds for elongation, and final extension at 72°C for 7 minutes. The PCR products were evaluated using a 2% agarose gel electrophoresis. PCR products were labeled with BigDye Terminator v3.1 Cycle Sequencing Kit (Applied Biosystems, United States). The above-mentioned PCR primer (PMM2 Forward) was used as a sequencing primer and then analyzed by ABI 3500 Genetic Analyser (Applied Biosystems, United States). Sequence data were analyzed with Seqscape v3 software (Applied Biosystems, United States)."

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is an 11-year-old female from Ukraine. She was born from a full-term pregnancy with a birth weight of 3,650 g and length of 55 cm.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient's first disease manifestations appeared at 10 months of age, including stomatitis, gingivitis, and cervical lymphadenomegaly. During her second year, she experienced recurrent stomatitis, impetigo, and skin abscesses. At 2 years old, she was evaluated for anemia, recurrent fever episodes, mucositis, and urinary tract infections. Ulcerative stomatitis recurred every 2 to 4 weeks with fever, gingivitis, painful cervical lymphadenomegaly, and angular cheilitis. From age 3, she developed chronic constipation, and radiology examination revealed dolichocolon. She later developed steatorrhea and constipation alternating with intermittent diarrhea. The patient did not present with psychomotor developmental delay or autistic behavior, but her parents noted she was irritable, often nervous, and emotionally unstable. At age 10, G-CSF treatment was initiated at a dose of 5 mcg/kg for at least 4 days every 3 weeks, which improved her ANC counts and reduced the frequency and severity of infections. After a year of treatment, mild aphthous ulcers appeared every two months but healed without additional treatment in 1-2 days. Her growth parameters remained in the normal range, and her parents noted improved behavior and calmness.",

  "Physical Examination": "Abdominal ultrasound revealed an enlarged liver and enlarged, hyperechoic pancreas with homogeneous pancreatic parenchyma. Neurological examination did not show any organic abnormalities.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was born from a pregnancy complicated with placental dysfunction, polyhydramnion, and pyelonephritis. After birth, she developed purulent conjunctivitis, which was successfully treated with local antibiotics. She was breastfed for up to 1 year of age and received all vaccines of the Ukrainian mandatory vaccination program, except for hepatitis B vaccine for unknown reasons. Her 27-year-old mother and 38-year-old father had recurrent herpes labialis and herpetic keratitis, respectively. The family history was negative for dysmorphic features, hematological disease, immune deficiency, or neonatal deaths.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests revealed neutropenia with compensatory monocytosis, anemia (lowest RBC: 3.16 T/L, lowest Hgb: 9.4 g/dL) with normal serum iron concentration and normal platelet count. Serial blood counts showed a cyclical pattern of neutropenia occurring in a 20-day period. Serum amylase level was normal, and stool analysis revealed normal elastase activity. Serum IgG, IgA, IgM, and IgE levels and lymphocyte immunophenotypes were in the normal ranges."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is an 11-year-old female from Ukraine. She was born from a full-term pregnancy with a birth weight of 3,650 g and length of 55 cm.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient's first disease manifestations appeared at 10 months of age, including stomatitis, gingivitis, and cervical lymphadenomegaly. During her second year, she experienced recurrent stomatitis, impetigo, and skin abscesses. At 2 years old, she was evaluated for anemia, recurrent fever episodes, mucositis, and urinary tract infections. Ulcerative stomatitis recurred every 2 to 4 weeks with fever, gingivitis, painful cervical lymphadenomegaly, and angular cheilitis. From age 3, she developed chronic constipation, and radiology examination revealed dolichocolon. She later developed steatorrhea and constipation alternating with intermittent diarrhea. The patient did not present with psychomotor developmental delay or autistic behavior, but her parents noted she was irritable, often nervous, and emotionally unstable. At age 10, G-CSF treatment was initiated at a dose of 5 mcg/kg for at least 4 days every 3 weeks, which improved her ANC counts and reduced the frequency and severity of infections. After a year of treatment, mild aphthous ulcers appeared every two months but healed without additional treatment in 1-2 days. Her growth parameters remained in the normal range, and her parents noted improved behavior and calmness.",

  "Physical Examination": "Abdominal ultrasound revealed an enlarged liver and enlarged, hyperechoic pancreas with homogeneous pancreatic parenchyma. Neurological examination did not show any organic abnormalities.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was born from a pregnancy complicated with placental dysfunction, polyhydramnion, and pyelonephritis. After birth, she developed purulent conjunctivitis, which was successfully treated with local antibiotics. She was breastfed for up to 1 year of age and received all vaccines of the Ukrainian mandatory vaccination program, except for hepatitis B vaccine for unknown reasons. Her 27-year-old mother and 38-year-old father had recurrent herpes labialis and herpetic keratitis, respectively. The family history was negative for dysmorphic features, hematological disease, immune deficiency, or neonatal deaths.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests revealed neutropenia with compensatory monocytosis, anemia (lowest RBC: 3.16 T/L, lowest Hgb: 9.4 g/dL) with normal serum iron concentration and normal platelet count. Serial blood counts showed a cyclical pattern of neutropenia occurring in a 20-day period. Serum amylase level was normal, and stool analysis revealed normal elastase activity. Serum IgG, IgA, IgM, and IgE levels and lymphocyte immunophenotypes were in the normal ranges.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Bone marrow cytology at 7 years of age revealed normocellularity, with polymorphic composition and no blast infiltration. Bone marrow aspirations also showed signs of a slight dysgranulopoiesis with eosinophilia (11.6%) and myeloid maturation arrest at the promyelocyte stage. It was performed in the nadir phase (370 neutrophils/µL). Mutational analysis was first performed to search for possible ELANE sequence variants, but direct sequencing of all exons and exon-intron boundaries of ELANE NM_001972.3 did not reveal pathogenic variants. Whole Exome Sequencing (WES) analysis was performed at the New York Genome Center and the Rockefeller University, revealing a heterozygous p.T117del (c.349_351del) in-frame deletion mutation in the SRP54 gene. The same sequence variant was found in an Invitae Laboratory using a different sample. Screening for genetic causes of neutropenia did not reveal mutations in other congenital neutropenia genes."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 6-month-old female born to consanguineous parents (first cousins). The patient's geographic location is unspecified.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with fever for two weeks, diarrhea for five days, poor feeding, and restlessness. She had a history of recurrent fever of unknown origin and multiple episodes of oral candidiasis, controlled by Nystatin suspension. She had three hospitalizations for fever workup and a history of urinary tract infection (UTI). The patient was placed on vancomycin (10 mg/kg/dose/QID), meropenem (20 mg/kg/dose/TDS), voriconazole (30 mg/kg/BD), and G-CSF (10 mcg/kg/day due to persistent neutropenia), but the fever persisted and neutropenia was non-responsive to G-CSF. She was later diagnosed with T− B+ NK+ severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) and received intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) along with previously prescribed antimicrobials, resulting in considerable clinical improvement. She was discharged with prophylactic treatment including cotrimoxazole (10 mg/kg daily), voriconazole (5 mg/kg), acyclovir (15 mg/kg daily), isoniazid (25 mg daily), G-CSF (10 mcg/day), and monthly IVIg (3 gr/month).",
  "Physical Examination": "On physical examination, the patient appeared toxic and febrile. She had microcephaly with a head circumference of 36.5 cm (<3rd percentile) and failure to thrive with a height of 58 cm (−3.0 SD) and weight of 4.7 Kg (−3.7 SD), both under the 3rd percentile. No facial dysmorphism was observed. She had hoarseness, and lung auscultation revealed rhonchi and wheezing. There was erythema and swelling at the site of the BCG vaccine injection that resolved after 10 days. Oral candidiasis, a pustular rash on the fingers, and multiple perianal punched-out ulcers were observed. No hepatosplenomegaly or lymphadenopathy was detected.",
  "Past Medical History": "The family history was non-contributory, and her 8-year-old brother was healthy. She had a history of recurrent fever of unknown origin, multiple episodes of oral candidiasis, and a history of UTI.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Initial laboratory tests revealed leukopenia with WBC count of 1100 cells/μl, lymphopenia with ALC of 1089 cells/μl, neutropenia with ANC of 11 cells/μl, normocytic anemia with Hb of 7.5 g/dL, high inflammatory markers with ESR of 44 mm/hour and CRP of 153 mg/L, elevated lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) of 444 IU/L, and abnormal liver enzymes with AST of 178 IU/L and ALT of 110 IU/L. The blood culture was positive for gram-positive cocci. EBV and CMV viral loads, HIV antibody (Ab), HBS antigen, HBS Ab, and HCV Ab were all negative. The COVID-19 PCR test was negative. TORCH study and metabolic disorder workup performed in another center yielded normal results. The bone marrow aspiration was hypocellular without any maturation arrest. Immunologic workup showed low T CD3+ (141 cells/μl), low T CD4+ (119 cells/μl), low T CD8+ (22 cells/μl), normal B CD19+ (555 cells/μl) and B CD20+ (544 cells/μl), and normal NK CD16+CD56+ (272 cells/μl). The immunologic profile revealed low IgG (83 mg/dL), with normal IgA (195 mg/dL), IgM (203 mg/dL), and IgE (0.2 IU/ml). The nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test was normal. The T-cell receptor excision circle (TREC) was low. The lymphocyte transformation test (LTT) was abnormal to mitogens and antigens (PHA: 1.5, BCG: 2, Candida: 1.5)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 17-year-old male with no significant past medical history, no smoking history, no allergies, and not on any regular medications. There is no significant medical history in his family. The patient resides in Japan.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially developed a dry cough and fever. He visited a previous doctor and was prescribed cough suppressants and clarithromycin, but there was no improvement. Upon re-consultation, multiple pulmonary infiltrates were observed in both lung fields on chest X-ray and CT, resulting in hospitalization with a diagnosis of pneumonia. After hospital admission, the patient received ampicillin/sulbactam and garenoxacin for four days, but due to progressing respiratory failure, he was transferred to another hospital. Given the significant decrease in immunoglobulins, a replenishment at 5 g/day for three days was performed. Considering bacterial pneumonia and pulmonary cryptococcosis, meropenem 3 g/day, levofloxacin 500 mg/day, and fluconazole 400 mg/day were initiated. As respiratory failure progressed further on the second day of illness, high-dose steroid therapy with methylprednisolone 1000 mg/day for three days was started. Blood and sputum cultures were negative. On the fourth day, both respiratory status and imaging findings improved, prompting a bronchoscopy for diagnostic purposes. Consultation and registration of clinical information with the Primary Immunodeficiency Database in Japan confirmed the diagnosis of Common Variable Immunodeficiency (CVID). The lung lesions were diagnosed as Granulomatous Lymphocytic Interstitial Lung Disease (GLILD) complicating CVID. After high-dose steroid therapy, tapering and maintenance therapy with prednisolone (PSL) were initiated, reducing to PSL 10 mg/day by discharge. Currently, the patient is maintained on PSL 5 mg/day and regular supplementation of 10 g immunoglobulins, with no recurrence and disappearance of pulmonary shadows.",
  "Physical Examination": "Upon admission, the patient was conscious with the following vital signs: temperature of 37.0°C, pulse of 119 beats per minute (regular), blood pressure of 101/64 mmHg, and SpO2 of 86% on 6 L/min oxygen via a reservoir mask. There was no conjunctival pallor or jaundice, no palpable cervical lymph nodes, and no heart murmurs. Fine crackles were heard in both lungs, and no lower limb edema was observed.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no significant past medical history, no smoking history, no allergies, and was not on any regular medications. There was also no significant medical history in his family.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Blood test results showed no significant elevation in white blood cell count or C-reactive protein, indicating an absence of inflammatory markers in blood tests, but a marked decrease in immunoglobulins. Arterial blood gas analysis under 6 L/min of oxygen showed hypoxemia with a PaO2 of 62.6 Torr. Lymphocyte subset analysis of peripheral blood showed normal ranges for CD3 and CD19 cell counts. Initial chest radiography revealed patchy infiltrates and ground-glass opacities predominantly in the lower fields of both lungs. Initial chest CT showed diffuse infiltrates and ground-glass opacities dominantly on the dorsal side of both lower lobes. Blood and sputum cultures were negative."
}"

The infiltrating lymphocytes were small in size, predominantly CD3-positive T cells, with a few CD20, CD79a-positive B cells, no atypia, and no indication of lymphoma. Epstein-Barr virus expressing mRNA (EBER)-positive cells were not observed, ruling out lymphomatoid granulomatosis. Comprehensive blood tests and CT scans ruled out secondary hypogammaglobulinemia due to conditions such as nephrotic syndrome, protein-losing enteropathy, malignancy, history of medication or radiation therapy, and HIV infection. A CT scan on the 11th day of illness showed significant improvement in the infiltrates and ground-glass opacities in both lungs."

  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 6-year-old female weighing 13 kg. Her geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented with a fever of 38.6°C in November 2014. She experienced recurrent episodes of fever, splenomegaly, and anemia over the next several years. In October 2018, she was admitted with recurrent symptoms including moderate anemia, abdominal distention, and massive splenomegaly. In December 2019, she underwent haploidentical allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) from her brother. The patient had a history of recurrent EBV infections. She experienced seizures manifesting as involuntary twitching of the left upper limb prior to the HSCT. During the HSCT conditioning, she developed fever, progressive splenomegaly, and occasional seizures. Post-transplant, she showed signs of poor graft function but eventually achieved engraftment.",

  "Physical Examination": "Initial examination in 2014 revealed no palpable liver or spleen enlargement. In February 2015, splenomegaly was noted. In October 2018, physical examination showed moderate anemia, abdominal distention, and massive splenomegaly [Line 1: 12cm; Line 2: 13cm; Line 3: +5cm]. Prior to HSCT in February 2019, moderate splenomegaly was observed [Line 1: 8.5 cm; Line 2: 9 cm; Line 3: -2 cm]. Post-HSCT, the spleen size gradually reduced.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of recurrent EBV infections and hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis (HLH). Gene mutation analysis showed mutations in UNC13D-exon26 and UNC13D-exon12 genes, with specific mutation sites of c.1055 + 1G > A and c.2448–13G>A.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial tests in 2014 showed EBV-DNA positive and mild anemia. Subsequent tests revealed moderate anemia (Hb: 60-80g/L), thrombocytopenia (Plt: 30-70 × 109/L), and continuously positive EBV-DNA. In October 2018, blood tests showed WBC: 3.4 × 109/L, NE: 0.68 × 109/L, Hb: 68g/L, Plt: 55 × 109/L. Biochemical indicators included LDH: 305U/L, albumin: 32.8g/L, triglyceride: 1.93mmol/L, ferritin: 1440ng/mL, and fibrinogen: 1.93 g/L. EBV-DNA level was 5.01 × 104 IU/mL. Soluble CD25 was > 44000 U/ml, and NK cell activity was 7.45%."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient was a 27-year-old pregnant woman, gravida 1 para 0. She was from a non-consanguineous marriage. The pregnancy was at 24+1 gestational weeks when the initial examination was performed.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient underwent a routine mid-trimester fetal ultrasound scan at 24+1 gestational weeks. The ultrasound estimated that the fetus' gestational age was 22w4d, indicating growth restriction. Cystic structures were detected at the posterior horn of the lateral ventricles. A single umbilical artery (SUA) was also detected. Follow-up ultrasound at 28+1 gestational weeks showed persistent cystic structures at the posterior horn of each lateral ventricle, which had increased in size from the previous examination. The fetal growth trend was slower than that of a normal fetus, manifesting as fetal growth restriction (FGR). In particular, fetal BPD and HC were especially small (less than the 1st percentile) with progressively reduced growth velocity, manifesting as progressive microcephaly. The pregnancy was terminated at 33 weeks of gestation after evaluation by multidisciplinary consultation, considering the poor prognosis.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination details were provided for the pregnant woman.",

  "Past Medical History": "Both the patient and her husband were usually in good health, with no bad habits such as smoking and drinking. There was no remarkable family history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Routine maternal serologic screening in the first trimester returned negative results for rubella virus, toxoplasma, human immunodeficiency virus, and hepatitis B and C. The initial ultrasound at 24+1 weeks showed fetal growth parameters: fetal biparietal diameter (BPD), 54 mm (< P10, -1.85 SD); head circumference (HC), 204 mm (< P10, -1.53 SD); abdominal circumference (AC), 177 mm (< P10, -1.55 SD); and femur length (FL), 39 mm (P15.4, -1.02 SD). Follow-up ultrasound at 28+1 weeks showed: BPD 63 mm (< P1, -2.64 SD), HC 232 mm (< P1, -2.99 SD), AC 205 mm (< P1, -2.56 SD), and FL 46 mm (< P3, -1.94 SD). All indicators of intrauterine infection were negative."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a female fetus prenatally diagnosed with hyperoxaluria type 1. She was born at 36 weeks + 4 days of gestation with a birth weight of 2,615 grams.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was prenatally diagnosed with hyperoxaluria type 1 based on family history and genetic testing. Fetal ultrasound scans and amniotic fluid were normal, with a regular course of pregnancy. After birth, hyperidratation by intravenous fluids (glucosaline solution, 70 ml/kg) and complementary breastfeeding were started, preventing weight loss of more than 5% of birth weight. Intravenous fluid administration was stopped on day 7 of life when the infant reached birth weight after a weight loss of 3% of birth weight. A fluid intake of 1.5 L/m2 was then given to maintain high hydration by breastfeeding and complementary breastfeeding. Lumasiran was initiated for compassionate use on the tenth day of life, administered according to a specific schedule. The baby also received hyperhydration with complementary breastfeeding, and from the first month of life, alkalizing therapy with potassium citrate. At 3 months of age, nephrocalcinosis was detected. At 9 months, concomitantly with acute pyelonephritis, kidney stones were observed. The patient was placed on tamsulosin 0.2 mg daily, resulting in ureteral stone expulsion 3 days later without symptoms. At 12 and 20 months of age, the child showed growth according to the birth percentile. No signs of systemic oxalosis were observed up to 20 months of age. No adverse effects associated with lumasiran were observed during the treatment.",

  "Physical Examination": "At 7 days of age, the first ultrasound scan of the kidneys and urinary tract showed well-differentiated kidneys with normal echogenicity. Serial ultrasound scans revealed nephrocalcinosis at 3 months of age. At 9 months, two hyperechogenic images with slight posterior acoustic shadowing of 6 and 5 mm were observed at the left lower renal pole, and a stone of about 6 mm in the premural tract of the right ureter, with modest dilation of the upstream ureter in the pelvic tract (5 mm). A fluid intake of 1.5 L/m2 was then given to maintain high hydration by breastfeeding and complementary breastfeeding. The baby also received hyperhydration with complementary breastfeeding, and from the first month of life, alkalizing therapy with potassium citrate. At 3 months of age, nephrocalcinosis was detected. At 9 months, concomitantly with acute pyelonephritis, kidney stones were observed. The patient was placed on tamsulosin 0.2 mg daily, resulting in ureteral stone expulsion 3 days later without symptoms. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 7-month-old Chinese girl. She was born at 37 weeks' gestation and weighed 3,400 g. Her growth and development were normal, except that she was unable to sit.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the hospital with nystagmus for 2 months. One and a half months after diagnosis, the girl lost the ability to roll over and hold her bottle. She developed hyperacusis, a heightened sensitivity to sound, and her natural smile lessened.",

  "Physical Examination": "An examination of the anterior segment of both her eyes revealed no abnormalities. Color fundus photography showed a cherry-red spot with a ring of whitish infiltrate surrounding both macula. Fluorescein fundus angiography (FFA) showed normal retinal circulation and vessels. Optical Coherence Tomography (OCT) revealed a thickening and increased reflectivity of the inner retinal layers with a shadowing effect on the outer structures. The marked thickening and hyperreflective part was within a 1–2 papillary diameter (PD) area around the fovea. It was difficult to distinguish the inner retinal structure.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's family history was negative for this condition, and her parents were not known to be consanguineous.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The head MRI of the girl's head revealed no visible anomalies."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 23-year-old female from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with blurring of vision affecting both eyes, which was gradual, progressive, and painless. This symptom started 4 months prior to presentation and was not associated with redness, discharge, or abnormal sensation in the eyes. There was no history of preceding trauma or eye intervention. She had experienced similar visual disturbances intermittently over the last 3 years, previously limited to the right eye. The patient reported a history of unusual symptoms for many years, including an episode of inability to move both legs and slurred speech approximately 12 years ago. These symptoms improved without medical intervention but recurred periodically. At the time of presentation, she was experiencing weakness in her right leg, causing difficulty in walking. The patient could not recall any potential triggers for her symptoms. There was no history of headaches, loss of consciousness, irregular body movements, abnormal sensations, or sensory loss throughout her body. Her hearing had never been affected. Bowel and bladder control had never been compromised. The patient had withdrawn from other family members, displayed signs of anxiety, and frequently experienced mood fluctuations. She also exhibited forgetfulness and struggled with maintaining focus, which led to her discontinuing her studies.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had a slender physique and was oriented to time, place, and person. No facial dysmorphism was observed. There were no signs of pallor, jaundice, lymph node enlargement, or dehydration. Vital signs were stable. Visual acuity was measured at 6/60 in both eyes. Color vision was impaired, and visual fields appeared narrowed. The corneas were clear, while bilateral optic disc pallor was observed. Sensations were normal across all 4 limbs. Hypotonia and reduced power (graded as 3/5) were observed in the right hip and knee muscles. The patient displayed emotional instability.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was delivered at home through spontaneous vaginal birth and did not receive standard postnatal care. Her immunizations were administered according to the prevailing national immunization schedule. Her developmental milestones aligned with those of her siblings. Menarche occurred at the age of 13, and she has been experiencing regular menstrual cycles. There were no documented diagnosed comorbidities, and her family history did not indicate any comorbidities. The patient had never undergone surgical procedures. There was no history of consanguinity in the family.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Routine investigations were conducted, but specific results were not provided in the given information."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "MRI revealed that the T2 signal of the bilateral posterior horn of the lateral ventricle was slightly extended. These variants were confirmed in the family by Sanger sequencing. The c.544_545del variant was inherited from the father, and the c.230-3C>G variant was inherited from the mother. A Splicing Reporter Minigene assay was performed to determine the impact of the c.230-3C>G variant on transcript splicing. The RT-PCR products were analyzed by electrophoresis, which showed that the length of the PCR product was shortened in the MT construct. Sequencing of the excised gel bands confirmed the absence of the sequence of exon 4 of 151 nt in length in the MT construct."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Whole exome sequencing (WES) was performed commercially at Berrygenomics on the patient and her parents. Sequencing was performed on Illumina Novaseq 6000 (Illumina, San Diego, United States), using the Nano WES Human Exome V1.0 (Berrygenomics, Beijing, China) kit with 200 bp paired-end read, according to the manufacturer’s instructions. Annotation of variants was performed using GATK, gnomAD, 1000genomes, SIFT, FATHMM, MutationAssessor, OMIM, ClinVar, HGMD. Sequence analysis of exon 28 and 12 of PIGN, using genomic DNA from the patient and her parents were performed by amplification of a 438 bp and 239 bp fragment containing the putative mutation identified via exome sequencing. The sense primer sequence was 5’-TAAGTCAGTTTCATCACCGTTCTAT-3’ and the antisense primer sequence was 5’-ATTTCCTCTAATGACAAGCAACAC-3’ for exon 28. The sense primer sequence was 5’-TCTAGCAAATGACACTTTTAGAGA-3’, and the antisense primer sequence was 5’-TTCCTTACCACTGAGTTAAGAGG-3’ for exon 12."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 3-year-old boy from Japan. His height and weight were 99.9 cm (+ 0.2 SD score) and 15.3 kg (+ 0.0 SD score), respectively, on presentation.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a mass on his left elbow that had been present for 6 months. The tumor limited extension movements. He was born uneventfully (delivered at 41 weeks and 1 day of gestation, with a birth weight of 3,034 g and a body length of 50.0 cm). He was healthy until the onset of symptoms and had no history of medications or nutritional supplements. Based on the findings, the patient was diagnosed with Hyperphosphatemic Familial Tumoral Calcinosis (HFTC). A low phosphate diet was initiated to reduce the risk of arteriosclerosis. After four months of avoiding phosphate-rich foods, hyperphosphatemia did not improve. Phosphate-binding therapy with 500 mg bixalomer thrice daily (approximately 100 mg/kg/d) was administered, resulting in a decrease in serum phosphorus levels. However, the tumor in the elbow enlarged. Tumor resection was performed due to the risk of self-destruction of the skin. After surgery, the patient was maintained on a low-phosphate diet and administered bixalomers, with no signs of relapse or new pathological lesions observed.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed a hard, tender, irregular mass measuring approximately 5 cm on the left elbow. No lymphadenopathy was detected. The remaining physical examination findings were normal. Both head CT and ultrasonography confirmed no calcification in the basal ganglia, kidney, urinary tract, or vessel walls. Fundoscopic findings were normal.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's parents and sibling were healthy, with no family history of calcified masses, mineral disorders, or cardiovascular events. His parents were not in a consanguineous marriage.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory data revealed hyperphosphatemia (8.7 mg/dL; reference: 4.1–5.3 mg/dL). The iFGF23 level was low (13 pg/mL; reference:14–68 pg/mL), and the TRP level was inappropriately high (96.1%; reference: 84.3–90.3%). The 1,25(OH)2D3 level was inappropriately normal (59 pg/mL; reference: 20–60 pg/mL). The levels of blood urea nitrogen, creatinine, alkaline phosphatase, growth hormone, and thyroid function were normal. Radiography revealed a calcified mass around the left elbow. After dietary intervention, follow-up tests showed: Ca 9.8 mg/dL, P 7.2 mg/dL, iFGF23 10 pg/mL, TRP 98.7%. After bixalomer treatment: P 6.1 mg/dL, TRP 96.03%."
}"

Histopathological examination of the needle biopsy specimen revealed calcified deposits with multinucleated giant cell formation. Genetic analysis revealed a novel homozygous variant in intron 10 (c.1780-1G>C) affecting the splice site in GALNT3. Analysis of the GALNT3 mRNA in the patient confirmed that this variant resulted in the deletion of exon 11. G-banding karyotype analysis and high-resolution chromosome banding techniques of the proband revealed a normal 46,XY karyotype without monosomy 2q24.3. Genome-wide SNP array revealed a maternal UPD on chromosome 2. Histopathological examination of the resected tumor tissue indicated diffuse multinodular and map-like ectopic calcinosis, with foreign body giant cells, histiocytic infiltrates, fibrosis, and lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltrates, consistent with HFTC. The mRNA extracted from the tumor did not express GALNT3 mRNA."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 53-year-old male from Jamaica who frequently travels between Jamaica and his current location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented with one month of headaches, dizziness, and generalized weakness. He experienced an episode of near syncope on the day of presentation. After being discharged from his first hospital visit, he returned 10 days later following a witnessed seizure consisting of upper and lower body tonic-clonic movements at home. The patient became unresponsive with upper and lower body jerking and a period of confusion afterward. He did not have any headaches, weakness, or confusion since his discharge and prior to this event. The patient had a previously unexplained transitory febrile episode four months prior to his initial presentation. At his nine-month follow-up visit, his headaches had completely resolved, and he did not have any recurrent seizures while on an anti-seizure regimen of levetiracetam.",

  "Physical Examination": "The initial neurologic examination was notable for wide-based gait and imbalance but was otherwise within normal limits.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no significant past medical history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Peripheral blood work did not reveal evidence of inflammation without leukocytosis or elevated acute phase reactants. The initial lumbar puncture (LP) revealed one red blood cell (RBC), seven nucleated cells with 95% lymphocytes, and normal protein and glucose, consistent with lymphocytic pleocytosis. Infectious studies, including treponema pallidum, human immunodeficiency virus, Epstein-Barr virus, enteroviruses, JC virus, and herpesviruses, were negative. A repeat LP re-demonstrated lymphocytic pleocytosis with 14 nucleated cells and 99% lymphocytic predominance. Infectious studies demonstrated positive West Nile Virus IgG in the CSF and the serum with negative IgM in the CSF and serum. The paraneoplastic panel returned negative."
}"
