Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 57-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with sudden right postauricular tingling for 3 days, starting on June 10th. He experienced discharge-like pain in the right postauricular region for a few minutes each time, lasting several seconds. The pain was intense and severely affected the patient's life. No obvious nausea, vomiting, cough, diarrhea, limb weakness, or fever was initially observed. On the day of admission, fever occurred in the afternoon, with the patient's temperature reaching 39.2 °C. The patient developed a cough that night. Fine moist rales were heard in the right lower lung, but oxygen saturation was normal. The patient's condition changed rapidly, with high fever, unexpected respiratory failure, and multiple organ failure developing.",

  "Physical Examination": "Initial physical examination results were normal. Nervous system examination showed that the right postauricular occipital nerve distribution area had acupuncture-induced hypersensitivity, whereas the rest of the nervous system examination showed no abnormalities.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no special history of past illness. No special personal and family history was reported.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Routine blood analysis on June 13th showed that the percentage of neutrophils was 84.6%. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was 25 mm/h, and sodium was 131.0 mmol/L. Other blood biochemical indicators were generally normal. Coagulation tests, thyroid function tests (FT3, FT4, TSH, TG-Ab, and TPO-Ab), and liver and kidney function tests were normal. Antistreptolysin O (ASO), rapid detection of infectious diseases, and urine analysis showed no abnormalities. Stool analysis, glycosylated hemoglobin, and serum homocysteine levels were normal. The current perception threshold (CPT) indicated that the right lesser occipital nerve was hypersensitive (with small fibers involved). Chest X-ray examinations were performed twice."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 57-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with sudden right postauricular tingling for 3 days, starting on June 10th. He experienced discharge-like pain in the right postauricular region for a few minutes each time, lasting several seconds. The pain was intense and severely affected the patient's life. No obvious nausea, vomiting, cough, diarrhea, limb weakness, or fever was initially observed. On the day of admission, fever occurred in the afternoon, with the patient's temperature reaching 39.2 °C. The patient developed a cough that night. Fine moist rales were heard in the right lower lung, but oxygen saturation was normal. The patient's condition changed rapidly, with high fever, unexpected respiratory failure, and multiple organ failure developing.",

  "Physical Examination": "Initial physical examination results were normal. Nervous system examination showed that the right postauricular occipital nerve distribution area had acupuncture-induced hypersensitivity, whereas the rest of the nervous system examination showed no abnormalities.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no special history of past illness. No special personal and family history was reported.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Routine blood analysis on June 13th showed that the percentage of neutrophils was 84.6%. Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) was 25 mm/h, and sodium was 131.0 mmol/L. Other blood biochemical indicators were generally normal. Coagulation tests, thyroid function tests (FT3, FT4, TSH, TG-Ab, and TPO-Ab), and liver and kidney function tests were normal. Antistreptolysin O (ASO), rapid detection of infectious diseases, and urine analysis showed no abnormalities. Stool analysis, glycosylated hemoglobin, and serum homocysteine levels were normal. The current perception threshold (CPT) indicated that the right lesser occipital nerve was hypersensitive (with small fibers involved). Chest X-ray examinations were performed twice.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Head magnetic resonance imaging was normal. Pulmonary computed tomography (CT) on June 14th showed inflammation in the right lower lung. The nucleic acid polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for influenza H7N9 virus in sputum specimens was positive at Chaoyang Hospital. The specimens sent to the Beijing Center for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) and the Chinese National Influenza Center (CNIC) also tested positive for H7N9 virus. A subsequent chest X-ray re-examination showed that bilateral lung infection was significantly worse than the previous day's chest film."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 2-month-old Bahraini baby girl. She was delivered at term via normal vaginal delivery. Her birth weight was 2.8 kg, with a head circumference of 33.4 cm and an abdominal circumference of 35 cm. At the time of evaluation, her weight was 3.7 kg.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The baby was referred to the hospital due to inadequate weight gain, which led to the deferral of her two-month vaccination. Her feeding pattern exhibited suboptimal intake, necessitating exclusive reliance on milk formula. There were no reported instances of vomiting, diarrhea, or irritability. The mother had concerns regarding inadequate weight gain and abdominal distension. During the neonatal period, the baby remained asymptomatic and did not develop jaundice; her skin color remained normal. The baby received her first vaccination at birth. The mother, gravida 2 and parity 2, received routine prenatal care, including surveillance and screening for TORCH and anemia, with multiple visits to an obstetrician. She was found to have iron deficiency anemia during pregnancy, which was controlled after giving her 30 mg of ferrous iron from week 13.",

  "Physical Examination": "Upon general inspection, the baby appeared pale, dehydrated, and hypoactive. The central nervous system examination revealed a paralyzed and swollen right arm with excessive crying on moving the right shoulder, and a flat anterior fontanelle with a dilated vein of the scalp. The abdomen was distended with a visible dilated vein and hepatomegaly. Cardiovascular examination showed normal heart sounds S1 and S2, with no click or gallop systolic ejection murmur. The baby's left arm and right leg appeared intact and remained active during the physical examination.",

  "Past Medical History": "The baby's APGAR score was 9/10 at 1 minute. Physical examinations during the neonatal period revealed no abnormalities across all systems. The pregnancy history was reviewed with an obstetrician, and all screenings during pregnancy showed negative results for syphilis.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory results displayed elevated white blood cell count, inflammatory markers, and reticulocyte levels, and abnormal liver function test findings. TORCH testing indicated a positive result for cytomegalovirus (CMV), and the T. pallidum hemagglutination assay was reactive. An abdominal X-ray scan showed a very distended abdomen, possibly hepatosplenomegaly or ascites. An abdominal ultrasound confirmed hepatosplenomegaly and mild ascites. An X-ray of the swelling in the right arm showed a periosteal reaction in the right radius with small cystic lesions in the proximal humerus and abnormal bone quality. A skeletal survey showed that the thoracic cage, spine, and pelvic bones appeared normal. However, areas of destruction were observed in the proximal shaft of the left humerus and the distal shaft of the right femur. The U/S of the right arm revealed suspected osteomyelitis."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A non-contrast CT brain scan showed a thin corpus callosum, no intracranial hemorrhage or infarctions, and gray-white matter differentiation was maintained with no midline shifts. Ventricles, sulci, and basal cisterns were normal. The posterior fossa structures appeared grossly unremarkable. Opacification of the pneumatized ethmoid air cells and bilateral maxillary sinuses was present, but bilateral opacification of the mastoid air cells was more on the left side. Visualized osseous structures appeared unremarkable, and no fracture line was apparent. An echocardiogram revealed normal cardiac segments with a small patent foramen ovale (PFO), normal mitral and tricuspid valves, normal aortic and pulmonary valves, normal right and left ventricle morphology, and an intact ventricular septum. There was evidence of branch stenosis in the pulmonary arteries, with a peak gradient of 28 mmHg. The aortic arch appeared normal, with no evidence of patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) or coarctation. Cardiac function was assessed as normal."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 40-year-old male, type 2 diabetic patient, who works as a field worker in an unspecified geographic location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient noticed a small swelling on the medial surface of his ankle two years ago. The swelling slowly increased in size, causing minor discomfort when wearing shoes. Four months before his presentation, he began to notice dark granular discharge from the swelling. He was given an unspecified topical ointment, however, there was no improvement. Apart from this swelling, the patient is relatively healthy with no fever, night sweats, weight loss, and no difficulty walking.",
  "Physical Examination": "A 2 × 2 cm swelling was observed in the right medial calcaneal region. The overlying skin appeared normal, with no redness, warmth, or tenderness. A 3 × 3 mm opening was noted in the center of the swelling, through which black dot-like granules discharged upon pressure. The range of motion of the ankle joint was maintained.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient has been living with type 2 diabetes for five years and has been on metformin for this condition. There is no mention of any significant past medical or family history relevant to the current condition.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory investigations were within the normal range, including complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, liver function tests, and renal function tests. HbA1c was controlled (6.2%)."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 40-year-old male, type 2 diabetic patient, who works as a field worker in an unspecified geographic location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient noticed a small swelling on the medial surface of his ankle two years ago. The swelling slowly increased in size, causing minor discomfort when wearing shoes. Four months before his presentation, he began to notice dark granular discharge from the swelling. He was given an unspecified topical ointment, however, there was no improvement. Apart from this swelling, the patient is relatively healthy with no fever, night sweats, weight loss, and no difficulty walking.",
  "Physical Examination": "A 2 × 2 cm swelling was observed in the right medial calcaneal region. The overlying skin appeared normal, with no redness, warmth, or tenderness. A 3 × 3 mm opening was noted in the center of the swelling, through which black dot-like granules discharged upon pressure. The range of motion of the ankle joint was maintained.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient has been living with type 2 diabetes for five years and has been on metformin for this condition. There is no mention of any significant past medical or family history relevant to the current condition.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory investigations were within the normal range, including complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate, liver function tests, and renal function tests. HbA1c was controlled (6.2%).",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Initial investigation with an X-ray revealed multiple calcaneal lytic lesions with wide zones of transition and diffuse sclerotic changes. A focused ultrasound scan showed multiple hyperechoic foci surrounded by hypoechoic lesions resembling 'dot in circle.' An ankle MRI with MR PD fat-sat sequence revealed multiple well-defined small high signal intensities with central hypointensity, also resembling 'dot in circle.' The X-ray findings were multiple lytic-permeative lesions having wide zones of transition in the calcaneal neck with associated diffuse sclerotic changes of the surrounding bone. A focused ultrasound of the swelling showed multiple soft tissue hypoechoic relatively well-defined rounded nodules with central echogenic foci. The foci did not show any posterior acoustic changes. Sagittal and axial MR images with fat-saturated proton density sequence revealed multiple small, well-defined round high-signal lesions with a central low signal intensity on the calcaneal neck and the adjacent soft tissue. Additional features suggestive of diffuse bone marrow edema of the calcaneus were also noted. Fine needle aspiration from the lesion suggested fungal elements. Fine needle aspiration performed from the soft tissue lesion yielded findings consistent with fungal elements upon microscopic examination using potassium hydroxide (KOH) staining."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 21-year-old female patient referred to our hospital due to primary infertility for 18 months. The patient’s menarche was at the age of 14, with regular menses every 30 days, lasting for 5 days. She has a history of hypothyroidism, which was well controlled by treatment.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient reported primary infertility for 18 months, along with complaints of dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. She underwent a comprehensive diagnostic workup and had an elevated prolactin level. Pelvic and transvaginal ultrasounds were inconclusive but pelvic MRI revealed a normal-sized uterus with two uterine cavities separated by a low T2 signal septum. Hysteroscopy showed a complete vaginal septum, cervical septum, and a septum inside the uterus reaching the fundus, which was confirmed by laparoscopy. Therapeutically, the patient underwent septum removal via a hysteroscopic approach, followed by insertion of an intrauterine contraceptive device and contraceptive pills for 3 months. After 3 months, another hysteroscopy removed remnants of the septa. Following failed attempts to conceive naturally, two trials of ovulation induction were performed, leading to pregnancy. Three months into the pregnancy, Shirodkar cervical cerclage was performed due to cervical insufficiency caused by previous cauterization. The pregnancy was closely supervised, and the baby was delivered at term, healthy.",
  "Physical Examination": "Upon physical examination, a complete septum was detected. Otherwise, no abnormality was noted.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a history of hypothyroidism, which was well controlled by treatment. No other significant past medical or surgical history. Family history was negative for any known anomaly.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Hormonal assay results showed that follicle-stimulating hormone, luteinizing hormone, and thyroid-stimulating hormone were all within the normal range, except for the prolactin level, which was elevated (64.72 ng/ml; reference range 4.79–23.3). Pelvic and transvaginal ultrasounds were performed but were inconclusive."
}"

Pelvic and transvaginal ultrasounds were performed but were inconclusive.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Pelvic MRI revealed a uterus that was normal in size with two uterine cavities separated by a septum of low T2 signal, extending into the endocervical canal. The surface of the fundus was convex in shape with an acute angle between uterine cavities (about 60°). A thin regular endometrium about 7 mm in each cavity was observed. Hysteroscopy confirmed a complete vaginal septum, cervical septum, and a septum inside the uterus, reaching the fundus and separating the uterus into two cavities. Laparoscopy indicated a normal outer wall of the uterus."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 69-year-old man from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient visited the hospital for investigation of hypoglycemia. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes in his 40s. His medication was gradually changed from insulin injection (insulin degludec) to oral OHA, metformin 1500 mg and vildagliptin 100 mg, from age 60. At age 68, he had a hypoglycemia attack (22 mg/dL) and was transferred to a previous hospital. OHAs were stopped, and he was treated with intravenous glucose infusion. After glucose levels stabilized, he was referred to the current hospital. His body weight had gradually decreased from around 60 kg to 50 kg over several years, along with decreased daily activities due to blindness in his left eye. Food intake had also gradually decreased. He did not show hyperphagia, polydipsia, or polyuria. At first appearance, he did not show any specific symptoms suggesting hypoglycemia. His consciousness was normal. Four months after the first appearance, there were concerns about prolonged elevated glucose profiles. Lanreotide dosage was increased to 120 mg, resulting in improved blood glucose and HbA1c levels at six months. In the follow-up period, the patient complained of back pain, revealing multiple spinal compression fractures. He became unable to visit outpatient and died at a retirement home from prostration.",

  "Physical Examination": "Blood pressure was 135/70 mmHg and pulse rate was 79 beats/min. There was no rale, murmur, or extracardiac sound in chest auscultation. Grip strength was 5.9 kg and 5.8 kg at right and left. Walking speed was 0.45 m/sec. Body weight was 50 kg, body height was 170 cm, and body mass index was 17.30 kg/m2. Physical examination revealed acromegalic features including prominent brow ridges, macroglossia, and thickened nose. Neurological examination suggested carpal tunnel syndrome. There was decreased bilateral ankle reflex and vibration sensations without the presence of symptoms.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes in his 40s. He had no history of macrovascular complications. His left eye lost vision due to diabetic retinopathy at age 64. He had no history of chronic liver disease, gastrectomy, or other causes of dumping syndrome.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Serum albumin was 3 g/dL, low-density lipoprotein cholesterol was 61 mg/dL, and total cholesterol was 110 mg/dL. Anti-insulin antibody was positive (3.6 U/mL; reference range <0.4 U/mL). Immunoreactive insulin and C-peptide levels were 5.1 mU/mL and 1.97 ng/mL at fasting glucose level 275 mg/dL. Skeletal muscle index (SMI) at the third lumbar vertebra level in a CT image-calculated area was 29.4 cm2/m2. Diabetic retinopathy was proliferative after laser photocoagulation. Nephropathy was G1A2. GH was 4.42 ng/mL and IGF-1 was 364 ng/mL (+4.70 standard deviation) at fasting plasma glucose level of 245 mg/dL. Heel pad thickness was 27.0 mm. Apnea-hypopnea index was 19.2."
}"

Transthoracic echocardiography and electrocardiogram showed no evidence of impaired cardiopulmonary dysfunction. X-rays revealed cauliflower-like tufting of the finger bones. CT imaging also revealed multiple spinal compression fractures."

Cases.Final Name: Prader-Willi syndrome due to paternal 15q11q13 deletion
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 10-month-old boy. His weight is 8.5 kg (25th percentile), body length is 73 cm (50th percentile), and head circumference is 43 cm (3rd percentile).",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presents with global developmental delay. He cannot roll over or sit alone, and his deciduous teeth have not yet erupted. He can only make monosyllabic 'ba, ma' sounds unconsciously. At birth, the patient weighed 2.6 kg (5th percentile) and was 47 cm long (5th-15th percentile). He was born with muscular hypotonia but had no abnormalities in sucking power and no special feeding required. Due to weak cry, poor spirit, and neonatal jaundice, he was transferred to the neonatal department for immediate treatment. During hospitalization, he was fed with normal milk powder and had occasional blood in stool. He was discharged at 14 days weighing 2.55 kg (<1st percentile). After discharge, he was breastfed but still had occasional blood in stool. At 1 month, his weight had not increased. At 3 months, he weighed 4.5 kg (<1st percentile) and was 59 cm long (5th-15th percentile). He could not raise his head in prone position until 5 months old. At 9 months, he weighed 7.6 kg (5th-15th percentile) and was 69 cm long (5th-15th percentile). He could not sit, roll over, or grab objects, and could only babble and pronounce the lip sound 'poof'. The feeding mode was switched to deep hydrolyzed protein milk powder due to suspected milk protein and breast milk allergy, after which weight gain improved and blood in stool disappeared.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient has characteristic facial features including almond eyes, short jaw, thin upper lip, turned down corners of the mouth, and prominent forehead. Muscular hypotonia in the extremities and simian crease were observed.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient is the first child of healthy non-consanguineous parents. The mother was 32 years old and the father 35 at the time of birth. There is no family history of developmental delay, intellectual disabilities, genetic syndrome, or congenital disease. The mother had no history of smoking, alcohol consumption, or drug use during pregnancy, and reported no decrease in fetal movements. The patient was delivered by cesarean section at 38 weeks of gestation due to abnormal fetal heartbeat, intrauterine hypoxia, and low amniotic fluid.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Cytogenetic analysis revealed a mosaic karyotype (45XY,der(15)?t(15;21),-21 [1]/46,XY [2]) in the proband. The chromosomal karyotypes of the parents were normal."
}"

At 9 months, he weighed 7.6 kg (5th-15th percentile) and was 69 cm long (5th-15th percentile). He could not sit, roll over, or grab objects, and could only babble and pronounce the lip sound 'poof'. The feeding mode was switched to deep hydrolyzed protein milk powder due to suspected milk protein and breast milk allergy, after which weight gain improved and blood in stool disappeared.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient has characteristic facial features including almond eyes, short jaw, thin upper lip, turned down corners of the mouth, and prominent forehead. Muscular hypotonia in the extremities and simian crease were observed.",

There is no family history of developmental delay, intellectual disabilities, genetic syndrome, or congenital disease. The mother had no history of smoking, alcohol consumption, or drug use during pregnancy, and reported no decrease in fetal movements. The patient was delivered by cesarean section at 38 weeks of gestation due to abnormal fetal heartbeat, intrauterine hypoxia, and low amniotic fluid.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Cytogenetic analysis revealed a mosaic karyotype (45XY,der(15)?t(15;21),-21 [1]/46,XY [2]) in the proband. The chromosomal karyotypes of the parents were normal.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Whole exome sequencing (WES) showed a deletion of 22.7 Mb in the chr15q11.2q21.1(22833515–45,564,992) region and a 2.1 Mb deletion in the chr21q22.3 (45817620–47,953,570) region with a copy number of about 1.5. Methylation-specific multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MS-MLPA) results showed the copy number of the 15q11-q13 region ranged between 0.5–0.7 (normal value 0.7–1.3), indicating the presence of gene deletion mutation. Methylation analysis showed a methylation level of approximately 70% (normal value 50%), indicating partial deletion of the methylated paternal allele, due to a mosaic deletion of the paternal allele."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 12-year-old individual raised as a girl. Her height was 158 cm (+1 SDS), weight 50 kg (+1 SDS), and BMI 20.0 kg/m2. The patient's blood pressure was 106/50 mmHg.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the hospital due to hirsutism and a deep voice that began at 11 years old. She had vellus hair on the upper lip, longer hair on the arms and legs, and had no obvious Adam's apple. She had not yet experienced menarche. After bilateral orchiectomy, a feminizing hormonal treatment of 0.5 mg/day of estradiol valerate tablets was started, which resulted in regression of hirsutism and clitoromegaly.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed clitoromegaly, with a length of 1.5 cm and width of 1.0 cm. Breast development was at Tanner stage II.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no similar family and genetic medical history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory examination revealed the following hormone values: luteinizing hormone 17.44 mIU/mL (0.56–58.96), prolactin 14.91 ng/mL (5.12–26.91), progesterone 0.49 ng/mL (0.16–13.03), and estradiol 11.37 pg/mL (22.03–315.88); all these values were in normal range. Follicle stimulating hormone was elevated at 53.31 mIU/mL (1.78 to 11.60) and testosterone was elevated at 2.58 ng/mL (0–1.23). Alpha-fetoprotein was 0.83 ng/mL (0.89–8.78), insulin-like growth factor-1 was 377.10 ng/mL (60–350). Carcinoembryonic antigen, glycobased antigen CA125, CA153, and CA199 were all negative. The cytogenetics revealed a 46,XY karyotype. DNA sequencing showed a variant in NR5A1. The adrenal ultrasound showed no cystic or solid mass in bilateral adrenal. The abdominopelvic ultrasound revealed a hypoechoic mass (considered primordial uterus) in posterior bladder, and hypoechoic masses (considered bilateral testicles) in bilateral groin. The bone age DR indicated that bone age was in the normal range (12 years old)."
}"

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory examination revealed the following hormone values: luteinizing hormone 17.44 mIU/mL (0.56–58.96), prolactin 14.91 ng/mL (5.12–26.91), progesterone 0.49 ng/mL (0.16–13.03), and estradiol 11.37 pg/mL (22.03–315.88); all these values were in normal range. Follicle stimulating hormone was elevated at 53.31 mIU/mL (1.78 to 11.60) and testosterone was elevated at 2.58 ng/mL (0–1.23). Alpha-fetoprotein was 0.83 ng/mL (0.89–8.78), insulin-like growth factor-1 was 377.10 ng/mL (60–350). Carcinoembryonic antigen, glycobased antigen CA125, CA153, and CA199 were all negative. The cytogenetics revealed a 46,XY karyotype. DNA sequencing showed a variant in NR5A1. The adrenal ultrasound showed no cystic or solid mass in bilateral adrenal. The abdominopelvic ultrasound revealed a hypoechoic mass (considered primordial uterus) in posterior bladder, and hypoechoic masses (considered bilateral testicles) in bilateral groin. The bone age DR indicated that bone age was in the normal range (12 years old).",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "The pelvic magnetic resonance imaging showed mixed signals in bilateral inguinal canal (considered vascular shadow). Uterus and ovaries were not visualized. The patient underwent diagnostic laparoscopy and bilateral orchiectomy at age 12 years. Pathology showed testes dysgenesis, composed mainly of hypoplastic seminiferous tubules."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 13-year-old female from an unspecified geographic location. She was born at term via normal vaginal delivery with a birth weight of 3 kg.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a history of irregular growth on the lateral aspect of the right foot, which began at the age of four and has progressively worsened since. She also had a motor developmental delay. There was a history of intrauterine hydrocephalus. Inversion of the right foot was observed, along with a limb length discrepancy where the right forearm and hand were longer than the left, and the right foot was longer than the left. A cerebriform connective tissue overgrowth was noted on the plantar and lateral aspects of the right foot.",

  "Physical Examination": "Clinical examination revealed inversion of the right foot. A cerebriform connective tissue overgrowth was noted on the plantar and lateral aspects of the right foot.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of intrauterine hydrocephalus. No other significant maternal history was noted.",

  "Initial Test Results": "A radiograph of the lumbar spine revealed levoconvex scoliosis."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 13-year-old female from an unspecified geographic location. She was born at term via normal vaginal delivery with a birth weight of 3 kg.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a history of irregular growth on the lateral aspect of the right foot, which began at the age of four and has progressively worsened since. She also had a motor developmental delay. There was a history of intrauterine hydrocephalus. Inversion of the right foot was observed, along with a limb length discrepancy where the right forearm and hand were longer than the left, and the right foot was longer than the left. A cerebriform connective tissue overgrowth was noted on the plantar and lateral aspects of the right foot.",

  "Physical Examination": "Clinical examination revealed inversion of the right foot. A limb length discrepancy was observed, with the right forearm and hand being longer than the left, and the right foot longer than the left. A cerebriform connective tissue overgrowth was noted on the plantar and lateral aspects of the right foot.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of intrauterine hydrocephalus. No other significant maternal history was noted.",

  "Initial Test Results": "A radiograph of the lumbar spine revealed levoconvex scoliosis.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "MRI of the right lower limb showed: On T1-weighted imaging (T1WI), a cerebriform connective tissue overgrowth or nevus was identified on both the plantar and lateral aspects of the right foot. The right foot appeared enlarged in size. A visible discrepancy in length and size was noted between the right and left legs. In the thigh, muscle atrophy was evident, accompanied by hypertrophy of the intermuscular and subcutaneous fat planes. Hypertrophy of subcutaneous fat and fatty infiltration within the calf muscles were observed. Both fibulas displayed inward bowing. Right lower limb contrast-enhanced angiography and venography revealed: Enlargement in the right superficial femoral, popliteal, and posterior tibial arteries. Feeders originating from the posterior tibial artery were identified in the lower third of the leg, alongside prominent vascular channels on the posterolateral aspect of the right leg and foot, as well as abnormal vessels within the foot itself. Dilation was observed in the lower third of the superficial femoral and popliteal veins. A prominent long saphenous vein was evident. Multiple varicosities were detected along the anterior and lateral aspects of the thigh, as well as the anterior, lateral, and posterior aspects of the leg within the subcutaneous plane."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 57-year-old female from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented with a 'hive-like' skin rash in the lower abdominal, pubic, and medial thigh areas that had been waxing and waning for about 6 months. Associated symptoms included fever, myalgia, and fatigue. The rash did not itch. Symptoms typically occurred every 1–3 weeks and resolved after 2–4 days. Prior to presentation, frequency of symptoms had increased to every 4 days. Myalgia heralded the onset of skin rash and was followed by fever that could be as high as 102 F. The patient denied any recent exposure to allergens or changes to skin care and detergent products. Initially diagnosed as Urticaria, the patient was sent home on a 5-day course of Steroid. Three weeks later, the patient returned with worsening symptoms and spreading of the rash to face and scalp. At this visit, a diagnosis of Chronic Papular Urticaria was made, and she was placed on Cimetidine and topical triamcinolone. Her symptoms became more severe in frequency and distribution 2 weeks later.",

  "Physical Examination": "A 'hive-like' skin rash was observed in the lower abdominal, pubic, and medial thigh areas. Later, the rash spread to the face and scalp.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a past medical history of osteoarthritis, right vestibular schwannoma status post stereotactic radiotherapy, vulva Bartholin's gland carcinoma, and hypothyroidism. The patient had no known allergies.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory evaluation was significant for elevated CRP—11.8 mg/L (0.0–8.0 mg/L). A subsequent test showed CRP elevated at 50.4 mg/L. CBC, CMP, and LFT were unremarkable. Urine studies were within normal limits. Serological tests including Complement, dsDNA Antibodies, Antibody to Extractable Nuclear Antigen, ANA, Creatine Kinase, ESR, and Anti-CCP were normal. Chronic urticaria index and anti-TPO antibodies were normal. Pelvic ultrasound showed no evidence of endometrial, myometrial, or adnexal solid or cystic mass."
}"

Associated symptoms included fever, myalgia, and fatigue. The rash did not itch. Symptoms typically occurred every 1–3 weeks and resolved after 2–4 days. Prior to presentation, frequency of symptoms had increased to every 4 days. Myalgia heralded the onset of skin rash and was followed by fever that could be as high as 102 F. The patient denied any recent exposure to allergens or changes to skin care and detergent products. Initially diagnosed as Urticaria, the patient was sent home on a 5-day course of Steroid. Three weeks later, the patient returned with worsening symptoms and spreading of the rash to face and scalp. At this visit, a diagnosis of Chronic Papular Urticaria was made, and she was placed on Cimetidine and topical triamcinolone. Her symptoms became more severe in frequency and distribution 2 weeks later.",

  "Physical Examination": "A 'hive-like' skin rash was observed in the lower abdominal, pubic, and medial thigh areas. Later, the rash spread to the face and scalp.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a past medical history of osteoarthritis, right vestibular schwannoma status post stereotactic radiotherapy, vulva Bartholin's gland carcinoma, and hypothyroidism. The patient had no known allergies.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory evaluation was significant for elevated CRP—11.8 mg/L (0.0–8.0 mg/L). A subsequent test showed CRP elevated at 50.4 mg/L. CBC, CMP, and LFT were unremarkable. Urine studies were within normal limits. Serological tests including Complement, dsDNA Antibodies, Antibody to Extractable Nuclear Antigen, ANA, Creatine Kinase, ESR, and Anti-CCP were normal. Chronic urticaria index and anti-TPO antibodies were normal. Pelvic ultrasound showed no evidence of endometrial, myometrial, or adnexal solid or cystic mass.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Two series of skin biopsy were performed. The first biopsy showed urticarial tissue reaction with focal leukocytoclastic changes and negative direct immunofluorescence. Repeat punch biopsy a week later showed nonspecific findings of perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates with a few scattered eosinophils, mast cells, and neutrophils. Direct immunofluorescence did not reveal evidence for a specific dermatosis. Autoinflammatory Primary Immunodeficiency Gene Panel (CARD14, IL10RA, IL10RB, IL1RN, IL36RN, ISG15, LPIN2, MEFV, MVK, NLRP12, NLRP3 (CIAS1), NOD2 (CARD15), PLCG2, PSMB8, PSTPIP1 (CD2BP1), RBCK1 (HOIL1), SH3BP2, and TNFRSF1A) and Serum protein electrophoresis returned negative. Whole genome sequencing (WGS) revealed the presence of heterozygous mutation in the FLCN gene with pathogenic variant c.779+1G>T. CT chest showed small lung cysts, calcified granulomas and noncalcified pulmonary micronodules. Abdominal MRI showed a 14-mm lesion in the left kidney, which demonstrated mild enhancement, likely representing a hemorrhagic or proteinaceous cyst. There were several additional renal and hepatic cysts with no concerning features."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 26-year-old North African woman",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to the emergency department with a 2-month complaint of multiple tender violaceous lesions on her face, abdomen, and legs that rapidly spread all over her body. Many of the lesions were ulcerated with extensive necrosis, with a maximum diameter of 5 cm. These symptoms were associated with recurrent fever, aggravating asthenia, decreased appetite, and an estimated weight loss of 11 kg over 4 months. She was immediately started on intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics. While awaiting the skin biopsy report, the patient was started on intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics again. The patient was then treated with the CHOP regimen (cyclophosphamide, doxorubicin, vincristine, and prednisone). Forty-eight hours after the first course of chemotherapy, the fever resolved, and improvement in disease markers was noted. The skin lesions began healing. However, a few days after her second course, the patient died at home with no clear explanation of the cause of death.",
  "Physical Examination": "On physical examination, the patient was pale and presented with a fever of 39.1°C. Numerous erythematous, subcutaneous nodules were present on her face, neck, breasts, abdomen, back, and limbs. The nodules were indurated and ulcerated with signs of extensive necrosis. No lesions were noted on mucous membranes or the scalp. The liver and spleen were both palpable without peripheral lymphadenopathy.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no significant past medical history.",
  "Initial Test Results": "A full blood count on admission demonstrated microcytic anemia with hemoglobin at 7.5 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) at 78.6 fL, platelets at 307×10^9/L, white blood cell count revealed neutropenia with an absolute neutrophil count at 880/mm3 and lymphopenia with an absolute lymphocyte count at 140/mm3. C-reactive protein was elevated at 268 mg/L. The serum creatinine was normal. Liver enzymes were within normal limits. Serologic tests were negative for hepatitis A, B and C, HIV, and cytomegalovirus (CMV). Results of an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) serologic test were consistent with previous exposure. Blood cultures were negative. Serologic tests were negative for antinuclear antibodies, anti-native DNA antibodies, and rheumatoid factor. Serum angiotensin-converting enzyme level was normal, and tuberculosis quantiferon PCR was negative. Full body computed tomography scan showed multiple enhancing nodules in the subcutaneous layer at all body sites and hepatosplenomegaly."
}"

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no significant past medical history.",
  "Initial Test Results": "A full blood count on admission demonstrated microcytic anemia with hemoglobin at 7.5 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume (MCV) at 78.6 fL, platelets at 307×10^9/L, white blood cell count revealed neutropenia with an absolute neutrophil count at 880/mm3 and lymphopenia with an absolute lymphocyte count at 140/mm3. C-reactive protein was elevated at 268 mg/L. The serum creatinine was normal. Liver enzymes were within normal limits. Serologic tests were negative for hepatitis A, B and C, HIV, and cytomegalovirus (CMV). Results of an Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) serologic test were consistent with previous exposure. Blood cultures were negative. Serologic tests were negative for antinuclear antibodies, anti-native DNA antibodies, and rheumatoid factor. Serum angiotensin-converting enzyme level was normal, and tuberculosis quantiferon PCR was negative. Full body computed tomography scan showed multiple enhancing nodules in the subcutaneous layer at all body sites and hepatosplenomegaly.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Bone marrow examination showed the presence of hemophagocytosis. Additional laboratory data revealed a high ferritin level of 11,000 ng/mL, elevated triglycerides at 0.013 mmol/L, and low fibrinogen at 1.0 g/L. Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) was elevated at 989 U/L. A punch biopsy specimen from the skin lesion showed atrophic epidermis and lobular necrosis in the dermis and hypodermis associated with an atypical lymphocytic infiltrate. The atypical lymphocytes showed subtle rimming surrounding fat cells. Direct immunofluorescence was negative. Immunohistochemistry analysis showed positive expression for CD3, CD8, and CD5 and negative expression for CD4, CD56, CD20, CD30, and CD10. This confirmed the diagnosis of subcutaneous panniculitis-like T-cell lymphoma. The patient was staged T3bN0M0 subcutaneous panniculitis-like T-cell lymphoma according to the TNM classification system."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 29-year-old man. The case was initially reported in 2020, with follow-up care continuing through 2021 and beyond.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "In 2020, the patient presented with ecchymosis of both lower limbs without obvious explanation. Despite corticosteroid treatment, the patient experienced persistent splenomegaly and increasing thrombocytopenia. In February 2021, the patient reported to the hospital. Approximately 3 weeks after splenectomy, the patient's platelet levels recovered to within the normal range. The patient underwent chemotherapy with an ICE regimen (ifosfamide, etoposide, carboplatin) on 2/23/2021, 3/15/2021, 4/12/2021, and 5/12/2021. After treatment, PET-CT results were negative, and the patient was considered to have achieved complete remission (CR). The patient then underwent allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT) with a FACT conditioning regimen starting on 6/18/2021. Haplotypic hematopoietic stem cells were transfused between 6/29/2021 and 6/30/2021, with an auxiliary cord blood transfusion on 6/28/2021. Leukocyte and platelet engraftment occurred on days +10 and +11, respectively. On day +46, the patient's CMV DNA levels rose to 7.82x103 copies/mL but improved with ganciclovir antiviral treatment. On day +85, the patient developed nausea and vomiting, considered as grade I/II gastrointestinal graft-versus-host response, which improved with glucocorticoid and cyclosporine treatment. On day +443, the patient developed herpes zoster infection, which improved with valaciclovir antiviral therapy. As of day +732 post-transplantation, the patient remains disease-free with good overall health.",

  "Physical Examination": "In February 2021, physical examination revealed that the lower pole of the spleen was located two finger widths above the umbilicus and was palpable below the left costal margin. Significant splenic enlargement was observed during surgery.",

  "Past Medical History": "No specific past medical history was provided in the given information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial test results were not explicitly mentioned in the provided information."
}"

  "Past Medical History": "No specific past medical history was provided in the given information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial test results were not explicitly mentioned in the provided information.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A thorough assessment was performed before splenectomy (details not provided in the given information). Histological examination of the spleen revealed cells of moderate size with oval-shaped nuclei, exhibiting abnormalities in their nuclear structure and small nucleoli. Immunohistochemistry results of the spleen showed: CD2-, CD3+, CD5-, CD7+, CD20- PAX5-, CD79α-, CD23-, TIA-1+, CD56-, granzyme B-, CD4-, CD8-, CD30-, CD138-, ALK-, Ki-67 + 60%. Cells were positive for TCRγ rearrangement. Splenic flow cytometry analysis demonstrated abnormal T cells accounting for ~22.94% of total cells, with the following characteristics: CD7++, CD16++, CD33-, CD13-, CD38-, CD117-, CD19-, CD34-, HLA-DR dim, CD56-, CD5-, CD25-, CD3++, CD99dim, CD2 minimal expression, CD4++, CD8-, TCRαβ-, TCRγδ+, CD335-, CD28dim, CD24, CD57-, CD94+, CD337-, CD158a,h-, CD158f-, CD158e1/e2-, CD158b1/b2j+, CD158i (46.00%). PET-CT scans were performed after chemotherapy and later in the course of treatment, showing a substantially reduced number of lesions compared to prior scans."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 33-year-old female. Her geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient complained of bilateral eye redness with mild discomfort for the past 3 months. She denied blurring of vision, eye discharge, or preceding trauma. She was otherwise well systematically. Eye assessment revealed injected conjunctivae with pinkish nodular lesions on the upper bulbar conjunctivae. The lesions had an ill-defined margin, with peripheral tortuous vessels and were immobile with palpation. Both eyes did not blanch with phenylephrine 2.5% eye drops. Given the protracted symptoms and prolonged history, she was initially treated as nodular anterior scleritis with ibuprofen tablets and prednisolone acetate 1% eye drops. Unfortunately, her symptoms failed to improve despite anti-inflammatory medications. An excisional biopsy of the conjunctival lesions was carried out. In view of the localized disease, she was kept on watchful observation. A surveillance CT scan after 6 months showed no sign of dissemination. The patient continued to be well 2 years after the initial diagnosis.",

  "Physical Examination": "Her visual acuity was 6/9 bilaterally, with no relative afferent pupillary defect. The extraocular muscle movements were normal, with no pain elicited on eye movement. There was no ptosis, and her intraocular pressure was normal. Fundus and systemic examinations were unremarkable.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was described as healthy with no remarkable past medical history mentioned.",

  "Initial Test Results": "B-scan ultrasonography showed normal scleral thickness with no 'T' sign. Laboratory studies included complete blood count, renal profile, liver function tests, serum lactate dehydrogenase, which were all normal."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 63-year-old man presenting from hospital [REDACTED] with a history of urinary urgency and frequency for 6 months.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient complained of urinary urgency, frequency, and urinary interruption for 6 months, with no gross hematuria or other discomfort. An ultrasonography examination revealed a substantial mass located in the bladder and two small stones. After admission, computed tomography (CT) showed a lobulated tumor located in the bladder’s posterior wall with a clear boundary. The size was approximately 3.5 × 2.4 × 2.1 cm. An enhanced CT scan indicated significant enhancement of the tumor. TURBT was performed to remove the tumor and obtain an exact pathological and staging diagnosis. Postoperative pathological results confirmed the tumor cells' characteristics, with immunohistochemical results showing specific markers. No tumor invasion of muscular bladder tissue was found. The postoperative staging was determined as T1N0M0, a high-risk NMIBC. The patient was treated twice with 50 mg of epirubicin for bladder irrigation, once within 24 hours after surgery and the other 1 week after surgery. Due to drug accessibility and economic reasons, the patient refused Bacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) therapy and did not cooperate with other treatments or follow-up planning. Fortunately, the patient had no significant discomfort after 3 years of follow-up, with both cystoscopy and evaluation of exfoliative cytology specimens revealing no tumor recurrence.",
  "Physical Examination": "During TURBT, the tumor was located on the left posterior wall, with around 1.5-cm pedicle, resembling a cauliflower.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient's medical history is not unique and includes no significant ailments. There is no family medical history available.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Ultrasonography examination revealed a substantial mass located in the bladder and two small stones. Computed tomography (CT) showed a lobulated tumor located in the bladder’s posterior wall with a clear boundary, sized approximately 3.5 × 2.4 × 2.1 cm. An enhanced CT scan indicated significant enhancement of the tumor."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 20-year-old male.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient has experienced seizures for the past 6 years. Initially, the patient experienced seizures without any discernible trigger presenting in three primary forms. Seizure type 1 (focal aware autonomic seizures) includes tightness in the chest, palpitations, and flushing of the cheeks without any loss of awareness, lasting for tens of seconds and occurring several times a day. Seizure type 2 (focal impaired awareness behavior arrest seizures) built on type 1 symptoms, adding impaired responsiveness, blank staring, interruption of ongoing activities, dropping objects, loss of awareness, reddening of the eyes, right hand dystonia, and oral automatisms, lasting for dozens of seconds to a minute and occurring 5-6 times a year. Seizure type 3 (focal to bilateral tonic-clonic seizures) built on type 2 symptoms and included head and eye version, tonic and clonic movements of the limbs, foaming at the mouth, loss of awareness, without tongue biting or incontinence, lasting tens of seconds and occurring once a year. The patient has been taking lamotrigine and valproic acid regularly for approximately 5 years, but seizure type 1 and seizure type 2 are still not well controlled. On EEG, interictal period recordings showed slow spike-wave discharges originated from bilateral temporal lobes, and ictal period recordings included focal impaired awareness behavior and focal to bilateral tonic-clonic seizures, with discharges originating from the left temporal-occipital junction and generalizing to the bilateral cerebral hemispheres. SEEG registered discharges mainly from heterotopic nodes in the left occipital lobe, temporal-occipital junctions (both left and right), right superior temporal gyrus, and the middle temporal gyrus posterior during the interictal period. Ictal onset was registered from the left temporal-occipital junction heterotopic nodes. RF-TC was chosen due to the diffuse distribution of heterotopic gray matter nodes in both hemispheres. Post-coagulation SEEG registered a significant reduction in epileptiform discharges during the interictal period. The patient continues taking lamotrigine and valproic acid regularly. Follow-up showed occasional epileptiform discharges in bilateral temporal lobes during the interictal period after 2 months, and only one focal impaired awareness behavior arrest seizure at 11 months follow-up due to stopping medication without permission. "{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 20-year-old male.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient has experienced seizures for the past 6 years. Initially, the patient experienced seizures without any discernible trigger presenting in three primary forms. Seizure type 1 (focal aware autonomic seizures) includes tightness in the chest, palpitations, and flushing of the cheeks without any loss of awareness, lasting for tens of seconds and occurring several times a day. Seizure type 2 (focal impaired awareness behavior arrest seizures) built on type 1 symptoms, adding impaired responsiveness, blank staring, interruption of ongoing activities, dropping objects, loss of awareness, reddening of the eyes, right hand dystonia, and oral automatisms, lasting for dozens of seconds to a minute and occurring 5-6 times a year. Seizure type 3 (focal to bilateral tonic-clonic seizures) built on type 2 symptoms and included head and eye version, tonic and clonic movements of the limbs, foaming at the mouth, loss of awareness, without tongue biting or incontinence, lasting tens of seconds and occurring once a year. The patient has been taking lamotrigine and valproic acid regularly for approximately 5 years, but seizure type 1 and seizure type 2 are still not well controlled. On EEG, interictal period recordings showed slow spike-wave discharges originated from bilateral temporal lobes, and ictal period recordings included focal impaired awareness behavior and focal to bilateral tonic-clonic seizures, with discharges originating from the left temporal-occipital junction and generalizing to the bilateral cerebral hemispheres. SEEG registered discharges mainly from heterotopic nodes in the left occipital lobe, temporal-occipital junctions (both left and right), right superior temporal gyrus, and the middle temporal gyrus posterior during the interictal period. Ictal onset was registered from the left temporal-occipital junction heterotopic nodes. RF-TC was chosen due to the diffuse distribution of heterotopic gray matter nodes in both hemispheres. Post-coagulation SEEG registered a significant reduction in epileptiform discharges during the interictal period. The patient continues taking lamotrigine and valproic acid regularly. Follow-up showed occasional epileptiform discharges in bilateral temporal lobes during the interictal period after 2 months, and only one focal impaired awareness behavior arrest seizure at 11 months follow-up due to stopping medication without permission. Currently, the patient continues ASMs treatment, exhibiting a MoCA score of 28, indicating no cognitive dysfunction and no complaints of headache, dizziness, vision impairments, or visual field deficits.",
  "Physical Examination": "No notable facial features or positive signs were observed during cardiac, pulmonary, abdominal, or neurological examinations. Neurological function assessments revealed a Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score of 29, a Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) score of 25 (indicative of mild cognitive dysfunction), a Hamilton Depression Scale (HAMD) score of 12 (suggestive of possible anxiety), and a Hamilton Anxiety Scale (HAMA) score of 3 (within normal range).",
  "Past Medical History": "There is no reported history of dystocia, febrile convulsions, encephalitis, cranio-cerebral trauma, or family history of epilepsy.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Interictal EEG showed slow spike-wave discharges originating from bilateral temporal lobes. EEG registered three seizures during the ictal period, with epileptiform discharges originating from the left temporal-occipital junction and gradually generalizing to the bilateral cerebral hemispheres. SEEG registered epileptiform discharges mainly originated from heterotopic nodes in the left occipital lobe, temporal-occipital junctions (both left and right), right superior temporal gyrus, and middle temporal gyrus posterior during the interictal period. Ictal onset was registered from the left temporal-occipital junction heterotopic nodes on SEEG.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "MRI showed heterotopic nodules of grey matter in the bilateral temporal and occipital lobes adjacent to posterior horns of the lateral ventricles, and thick bands of heterotopic grey matter extending along the posterior horns of the lateral ventricles. PET/MRI revealed unevenly attenuated glucose metabolism in heterotopic nodules. Whole-exome sequencing identified a heterozygous missense mutation: RELN c.331G>A, amino acid alteration: p.G111R, present in the patient and also found in the asymptomatic mother. The father had a wild-type genotype. Post-coagulation SEEG registered a significant reduction in epileptiform discharges during the interictal period. At the 2 months follow-up, EEG registered occasional epileptiform discharges in bilateral temporal lobes during the interictal period. At the 11 months follow-up, there was only one focal impaired awareness behavior arrest seizure due to stopping medication."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 20-year-old male. He is a non-smoker without history of alcohol or illicit drugs use.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with worsening exertional dyspnoea. He appeared in acute respiratory distress and was not able to tolerate decubitus. He was managed in the intensive care unit (ICU) with diuresis and inotropes (dobutamine) along with mechanical cardiac support using Impella (CP and RP) for cardiogenic shock. He was then slowly weaned off Impella and intravenous inotropes, followed by introduction of guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT). He also received thyroid hormone replacement. He was discharged home with oral medications (metoprolol, spironolactone, digoxin, and furosemide), which were titrated during outpatient follow-up. He was readmitted around 3 months later due to worsening cardiomyopathy. Milrinone infusion was started. He underwent MitraClip NTW placement for severe mitral regurgitation and a single-chamber implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) placement due to persistent low left ventricular ejection fraction despite optimal medical therapy and thyroid function normalization. He was then slowly weaned off milrinone and tolerated GDMT with metoprolol, spironolactone, sacubitril–valsartan, dapagliflozin, and digoxin. Ivabradine was also initiated for better heart rate control. He showed significant clinical improvement and was discharged home with cardiac outpatient rehabilitation. During the subsequent 2 years of follow-up, he has been tolerating GDMT well, has been experiencing improved clinical symptoms (New York Heart Association class II), and has had no further admissions for congestive heart failure.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed hypotension (81/40 mmHg), tachycardia (112 b.p.m.), and hypoxia (85% on room air). Jugular venous pressure was elevated. Auscultation revealed diffuse rales over the lower lung fields bilaterally but no gallops or murmurs. There was no significant peripheral oedema.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was born with microcephaly and later, as a child, developed retinitis pigmentosa and recurrent ear infection. When he turned 11 years old, he was found to be adrenal and thyroid insufficient [autoimmune polyglandular syndrome (APS) type 2] for which he started taking hydrocortisone and levothyroxine. Levothyroxine was slowly tapered down and discontinued when he was 18 years old. He has one younger sister with microcephaly, adrenal insufficiency, and type 1 diabetes mellitus, and two elder unaffected sisters. The parents are both healthy and the medical history of relatives is unremarkable.",

  "Initial Test Results": "On admission, thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) was elevated at 70 mU/L. N-terminal pro-hormone B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) was 5340 pg/mL, and chest X-ray (CXR) showed diffuse pulmonary oedema. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) revealed a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 20% with severe LV dilatation. Repeat TTE revealed improved LVEF of 30%. TTE showed LVEF of 17% with severe mitral valve regurgitation (MR) during readmission. LVEF has improved to 33% per a recent TTE."
}"

Auscultation revealed diffuse rales over the lower lung fields bilaterally but no gallops or murmurs. There was no significant peripheral oedema.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was born with microcephaly and later, as a child, developed retinitis pigmentosa and recurrent ear infection. When he turned 11 years old, he was found to be adrenal and thyroid insufficient [autoimmune polyglandular syndrome (APS) type 2] for which he started taking hydrocortisone and levothyroxine. Levothyroxine was slowly tapered down and discontinued when he was 18 years old. He has one younger sister with microcephaly, adrenal insufficiency, and type 1 diabetes mellitus, and two elder unaffected sisters. The parents are both healthy and the medical history of relatives is unremarkable.",

  "Initial Test Results": "On admission, thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) was elevated at 70 mU/L. N-terminal pro-hormone B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) was 5340 pg/mL, and chest X-ray (CXR) showed diffuse pulmonary oedema. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) revealed a left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) of 20% with severe LV dilatation. Repeat TTE revealed improved LVEF of 30%. TTE showed LVEF of 17% with severe mitral valve regurgitation (MR) during readmission. LVEF has improved to 33% per a recent TTE.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Cardiac catheterization ruled out obstructive coronary artery disease, and cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed non-specific non-ischaemic cardiomyopathy with LVEF of 32% without infiltration or inflammation. Cardiac endomyocardial biopsy showed no histopathological abnormalities (no lymphoid infiltrates, deposits, necrosis, granulomas, or multinucleated giant cells, stains for C3b and C4b negative). The initial cardiomyopathy comprehensive panel (Invitae, San Francisco, CA, USA) was positive for one likely pathogenic variant identified in aminoglycosides (AGL), c294-aA>T (splice receptor), heterozygous. Whole genome sequencing from Baylor Genetics for Undiagnosed Disease Network (UDN) was performed and revealed a compound heterozygous pathogenic variant in RNU4ATAC [NR_023343.1:n.118T>C, autosomal recessive (AR) inheritance, heterozygous, mother is heterozygous and father is negative, pathogenic]. The whole genome sequencing report for his younger sister revealed the same results."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 6-year-old boy of Han ethnicity. He is tall for his age, measuring 127 cm compared to the normal value of 117.4 ± 5.0 cm for 6-year-old Han boys.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient has experienced progressive deterioration of vision bilaterally over the past 2 years. He has had poor vision since early childhood and motor development delays, including holding his head up at 6-7 months old and walking at 1.5 years old. The patient was diagnosed with micropenis in the pediatric outpatient clinic. He presents with craniofacial dysmorphology characterized by ocular hypertelorism, depressed nasal bridge, and epicanthic folds. Sparse hair was observed in the occipital region.",

  "Physical Examination": "Cycloplegic refraction revealed bilateral high myopia and astigmatism (RE: -9.75DS/-3.50DC*177°, LE: -12.50DS/-3.50DC*12°). Best corrected visual acuity (BCVA) was LogMAR 0.4 (Snellen 20/50) in the right eye and LogMAR 0.54 (Snellen 20/70) in the left eye. The anterior segment was unremarkable. Vitreous liquification and tessellated fundus were noted. The optic disc was surrounded by a ring of chorioretinal atrophy. Multiple thin emanating vessels and posterior staphyloma centered with the optic disc were observed. Grade 3 macular hypoplasia was noted, specifically the absence of foveal pit, extrusion of the inner retina layer, and lengthening of the outer segment. Choroidal atrophy and staphyloma were present in both eyes. Subfoveal choroidal thickness was 40 μm in the right eye and 38 μm in the left eye. Optical coherence tomography angiography (OCTA) showed increased vessel density with reduction of the foveal avascular zone. Axial lengths were 28.88 mm (OD) and 29.59 mm (OS).",

  "Past Medical History": "Both parents were emmetropic without any visual or systemic medical disorders. No other family history was noted.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Significant reduced amplitudes were observed on light-adapted electroretinography (ERG) and light-adapted 30 Hz ERG bilaterally."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"Here is the restructured and anonymized medical information in the requested JSON format:

{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 2-month-old girl from Saudi Arabia. She was born at 37 weeks of gestation by elective cesarean section. Her weight was 3.6 kg, which was below the 5th percentile according to WHO Child Growth Standards.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted for urgent ventriculoperitoneal shunt insertion. Prenatal maternal ultrasound showed Chiari II malformation with cerebral atrophy. Immediately after delivery, the patient was admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) due to hydrocephalus and episodic apnea, which required gastric tube insertion for feeding.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed dysmorphic features including severe macrocephaly, low nasal bridge, frontal bulging, micrognathia, receding mandible, moderate hypotonia, exophthalmos with hazy cornea on the left eye, and sluggish pupillary reflexes to light. Preoperative vital signs were within normal ranges (heart rate: 137 bpm; blood pressure: 89/52 mm Hg; respiratory rate: 20 bpm; oxygen saturation at room air: 95%; temperature: 36.9°C). Cardiorespiratory examination revealed normal heart and lung sounds on auscultation.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's parents were relatives and consanguineous. The patient had four siblings in total. The first sibling died at the age of 14 months and required ventriculoperitoneal shunt insertion at the age of 2 months. The second sibling was immediately admitted to the NICU upon delivery and died after 1 month. The third sibling required ventriculoperitoneal shunt insertion at the age of 2 months but died due to cardiac arrest during the induction of anesthesia. The fourth sibling was a healthy 16-year-old boy. Genetic tests conducted during pregnancy were negative for trisomy 13, 18, and 21.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory investigations showed no abnormalities in hemoglobin, serum electrolytes, blood glucose, and creatinine kinase levels. The renal function tests were normal."
}"

Cases.Final Name: Microcephalic osteodysplastic primordial dwarfism type II
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male child who was 3 years and 7 months old at the time of first evaluation. He was born in Moldova and later moved to Italy. The patient's ethnicity is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The child was referred to a pediatric endocrinology outpatient clinic due to severe short stature and absence of catch-up growth since birth. At 3 years and 7 months, his length was 62.4 cm (-9.53 SDS by WHO references), weight was 5.15 kg (-9.36 SDS by WHO references), and he had microcephaly (43 cm, -4.8 SDS by WHO references). He presented with intellectual disability and distinctive craniofacial features including a high forehead with ocular proptosis, a prominent beaked nose, micrognathia, and a relatively proportioned small mouth with multiple dental caries. He had brachymesophalangy, arthrogryposis of the hands, and equinus right foot. The patient had a micropenis, hypotrophic-like right testis, and non-palpable left testis. Ultrasound confirmed clinical cryptorchidism with the left testis intra-abdominal and the right testis within the inguinal canal. He exhibited generalized hypotonia and resistance to dorsiflexion of the right lower limb due to tendon retraction. Brisk and asymmetrical patellar osteotendinous reflexes were observed. The patient would eat only smooth foods and exhibited slow and difficult chewing. After dental eruption, fragmentation of the teeth was observed.",

  "Physical Examination": "The child had a high forehead with ocular proptosis, a prominent beaked nose, micrognathia, a relatively proportioned small mouth with multiple dental caries, brachymesophalangy, arthrogryposis of the hands, and equinus right foot. He had a micropenis, hypotrophic-like right testis, and non-palpable left testis. He presented with generalized hypotonia and resistance to dorsiflexion of the right lower limb due to tendon retraction. Brisk and asymmetrical patellar osteotendinous reflexes were observed.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's pregnancy was characterized by severe intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR). He was born around 28 weeks of gestational age with a birth weight of 890 g. He was admitted for congenital CMV infection at birth. The patient was breastfed during the first weeks of age and subsequently received formula milk. He was admitted to hospital again at 18 months of age for pneumonia. The patient's karyotype was 46,XY.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) was 267.1 ng/mL (normal range: 56.2-267.1 ng/mL), and its binding protein 3 (IGFBP3) was 3941 ng/mL (normal range: 1995-4904 ng/dL). Renal function and glucose metabolism were normal. Liver function tests initially showed elevation of transaminases, with negative infectious and immunologic liver tests, which progressively improved until normalization at 6 years of age. Abdominal ultrasound at 3 years of age showed normal echostructure and size of both kidneys. At 6 years of age, bilateral increased echogenicity was present, with poor corticomedullary differentiation and hyperechoic thickening of the adipose tissue of the bilateral perirenal space."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 15-year-old boy from a tertiary care center. He is male.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with shortness of breath for 12 hours, a headache for 3 hours, and one episode of abnormal body movements with loss of consciousness 1 hour prior to arrival. According to his mother, the shortness of breath was gradual in onset and associated with chest retraction. The generalized headache was followed by abnormal body movements for 5 minutes, eye rolling, body stiffening, teeth clenching, frothy discharge from the mouth, and loss of consciousness. Following intravenous medications at a nearby hospital, symptoms disappeared, and the patient was referred for specialized respiratory care. There was no history of projectile vomiting, fever, neck stiffness, loose stools, burning micturition, frequency, or pain abdomen. The patient had a history of obstructive hydrocephalus with recurrent abnormal body movements and respiratory problems since 3 years of age. He underwent herniotomy for a right congenital inguinal hernia at 18 months of age. Delivered via normal vaginal delivery at a local hospital, he weighed 2.5 kg at birth, cried immediately after birth, and had a smooth perinatal transition. Developmental milestones were achieved normally until 3 years of age when symptoms began, starting with hydrocephalus and seizures. He attended school up to 5th grade with poor scholastic performance and left school due to diminished vision and recurrent abnormal body movements. He received adequate nutrition and there was no known consanguinity in family history.",
  "Physical Examination": "Examination revealed dolichocephaly with marked macrocephaly, short neck, corneal clouding, and stiffness of joints. Coarse facial characteristics included a large and depressed nasal bridge, flared nostrils, ocular hypertelorism, dental malocclusion, interdental spacing, thick eyelids, and big, thick lips. The child was below -3 SD for height for age, blood pressure was 100/60 mmHg, heart rate was 148 BPM, respiratory rate was 38 breaths per minute, and temperature was 98.2°F. Respiratory examination revealed bilateral equal air entry with left infra-axillary and infra-scapular crepitations. The abdomen was soft and non-tender with an umbilical stump, and the liver was palpable 3 cm below the costal margin with a liver span of 10 cm.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had obstructive hydrocephalus with recurrent abnormal body movements and respiratory problems starting at 3 years of age. He underwent herniotomy for a right congenital inguinal hernia at 18 months old. There is no known consanguinity in the family history.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Complete blood count was normal with normocytic normochromic red blood cells. Liver function tests and renal function tests were normal. Echocardiography screening revealed moderate mitral stenosis, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation, and moderate tricuspid regurgitation."
}"

Following intravenous medications at a nearby hospital, symptoms disappeared, and the patient was referred for specialized respiratory care. There was no history of projectile vomiting, fever, neck stiffness, loose stools, burning micturition, frequency, or pain abdomen. The patient had a history of obstructive hydrocephalus with recurrent abnormal body movements and respiratory problems since 3 years of age. He underwent herniotomy for a right congenital inguinal hernia at 18 months of age. Delivered via normal vaginal delivery at a local hospital, he weighed 2.5 kg at birth, cried immediately after birth, and had a smooth perinatal transition. Developmental milestones were achieved normally until 3 years of age when symptoms began, starting with hydrocephalus and seizures. He attended school up to 5th grade with poor scholastic performance and left school due to diminished vision and recurrent abnormal body movements. He received adequate nutrition and there was no known consanguinity in family history.",
  "Physical Examination": "Examination revealed dolichocephaly with marked macrocephaly, short neck, corneal clouding, and stiffness of joints. Coarse facial characteristics included a large and depressed nasal bridge, flared nostrils, ocular hypertelorism, dental malocclusion, interdental spacing, thick eyelids, and big, thick lips. The child was below -3 SD for height for age, blood pressure was 100/60 mmHg, heart rate was 148 BPM, respiratory rate was 38 breaths per minute, and temperature was 98.2°F. Respiratory examination revealed bilateral equal air entry with left infra-axillary and infra-scapular crepitations. The abdomen was soft and non-tender with an umbilical stump, and the liver was palpable 3 cm below the costal margin with a liver span of 10 cm.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had obstructive hydrocephalus with recurrent abnormal body movements and respiratory problems starting at 3 years of age. He underwent herniotomy for a right congenital inguinal hernia at 18 months old. There is no known consanguinity in the family history.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Complete blood count was normal with normocytic normochromic red blood cells. Liver function tests and renal function tests were normal. Echocardiography screening revealed moderate mitral stenosis, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation, and moderate tricuspid regurgitation.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "The lateral view of the skull radiograph revealed an inverted j-shaped sella turcica. Hand and wrist radiographs showed bullet-shaped phalanges with the proximal pointing of all metacarpals. The lateral view of the spine radiograph showed anterior bending of thoracolumbar vertebrae. X-ray AP view of both hips showed acetabular dysplasia. The patient was admitted to the PICU with respiratory support using CPAP with PEEP of 8 cm of water, which was removed after 43 hours. The patient maintained saturation in room air but experienced occasional obstructive sleep apnea and decreased SPO2 to 86–88% during sleep. Sodium Valproate was used for seizure disorder treatment. Neurosurgery consultation was done for hydrocephalus, but further management was refused by the patient's family. Urine examination for increased amounts of heparan sulfate and dermatan sulfate and blood tests for alpha-L iduronidase enzyme activity to confirm Hurler syndrome could not be done due to unavailability of testing facilities. On follow-up, the child is on intermittent oxygen support for respiratory difficulties and continues to take Valproate for seizure disorder, remaining seizure-free at the time of follow-up."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 26-year-old Chinese woman, gravida 2, para 0, from an unspecified geographic location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred for further evaluation due to thickened nuchal translucency (NT) and indistinct fetal nasal bones on the initial ultrasound. During the current pregnancy, there were no maternal complications. The patient had experienced spontaneous abortion during the first pregnancy at 45 days. Initial ultrasound at 13 weeks 2 days gestation showed appropriate biometric measurements with thickened NT of 3.4 mm and absence of nasal bones. Poor ossifications in the cranium and vertebrae were also observed. A follow-up ultrasound at 21 weeks 4 days estimated the gestation at 20 weeks 4 days. The nasal bones were still unidentifiable, ossification of the cranium had slightly improved with mild hypo-mineralization, and vertebrae remained poorly ossified. Both femur and humerus lengths were below the tenth percentile, and bowing of the tibia and fibula was observed. Fetal echocardiography showed negative findings. Abnormal sonographic findings prompted further genetic testing, which confirmed a frame shift deletion in RUNX2 on chromosome 6p21. Parents consulted with the obstetrician and requested pregnancy termination. They returned to their local area for the procedure and denied postpartum autopsy and imaging studies. Despite the low risk of recurrence due to the de novo mutation, prenatal counseling was recommended for future pregnancies, and the parents concurred.",
  "Physical Examination": "The physical examination of the parents was normal with normal shoulder mobility. Previous X-rays showed no skeletal abnormalities. There were no abnormalities in the development of the teeth or in the time of closure of the fontanel.",
  "Past Medical History": "No pertinent family history in both parents and other family members. Patient had a previous spontaneous abortion at 45 days of gestation.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Initial ultrasound at 13 weeks 2 days showed thickened NT of 3.4 mm, absence of nasal bones, and poor ossifications in the cranium and vertebrae."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 37-year-old Indian male.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient reported to the department of Conservative Dentistry and Endodontics with a chief complaint of throbbing pain in the lower left back tooth region for 5 days. The patient experienced night pain that did not subside even after taking analgesics. The patient had a history of an odontogenic keratocystic (OKC) lesion in the anterior mandible that was managed by surgical intervention and followed by rehabilitation with a removable prosthesis for aesthetic purposes. Extra-oral examination disclosed normal mouth opening and no temporomandibular joint problems. The patient was healthy with no comorbidities.",

  "Physical Examination": "Intraoral examination revealed a class II composite restoration present with respect to tooth 36. The tooth was tender on percussion. Teeth 35 and 36 exhibited grade II mobility. Pulp sensibility testing gave an exaggerated lingering response. Occlusion was assessed after obtaining diagnostic casts. The mobility of tooth 36 was reduced following endodontic therapy.",

  "Past Medical History": "Family history and medical history were non-contributory.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Radiographic examination revealed a well-defined radio opacity involving enamel, dentin, and pulp with periapical radiolucency, suggestive of deep restoration. Radiographic examination included full mouth orthopantomogram (OPG) and intraoral periapical radiograph (IOPA) of tooth 36. A panoramic radiograph (OPG) was taken after surgical intervention depicted resected OKC in the anterior mandible reconstituted with reconstruction plates."
}"
