Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A male infant of Han ethnicity, G1P1, the first of monozygotic twins, with a gestational age of 36+2 weeks and birth weight of 2,120 g, was delivered by cesarean section in another hospital. The twins were conceived naturally, with prenatal use of magnesium sulfate and a full course of steroids. The infant was preterm and small for gestational age. His parents are healthy, not consanguineous, and denied any history of genetic disease.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "Herpes was found scattered all over the body after birth, and the infant was then transferred with herpes of unknown cause and preterm small for gestational age. The infant continued to have recurrent herpes, which worsened and fused into patches, followed by warty crusting and hyperpigmentation. On day 30, the infant presented a marked decrease in milk intake, poor response, and apnea.",
  "Physical Examination": "A physical examination showed stable vital signs and good mental response. Scattered yellow pustules the size of corn to green beans were seen on the extremities, trunk, axillae, and groin, with cloudy fluid and semilunar accumulation of pus, thin loose walls, and partial rupture with superficial erosion and a yellowish scab on top. No abnormal findings were found during other systemic physical examinations.",
  "Past Medical History": "The twins were naturally conceived, and the prenatal use of magnesium sulfate and a full course of steroids was administered. His parents denied any history of genetic disease and are healthy.",
  "Initial Test Results": "After admission, complete blood count, C-reactive protein, and procalcitonin were normal; eosinophils were 4.2%, and viral spectrum screen and blood antinuclear antibody were negative. Herpes fluid culture was negative and repeated markers of infection were normal on day 3. Blood eosinophils increased to 16.6% and were consistently elevated, up to 42.4% on day 26. There were no abnormal findings on multiple cranial ultrasound examinations."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A male infant of Han ethnicity, G1P1, the first of monozygotic twins, with a gestational age of 36+2 weeks and birth weight of 2,120 g, was delivered by cesarean section in another hospital. The twins were conceived naturally, with prenatal use of magnesium sulfate and a full course of steroids. The infant was preterm and small for gestational age. His parents are healthy, not consanguineous, and denied any history of genetic disease.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "Herpes was found scattered all over the body after birth, and the infant was then transferred with herpes of unknown cause and preterm small for gestational age. The infant continued to have recurrent herpes, which worsened and fused into patches, followed by warty crusting and hyperpigmentation. On day 30, the infant presented a marked decrease in milk intake, poor response, and apnea.",
  "Physical Examination": "A physical examination showed stable vital signs and good mental response. Scattered yellow pustules the size of corn to green beans were seen on the extremities, trunk, axillae, and groin, with cloudy fluid and semilunar accumulation of pus, thin loose walls, and partial rupture with superficial erosion and a yellowish scab on top. No abnormal findings were found during other systemic physical examinations.",
  "Past Medical History": "The twins were naturally conceived, and the prenatal use of magnesium sulfate and a full course of steroids was administered. His parents denied any history of genetic disease and are healthy.",
  "Initial Test Results": "After admission, complete blood count, C-reactive protein, and procalcitonin were normal; eosinophils were 4.2%, and viral spectrum screen and blood antinuclear antibody were negative. Herpes fluid culture was negative and repeated markers of infection were normal on day 3. Blood eosinophils increased to 16.6% and were consistently elevated, up to 42.4% on day 26. There were no abnormal findings on multiple cranial ultrasound examinations.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A skin biopsy of the thigh taken on day 6 reported eosinophilic spongiform edema of the lesioned skin, eosinophilic microabscesses in the focal epidermis, liquefaction of the basal layer, and eosinophilic infiltration in the superficial dermis after 10 days. Routine brain MRI on day 21 revealed diffuse multiple cystic and lamellar abnormal signal areas in the left frontal and parietal lobes, with a low signal in T1-weighted imaging and a high signal in T2-weighted imaging, with speckled diffusion restriction within the lesion, and no abnormalities in the sacrococcygeal MRI scan. An urgent cranial CT scan found diffuse hypodensity in the left cerebral hemisphere and bilateral cerebellum, with a large patchy hypodense area in the left frontoparietal lobe with a CT value of 10–15 HU and multiple speckled hyperintensities within it, as well as a widened left ventricle and additional patchy hyperintensities in the left cerebellar hemisphere. Chromosomal copy number variation (CNV-Seq plus) and cytological karyotype detection found approximately 18.29 Mb mosaicism repeats in the Yp11.31q11.222 region (16%), approximately 7.83 Mb mosaicism deletions in the Yq11.222q11.23 region (17%), approximately 317.54 kb repeats in the Yp11.2p11.2 region (copy number: 2) and 3p26.3p26.3 region with approximately 440.50 kb duplication (copy number 3). Karyotype analysis showed a normal parental karyotype and the brother was 46,X,del (Y) (q11.23) [7]/46,XY [93] with a mosaicism rate of 7%. Whole exome sequencing (WES) found no pathogenic minor variants in the IKBKG gene, and multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) testing found no large deletion repeat variants in large segments of the IKBKG gene; multiplex PCR amplification testing did not find deletion variants in exons 4–10 of the IKBKG gene."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 12-year-old Ugandan female. She was referred from a peripheral health center.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a 2-year history of on-and-off spontaneous progressively worsening epistaxis, associated with an 8-month history of progressive abdominal distension and mild pain. The bleeding was preceded by a sharp frontal throbbing headache. Two weeks prior to admission, epistaxis worsened with up to 4 episodes per day, along with an increase in abdominal distension and pain. During this period, she developed on-and-off low-grade fevers, associated with severe headaches, palpitations, dizziness, and general malaise. She had three admissions in the previous year, managed for malaria without blood transfusion. After diagnosis and initial treatment, the patient was discharged on tranexamic acid as needed, fansidar two tablets monthly, and monthly reviews. Six months later, due to worsening hematological parameters, a splenectomy was performed. The spleen weighed 695g and was firm solid with no infarcts or discrete nodules. Five weeks post-operatively, she developed severe bone pains in the pelvis and thighs with inability to walk and stand, as well as episodic fevers. Her pain was managed with morphine and physiotherapy. She currently attends monthly reviews at the pediatric oncology clinic and physiotherapy, and has returned to school.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient exhibited moderate anemia, mild jaundice, and nontender mild submandibular lymphadenopathy. She was pyrexic with an axillary temperature of 38.4°C, and tachycardic at 120 beats per minute. Other vitals were unremarkable. The abdomen was non-tender and moderately distended, with massive hepatosplenomegaly (spleen 8cm below the coastal margin and liver 12 cm below the coastal margin). Other organ systems were unremarkable.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient is the last born of 6 children and had no family history of a similar condition. She had three admissions in the previous year, managed for malaria without blood transfusion.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Complete blood count revealed pancytopenia with hemoglobin of 5.9g/dl, white cell count of 2100/µL, and platelets of 76,000/µL. Peripheral blood smear showed ring forms of plasmodium falciparum and marked thrombocytopenia. Abdominal ultrasonography noted gross hepatosplenomegaly and scanty mesenteric lymphadenopathy. Two weeks post-splenectomy, blood tests showed leukocytes at 14,400/µL, platelets at 666,000/µL, and hemoglobin at 10.0g/dl. Five weeks post-operatively, tests showed leukocytosis (18,700/µL), normal hemoglobin (11.4g/dl), and thrombocytopenia (28,000/µL)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 63-year-old female with a left-sided peripheral eye tumor.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented for a complete ophthalmologic examination. She underwent gamma ray surgery (GRS) on January 17th, 2024 as an outpatient procedure. The procedure involved retrobulbar anesthesia for akinesia of the globe within the orbit. The patient was positioned on a CT scanner couch, and a three-point thermoplastic mask was molded to establish a reproducible head position and patient immobilization. Treatment was delivered in a single session using a ZAP-X system. The overall duration of the workflow from retrobulbar anesthesia until completion of the treatment was 122 minutes. Seven days after radiosurgery, the patient did not experience any treatment-related side effects.",

  "Physical Examination": "The best-corrected visual acuity was 0.8 for both eyes. Ultrasound examination revealed a left-sided peripheral tumor with base dimensions of 11.8 mm by 11.3 mm and a height of 4.3 mm. The volume of the visible tumor was 0.53 cm³ in CT and MR imaging. Akinesia of the globe persisted until the end of the treatment. After completion of the treatment, the mobility of the globe was assessed by ophthalmologic examination.",

  "Past Medical History": "No specific past medical history was provided in the given information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient received a complete ophthalmologic examination with an assessment of visual acuity, indirect ophthalmoscopy, and standardized A-/B-scan ultrasound. The best-corrected visual acuity was 0.8 for both eyes. Ultrasound examination revealed a left-sided peripheral tumor with base dimensions of 11.8 mm by 11.3 mm and a height of 4.3 mm."
}"

Treatment was delivered in a single session using a ZAP-X system. The overall duration of the workflow from retrobulbar anesthesia until completion of the treatment was 122 minutes. Seven days after radiosurgery, the patient did not experience any treatment-related side effects.",

  "Physical Examination": "The best-corrected visual acuity was 0.8 for both eyes. Ultrasound examination revealed a left-sided peripheral tumor with base dimensions of 11.8 mm by 11.3 mm and a height of 4.3 mm. The volume of the visible tumor was 0.53 cm³ in CT and MR imaging. Akinesia of the globe persisted until the end of the treatment. After completion of the treatment, the mobility of the globe was assessed by ophthalmologic examination.",

  "Past Medical History": "No specific past medical history was provided in the given information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient received a complete ophthalmologic examination with an assessment of visual acuity, indirect ophthalmoscopy, and standardized A-/B-scan ultrasound. The best-corrected visual acuity was 0.8 for both eyes. Ultrasound examination revealed a left-sided peripheral tumor with base dimensions of 11.8 mm by 11.3 mm and a height of 4.3 mm.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Magnetic resonance images (MRI, 3T Magnetom Vida, Siemens, Germany, T2, and gadolinium-contrast enhanced T1) of the orbit were acquired with 1.0- and 1.1-mm axial slices. A planning CT scan of the patient was acquired with 1.0 mm axial slices. CT and MRI scans were overlaid for contouring of the target and organs at risk. The volume of the visible tumor was 0.53 cm³ in CT and MR imaging, which resulted in a planning target volume (PTV) of 0.97 cm³. A GRS treatment planning system was utilized to place isocenter coordinates inside the PTV. A total of 459 non-coplanar candidate beams of different diameters were targeted at the isocenter coordinates. The final plan used six isocenters (three with the 10 mm and three with the 7.5 mm apertures) and 140 beams to cover 99.2% of the PTV with 21 Gy at the 54% isodose line."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male with a diagnosis of septo-optic dysplasia (SOD). He was initially evaluated by psychiatry at age six and later underwent psychological testing at age 12.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was initially evaluated for behavioral concerns at age six. These concerns included issues with attention, focus, concentration, inability to stay on task, impulsivity, intrusiveness, oppositional behavior, defiance, argumentativeness, and easy frustration. He was diagnosed with a condition (XXX) and started on methylphenidate hydrochloride extended-release. His grandmother reported that the medication helped somewhat in school but caused agitation and aggression, especially in the evenings. The patient's care was transferred to the psychiatry clinic associated with his ophthalmology care. At age six, the patient's medication was changed from methylphenidate hydrochloride extended-release to lisdexamfetamine, resulting in significant improvement in behaviors without side effects. The patient also continued behavioral therapy. For several years, the patient did well on his medication. However, escalating behavior issues and a change in guardianship from grandmother to mother led to psychological testing being administered at age 12 to clarify the diagnostic picture. This testing confirmed the diagnosis of the condition (XXX) with some depressive symptoms and ruled out Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD).",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient was diagnosed with optic nerve hypoplasia (ONH) around six to eight months of age. He was referred for an ophthalmology evaluation at that time due to wandering eye movements and poor focus. An initial evaluation done at two years of age in the ophthalmology clinic verified his diagnosis of SOD. Examination details are referenced in Tables 1-3 in the original text, but specific details are not provided.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was diagnosed with SOD. A brain MRI at 14 months of age revealed marked hypoplasia of the optic nerves bilaterally and the absence of septum pellucidum. He was referred to an endocrine clinic and seen at 20 months, with no sign of pituitary dysfunction, although labs showed slight insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) elevation. Over the next couple of years, the patient's growth continued to be on track with a normal growth velocity. The patient had no other major medical health issues except for mild asthma. The prenatal course had no substance abuse but was complicated by gonorrhea in the second trimester, which was treated with antibiotics. The patient was born at 38 weeks gestation with a birth weight of five pounds, 13 ounces. No problems were noted at birth, and there were no developmental concerns. Family history was positive for depression and substance abuse.",

  "Initial Test Results": "At 20 months, endocrine labs showed slight insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) elevation. The patient's XXX diagnosis was confirmed with a history, an exam, and the ASEBA (specific results not provided). At age 12, the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children® Fifth Edition (WISC®-V) performance placed him in the average range of intelligence, with a high degree of scatter among his scores and a particular weakness in processing speed. The Woodcock-Johnson IV Tests of Cognitive Abilities showed short-term working memory in the average range, long-term working memory in the low average range, auditory processing in the average range, and cognitive efficiency in the low range. The Woodcock-Johnson IV Tests of Achievements showed no sign of a specific learning disability."
}"

At age 12, psychological testing was administered, including the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children® Fifth Edition (WISC®-V), the Woodcock-Johnson IV Tests of Cognitive Abilities, the Woodcock-Johnson IV Tests of Achievements, the BRIEF-2 Score, and ADOS-2. The BRIEF-2 Score showed clinically significant concerns in all subscales except organization of materials, which indicated at-risk concerns. The ADOS-2 classified the patient as not being on the autism spectrum."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male neonate weighing 3350g, born at 39+3 weeks of gestation via cesarean section due to cephalopelvic disproportion and abnormal fetal heart rate monitoring. He is the first child of non-consanguineous parents. The mother is 26 years old, G1P1, and was diagnosed as a hepatitis B carrier one year before pregnancy.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The neonate was transferred to the NICU 32 minutes after birth due to dyspnea. Ten minutes after birth, he became cyanotic, apathetic, and had mild grunting. On admission to the NICU, he remained apathetic and required gastric tube mix feeding and intermittent oral suction due to inability to clear airway secretions. Nasal continuous positive airway pressure (nCPAP) ventilation was performed immediately. The sucking, swallowing, moro and grasp reflexes were decreased or absent. On day 7 to 9, high dose intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIG, 2.2g/kg total) and oral pyridostigmine were administered. The infant was successfully weaned from the ventilator with spontaneous movements enhancement. He started bottle feeding at 17 days of age. He was discharged home on day 26 with disappearance of clinical symptoms. On follow-up one month later, he had no neurologic abnormalities with muscular tension similar to a normal baby. The neonate continued oral pyridostigmine for 1.5 months after discharge. At 3 months old, the boy had normal gross motor function development except for a little poor head erection.",

  "Physical Examination": "On admission to the NICU, the vital signs were as follows: temperature 36.5°C, pulse 150 beats/min, blood pressure 68/48 mmHg, respiratory rate 65 breaths/min and arterial oxygenation 80%. The sucking, swallowing, moro and grasp reflexes were decreased or absent.",

  "Past Medical History": "The neonate's 50-year-old maternal grandmother had a 10-year history of ocular myasthenia gravis (OMG). The mother was diagnosed with hepatitis B carrier one year before and was asymptomatic without treatment during pregnancy. The pregnancy was well-followed, and the mother felt normal fetal movements.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Blood gases revealed respiratory acidosis. Creatine kinase was elevated (682U/L, normal<170U/L). No abnormalities were found in blood glucose; liver, kidney, and thyroid function; muscle enzymes (except CK); arterial blood gas; infection and coagulation parameters; ammonia in blood and urine; TORCH in blood; chest x-ray, video electroencephalogram, cerebral ultrasound and cerebral computer tomography (CT). Apgar scores were 8 and 8 at one and five minutes, respectively."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a female diagnosed with XXX at 1 year old. She lived with her family and passed away at the age of 8 years due to multiorgan failure.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient faced multiple challenges including profound bilateral sensorineural hearing loss (HL), congenital bilateral cataracts, developmental delay, and gastro-esophageal reflux. Her hearing loss was detected early, as she failed the newborn screening test. She received binaural hearing aids at 4 weeks old, but her benefit from them was limited. By age 4, she could communicate with simple vocalizations but struggled with behavioral audiometry due to cognitive issues. At age 5, she underwent a left cochlear implantation with a Cochlear CI512 device. Post-implantation, her family noticed positive changes as she responded to sounds, turned toward speech, and showed increased alertness and activity at school. Despite limitations in her ability to link sounds with visual rewards, she showed improved response to auditory stimuli, direction awareness, and appreciation for music with the implant.",

  "Physical Examination": "Intraoperatively, her left cochlea was found to be grossly abnormal (rotated).",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was diagnosed with XXX at 1 year old. She had profound bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, congenital bilateral cataracts, developmental delay, and gastro-esophageal reflux.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient failed the newborn hearing screening test. ABR testing revealed profound hearing loss. Follow-up assessments using visual reinforcement audiometry showed no discomfort, and the implant functioned correctly according to neutral response telemetry."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 9-year-old boy.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the outpatient clinic with a congenital deformity of the lower lip. He had a history of recurrent inflammation on his lower lip. With gentle compression, a saliva-like mucous secretion was excreted through the orifices of the lower lip. Based on these pathognomonic features, Van der Woude syndrome (VWS) was diagnosed. The patient underwent surgery under general anesthesia. Gentian violet dye was injected into the sinus fistula to trace and remove the entire tract. Meticulous dissection was performed to remove the entire lining of the tract while preserving surrounding tissues, including the mucosa and orbicularis oris muscle. The wound was closed in a direction parallel to the vermilion border. At a 6-month follow-up, the patient had no complications, including mucocele formation or recurrence of inflammation.",

  "Physical Examination": "Bilateral pits were observed in the vermilion of the lower lip. Intraoperative findings revealed that the depth of the pits was 28 mm on the right side and 13 mm on the left side.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no specific medical history and no family history of other craniofacial deformities.",

  "Initial Test Results": ""
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "Early adolescent girl, born at term to non-consanguineous healthy parents. She has three healthy older siblings. No family history of congenital or neurological diseases.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "Multiple episodes of vomiting on the first day of life with delayed passage of meconium. Focal areas of skin hypopigmentation were noted over bilateral lower limbs, dorsum of bilateral hands sparing the palms, and over the anterior neck during late neonatal period. The hypopigmented patches were punctuated with islands of pigmented macules. The distribution pattern was non-specific and did not follow the Blaschko lines. No white forelocks. Bilateral horizontal nystagmus with involuntary tremors of all limbs and the head were noted during early infancy. Cerebellar signs progressively worsened with age, associated with significant global developmental delay. Poor truncal tone causing difficulty to sit unsupported and ambulate. Speech was markedly impaired with no spoken words. First episode of seizure occurred in late childhood, which was generalised with tonic and clonic movement of all limbs, lasting for 3 minutes and self-aborted with brief postictal drowsiness. No clinical features of meningitis and was afebrile during the presentation.",

  "Physical Examination": "Severely underweight with a weight of 18.5 kg (<3rd percentile), height 135 cm (<3rd percentile) and body mass index (BMI) 10.2 kg/m2 (<3rd percentile). Neurological examination showed ataxia and hypotonic posture with severe atrophy of all four limbs. Upper limbs demonstrated a Medical Research Council muscle strength grading of 3, lower limbs graded 2. Deep tendon reflexes were absent, with contracture of bilateral ankles. Babinski reflexes were down-going, and no ankle clonus was elicited. Lack of withdrawal response to pain stimulus, suggesting reduced sensation, particularly over the lower limbs. Limited cranial nerves assessment revealed bilateral horizontal nystagmus with intact vision. Abdomen was scaphoid with no palpable mass or hepatosplenomegaly. Respiratory and cardiovascular examination were unremarkable.",

  "Past Medical History": "Born after an uneventful pregnancy and had a normal Apgar score. Diagnosed with Hirschsprung disease in neonatal period. Had a transanal pull-through surgery at 3 months of age. Diagnosed with vitiligo by a dermatologist in neonatal period. Partial albinism diagnosed in early infancy. Bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss diagnosed as a toddler.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Abdominal radiograph showed dilated bowels with absent distal bowel gas. Rectal biopsy showed the absence of ganglion cells in the submucosal plexus. CT scan of the brain showed no structural abnormalities. Ophthalmology assessment revealed bilateral blue irides, and funduscopy showed choroidal hypopigmentation. Auditory brainstem response showed bilateral profound sensorineural hearing loss. Electroencephalogram was reported as normal."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The proband is a 28-year-old male patient from Beijing, China. He has a family history of early-onset hypertension, with affected family members including his father, two paternal aunts, and a deceased paternal uncle. Seven biological relatives (five females and two males) with a median age of 42 years (interquartile range 35, 60 years) were also enrolled in the study.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted with severe hypertension to the Department of Hypertension in 2021. His hypertension had been incidentally diagnosed during a medical examination at the age of 16 years. Detailed screening tests were performed to identify the etiology of hypertension. The fundus lesions of hypertension were evaluated by mydriasis followed by fundoscopy.",

  "Physical Examination": "A physical examination was performed as part of the detailed screening tests. No specific findings from the physical examination were mentioned in the provided information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had been diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 16 years during a medical examination. There is a family history of early-onset hypertension affecting multiple family members across two generations.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Biochemical assessments were performed, including plasma serum, aldosterone, renin, and urinary microalbumin concentration measurements. Hormone measurements were also conducted, including growth hormone, cortisol, and adrenocorticotropic hormone concentration measurements. Echocardiography and computed tomography of the aortic and renal arteries were performed. The seven enrolled family members underwent blood pressure measurement and biochemical testing, including plasma serum, aldosterone, and renin concentration measurements. However, specific numerical values for these tests were not provided in the given information."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The proband is a 28-year-old male patient from Beijing, China. He has a family history of early-onset hypertension, with affected family members including his father, two paternal aunts, and a deceased paternal uncle. Seven biological relatives (five females and two males) with a median age of 42 years (interquartile range 35, 60 years) were also enrolled in the study.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted with severe hypertension to the Department of Hypertension in 2021. His hypertension had been incidentally diagnosed during a medical examination at the age of 16 years. Detailed screening tests were performed to identify the etiology of hypertension. The fundus lesions of hypertension were evaluated by mydriasis followed by fundoscopy.",

  "Physical Examination": "A physical examination was performed as part of the detailed screening tests. No specific findings from the physical examination were mentioned in the provided information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had been diagnosed with hypertension at the age of 16 years during a medical examination. There is a family history of early-onset hypertension affecting multiple family members across two generations.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Biochemical assessments were performed, including plasma serum, aldosterone, renin, and urinary microalbumin concentration measurements. Hormone measurements were also conducted, including growth hormone, cortisol, and adrenocorticotropic hormone concentration measurements. Echocardiography and computed tomography of the aortic and renal arteries were performed. The seven enrolled family members underwent blood pressure measurement and biochemical testing, including plasma serum, aldosterone, and renin concentration measurements. However, specific numerical values for these tests were not provided in the given information.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Genetic analysis was performed on the patient and his family members. DNA was extracted from leukocytes in the peripheral blood of all enrolled family members. Whole-exome sequencing was performed on the proband's DNA using the SureSelectXT Human All ExonV6 kit and the Novaseq 6000 platform. Sanger sequencing was performed on the DNA of the family members to evaluate the candidate variant and to perform co-segregation analysis. The sequenced data were aligned to the reference human genome (GRCh37/hg19), and various bioinformatics tools were used for variant identification and annotation. In silico analysis software, including MutationTaster and Phylogenetic Analysis with Space/Time Models (phast) Cons, were used to predict the pathogenicity of variants. The pathogenicity of the sequence variants was assessed using the method developed by the American College of Medical Genetics and Genomics (ACMG)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a female born at 37 weeks and 4 days of gestation. Her birth length was 43.0 cm (–2.1 SD), and her weight was 2,646 g (–0.2 SD). She was born to non-consanguineous parents as their second child.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to a local hospital shortly after birth due to an elevated TSH level detected during newborn screening for congenital hypothyroidism. She did not exhibit clinical features of hypothyroidism such as neonatal jaundice, hypotonia, poor feeding, umbilical hernia, or macroglossia. Congenital bilateral sensorineural deafness was identified during the neonatal period. Around 5 months of age, multiple subcutaneous ossifications were observed on the abdomen, back, and lower extremities. Marked weight gain was also observed up to 12 months of age, which became inconspicuous afterward.",

  "Physical Examination": "Multiple subcutaneous ossifications were observed on the abdomen, back, and lower extremities around 5 months of age.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother had multiple subcutaneous ossifications and normal serum calcium, inorganic phosphorus, and intact PTH levels. She was clinically diagnosed as having PPHP. The father and older brother were clinically healthy, with no discernible AHO features. The maternal grandfather was free from clinical features, although he was obese and had diabetes mellitus. The maternal grandmother exhibited no AHO features.",

  "Initial Test Results": "At the time of referral, the patient's serum TSH was 53.27 mIU/mL (reference range, 0.36–9.75 mIU/mL), and free T4 was 2.10 ng/dL (0.70–2.47 ng/dL). Based on these results, she was diagnosed with subclinical congenital hypothyroidism and treated with l-thyroxine."
}"

}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 66-year-old Caucasian male from an unspecified geographic location. He is a renowned and award-winning cartoonist.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was brought to the emergency department due to violent behavior. He was restless, disoriented, and had delusions and visual hallucinations. His initial vital signs were: temperature 36.7°C, heart rate 79 beats per minute, respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute, blood pressure 126/88 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 98% on ambient air. He appeared in distress, agitated, and unable to be redirected. On mental status examination, he was awake and alert, disoriented, in an angry mood, with a labile affect, limited cognition, and poor insight and judgment. His behavior was aggressive, with mixed delusions and visual hallucinations. His speech rate was rapid and pressured. The patient's condition worsened after admission, progressing to hyperactive delirium. He became tachycardic with new vital signs: temperature 37.5°C, heart rate 150 beats per minute, blood pressure 166/91 mmHg, and oxygen saturation 95% on 2 liters per minute of oxygen. He was severely agitated, profusely sweating, and unable to be redirected. The patient developed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response. He became more aggressive and violent, requiring four-point physical restraints. His condition further deteriorated with a high-grade fever of 39.1°C. He developed suppurative superficial thrombophlebitis and blistering skin lesions on dorsal bilateral upper extremities. After initiating treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, his urine sample turned brown. His wife reported that the patient intermittently had skin lesions on his dorsal hands for the last few years. After discontinuing porphyrinogenic medications and administering glucose infusions, his acute psychiatric symptoms resolved entirely, he no longer required restraints, and his skin lesions improved. After discharge, he had two further episodes, which were short-lived and treated with IV Hemin.",

  "Physical Examination": "Crusted skin lesions were observed on the dorsum of the hands and the forearms. The remainder of the physical examination was initially unremarkable. Later examinations revealed increased heart rate and irregular heart rhythm. The patient developed suppurative superficial thrombophlebitis and blistering skin lesions on dorsal bilateral upper extremities.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of dementia, insomnia, and depressive disorder. His family history was initially reported as unremarkable. However, on further questioning, it was revealed that the patient's father had a similar rash at an older age. The patient did not smoke tobacco, drink alcohol, or use recreational drugs. His medications included cyanocobalamin, fluoxetine, and olanzapine.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Complete blood count was normal except for a low hemoglobin level (12.0 g/dl; normal range 13.5–17.5). Blood glucose, serum creatinine, liver function tests, total bilirubin, albumin, and protein levels were normal. Serum magnesium, phosphorus, thyroid-stimulating hormone, vitamin B12, and folic acid levels were also normal. Blood ethanol level was <10 mg/dl. Urine toxicology screen was negative. Later tests showed leukocytosis of 18,700 per cubic millimeter and an aspartate transaminase level of 42 IU/L. Electrocardiogram showed atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response and a heart rate of 123 beats per minute."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A male infant was born prematurely at 32+4 weeks of gestation by cesarean section. The mother was 22 years of age, and the father was 27 years of age. The couple was nonconsanguineous and of Chinese origin, from Ya'an, Sichuan Province, China. The birth weight and length were 1680 g and 42 cm, respectively.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The infant was born due to severe oligohydramnios (amniotic fluid index: 2.8 cm) on prenatal ultrasound. A prenatal ultrasound at 23 weeks of gestation demonstrated multicystic kidneys. There was no obvious amniotic fluid at delivery. The placenta and umbilical cord were normal. There was no deformity. Apgar scores were 10 at 1 min and 8 at 5 min of age. The baby developed respiratory distress approximately 10 min after delivery. At 15 min of life, the oxygen saturation acutely decreased from 90 to 50%, and the patient was intubated and mechanically ventilated. Pulmonary surfactant was intratracheally aspirated. The infant experienced repeated severe metabolic acidosis, hyperkalemia, hypocalcemia, and hyperglycemia. He had episodic oxygen desaturation and pulmonary hypertension. The patient's repeated hypoxemia and white lung on chest radiographs persisted after 3 rounds of pulmonary surfactant therapy. The infant's urine output was significantly diminished, with a total urine volume of 35 ml from birth to the end of life. Abdominal X-rays indicated little aeration of the abdominal bowel, wherein the colon was not aerated, and there was no fetal fecal discharge at any time. At 1 day 10 h of life, the infant made a difficult respiratory effort with little chest movement, and his parents elected to withdraw ventilatory support.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination indicated continuous machine-like murmurs and hepatomegaly. The cyanosis and labored breathing of the infant under invasive ventilator-assisted ventilation improved and oxygen saturation gradually increased, but levels could not be maintained in the normal range. After replacing the oscillating ventilator with auxiliary ventilation, the patient's peripheral oxygen saturation increased to the normal range and was maintained at 93–95%.",

  "Past Medical History": "This was the couple's second pregnancy. There was no history of prenatal exposure to alcohol, drugs, or medications. The couple's first child was delivered at 28 weeks after prenatal ultrasound suggested bilateral renal cysts and severe oligohydramnios. The first child had a normal male karyotype but did not survive after delivery. The couple was unaware of other renal, liver or pancreatic disease cases in their families.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Arterial blood showed severe metabolic acidosis with respiratory acidosis, hypoxemia, and hyperlactacidemia (pH 6.852, PaCO2 47.3 mmHg, PaO2 56.8 mmHg, SO2 74.8%, BE -25.3 mmol/L, lactic acid 11.3 mmol/L). Laboratory results showed: serum potassium ion concentration of 6.2 mmol/L, serum-free calcium concentration of 0.62 mmol/L, serum creatinine concentration of 130 μmol/L, BUN level of 6.7 mmol/L, serum β2 microglobulin level of 9.5 mg/L, lactic acid level of 20.5 mmol/L, albumin level of 28.6 g/L, and serum total bilirubin and direct bilirubin levels of 30.3 μmol/L and 12.9 μmol/L, respectively. Serum glucose concentration showed fluctuations ranging from 11.2 mmol/L to 17 mmol/L. Routine blood tests and aspartate, alanine aminotransferase, amylase and lipase levels were normal. Routine urine and microscopy examination revealed no protein or red blood cells and no hypercalciuria. A bedside chest radiograph documented normal ribs and vertebrae, and the transmittance of both lungs decreased significantly, leading to a presentation of white lung, in line with neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (NRDS) grade IV."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 39-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted to hospital in March 2021 with recurrent post-activity chest pain and shortness of breath for more than 11 years and bilateral lower extremity edema for one week. In 2010, he was first admitted due to post-activity chest pain and shortness of breath for half a year. He was diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (IPAH) with World Health Organization functional class (WHO-FC) Ⅱ. He received PAH-targeted therapy with sildenafil (25mg, PO, tid), yet experienced a gradual increase in pulmonary artery pressure (PAP). In July 2016, the patient progressed from WHO-FC Ⅱto IV and the pulmonary artery systolic pressure (PASP) increased from 80 to 120 mm Hg. A week later, the patient encountered severe cough and hemoptysis, approximately 50 ml in volume, attributable to a severe cold leading to pneumonia. Following the cessation of hemoptysis, he continued the treatment with sildenafil at the same dose as before. The patient was acyanotic from 2010 to 2016, with a femoral artery oxygen saturation of 93.4% observed during the 2016 hospitalization. However, subsequent to hemoptysis, he gradually became cyanotic, with a concomitant improvement in symptoms. At the same time, the PAP decreased and the left ventricle enlarged spontaneously. The patient was re-admitted in March 2021 due to mild bilateral lower extremity edema for approximately one week.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient was acyanotic from 2010 to 2016 but gradually became cyanotic after the hemoptysis episode in 2016. In March 2021, he presented with mild bilateral lower extremity edema.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (IPAH) in 2010. In July 2016, he experienced severe cough and hemoptysis due to a severe cold leading to pneumonia.",

  "Initial Test Results": "In 2010, the echocardiographically estimated pulmonary artery systolic pressure (PASP) was 80 mmHg. In July 2016, the PASP increased to 120 mm Hg. The femoral artery oxygen saturation was 93.4% during the 2016 hospitalization. In March 2021, the CT scan of the chest revealed an enlarged hilar shadow and widened pulmonary arteries, but no parenchymal lesions were discerned. The echocardiographically estimated PASP was 55 mm Hg. Right heart catheterization showed PAP of 60/39 mmHg, notably lower than the aortic pressure. The oxygen saturation of femoral artery was 88.5%. The plasma N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide was 94.2 pg/ml in August 2021. The PASP estimated by echocardiography in June 2022 and February 2023 was 47 and 45 mmHg, respectively."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 17-year-old male from Bengaluru, Karnataka.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a history of fever and ascending limb paralysis for 3 days. He was bed bound and had difficulty breathing for one day. Pain in the legs preceded weakness in the lower limbs. There was no recent history of cough, rhinorrhea, or loose stools. There was no history of any drug abuse or major illnesses in the past. Given the impending respiratory failure, intubation and mechanical ventilation were commenced. The patient was resuscitated according to Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines. Antibiotics ceftriaxone, amikacin, and metronidazole were started empirically after sending blood, tracheal, and urine cultures. Plasmapheresis at 10 mL/kg of body volume was performed within 24 hours of admission due to the inability to afford intravenous immunoglobulin for Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS). The next day, the patient had generalized anasarca with a serum albumin of 1.7 g/dL. He received intravenous albumin (100 mL of 20% each day) for 3 days. Significant improvement in lower limb power was noted on Day 3. Noradrenaline infusion was started to maintain blood pressure. Chest consolidation progressed with near-complete opacification of the left hemithorax. Vancomycin was started at 500 mg four times a day. By Day 4, power in all the limbs improved to MRC grade 4. At the end of one week, power in all limbs was normal and noradrenaline was stopped. However, ventilator weaning was difficult due to underlying respiratory infections. The patient developed repeated ventilator-associated pneumonias with nonfermenting gram-negative bacteria treated with intravenous Colistin. On Day 10, X-ray revealed cavitary changes in both lungs and progressive right-sided pleural effusion. CT thorax confirmed multiple thin-wall cavitary lesions suggestive of pneumatoceles. On Day 16, cultures revealed methicillin-resistant SA in blood sensitive to linezolid, which was started two days prior. Ventilator weaning trials were initiated on Day 21 with slow progress. On repeat X-rays, cavitary lesions and right-sided pleural collection had increased in size. On Day 22, thoracentesis was performed and about 200 mL of purulent right-sided pleural collection was drained, revealing SA on culture. Following this, the patient showed drastic clinical improvement. Post-thoracentesis, X-ray chest revealed right hydropneumothorax which increased remarkably over the next 4 days without mediastinal shift. On Day 27, he coughed violently followed by sudden profuse bleeding from the endotracheal tube, resulting in cardiopulmonary resuscitation. Despite efforts, the patient could not be revived, and CT thorax after death revealed loculated right hydropneumothorax with no evidence of an air-fluid level in the cavitary lesion.",
  "Physical Examination": "On physical examination, mental status was normal with hypophonic speech. The patient was febrile, tachycardic, and tachypneic with a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg, bilateral coarse crepitations, hypotonic limbs, significant neck flexor weakness, and lower motor neuron facial diplegia. Motor power in upper limbs by Medical Research Council (MRC) scale was grade 4 and in lower limbs grade 1. Deep tendon reflexes were absent, and sensory examination was normal.",
  "Past Medical History": "There was no history of any drug abuse or major illnesses in the past.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory investigations revealed leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, deranged coagulation, and elevated bilirubin with normal creatinine phosphokinase levels. Screening for viral infections, including HIV, was negative. On imaging, a frontal chest radiograph revealed inhomogeneous opacity in the left hemithorax and right lower zone and hypoxemia (PaO2 78 mmHg on 6 L/min oxygen flows) on arterial blood gas analysis."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 14-year-old male from Mexico.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the rheumatology department for assessment of an incidental finding of asymptomatic hyperCKemia (26,372 IU/L). He engaged in 3 hours daily of high-performance sports and had not experienced myalgia, cramps, or pigmenturia during or after physical activity. Initially, a neurologist considered that the hyperCKemia was related to exercise, but the patient's CK serum levels persisted above 20,000 IU/L despite cessation of sports. Six months after initial presentation, the patient underwent muscle biopsy from the right quadriceps. He was treated with intravenous methylprednisolone (IVMP) 1 g/day for 3 days and continued with prednisone 0.5 mg/kg/day and methotrexate 15 mg/weekly. Despite a decrease in CK serum levels from 28,457 to 21,671 IU/L, the patient began to experience proximal muscle weakness of both lower limbs, which worsened after a second monthly IVMP (500 mg/day for two days), with sparing of the upper limbs. Based on CK serum levels, the onset of proximal lower limb weakness after corticosteroid treatment, and the prominent inflammatory changes seen on muscle biopsy, methotrexate and glucocorticoid treatment was suspended.",

  "Physical Examination": "Neuromuscular and systemic examination was normal. No cardiac or respiratory complications were found.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no history of familial neuromuscular disorder or parental consanguinity or of exposure to myotoxic medications or substances.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial CK levels were 26,372 IU/L. Myositis-specific (Mi2, TIF1g, MDA5, NXP2, SAE1, Jo1, SRP, PL7, PL12, EJ, OJ), myositis-associated (Ku, PM-Scl 75/100, Ro52), and antinuclear antibodies were negative. Thyroid-stimulating hormone level was normal. Electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies were initially normal. Multiplex polymerase chain reaction analysis and multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification analysis detected no DMD deletions."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 14-year-old male from Mexico.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred to the rheumatology department for assessment of an incidental finding of asymptomatic hyperCKemia (26,372 IU/L). He engaged in 3 hours daily of high-performance sports and had not experienced myalgia, cramps, or pigmenturia during or after physical activity. Initially, a neurologist considered that the hyperCKemia was related to exercise, but the patient's CK serum levels persisted above 20,000 IU/L despite cessation of sports. Six months after initial presentation, the patient underwent muscle biopsy from the right quadriceps. He was treated with intravenous methylprednisolone (IVMP) 1 g/day for 3 days and continued with prednisone 0.5 mg/kg/day and methotrexate 15 mg/weekly. Despite a decrease in CK serum levels from 28,457 to 21,671 IU/L, the patient began to experience proximal muscle weakness of both lower limbs, which worsened after a second monthly IVMP (500 mg/day for two days), with sparing of the upper limbs. Based on CK serum levels, the onset of proximal lower limb weakness after corticosteroid treatment, and the prominent inflammatory changes seen on muscle biopsy, methotrexate and glucocorticoid treatment was suspended.",

  "Physical Examination": "Neuromuscular and systemic examination was normal. No cardiac or respiratory complications were found.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no history of familial neuromuscular disorder or parental consanguinity or of exposure to myotoxic medications or substances.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial CK levels were 26,372 IU/L. Myositis-specific (Mi2, TIF1g, MDA5, NXP2, SAE1, Jo1, SRP, PL7, PL12, EJ, OJ), myositis-associated (Ku, PM-Scl 75/100, Ro52), and antinuclear antibodies were negative. Thyroid-stimulating hormone level was normal. Electromyography (EMG) and nerve conduction studies were initially normal. Multiplex polymerase chain reaction analysis and multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification analysis detected no DMD deletions.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Muscle biopsy from the right quadriceps showed necrosis along with endomysial and perivascular lymphocytic infiltrates, and no fibrosis or fatty infiltration was seen. A new EMG and nerve conduction studies revealed a myopathic pattern. Whole-exome sequencing (WES) confirmed the diagnosis of LGMDR2 based on a compound heterozygous variant of the DYSF gene. The first mutation was c.3851C > T, which causes a Gln →Ter amino acid change at position 1160 (p.Q1160X), leading to a stop codon in exon 32. The other mutation was a c.5979dup in exon 53, which causes a p.Glu1994ArgX3 frame shift. Sanger sequencing confirmed that the mother was a c.3851C > T carrier and that the father had the c.5979dup mutation."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 77-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "In July 2020, the patient was referred due to persistent proteinuria for the past 6 months. Two years prior, he experienced scattered light red rashes on both lower extremities, which did not protrude from the skin surface or fade under pressure, accompanied by numbness. He reported worsening bilateral numbness in the lower extremities, along with weakness and tingling sensation. Approximately a year before referral, he received methylprednisolone due to peripheral neuropathy, but experienced no improvement. His rash extended to involve the knee joints, with increased tingling sensation, leading to unstable walking. He gradually developed bilateral pitting edema in the lower extremities along with 3+ proteinuria. Four months after the last dose of rituximab (March 2021), he developed nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria increasing to 5.45g/day and serum albumin of 27 g/L, although his serum creatinine remained stable. One month after starting ibrutinib treatment, his nephrotic syndrome achieved complete remission. However, he suffered atrial fibrillation with long intervals (maximum R-R interval of 2.55 seconds) which led to dizziness, causing him to discontinue ibrutinib treatment. One year later, his 24-hour UP increased to 3.523g/day.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had scattered light red rashes on both lower extremities, which did not protrude from the skin surface or fade under pressure. The rash later extended to involve the knee joints. He developed bilateral pitting edema in the lower extremities.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient denied any history of diabetes. There was no mention of other significant past medical history or family medical history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Upon presentation to the department, laboratory tests revealed a urine protein level of 2.2g/day, serum creatinine of 82μmol/L, albumin of 38g/L, and hemoglobin of 93g/L. C-reactive protein levels were within normal range. Serology showed positive RF activity (exceeding the upper limit) and negative ANA, anti-dsDNA, ENA as well as ANCA. Complement testing indicated C4 levels <0.068g/L and C3 levels of 0.530g/L. HIV, HBV, and HCV tests returned negative results. Cryoglobulin testing was positive. ECG results were not mentioned in the initial tests."
}"

  "Clinical Presentation": "In July 2020, the patient was referred due to persistent proteinuria for the past 6 months. Two years prior, he experienced scattered light red rashes on both lower extremities, which did not protrude from the skin surface or fade under pressure, accompanied by numbness. He reported worsening bilateral numbness in the lower extremities, along with weakness and tingling sensation. Approximately a year before referral, he received methylprednisolone due to peripheral neuropathy, but experienced no improvement. His rash extended to involve the knee joints, with increased tingling sensation, leading to unstable walking. He gradually developed bilateral pitting edema in the lower extremities along with 3+ proteinuria. Four months after the last dose of rituximab (March 2021), he developed nephrotic syndrome with proteinuria increasing to 5.45g/day and serum albumin of 27 g/L, although his serum creatinine remained stable. One month after starting ibrutinib treatment, his nephrotic syndrome achieved complete remission. However, he suffered atrial fibrillation with long intervals (maximum R-R interval of 2.55 seconds) which led to dizziness, causing him to discontinue ibrutinib treatment. One year later, his 24-hour UP increased to 3.523g/day.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had scattered light red rashes on both lower extremities, which did not protrude from the skin surface or fade under pressure. The rash later extended to involve the knee joints. He developed bilateral pitting edema in the lower extremities.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient denied any history of diabetes. There was no mention of other significant past medical history or family medical history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Upon presentation to the department, laboratory tests revealed a urine protein level of 2.2g/day, serum creatinine of 82μmol/L, albumin of 38g/L, and hemoglobin of 93g/L. C-reactive protein levels were within normal range. Serology showed positive RF activity (exceeding the upper limit) and negative ANA, anti-dsDNA, ENA as well as ANCA. Complement testing indicated C4 levels <0.068g/L and C3 levels of 0.530g/L. HIV, HBV, and HCV tests returned negative results. Cryoglobulin testing was positive. ECG results were not mentioned in the initial tests.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Immunofixation of cryoglobulin revealed a monoclonal IgM κ and polyclonal IgG, characterized of type II cryoglobulinemia. Skin biopsy suggested leukocytoclastic vasculitis. Nerve biopsy showed chronic axonal damage with massive perivascular infiltration of numerous mononuclear cells. Renal biopsy revealed MPGN with suspected cryoglobulinemic renal damage. Immunofluorescence showed IgG (++), IgM (2+~3+), IgA (-), C3 (+), C1q (-), κ (+), and λ (+/-). Bone marrow biopsy indicated abnormal lymphocytes accounting for approximately 2%, and flow cytometry showed abnormal small and medium B lymphocytes (CD19+, CD20+, CD22+, CD5-, CD10-, slgM+, cyκ+, cyλ-) occupying 3% of the nucleated cells, and abnormal plasma cells (CD38+, CD138+part, CD27+, CD19+, CD56-, CD28-, CD117-, restricted expression of cyκ+) occupying 0.37% of nucleated cells. No pathogenic mutations associated with Waldenström macroglobulinemia were found in the MYD88 genes. In the most recent follow-up (July 2023), tests revealed hemoglobin of 102g/L, albumin of 28 g/L, serum creatinine of 109μmol/L, C3 of 0.480g/L, and C4 of <0.068g/L. Bone marrow biopsy revealed abnormal lymphocytes accounting for approximately 4.07%, and flow cytometry showed abnormal small and medium B lymphocytes occupying 1.11% of the nucleated cells, and abnormal plasma cells occupying 0.10% of nucleated cells."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a Chinese boy born at 36 + 6 weeks gestation via elective lower segment cesarean section. He is the first living child of nonconsanguineous parents.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "Upon delivery, the patient was noted to have extensive areas of purpuric erosions over the back, buttocks, anterior aspect of the chest, arms, neck, and scalp. The erosions on his back formed a characteristic 'X'-shaped configuration. His oral mucosa, hair, and nails were normal. He was born flat and dusky, required positive pressure ventilation for 3 minutes, and remained hemodynamically stable after this. The skin lesions healed with atrophic and hypertrophic scars over the next 3 months with no new vesicular or erosive lesion observed. Alopecia was seen over previously involved scalp areas. At the 15-month review, his growth and development were normal.",

  "Physical Examination": "Extensive areas of purpuric erosions were observed over the back, buttocks, anterior aspect of the chest, arms, neck, and scalp. The erosions on his back formed a characteristic 'X'-shaped configuration. His oral mucosa, hair, and nails were normal. Ophthalmological examination was normal.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother is a 33-year-old female with systemic lupus erythematosus diagnosed at 17 years of age. Her disease control had been relatively stable on oral prednisolone 5 mg daily, hydroxychloroquine 300 mg daily, and aspirin 100 mg daily throughout the pregnancy. There was 1 previous miscarriage, and the current pregnancy was conceived via in vitro fertilization. Antenatally, fetal growth, amniotic fluid, and fetal abnormalities scans were unremarkable. The mother did not have a history of oral or genital ulcers.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) for herpes simplex virus (HSV) type 1 returned positive from surface swabs of the skin lesions on his back and oral cavity. HSV total antibody was 1:128 on day 2 of life. Cerebrospinal fluid, blood, and conjunctiva for HSV PCR and serum HSV Immunoglobulin M serology (done on day 2 and day 11 of life) were negative. The baby's skin lesions were negative for cytomegalovirus PCR, varicella-zoster PCR and Toxoplasma gondii PCR. Mother's HSV Immunoglobulin G serology was 1:128. Serological evaluation for congenital lupus done on day 1 of life showed antinuclear antibody titer at 1:320 in homogeneous pattern, and anti–double-stranded DNA antibody at 219.35 IU (<25 IU negative). Antiextractable nuclear antigen profile was negative. Electrocardiogram and 2D echocardiogram were normal. Blood count and liver function test were normal. HSV antibody titers were 1:128 on day 2 of life, 1:64 at 2 months old, and 1:32 at 4 months old."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Skin biopsy on a purpuric lesion from the back showed a subepidermal blister with basal vacuolar degeneration and some extravasated red blood cells. No viral cytopathic changes were noted. Both HSV1 and HSV2 immunohistochemical stains were negative. Investigations to exclude antiphospholipid syndrome, including anticardiolipin antibodies, lupus anticoagulant, anti-β2 glycoprotein 1 antibodies, ultrasound Doppler of kidneys and renal vessels, and cranial ultrasound, all returned unremarkable. A repeat skin biopsy performed on an atrophic hypopigmented area at 4 months of age showed mild spongiosis in the epidermis, a thinned dermis, and fragmentation of dermal elastic tissue on the Elastic Verhoeff Van Gieson stain, consistent with scarring."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 52-year-old male. His geographic location is not specified.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented with chronic nasal congestion, tinnitus, and bilateral conduction and sensorineural hearing loss in both ears lasting over 8 months. After 4 months, he developed fever persisting for over 4 months, accompanied by excessive weight loss exceeding 8 kg. Tympanic puncture was performed and dexamethasone was injected into the tympanic membrane. Two days later, tympanic catheter drainage was performed. The patient received intravenous linezolid glucose 0.6 g every 12 hours for 1 week, but continued to experience fever. A trial of intravenous methylprednisolone at 40 mg once daily was initiated for 1 week, resulting in significant reduction in hs-CRP and ESR levels, resolution of fever, and alleviation of ear tightness and tinnitus. The patient was discharged on oral methylprednisolone tablets, gradually tapering down to a maintenance dose of 2 mg twice daily. After 3 months of glucocorticoid maintenance treatment, the patient developed fever again, with body temperature fluctuating between 36.9 °C and 38.0 °C, accompanied by right-sided migraine, stuffiness in the right ear, and poor ventilation in the right nostril. The patient was referred from the Ear, Nose and Throat Department to the Rheumatology Department.",

  "Physical Examination": "Temperature: 37.5 °C, pulse rate: 112 beats/min, respiratory rate: 18 beats/min, blood pressure: 121/85 mmHg. The ear canal was clear and unobstructed. There was no tenderness observed in the sinuses, and both lungs showed no abnormalities upon auscultation. No edema was observed in both lower limbs. During the first stage of the disease, otolaryngological examination revealed a deviated nasal septum, purulent discharge in the right middle nasal passage, and absence of any masses in the nasopharynx. Otoscopy showed bilateral tympanic membrane invagination and bilateral tympanic effusion. After relapse, otolaryngological examination revealed a clear ear canal with no presence of pus or fluid discharge.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was diagnosed with chronic nephritis 20 years ago based on positive occult blood in urine, however, biopsy to determine the pathological type of the kidney was not performed. The patient had a history of raising parrots 1 year ago. The personal and family history did not reveal any notable features.",

  "Initial Test Results": "During the first stage of the disease, laboratory examination showed hs-CRP was 55 mg/L and ESR was 58 mm/h. Active urinary sediment examination revealed a urinary protein level of 1+, urinary erythrocyte count of 66.7/μL, and 24-h total protein excretion rate of 284 mg/L. Urinary pathogen culture and renal ultrasonography showed no abnormalities. The results of p-ANCA, c-ANCA, antinuclear antibody detected by indirect immunofluorescent assay and PR3 and MPO detected by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay were all negative as confirmed by two medical agencies. After relapse, laboratory examination results showed hs-CRP was 55 mg/L, ESR was 71 mm/h, urinary protein level of 1+, urinary erythrocyte count of 89.0/μL, and 24-h total protein excretion rate of 373 mg/L. c-ANCA was positive, PR3 was 100.8 RU/mL, p-ANCA and MPO were negative."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 30-year-old Pakistani male with a history of smoking marijuana.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented at another hospital a year prior with dyspnoea and haemoptysis. He was diagnosed with pulmonary embolism based on radiographic findings, without evidence of pulmonary aneurysms. He was started on Rivaroxaban, which he discontinued after seven months. At the current presentation, he complained of chest pain, haemoptysis, and dyspnoea. The patient later described a history of oral and genital ulcers. Inspection of the oral cavity and genitalia confirmed scarring from previous ulceration. The patient was given a pulse of 1g IV Methylprednisolone followed by 1mg/kg of oral prednisolone, which was gradually tapered each visit. He was also started on 1g IV cyclophosphamide monthly for six months. After six months, the patient did not develop a new episode of haemoptysis.",

  "Physical Examination": "On examination, he appeared tachypnoeic but was maintaining oxygen saturation. The general and systemic examination was unremarkable. There was no evidence of deep venous thrombosis on doppler evaluation of lower limbs. A skin pathergy test was performed, which was negative. There were no signs of eye disease, and the slit-lamp examination was unremarkable.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of unprovoked pulmonary embolism. His family history was unremarkable, and he did not have any risk factors for venous thromboembolism (VTE).",

  "Initial Test Results": "Complete blood count and metabolic workup were unremarkable. ESR was mildly elevated at 45mm/hour. The coagulation profile was within the normal range. A thrombophilia screen was negative. Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, and Tuberculosis screening were negative. A plain chest radiograph showed a lobular opacity on the left hilum."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 71-year-old female from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the emergency department following a syncopal episode. She had progressive diarrhea, weight loss, worsening jaundice, and fatigue. The patient had been undergoing outpatient evaluation for elevated liver enzymes over the past 2 years prior to admission. She was previously treated with ursodiol and low-dose prednisone without much benefit. In the emergency department, her vitals were remarkable for hypotension with a blood pressure of 72/53 mm Hg and a nadir HR of 62. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for vasodilatory shock, requiring vasopressors and chronotropic agents along with antibiotics. Her hospital course was also complicated by acute necrotizing pancreatitis, poorly controlled blood sugars, and new onset central diabetes insipidus that required treatment with desmopressin. The patient experienced repeated hospitalizations in the following 3 months, which prompted her to opt for comfort care with palliative measures.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical exam was significant for jaundice and cachexia.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of acid reflux.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Blood work demonstrated leukocytosis 27.7 × 109/L (normal 3.4–9.6 × 109/L) with neutrophilic predominance. Hepatic function panel showed an aspartate transaminase level of 85 U/L (normal 8–43 U/L), alanine aminotransferase 85 U/L (normal 7–45 U/L), bilirubin 9.3 mg/dL (normal <1.2 mg/dL), and alkaline phosphatase of 2262 U/L (normal 35–104 U/L). Gamma-glutamyl transferase was elevated to 494 U/L (normal 5–36 U/L). C-reactive protein was 52 mg/L (normal <8 mg/L). TSH was elevated to 22.8 mL U/L (normal 0.3–4.2 mlU/L) with undetectable T3 and T4 levels. Echocardiogram did not reveal any cardiac abnormality. Autoantibody screening including anti-nuclear antibody, SS-A and SS-B antibodies, and anti-smooth muscle antibody were negative. IgG4 subclass levels were normal. Subcutaneous fat aspirate was negative for amyloid deposition on Congo red staining."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 71-year-old female from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the emergency department following a syncopal episode. She had progressive diarrhea, weight loss, worsening jaundice, and fatigue. The patient had been undergoing outpatient evaluation for elevated liver enzymes over the past 2 years prior to admission. She was previously treated with ursodiol and low-dose prednisone without much benefit. In the emergency department, her vitals were remarkable for hypotension with a blood pressure of 72/53 mm Hg and a nadir HR of 62. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for vasodilatory shock, requiring vasopressors and chronotropic agents along with antibiotics. Her hospital course was also complicated by acute necrotizing pancreatitis, poorly controlled blood sugars, and new onset central diabetes insipidus that required treatment with desmopressin. The patient experienced repeated hospitalizations in the following 3 months, which prompted her to opt for comfort care with palliative measures.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical exam was significant for jaundice and cachexia.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of acid reflux.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Blood work demonstrated leukocytosis 27.7 × 109/L (normal 3.4–9.6 × 109/L) with neutrophilic predominance. Hepatic function panel showed an aspartate transaminase level of 85 U/L (normal 8–43 U/L), alanine aminotransferase 85 U/L (normal 7–45 U/L), bilirubin 9.3 mg/dL (normal <1.2 mg/dL), and alkaline phosphatase of 2262 U/L (normal 35–104 U/L). Gamma-glutamyl transferase was elevated to 494 U/L (normal 5–36 U/L). C-reactive protein was 52 mg/L (normal <8 mg/L). TSH was elevated to 22.8 mL U/L (normal 0.3–4.2 mlU/L) with undetectable T3 and T4 levels. Echocardiogram did not reveal any cardiac abnormality. Autoantibody screening including anti-nuclear antibody, SS-A and SS-B antibodies, and anti-smooth muscle antibody were negative. IgG4 subclass levels were normal. Subcutaneous fat aspirate was negative for amyloid deposition on Congo red staining.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Review of a 6-month prior outside liver biopsy was consistent with periportal fibrosis with lymphocytic and scattered neutrophilic infiltrates in the portal tracts. No infiltrating histiocytes were noted in this biopsy. Computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis with contrast illustrated diffusely heterogenous liver parenchymal enhancement without ductal dilatation, duodenitis, and diffuse colonic thickening concerning pancolitis. CT chest showed centrilobular ground glass opacities bilaterally with mild pulmonary edema. Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) with contrast revealed abnormal enhancement and thickening of the pituitary infundibulum and stalk. Magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography showed multifocal nodular hepatic steatosis and hepatomegaly without any focal liver abnormality; in addition, multiple indeterminate bony lesions were read as non-specific focal sclerosis and cystic lesions. A bone marrow biopsy showed 40% cellularity and reactive marrow changes without any blasts or infiltrate. A repeat liver biopsy revealed histiocytes infiltrating the biliary tree with chronic biliary tract injury. Tissue stained positive for CD1a and S100, markers of Langerhans cells, and BRAFV600E-mutated protein. No evidence of IgG4 sclerosing cholangitis was observed."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 36-year-old Chinese female presented to the ophthalmology department in May 2020. She was born to parents of fourth-degree consanguineous marriage.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with severe osteoporosis, scoliosis of approximately 20°, hyperextensibility of the joints, anti-thyroglobulin antibodies, and an elevated parathyroid hormone level. The best corrected visual acuity of the right eye was 14/20, with a manifest refraction of 4.50/-3.75 × 5. The best corrected visual acuity in the left eye was 12/20 with a manifest refraction of -5.25/-3.50 × 5. Slit lamp microscopy showed horizontal nystagmus in both eyes, significant bluish discoloration of the sclera, with decreased central corneal transparency. The posterior segment showed normal characteristics of the retina. The patient was educated about safety precautions and asked to come for follow-up visits every 3 to 6 months. During the two-year follow-up period, there was no significant decrease in the patient's best-corrected visual acuity, corneal topography curvature, corneal thickness, or corneal densitometry.",

  "Physical Examination": "Intraocular pressure was found to be within normal levels (13 mmHg in both eyes). The patient had scoliosis of approximately 20° and hyperextensibility of the joints.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's parents, siblings, and two sons all underwent tests including corneal topography, optometry, and a general physical examination, all of which showed no abnormal findings.",

  "Initial Test Results": "High-definition optical coherence tomography (HD-OCT) showed thinning of the entire cornea as well as a heterogeneous and mildly elevated stromal layer density. Pentacam anterior segment tomography showed increased corneal curvature in both eyes, with a maximum keratometric power of 50.5 D in the right eye and 50.60 D in the left eye. The thinnest point of each of the patient's corneas was assessed by Pentacam, which showed that the right eye had a minimum corneal thickness of 285 μm with astigmatism (-4.4D at 174 degrees) and the left eye had a minimum corneal thickness of 280 μm with astigmatism (-3.9 D at 11 degrees), with a white to white value of 11.6 mm in the right eye and a value of 11.7 mm in the left eye. Corneal densitometry results showed a significant increase in optical density in the 2-mm central area of the cornea. The values for the right and left eye were 29.3 grayscale units (GSU) and 30.6 GSU, respectively. Axial length values were determined to be 21.25 mm in the right eye and 21.13 mm in the left eye, respectively."
}"

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's parents, siblings, and two sons all underwent tests including corneal topography, optometry, and a general physical examination, all of which showed no abnormal findings.",

  "Initial Test Results": "High-definition optical coherence tomography (HD-OCT) showed thinning of the entire cornea as well as a heterogeneous and mildly elevated stromal layer density. Pentacam anterior segment tomography showed increased corneal curvature in both eyes, with a maximum keratometric power of 50.5 D in the right eye and 50.60 D in the left eye. The thinnest point of each of the patient's corneas was assessed by Pentacam, which showed that the right eye had a minimum corneal thickness of 285 μm with astigmatism (-4.4D at 174 degrees) and the left eye had a minimum corneal thickness of 280 μm with astigmatism (-3.9 D at 11 degrees), with a white to white value of 11.6 mm in the right eye and a value of 11.7 mm in the left eye.   "Further Diagnostic Tests": "In vivo confocal microscopy (IVCM) results showed that corneal epithelial cell morphology in the central cornea zone was disturbed. The corneal stromal nerves were found to be thicker than average; with the nuclei of the posterior stromal cells showing uneven size distribution with no apparent activation state. Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 50-year-old woman residing in Thailand who has never traveled abroad.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presents with a progressively increasing rash on her body over the course of a year. She had no rash on her face and other sun-exposed areas. Additional symptoms included telangiectasis and a positive Darier's sign. The patient did not report any other abnormal symptoms, such as dyspnea, arthralgia, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed multiple discrete reddish-brown macules and papules on the chest wall and upper back. The lymph node was not palpable.",

  "Past Medical History": "No specific past medical history was mentioned in the provided information.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Complete blood count was normal, with no signs of atypical lymphocytes. Kidney function and electrolyte levels were all within the normal limit. Serum protein levels showed an elevated globulin protein level of 3.7 g/dL (reference range: 1.3–3 g/dL). Serum protein electrophoresis test indicated an abnormally high level of gamma globulin at 1.83 g/dL (reference range: 0.70–1.50 g/dL) without monoclonal gammopathy. IgG-4 levels were 148 mg/dL (reference range: 11–330 mg/dL). Serology tests were negative for syphilis (VDRL and TPHA), human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), hepatitis B virus, and hepatitis C virus. The antinuclear antibody result was negative. A bone survey showed no bone lytic lesions. Interleukin 6 (IL-6) levels in the patient's blood were less than 1.5 pg/mL (reference range: 0–7)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 45-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient visited the outpatient clinic with refractory right pleural effusion. He had a chest tube at the time of visit. Two months prior, he experienced chest pain caused by lifting heavy objects. At the 4-month follow-up after initial treatment, the patient revisited the outpatient clinic with mild symptoms of chest discomfort. A chest radiograph at this time showed right pleural effusion. Percutaneous catheter drainage was performed to relieve the symptoms. Despite subsequent medication with sirolimus, the patient presented with a newly developed pain in the right shoulder.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were provided in the given information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no previous medical or surgical history prior to the current condition.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Chest CT showed an osteolytic lesion in the right 1st rib and a fracture in the right 2nd rib. The triglyceride level in the pleural effusion was 335 mg/dL. Noncontrast MR lymphangiograms showed suspicious leakage and web-like lymphatic channels around the right lower neck and subclavian vein. An intranodal lymphangiogram showed no abnormalities, except for prominent lymphatic channels in the right upper hemithorax. A subsequent thoracic ductogram showed no definite contrast leakage."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "PET/CT was performed to further evaluate the osteolytic bone lesions. FDG uptake in the right 1st and 2nd ribs increased (maximal standardized uptake value = 4.0).
