Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 58-year-old Hispanic female from a tertiary care center.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with acute onset of progressively worsening dyspnea and lower extremity edema over the past week. She noticed bilateral lower extremity edema, periorbital swelling, orthopnea, and dyspnea on exertion as well as rest. She denied fever, cough, chest pain, palpitations, dizziness, syncope, or new medications. She had a COVID-19 infection one month ago that had resolved without complications within one week. The patient was in distress and bending forward to improve dyspnea. In the emergency department, bedside echocardiography revealed a large pericardial effusion. Formal echocardiography showed tamponade physiology on Doppler imaging due to a massive circumferential pericardial effusion with chamber collapse, inferior vena cava dilatation, and septal bounce. The patient underwent right heart catheterization with pulmonary artery pressure at 54 mmHg and wedge pressure at 51 mmHg. Nontraumatic pericardiocentesis drained grossly hemorrhagic 500 mL of the effusion. Peri-procedurally, the patient developed paroxysmal atrial fibrillation with a rapid ventricular response with spontaneous resolution. The patient was started on 40 mg of prednisone daily with a tapering regimen and drastically improved within two days with the resolution of symptoms and exam findings. The patient was discharged to follow up at the clinic. On her last follow-up, the patient had no acute symptoms and continued to do well on mycophenolate mofetil and low-dose prednisone.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient was found to be tachypneic, tachycardic, hypotensive (90/70 mmHg), and saturating 88% on room air. Pitting edema up to the thighs and periorbital swelling were found, and bilateral basilar lung crackles were auscultated.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had type 2 diabetes mellitus, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc), and pulmonary hypertension (PHTN). Her lcSSc was diagnosed seven years ago, did not require immunosuppressive treatment, and remained stable. GERD was diagnosed on endoscopy at the same time, with intermittent symptoms only. She also had echocardiography done at the time of diagnosis with pulmonary artery pressure of 40 mmHg and right ventricular dilatation but was not limited by symptoms.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial labs revealed negative troponin, D-dimer elevated at 6.01, chest X-ray with diffuse pulmonary vascular congestion, brain natriuretic peptide level at 73 pg/mL, C-reactive protein 7.64 mg/dL, normal complement levels, and a negative COVID-19 PCR test. EKG showed normal sinus rhythm only. Echocardiography showed pulmonary artery pressure of 45 mmHg, and an ejection fraction of 50%."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 56-year-old Han Chinese man.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with recurrent fever for 15 years, accompanied by chilliness, fatigue, myalgia and arthralgia, with each episode lasting 10 days. He also suffered from chronic thyroiditis. There was no chest pain, abdominal pain, conjunctivitis, hearing loss or headache. Keratinized skin rashes were observed on his hands and feet, and verruca vulgaris was diagnosed.",

  "Physical Examination": "Keratinized skin rashes were observed on the patient's hands and feet.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of chronic thyroiditis. His father had interstitial lung disease and passed away at age 73 years. His mother died of myocardial infarction at age 60 years. Other family members had no similar symptoms.",

  "Initial Test Results": "During attack periods, acute phase reactants were elevated: ESR was 95.0 mm/h (normal <20.0 mm/h), CRP was 131.92 mg/l (normal <8.00 mg/l). Pro-inflammatory cytokines were also elevated: IL-6 was >1000 pg/ml (normal <5.9 pg/ml) and TNF-α was 77.6 pg/ml (normal <8.1 pg/ml). WBC count was 12.73 × 109/l (normal 3.50–9.50 × 109/l) and eosinophil count was 0.82 × 109/l (normal 0.02–0.50 × 109/l). These indicators decreased to normal levels during remission intervals. Laboratory examinations showed decreased B lymphocytes (112/μl, normal 180–324/μl), NK cells (168/μl, normal 175–567/μl) and IgG (5.59 g/l, normal 7.00–17.00 g/l). Testing for ANA and ANCA was negative."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 58-year-old male.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with pruritic skin plaques and papules on the scalp, face, back, and back of the hands that had persisted for over a year. The symptoms worsened upon exposure to sunlight and improved on cloudy and rainy days. The patient had previously sought medical help and received a diagnosis of 'eczema.' Treatment with glucocorticoid ointment and oral antihistamines provided only short-lived relief, leading to the progressive aggravation of symptoms. After diagnosis, the patient was initiated on tofacitinib at a dosage of 5 mg twice a day (bid), along with halometasone ointment and oral ebastine (20mg qd) tablets. During the first revisit (4th weeks after the first dose administration), the patient reported improved symptoms, including alleviation of itching and a decline in rash. The patient underwent subsequent revisits after one month (12th weeks after the first dose). The symptoms continued to improve steadily. By the fourth revisit (16th weeks after the first dose), the rash was almost imperceptible and pruritus was no longer prominent. The patient discontinued the use of halometasone ointment and oral ebastine tablets, while strictly adhering to sun protection measures. Follow-up for six months showed no recurrence of symptoms, and the patient continued to receive oral tofacitinib once daily.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination revealed hypertrophic and infiltrating nodules of varying sizes with significant scratches and local exudation.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of being diagnosed with 'eczema' and treated with glucocorticoid ointment and oral antihistamines, which provided only short-lived relief.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Blood tests, including routine coagulation and liver and kidney function tests, revealed no abnormalities (8th weeks after the first dose). The blood test results were within normal ranges at the subsequent revisit (12th weeks after the first dose)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is an 18-year-old woman with Russian Jewish ancestry.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with multiple erythematous, crusted, eroded papules on the dorsal aspects of the hands, as well as several lesions on the face. The lesions were painful, pruritic, nonhemorrhagic, and had been present for 1 month. Initially, the rash was thought to be consistent with impetigo, and she was prescribed mupirocin ointment. Over the next month, existing lesions partially improved but did not resolve, and she developed new lesions on the face and crusting of the eyelids. At a subsequent visit 1 month later, she continued to have round macules on the dorsal aspects of the hands and involvement of the nasal bridge. The patient had an etonogestrel implant placed 4 months prior to presentation, which was her first time on hormonal birth control. The implant was placed several weeks prior to the onset of symptoms. After removal of the etonogestrel implant, she reported substantial improvement in her cutaneous symptoms over the ensuing month, with minimal crusting and a decrease in size of lesions. She also used topical azelaic acid 10% in a cream vehicle with improvement in postinflammatory hyperpigmentation.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had round macules on the dorsal aspects of the hands and involvement of the nasal bridge.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a nonsignificant past medical history. She denied any acute porphyria symptoms, such as abdominal pain, neuropathy, nausea, or confusion. She has no known family history of porphyria and denies South African ancestry.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Punch biopsies of 2 lesions on the dorsal aspect of the hand demonstrated largely normal acral-site epidermis with superficial dermal fibrosis, reactive angioplasia, scattered foci of microhemorrhage, and sparse perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate. Direct immunofluorescence studies revealed smooth IgG, IgA (weak), immunoglobulin M (IgM) (weak), and C3 binding in the superficial vessel walls. Additionally, weak linear IgG deposition was observed along the dermoepidermal junction. Direct immunofluorescence results were compatible with a porphyria immune deposition pattern. In combination, the histologic features were consistent with reparative changes in the setting of porphyria."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is an 18-year-old woman with Russian Jewish ancestry.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with multiple erythematous, crusted, eroded papules on the dorsal aspects of the hands, as well as several lesions on the face. The lesions were painful, pruritic, nonhemorrhagic, and had been present for 1 month. Initially, the rash was thought to be consistent with impetigo, and she was prescribed mupirocin ointment. Over the next month, existing lesions partially improved but did not resolve, and she developed new lesions on the face and crusting of the eyelids. At a subsequent visit 1 month later, she continued to have round macules on the dorsal aspects of the hands and involvement of the nasal bridge. The patient had an etonogestrel implant placed 4 months prior to presentation, which was her first time on hormonal birth control. The implant was placed several weeks prior to the onset of symptoms. After removal of the etonogestrel implant, she reported substantial improvement in her cutaneous symptoms over the ensuing month, with minimal crusting and a decrease in size of lesions. She also used topical azelaic acid 10% in a cream vehicle with improvement in postinflammatory hyperpigmentation.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had round macules on the dorsal aspects of the hands and involvement of the nasal bridge.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a nonsignificant past medical history. She denied any acute porphyria symptoms, such as abdominal pain, neuropathy, nausea, or confusion. She has no known family history of porphyria and denies South African ancestry.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Punch biopsies of 2 lesions on the dorsal aspect of the hand demonstrated largely normal acral-site epidermis with superficial dermal fibrosis, reactive angioplasia, scattered foci of microhemorrhage, and sparse perivascular lymphocytic infiltrate. Direct immunofluorescence studies revealed smooth IgG, IgA (weak), immunoglobulin M (IgM) (weak), and C3 binding in the superficial vessel walls. Additionally, weak linear IgG deposition was observed along the dermoepidermal junction. Direct immunofluorescence results were compatible with a porphyria immune deposition pattern. In combination, the histologic features were consistent with reparative changes in the setting of porphyria.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Laboratory values confirmed the diagnosis of VP (Variegate Porphyria). Genetic testing with the Invitae Comprehensive Porphyrias Panel showed a heterozygous variant of uncertain significance in the PPOX gene (variant c.23T>C [p.Leu8Pro])."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 60-year-old Chinese man was admitted to the nephrology department. He had been a long-term smoker with 40 pack-years and an alcoholic, consuming about 10 units of alcohol daily for 20 years until a few weeks before his hospital admission.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was admitted due to poorly controlled hypertension and abnormal serum creatinine reported 3 weeks prior. He had been noted for slowly growing fat masses in his neck and upper trunk in the past 6 months. He denied any difficulty breathing, swallowing or speaking, and the function of his arms were not affected. Six months ago, he was commenced on perindopril, amlodipine, carvedilol, isosorbide mononitrate and febuxostat in a cardiology outpatient clinic. Following admission, his blood pressure was brought under control and his serum creatinine stabilized. The patient declined a kidney biopsy and a fine needle aspiration (FNA) of the fat mass. Without pressure symptoms from the masses, the patient also declined a lipectomy. He was subsequently discharged on losartan, atorvastatin, amlodipine, carvedilol and febuxostat, and advised to abstain from alcohol. Both the fatty masses and renal function had remained unchanged 5 months after discharge.",

  "Physical Examination": "On admission, his blood pressure was 180/108 mmHg without signs of Cushing's or lymphadenopathy. There were large tophi affecting the small joints of his hands and multiple and round subcutaneous fat masses over his upper body. MRI revealed widespread and distinct soft masses (fat density) in the subcutaneous layer of the neck region. Ultrasonography revealed excessive fat deposition in the mandible and elbows. There were also large tophi with joint destruction affecting the small joints of his hands.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had hypertension for 10 years as well as gouty arthritis affecting predominantly the small joints of his hands. There was no significant family history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "His serum urea was 13.1 mmol/l and serum creatinine was 172 μmol/l. Urine dipstick was negative for blood and protein. The urine analysis was unremarkable with no red blood cells or white blood cells. A full immunology screen was normal or negative. An ultrasound scan of the kidneys showed 9.8 cm left kidney and 10.1 cm right kidney with increased echogenicity in keeping with medical renal disease. A liver ultrasound scan indicated diffuse hepatic change consistent with alcoholic hepatic fibrosis."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A two-year six-month-old boy presented with slow growth in height and weight and developmental delay for more than two years. The boy was born to a 35-year-old mother at the gestation age of 33 weeks and 4 days by a cesarian section due to premature rupture of membranes. The neonate measured 45 cm in length and weighed 2.35 kg. Geographic location and race/ethnicity information are not specified.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The child presented with a neurodevelopmental delay, inability to sit independently, and no verbal communication; the height was 78.6 cm (−3.7 SD) and weight of 8.34 kg (−3.9 SD) at the time of first visit. Difficulty in consuming food, preference for semi-solid and liquid foods, although intake was on par with that of other children of the same age. Significant delays in cognitive, language, and motor development. The child was unable to sit or stand unassisted and did not smile until he was 2 years old. He responded to his name without using words and showed abnormal irritability, distress, and low muscle tension in all four limbs, as evidenced by his resistance to the prone position and the flexion of his two hips into a head-low-hip-high position while in the prone position. There were abnormalities in craniofacial and skin features, including a slightly wide forehead, a short face, sparse eyebrows, narrow coloboma of eyelids, and a hypertrophy and depressed bridge of the nose. The child had a long philtrum, a wide mouth, low ear position, and rough skin. The skin of the auricles, the front of the ears, and on the extended surface of the limbs felt grainy like sand.",
  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination indicated significant growth retardation compared to children of the same age, with the child’s height and weight measuring −3 SD to −4 SD. The head circumference (47 cm) and abdominal circumference (47.5 cm) fell within the normal range, which contrasted with the child’s height and weight. The Gesell developmental evaluation was as follows: Adaptability: 31 points, severe developmental delay; Gross motor: 13 points, very severe developmental delay; Fine motor: 33 points, severe developmental delay; Language: 21 points, very severe developmental delay; Individual-social: 18 points, very severe developmental delay. Peabody Motor Development Scale assessment: Gross Motor Quotient (GMQ) 45 points, <1%; Fine Motor Quotient (FMQ) 52 points, <1%; Total Motor Quotient (TMQ) 44 points, <1%. Severe neurodevelopmental delay, stereotypical behavior of regularly touching the tongue with the hands, rough skin, and an abnormal prone position.",
  "Past Medical History": "The child was initially breastfed and introduced to complementary foods at six months of age. Both parents were healthy, and the mother did not suffer from any of the conditions that put her at risk during pregnancy. No complications were seen in the neonatal period. The child’s parents took him to the hospital when he was 11 months old, where he underwent several tests.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Thyroid function, complete set of toxoplasmosis, rubella cytomegalovirus, herpes simplex, and HIV (TORCH) antibodies, fasting blood glucose, electrolytes, liver function, renal function, myocardial enzymes, blood ammonia, and phenylalanine were tested. TORCH test revealed a positive result for IgG against herpes simplex and rubella virus. Other test results, including adrenal and abdominal color Doppler ultrasounds, were normal. X-rays of both hip joints showed slightly larger collo-diaphyseal angles of the femur, and echocardiography was normal with a patent foramen ovale at birth that was closed at 6 months of age."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A head MRI showed patchy and slightly longer T2 signals in the white matter of both parietal lobes and slightly increased extra-cerebral space in both frontotemporal regions. Whole exome sequencing showed one pathogenic variant of MAP2K1 (chr15: 66436843-66436843, exon3, NM 002755.4c.389A>G:p.Y130C, missense variant). Two pathogenic variants with unclear significance were also found: ATP2B3 (chrX:153541460-153541460, exon4, NM_0010013 44.3: c.310G>A: p.E104K, missense_vari, hemizygote) and CDC42BPB (chr14: 102963 077-102963077, exon20, NM_006035.4: c.2805A>C: p.K935N, missense_vari, heterozygosis). The mutation types are missense mutation, with mutation rates of 8.38054372967718e-06 and 3.32336e-05, respectively, indicating that the clinical significance is unknown. The MAP2K1 gene validation test results of the parents were all normal."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 43-year-old male from Central South University area.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred for assessment and management of progressive trismus. His main complaints were difficulty in eating, a burning sensation when consuming spicy foods, and limited mouth opening (10 mm interincisal distance). These symptoms had been progressively worsening over the last two years but became more severe recently, with only liquid food passing with relative ease. He also experienced a change in his voice and restricted tongue movement over the past three months. The patient underwent treatment with weekly intralesional injections of salvianolic acid B combined with triamcinolone acetonide. A month later, whitening of the entire oral mucosa was observed. Three months later, a noticeable improvement in mouth opening was observed, approaching normal mouth opening (35 mm interincisal distance). The patient then sought further treatment at the hospital.",

  "Physical Examination": "Clinical examination indicated symmetry of the face and normal mouth opening. Intraoral examination revealed blanching of the throat mucosa, bilateral buccal mucosa, and palate, all presenting a hardened texture and star-like striations, along with an absent uvula. There was an enlargement at the tongue's base and a notable adhesion of the tongue's tip to the floor of the mouth, which restricted its mobility. The tongue itself was soft, well-defined, and had a dark purple hue. No signs of tenderness or numbness were detected, and no further obvious abnormalities were noted. Nasopharyngoscopy examination showed elevation of the mucosa at the base of the tongue and the absence of neoplasms in the hypopharynx.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's history included chewing betel nuts over 15 years. He denied any other significant medical or family issues.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were provided in the given information."
}"

Three months later, a noticeable improvement in mouth opening was observed, approaching normal mouth opening (35 mm interincisal distance). The patient then sought further treatment at the hospital.",

  "Physical Examination": "Clinical examination indicated symmetry of the face and normal mouth opening. Intraoral examination revealed blanching of the throat mucosa, bilateral buccal mucosa, and palate, all presenting a hardened texture and star-like striations, along with an absent uvula. There was an enlargement at the tongue's base and a notable adhesion of the tongue's tip to the floor of the mouth, which restricted its mobility. The tongue itself was soft, well-defined, and had a dark purple hue. No signs of tenderness or numbness were detected, and no further obvious abnormalities were noted. Nasopharyngoscopy examination showed elevation of the mucosa at the base of the tongue and the absence of neoplasms in the hypopharynx.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's history included chewing betel nuts over 15 years. He denied any other significant medical or family issues.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were provided in the given information.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) revealed thickening of the nasopharyngeal mucosa and abnormal signals on the right side at the base of the tongue, with unclear cause. A surgical intervention was performed under general anesthesia to resect the submucous oropharyngeal stenosis. During surgery, it was observed that the mucosa connected the anterior pillars, the base of the tongue, and the soft palate, creating a narrow, circular oropharyngeal opening of 0.5 cm in diameter. The patient underwent surgery similar to Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty, which involved several steps including incisions, separation of oral and nasal layers, excision of the submucous oropharyngeal stenosis, muscle dissection, reconstruction of uvula and arches, partial tonsillectomy, and suturing. Postoperatively, the patient had a satisfactory result."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 17-year-old female of Russian descent. Her height is 167 cm and body weight is 62 kg.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient's chief complaint is proximal muscle weakness from early childhood. She had motor development delay, holding her head from 7 months, sitting from 16 months, and walking from 21 months of age. She always required support to stand up. In early childhood, her mouth was slightly open in a vertical position. Phrasal speech developed by age. From 9-10 years, she developed prominent scoliotic deformity of the spine. Conservative treatment of scoliosis was carried out at 12-14 years. At 12, she underwent surgery for ankle tendon retraction without general anesthesia. In recent years, her condition has worsened, with marked gait disturbances, difficulties climbing stairs, and inability to rise from the floor by herself. Her cognitive functions are normal, and she is currently studying at university. The patient shows kyphoscoliosis of the thoracic spine and lumbar hyperlordosis, leading to a prominent asymmetric hip position. She has pes cavus on both sides.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient exhibits micrognathia with downturned corners of the mouth and clinodactyly of the fifth finger of the right hand. Neurological examination revealed atrophy of the pectoral muscles, proximal muscles, weakness of facial, neck, and limb-girdle muscles, positive Gowers' sign, and asymmetric Trendelenburg's gait. Leg tendon reflexes were absent, while biceps and triceps reflexes were normal.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient is the second child of healthy nonconsanguineous Russian parents. Pregnancy and delivery were unremarkable. Birth weight was 3.80 kg and length was 52 cm. On the third day of life, she was hospitalized with pneumonia due to aspiration, requiring mechanical ventilation until 4.5 months of age. This was the only episode of respiratory dysfunction in her life. There is no history of seizures. Vision and hearing are preserved.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Creatine kinase values were normal. Needle electromyography detected a myopathic pattern, and spontaneous activity was absent."
}"

Validation and segregation analyses confirmed compound heterozygosity of these SNVs in the patient. Each parent is a carrier of one variant, and the healthy brother is a carrier of the heterozygous variant c.862A>T, p.(Lys288Ter)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is an 11-year-old boy from Brazil. He was referred to the Dental Clinic of the University Hospital of Brasília.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with 'poor tooth formation and absence of one of the upper central incisors.' He has holoprosencephaly (HPE), hearing loss requiring a hearing aid, hypernatremia, psychomotor developmental delay, moderate mental retardation, irritability, and difficulty with urinary sphincter control. The patient is currently taking antipsychotic medication (periciazine) and psychotropic medication (methylphenidate hydrochloride). His parents report that he attends school and has shown progressive improvement in psychomotor development and language. His diet is described as healthy.",

  "Physical Examination": "Extraoral examination revealed correct proportion of facial thirds, slightly deficient zygomatic projection, right and left ear shells lateralization, prominent ears, an extra tubercle at the top of the left ear, left converging right eye strabismus, bilateral epicantal folds, and a broad nasal bridge. Lateral analysis showed a straight profile, suitable chin-neckline, and a closed nasolabial angle. The patient has bilateral ectrodactyly in hands and feet. The right hand is missing the third finger entirely. The left hand has all fingers but shows malformation of the distal phalanges of fingers three and four. Both feet are missing fingers two, three, and four completely.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's mother had a previous miscarriage at 2 months of gestation. The patient's intrauterine development was normal until the 7th month when cerebral malformations were observed via ultrasound. He was born by cesarean delivery at 38 weeks and spent 4 days in pediatric intensive care due to respiratory problems. At 2 years old, he was diagnosed with a specific condition (XXX). At 5 years old, he underwent cryptorchidism correction surgery.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Cone beam computed tomography (CBCT) identified 13 dental ageneses, including the upper central incisor (eight or nine), upper first premolars (5 and 12), upper and lower second premolars (4, 13, 20, and 29), lower second molars (31 and 18), and upper and lower third molars (1, 16, 17, and 32), characterizing oligodontia."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Genetic mapping was performed at the International Center for Neuroscience and Rehabilitation (SARAH Network of Rehabilitation Hospitals, Brasília, Brazil). CBCT images showed the position of the permanent lower canines in buccally displaced. The single median maxillary central incisor (SMMCI) was positioned practically in the midpalatal raphe, equidistant from the right and left upper lateral incisors. The shape of the SMMCI made it difficult to determine whether it was tooth eight or nine, with very similar mesiobuccal and distovestibular angles and a malformation in the middle of the incisal (invagination of the incisal enamel). Tomography images also showed the position of the upper canines in lingual displacement."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 35-year-old woman with a height of 152 cm and weight of 117 kg. She is wheelchair-bound due to paraplegia.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the Emergency Department (ED) for severe anemia discovered on laboratory testing completed by her primary care physician. She complained of marked weakness, fatigue, and lightheadedness for 3 days. She denied recent history of heavy menstrual periods, hematochezia, melena, hematuria, or easy bruising. She also denied constitutional symptoms of fevers, chills, or unintentional weight loss. The patient had presented to the hospital several times in the past 3 years for anemia and required multiple blood transfusions, without diagnosis. Outpatient testing over the last 3 years had been nondiagnostic. During hospitalization, she reported blood in her stool, and a repeat hemoccult test was positive. She underwent bidirectional endoscopy with no evidence of active bleeding but with evidence of hemorrhoids. Her transient blood in her stool was suspected to be secondary to hemorrhoids. She required a total of 5 units of packed red blood cells over a 2-week period before maintaining a stable hemoglobin level for discharge. Following discharge, she required outpatient packed red blood cell transfusions every other week and iron chelation. Steroids were started after genetic testing identified XXX, but there was no clinical response and these were discontinued.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient's vital signs were within normal limits. She appeared fatigued but in no acute distress. She was noted to have wide-set eyes, moon facies, and paraplegia. Her hands were free of any gross structural abnormalities, including thenar atrophy or hypoplastic thumbs.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's past medical history was significant for spina bifida with paraplegia, bladder reconstruction requiring suprapubic self-catheterization, and morbid obesity. She denied any family history of anemia, blood disorders, or malignancies. A bone marrow biopsy performed 4 months prior to admission displayed a normocellular marrow with erythroid hypoplasia.",

  "Initial Test Results": "A complete blood count revealed a hemoglobin level of 5.9 g/dL and a mean corpuscular volume 107 fL. Her reticulocyte count was 3.1%. A peripheral blood smear demonstrated a markedly decreased number of red blood cells, with hyperchromic and macrocytic red blood cells. Anisocytosis and poikilocytosis were markedly increased, including reticulocytes and spherocytes. Polychromasia was mildly increased. The white blood cell and platelet counts were normal; no blasts were identified. Hemoglobin electrophoresis was normal, with hemoglobin A1 accounting for 96% of her red cell line, hemoglobin A2 accounting for 2.8%, and hemoglobin F accounting for 0.6%. Iron studies revealed a normal serum iron level and total iron-binding capacity, but elevated ferritin (461 ng/mL) and transferrin saturation (70%). Lactate dehydrogenase, haptoglobin, vitamin B12, and folate levels were within normal limits. The erythropoietin level was 1437 mIU/mL (range, 2.6–18.5 mIU/mL) and the adenosine deaminase (ADA) level was elevated at 2200 mU/G Hg (range, 400–900 mU/G Hg). A stool hemoccult test was negative on admission but positive a few days into hospitalization. A transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrated normal structure and function."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 35-year-old woman with a height of 152 cm and weight of 117 kg. She is wheelchair-bound due to paraplegia.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the Emergency Department (ED) for severe anemia discovered on laboratory testing completed by her primary care physician. She complained of marked weakness, fatigue, and lightheadedness for 3 days. She denied recent history of heavy menstrual periods, hematochezia, melena, hematuria, or easy bruising. She also denied constitutional symptoms of fevers, chills, or unintentional weight loss. The patient had presented to the hospital several times in the past 3 years for anemia and required multiple blood transfusions, without diagnosis. Outpatient testing over the last 3 years had been nondiagnostic. During hospitalization, she reported blood in her stool, and a repeat hemoccult test was positive. She underwent bidirectional endoscopy with no evidence of active bleeding but with evidence of hemorrhoids. Her transient blood in her stool was suspected to be secondary to hemorrhoids. She required a total of 5 units of packed red blood cells over a 2-week period before maintaining a stable hemoglobin level for discharge. Following discharge, she required outpatient packed red blood cell transfusions every other week and iron chelation. Steroids were started after genetic testing identified XXX, but there was no clinical response and these were discontinued.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient's vital signs were within normal limits. She appeared fatigued but in no acute distress. She was noted to have wide-set eyes, moon facies, and paraplegia. Her hands were free of any gross structural abnormalities, including thenar atrophy or hypoplastic thumbs.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's past medical history was significant for spina bifida with paraplegia, bladder reconstruction requiring suprapubic self-catheterization, and morbid obesity. She denied any family history of anemia, blood disorders, or malignancies. A bone marrow biopsy performed 4 months prior to admission displayed a normocellular marrow with erythroid hypoplasia.",

  "Initial Test Results": "A complete blood count revealed a hemoglobin level of 5.9 g/dL and a mean corpuscular volume 107 fL. Her reticulocyte count was 3.1%. A peripheral blood smear demonstrated a markedly decreased number of red blood cells, with hyperchromic and macrocytic red blood cells. Anisocytosis and poikilocytosis were markedly increased, including reticulocytes and spherocytes. Polychromasia was mildly increased. The white blood cell and platelet counts were normal; no blasts were identified. Hemoglobin electrophoresis was normal, with hemoglobin A1 accounting for 96% of her red cell line, hemoglobin A2 accounting for 2.8%, and hemoglobin F accounting for 0.6%. Iron studies revealed a normal serum iron level and total iron-binding capacity, but elevated ferritin (461 ng/mL) and transferrin saturation (70%). Lactate dehydrogenase, haptoglobin, vitamin B12, and folate levels were within normal limits. The erythropoietin level was 1437 mIU/mL (range, 2.6–18.5 mIU/mL) and the adenosine deaminase (ADA) level was elevated at 2200 mU/G Hg (range, 400–900 mU/G Hg). A stool hemoccult test was negative on admission but positive a few days into hospitalization. A transthoracic echocardiogram demonstrated normal structure and function.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A computed tomography scan of the chest/abdomen/pelvis did not reveal any signs of hematoma or adenopathy and demonstrated normal thymus and spleen. Parvovirus B19 IgG testing was positive; however, subsequent quantitative viral polymerase chain reaction testing was negative. Genetic testing revealed a pathogenic variant in RPL11 c. 158-2_158-1 del AG ins CC, consistent with XXX."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 28-year-old Caucasian woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 26 weeks and 1 day of gestation. Her child is a premature Caucasian boy born at 27 weeks and 2 days of gestation.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The woman was admitted to the emergency ward due to progressive dyspnea caused by SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia with the Alpha variant (B.1.1.7). Despite conventional therapy, she experienced increasing respiratory failure, necessitating a primary cesarean section. The child was born prematurely with Apgar scores of 3, 5, and 6 at 1, 5, and 10 minutes, respectively. The boy required mechanical ventilation due to prematurity, respiratory insufficiency, recurrent bradycardia, and infant respiratory distress syndrome. He was extubated on the 4th day of life. The child's clinical status stabilized, and he was discharged from the intensive care unit six weeks after birth. The mother, unfortunately, died 7 weeks after giving birth, despite maximum intensive care including extracorporeal membrane oxygenation for 6 weeks.",

  "Physical Examination": "The child's first clinical examination after admission to the neonatal intensive care unit revealed no congenital malformations, except for a secundum type atrial septal defect. The body temperature was initially elevated (38.0 °C). Growth indices were below average with a birth weight of 980 g (10th–50th percentile), a head circumference of 25 cm (10th–50th percentile), and a length of 36 cm (10th–50th percentile). Cerebral ultrasound, ophthalmological, and neurological examinations of the premature child were without any pathological findings. At 11 weeks after birth, despite pathologic CSF results, neither cerebral ultrasound nor magnetic resonance tomography (MRT) imaging indicated any cerebral abnormalities, and no ophthalmological or clinical neurological manifestations were detected.",

  "Past Medical History": "The woman had no relevant past medical history. The child had no significant past medical history other than the complications related to premature birth.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The child's inflammatory parameters remained normal with C-reactive protein (CRP) levels < 0.4 mg/dl. SARS-CoV-2 RNA was not detected in sequential respiratory and stool samples. SARS-CoV-2 IgM was not detected in a serum sample collected on the 3rd day of life, while SARS-CoV-2 antinucleocapside IgG was positive. An umbilical blood sample revealed a weak positive result for the E-gene target (cycle threshold value 36.83) and a negative result for the ORF-region target. Initial Toxoplasma serology in the child showed a low IgG titer, while IgM and IgA tested negative. The competition test in a serum sample 1 week later was weakly positive, whereas selective screening for IgG, IgM, and IgA antibodies against T. gondii remained negative. A T. gondii-specific PCR from neonatal EDTA blood was negative. A follow-up serum sample 4 weeks after birth showed no significant serological changes."
}"

  "Past Medical History": "The woman had no relevant past medical history. The child had no significant past medical history other than the complications related to premature birth.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The child's inflammatory parameters remained normal with C-reactive protein (CRP) levels < 0.4 mg/dl. SARS-CoV-2 RNA was not detected in sequential respiratory and stool samples. SARS-CoV-2 IgM was not detected in a serum sample collected on the 3rd day of life, while SARS-CoV-2 antinucleocapside IgG was positive. An umbilical blood sample revealed a weak positive result for the E-gene target (cycle threshold value 36.83) and a negative result for the ORF-region target. Initial Toxoplasma serology in the child showed a low IgG titer, while IgM and IgA tested negative. The competition test in a serum sample 1 week later was weakly positive, whereas selective screening for IgG, IgM, and IgA antibodies against T. gondii remained negative. A T. gondii-specific PCR from neonatal EDTA blood was negative. A follow-up serum sample 4 weeks after birth showed no significant serological changes.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Postpartum maternal infection screening revealed a previously unknown T. gondii infection in the mother. Maternal serology indicated a primary infection during pregnancy, with proof of Toxoplasma-specific IgM antibodies and increasing titers of specific IgA and IgG antibodies. The IgG avidity was low (index 0.036). A PCR from maternal EDTA blood was negative. At 11 weeks after birth, significant serological changes in the child's serum were detected, with all Toxoplasma-specific antibody classes clearly positive. A significant increase of T. gondii-specific IgG antibody titers was observed (1:128 versus 1:2048). The IgG immunoblot profile indicated independent IgG synthesis by the child. Immunoblots for IgA and IgM antibodies against T. gondii were negative, but IgA was confirmed to be positive by ISAGA. A neonatal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) sample revealed a positive T. gondii-PCR result, and serum/liquor comparison blots for IgG indicated intrathecal IgG synthesis. CSF white blood cell count was 5/µl, glucose was 45 mg/dl, and protein was 1315 mg/l. At 29 weeks after birth, serum control showed slightly descending IgG titers and absence of IgA. Thirteen weeks after stopping sulfadiazine treatment, a significant increase in IgG titers (1:1024 versus 1:8192) and occurrence of IgA were observed."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 55-year-old man with a 20-year history of Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) complicated by lupus cerebritis and anti-phospholipid syndrome.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented to the clinic with a worsening eruption of innumerable pink-tan colored papules on his face, neck, upper portion of the chest, and upper portion of the back. He reported that these lesions had developed almost 20 years ago but had been rapidly increasing in number and severity over the past 3 years. The patient believed that the sebaceous neoplastic growth began soon after the resolution of his Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS), which he developed in 1996, possibly in response to therapy for SLE. Although the lesions were generally asymptomatic, he reported associated pain and discomfort coinciding with rapid lesion size increase when prednisone dosing was escalated. The patient denied any constitutional or gastrointestinal symptoms that would be concerning for occult internal malignancy. Treatment with XXX 50 mg daily (∼0.5 mg/kg) was initiated for the first month, then increased to 100 mg daily (∼1.0 mg/kg) after the first month (cumulative dose, 95 mg/kg). Within the first month of XXX therapy, his examination showed visible improvement with a smaller number of yellowish papules and significant flattening of the lesions. Further improvement was observed after the XXX dose was increased and immunosuppressive doses decreased. The patient is now on month 8 of XXX therapy at 100 mg daily, with plans to continue this dose for another 4 to 6 months until optimal clearance is achieved, with a possible lower maintenance dose if needed.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient presented with innumerable pink-tan colored papules on his face, neck, upper portion of the chest, and upper portion of the back.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a 20-year history of SLE complicated by lupus cerebritis and anti-phospholipid syndrome. He developed Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) in 1996, possibly in response to therapy for SLE. His long-standing medication list included azathioprine 200 mg daily, methotrexate 15 mg weekly, rituximab 2 g every 6 months, and prednisone 7 mg daily. The patient's family history was noncontributory, with no family history of colorectal cancer, hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer, or other familial cancer syndromes. He had a normal colonoscopy within the past 12 months.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The patient had 3 facial biopsies performed on both cheeks that were found to be consistent with sebaceous adenoma. Immunohistochemical staining showed intact expression of MutL homolog 1 gene and MutS homolog 2/6 genes."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male infant born vaginally at full term at 38 weeks of gestation with a birth weight of 2.3 kg. He is from a rural area.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was discharged from the hospital 4 days after birth. At home, his crying and feeding were normal, and his skin color was normal without rash or bleeding spots. He was hospitalized due to a 'respiratory tract infection' on the 16th day after birth. Hearing screening otoacoustic emissions failed in both ears, and a follow-up visit at 3 months of age confirmed the presence of hearing impairment. The patient was detected positive for XXX IgM antibody twice in the neonatal period. On the 23rd day after birth, throat swabs, urine, and tears were collected from the child, and RV nucleic acid was detected by reverse transcriptase polymerase chain reaction. The results were all negative. On the same day, the sera of parents were collected to test for XXX IgM antibodies, and the results were all negative.",

  "Physical Examination": "Physical examination on admission showed a body temperature of 37.4°C. The crying sound was loud, the skin color was rosy, the anterior fontanel was flat and soft, and the three concave signs were not present. The breath sounds in both lungs were clear and symmetrical, and no rales were heard. The heart rhythm was regular, the heart sounds were moderate, and no pathological murmur was heard. The abdomen was soft, the umbilicus was dry, and the liver and spleen were not abnormally enlarged below the ribs. The distal limbs were warm. The capillary refill time was <3 seconds and no mottling was seen.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no history of resuscitation for asphyxia and had an Apgar score of 10 points at 10 minutes. The mother is a 24-year-old rural woman with a history of immunization against hepatitis B vaccine, Bacille Calmette-Guerin vaccine, Diphtheria, and tetanus toxoid with whole cell pertussis vaccine, measles vaccine, and Meningococcal polysaccharide vaccine. She had not received XXX-containing vaccines (RCV), had no history of fever and rash during pregnancy, and had no contact with XXX patients. The prenatal examination was unremarkable and negative for Syphilis tolulized red unheated serum test and Human Immunodeficiency Virus.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Routine blood count: white blood cell count 12.9 × 10⁹/L, lymphocyte percentage 59.2%, monocyte percentage 13.1%, and neutrophil percentage 22.1%. The hemoglobin was 142 g/L, the red blood cell count was 4.35 × 10¹²/L, and the platelet count was 556 × 10⁹/L. Coagulation function, thyroid function routine, and blood biochemistry tests were normal. The results of two serum collections to detect XXX IgM and immunoglobulin G (IgG) antibodies were respectively: IgM① 5.010Index, IgG① 45.60IU/mL; IgM②4.440Index, IgG②39.20IU/mL. Cytomegalovirus IgM antibody was negative. Color Doppler ultrasonography of the heart in a newborn infant showed a patent foramen ovale and a small atrial septal defect. The pediatric head color ultrasound and abdominal color ultrasound showed no obvious abnormalities, the liver, spleen, and kidneys showed no obvious abnormalities, and the cardiopulmonary diaphragm showed no abnormal X-ray signs."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "Female child, 1st child, 1st delivery, 41 weeks + 1 full term, normal delivery, clear amniotic fluid, Apgar score: 9 at 1 min (skin-1), 9 at 5 min (skin-1), 8 at 10 min (skin-1, respiratory-1), birth weight at 3550g, geographic location not mentioned.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The neonate had a prenatal presentation of fetal non-immune edema and pleural effusion identified at 30 weeks of gestation. She developed progressive dyspnea and persistent pulmonary hypertension after birth. The breathing rate was 60 times/min, oxygen saturation was 92% in ambient air, with inspiratory depression and moaning. Respiratory sounds in both lungs were coarse, and she had no dry or wet rales on auscultation. The child received nitric oxide and lung surface-active substances administered endotracheally, mechanical ventilation respiratory support, and closed chest drainage. Despite treatments, the neonate developed 'white lung' on chest radiograph stated by marked decrease in the translucency of both lungs with significant bilateral pleural effusions (more prominent on the right side). Unfortunately, she died 1.5 hours after birth due to 'skin cyanosis and progressive respiratory failure'.",
  "Physical Examination": "At birth, the heart rate was 130 beats/min, the heart rhythm was uniform, and no murmurs were heard. The liver was 4 cm below the right rib, 5 cm below the saber, and 4 cm below the left rib, with mild edema of the skin.",
  "Past Medical History": "The medical history prior to birth includes fetal pleural effusion detected at 30 weeks of gestation. There were no structural heart defects found on echocardiography. No umbilical cord or placental abnormalities were noted.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Apgar scores were 9 at 1 minute (skin-1), 9 at 5 minutes (skin-1), and 8 at 10 minutes (skin-1, respiratory-1). Chest radiograph showed 'white lung' with a marked decrease in translucency of both lungs and significant bilateral pleural effusions. Blood biochemistry revealed severe hypoproteinemia (22.0 g/L)."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male newborn, born via cesarean section at 31 weeks and 4 days of gestation. His birth weight was 1820 g (64th percentile), length was 42 cm (59th percentile), and head circumference was 29 cm (50th percentile). The mother was 32 years old and had undergone prenatal in vitro fertilization and embryo transfer for ovarian cysts.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The newborn was delivered due to intrauterine distress and presented with limp tone and poor respiratory effort. Apgar scores at 1 min, 5 min, and 10 min were 7, 10, and 10, respectively. He was transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit due to respiratory distress. The condition worsened, requiring intubation at 7 hours after birth due to increased dyspnea, hypotonia, decreased responsiveness, and decreased blood pressure. The infant underwent two failed extubation attempts until 21 days after birth. He experienced two episodes of pneumonia. At 36 weeks postmenstrual age (PMA), the patient was still dependent on non-invasive intermittent positive pressure ventilation with FIO2 of 0.3. The infant did not begin sucking until 40 weeks PMA and had a generally weaker suck. On day 91 after birth (44 weeks and 4 days PMA), the infant was discharged from the hospital, requiring further oxygen therapy and partial nasal feeding at home. Post-discharge, the patient underwent atrial septal defect (ASD) repair and patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) ligation. At 4 months PMA, the infant was fed normally. At 10 months PMA, the patient shows overgrowth, delayed language and motor development, and still requires overnight oxygen due to left bronchial stenosis.",

  "Physical Examination": "The newborn had a limp tone and poor respiratory effort on delivery. Changes in appearance were noted, including forehead protrusion, pointed chin, widening eye distance, wide-set down-slanting eyes, high arched palate, skin relaxation, and pigmentation.",

  "Past Medical History": "Prenatal ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) showed ventricular widening and polyhydramnios. Prenatal amniocentesis showed no karyotype or chromosomal abnormalities. The mother developed hypertension during pregnancy.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Blood gas analysis indicated severe respiratory failure. Complete blood count was normal and blood culture was negative. Echocardiography (ECHO) suggested the presence of a large patent ductus arteriosus (PDA) and pulmonary hypertension. Subsequent ECHO confirmed the presence of an atrial septal defect. No ureaplasma urealyticum, virus, or bacteria were found in the etiological examination of the sputum. Bedside ECHO revealed an atrial septal defect (ASD) with a diameter of 5 mm and a left-to-right shunt; no ductus arteriosus flow was detected at 6 days after birth. Lung ultrasound showed pulmonary edema and exudative inflammation in bilateral lung fields."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 14-year-old male child from an unidentified location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The child presented with episodic cough for the past four days, which was spasmodic in nature and associated with breathlessness. These episodes lasted for 2-4 minutes. There was no history of similar episodes in the past. Treatment for the lower respiratory tract infection consisted of a three-day course of oral clarithromycin and syrup of chlorpheniramine maleate. The child and their parents were counseled regarding the condition and the potential risks of developing symptoms due to vertebrobasilar insufficiency, such as dizziness, vertigo, syncope, ataxia, sensory disturbances, and dysarthria. Additionally, they were informed about symptoms related to reduced blood flow in the arm, such as weakness, sensory disturbances, tingling, and numbness. Following the antibiotic course, the child remained clinically stable. Surgical management, including bypass grafting between the left common carotid and left subclavian artery, was recommended. However, since the child did not exhibit severe symptoms at the time, both the child and his parents were not willing to proceed with surgical intervention. The child is currently under close follow-up.",
  "Physical Examination": "On general physical examination, the pulse rate was normal, and the blood pressure measured in the right arm was 110/74 mmHg. On respiratory examination, the child was observed to have tachypnea and rhonchi in the right lung fields. The rest of the examination, including systemic examination of the cardiovascular system, was unremarkable. Upon re-evaluation, it was noted that the left radial pulse was feeble compared to the right, and the blood pressure in the left arm was 80/60 mmHg, while it was 110/74 mmHg in the right arm.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no history of similar episodes in the past. No significant family medical history was provided.",
  "Initial Test Results": "A chest radiograph revealed the absence of an aortic knuckle on the left side of the mediastinum, and the right border of the descending thoracic aorta was noted on the right side of the spine. Ultrasound of the neck was performed using a high-frequency linear probe to assess flow in the vertebral arteries. The right vertebral artery was prominent with high-velocity, low-resistance flow on the Doppler study, whereas the left vertebral artery showed flow reversal with a high-resistance waveform."
}"

"{
  "Basic Information": "A 14-year-old male child from an unidentified location.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The child presented with episodic cough for the past four days, which was spasmodic in nature and associated with breathlessness. These episodes lasted for 2-4 minutes. There was no history of similar episodes in the past. Treatment for the lower respiratory tract infection consisted of a three-day course of oral clarithromycin and syrup of chlorpheniramine maleate. The child and their parents were counseled regarding the condition and the potential risks of developing symptoms due to vertebrobasilar insufficiency, such as dizziness, vertigo, syncope, ataxia, sensory disturbances, and dysarthria. Additionally, they were informed about symptoms related to reduced blood flow in the arm, such as weakness, sensory disturbances, tingling, and numbness. Following the antibiotic course, the child remained clinically stable. Surgical management, including bypass grafting between the left common carotid and left subclavian artery, was recommended. However, since the child did not exhibit severe symptoms at the time, both the child and his parents were not willing to proceed with surgical intervention. The child is currently under close follow-up.",
  "Physical Examination": "On general physical examination, the pulse rate was normal, and the blood pressure measured in the right arm was 110/74 mmHg. On respiratory examination, the child was observed to have tachypnea and rhonchi in the right lung fields. The rest of the examination, including systemic examination of the cardiovascular system, was unremarkable. Upon re-evaluation, it was noted that the left radial pulse was feeble compared to the right, and the blood pressure in the left arm was 80/60 mmHg, while it was 110/74 mmHg in the right arm.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no history of similar episodes in the past. No significant family medical history was provided.",
  "Initial Test Results": "A chest radiograph revealed the absence of an aortic knuckle on the left side of the mediastinum, and the right border of the descending thoracic aorta was noted on the right side of the spine. Ultrasound of the neck was performed using a high-frequency linear probe to assess flow in the vertebral arteries. The right vertebral artery was prominent with high-velocity, low-resistance flow on the Doppler study, whereas the left vertebral artery showed flow reversal with a high-resistance waveform.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A computed tomography (CT) thoracic angiogram revealed a right-sided aorta giving three branches: the left common carotid, the right common carotid, and the right subclavian. The left subclavian artery was not visualized in the mediastinum, communicating with a small-caliber left vertebral artery at the level of the first thoracic vertebra with normal contrast opacification noted distal to it. A right-sided tracheal bronchus was noted arising just above the carina. The right main bronchus was compressed between the right-sided descending thoracic aorta and the right pulmonary artery, with an anteroposterior diameter of 4mm. Additionally, a patchy area of consolidation was observed in the medial basal segment of the right lower lobe. Time-of-flight magnetic resonance angiography (TOF-MRA) of neck vessels revealed the absence of flow-related enhancement in the left vertebral artery, likely due to flow reversal. Upon repeating TOF-MRA with the saturation bands removed, flow enhancement was noted in the left vertebral artery joining the left subclavian artery, with no flow enhancement in the subclavian artery proximal to the joining of the vertebral artery. Echocardiography yielded unremarkable results."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 14-month-old girl born at 35 weeks gestational age. She is from Korea.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient visited the hospital with fixed dilated pupils discovered during a neonatal ophthalmic examination. She could fix and follow an object with both eyes, and the Bruckner test was normal. Her pupils were 6 mm and nonreactive to light and 0.125% pilocarpine eye drops. Ophthalmologic examination showed the absence of an iris between the collarette and pupillary border, creating a scalloped pupillary margin. Fundus examination showed arteriolar tortuosity in both eyes. Anterior optical coherence tomography revealed undevelopment of insufficient growth of the iris sphincter and dilator muscles.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient's pupils were 6 mm and nonreactive to light and 0.125% pilocarpine eye drops. Ophthalmologic examination revealed the absence of an iris between the collarette and pupillary border, creating a scalloped pupillary margin. Fundus examination showed arteriolar tortuosity in both eyes.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had an unremarkable antenatal history. Patent ductus arteriosus and ventricular septal defect were surgically repaired before the age of 1 year. She had a developmental delay due to a history of severe bronchopulmonary dysplasia.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Anterior optical coherence tomography revealed undevelopment of insufficient growth of the iris sphincter and dilator muscles. Ultrasonography for the kidney showed normal size, shape, and echotexture of both kidneys."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Magnetic resonance imaging of the brain revealed periventricular white matter hyperintensities in T2 image and tortuous cortical veins. The genetic test was conducted using target panel sequencing and confirmed through Sanger sequencing. Parental testing was performed, but no genetic abnormalities were found."

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 70-year-old Asian male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with intermittent rectal bleeding lasting for 2 months. He had undergone a six-month course of androgen deprivation therapy with Goserelin injections, followed by primary radiotherapy using TomoTherapy, delivering a total dose of 76 Gy in 38 fractions after one month of neoadjuvant hormone therapy for prostate cancer. His PSA levels reached a nadir of 0.2 ng/mL and remained stable for 10 months post-radiotherapy until the onset of intermittent rectal bleeding. Initial conservative management with oral mesalamine, mesalamine enema and hydrocortisone enema was administered for two months, providing temporary relief, but rectal urgency, and intermittent small amounts of rectal bleeding, persisted. He received treatment with a novel enema formulation, applying 2% M-B (metformin and sodium butyrate) daily in a total of 60 ml per enema treatment. The M-B suppository, comprising 2.0% metformin and sodium butyrate, was coated with cocoa butter and molded into 2.5 Gm suppositories. His bloody stools improved within one week of starting this treatment. He continued maintenance therapy for an additional three weeks, resulting in significant clinical improvement, with cessation of rectal bleeding and only mild remaining proctitis symptoms (grade 1).",

  "Physical Examination": "Vital signs were stable. The physical examination was unremarkable, aside from the presence of fresh blood during digital examination.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had type 2 diabetes and hypertension on regular medicine with metformin 500 mg twice daily and amlodipine / valsartan 5/160 mg daily. He had a history of benign prostatic hypertrophy with rising PSA levels up to 11.9 ng/mL. He underwent Diode Laser enucleation to address low urinary obstruction symptoms. A trans-rectal needle biopsy reported prostate adenocarcinoma involving bilateral lobes. The Gleason score was 4 + 3 on the left side and 3 + 4 on the right side, with a clinical stage of cT2cN0.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory findings indicated elevated fasting plasma glucose and HbA1c levels consistent with diabetes. Hemoglobin, white blood cell count, platelets, and liver function tests were all within normal ranges. PSA levels remained at 0.2 ng/mL."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 26-year-old gravida 2 (G2P1L1) mother at 29 weeks + 2 days of gestation. The pregnancy resulted from a spontaneous conception.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with severe and persistent antepartum hemorrhage. The cause of antenatal hemorrhage was ascertained to be grade 4 placenta praevia. The patient had only one antenatal visit in the second trimester and did not receive any supplements or recommended vaccines. She did not receive antenatal corticosteroids or magnesium sulphate prior to the delivery. The neonate was delivered by an emergency lower-segment caesarean section and did not cry at birth. Adequate resuscitative measures were taken, and the baby was intubated in view of absent respiratory efforts. Apgar scores were 3 and 4 at one and five minutes of life, respectively. The baby had no spontaneous efforts and required 100% FiO2 on mechanical ventilation and a peak inspiratory pressure of 20 cm H2O with a positive end-expiratory pressure of 5 cm of H2O on the assist control mode of mechanical ventilation. The parents made an informed decision to not escalate treatment and not resuscitate the baby if needed again. The neonate went into bradycardia and later expired after three hours of life.",

  "Physical Examination": "The birth weight of the neonate was documented to be 1,091 grams. On clinical examination, the baby had multiple dysmorphic features. There was microcephaly, hypertelorism, complete cleft lip and palate, low-set ears, finger contractures bilaterally, oligosyndactyly in bilateral lower limbs and a two-vessel umbilical cord. A pansystolic murmur was auscultated at the apex.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient was on a daily phenytoin dose of 300 mg, in three divided doses, for the last three years. The medication was started in view of persistent seizures during the post-partum period of her previous pregnancy three years ago. The patient did not have any antenatal visits in the first trimester and had no fever, rash, or teratogen exposure besides daily phenytoin. There was no antenatal workup to rule out any high-risk factors or ultrasonography. There was no other significant medical history.",

  "Initial Test Results": "No initial test results were mentioned in the provided information."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 38-year-old male of Indian ethnicity.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient reportedly consumed 250 ml of brake oil containing ethylene glycol in a suicidal attempt at his residence. Three days later, the patient developed abdominal pain, vomiting, and reduced urine output. It was not until the fifth day that the patient disclosed his ingestion to family members, prompting his admission to the emergency room. The patient received immediate treatment with an intravenous bolus dose of fomepizole (1 g), thiamine (200 mg), and pyridoxine (50 mg). The subsequent monitoring revealed no improvement in urine output over the following three hours, prompting the initiation of urgent hemodialysis. Continuous treatment involved maintenance doses of fomepizole (650 mg every six hours), oral vitamin supplements, and daily hemodialysis for the first two cycles, transitioning to alternate-day hemodialysis thereafter. The patient remained anuric until day five of hospitalization, with a peak creatinine level of 12.3 mg/dl, before gradually showing signs of improvement in both renal function and urine output. On day 10 of hospitalization, the patient complained of difficulty closing both his eyes. On examination, the patient had weakness in eye closure, loss of nasolabial folds, and an inability to smile. The remainder of the neurological examination was within normal limits. A diagnosis of bilateral lower motor neuron-type facial nerve palsy was made. On day 13 of hospitalization, the patient complained of dizziness, difficulty hearing, and difficulty maintaining balance. Subsequent physical examination showed signs suggestive of cerebellar impairment, including dysdiadochokinesia, impaired finger-nose test, impaired heel-shin, and tandem walking, but no dysarthria. The examination also showed signs of vestibulocochlear nerve impairment. The patient was managed conservatively for his neurological symptoms with physiotherapy and programmed exercise. Following the completion of 14 cycles of hemodialysis, the patient was discharged on day 38 of hospitalization. Over the subsequent three months, gradual neurological improvement led to a complete recovery. Creatinine levels stabilized at a baseline of 3.2 mg/dl, managed conservatively.",
  "Physical Examination": "During the initial evaluation, the patient appeared conscious and cooperative, albeit with signs of physiological distress: tachycardia (106/min), tachypnea (26/min), normal oxygen saturation (99% in room air), blood pressure of 144/84 mmHg, and capillary blood glucose level of 106 mg/dl. A comprehensive systemic examination revealed no overt abnormalities. On day 10 of hospitalization, the patient had weakness in eye closure, loss of nasolabial folds, and an inability to smile. On day 13 of hospitalization, physical examination showed signs suggestive of cerebellar impairment, including dysdiadochokinesia, impaired finger-nose test, impaired heel-shin, and tandem walking, but no dysarthria. The examination also showed signs of vestibulocochlear nerve impairment.",
  "Past Medical History": "No past medical history or relevant family history was mentioned.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory investigations unveiled significant findings, including a high anion gap, metabolic acidosis, acute kidney injury, mild hyponatremia, transaminitis, and a normal serum osmolal gap. Urine screens for common toxins, including paracetamol, salicylates, and paraquat, were negative. Serum ethylene glycol levels were measured at 7 mg/dl. Additional diagnostic tests, such as the electrocardiogram (ECG), chest radiograph, and abdominal ultrasonogram, returned unremarkable results."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 12-year-old male with an obese appearance. He is from a family where his elderly elder brother has similar symptoms and is now bedbound.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient reported difficulty breathing for two months and generalized weakness for over five years. He also complained of repeated falls, fatigue, and an inability to walk or climb stairs. The patient started toe-walking at the age of five years. He displayed a waddling gait, toe-walking, and lumbar hyperlordosis. The patient showed a positive grower's sign. Bilateral lower and upper limb muscle strength was reduced. Examination of the reflexes revealed reduced deep and superficial responses. Muscle tone exhibited hypotonia upon examination and palpation.",

  "Physical Examination": "The child has an endomorphic build, calf hypertrophy on bilateral legs, and bilateral knee flexion contracture. The bilateral ankle demonstrated Pes Planus. Girth measurement revealed calf hypertrophy. Intraoral examination findings included an anterior open bite, left posterior crossbite, swollen tongue, crowding in the lower anterior region, decay in tooth 46, and poor dental hygiene status.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient's medical history revealed the presence of similar symptoms in his elderly elder brother, who is now bedbound. The patient started toe-walking at the age of five years.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Biochemistry analysis showed elevated levels of CK (20,232 U/L), alanine aminotransferase (208 U/L), aspartate aminotransferase (190.5 U/L), and lactate dehydrogenase (647 U/L). Electromyography revealed a myopathic pattern in the right vastus lateralis and deltoid muscle, suggestive of primary muscle disease."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 2-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient had a history of multiple infections starting 2 months after birth, including ruptured appendicitis at 22 months. He presented with new-onset Nocardia lymphadenitis and multiple cavitary lung nodules. Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) was diagnosed following an abnormal oxidative burst assay using dihydrorhodamine. Subsequent chromosomal microarray studies confirmed the loss of a 1.1-Mb region in Xp21.1-p11.4. The deleted region included XK and the CYBB genes, confirming the diagnosis of X-linked CGD with McLeod syndrome (MLS). Following maternal testing, this was determined to be a de novo mutation. The patient had remained transfusion naïve throughout his life with negative antibody screens. Due to the severity of the patient's immunodeficiency and disseminated Nocardia infection, allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation was deemed the best option for long-term survival.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were mentioned in the provided information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of multiple infections starting 2 months after birth, including ruptured appendicitis at 22 months. He had X-linked CGD with McLeod syndrome (MLS) due to a de novo mutation.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The oxidative burst assay using dihydrorhodamine was abnormal. Chromosomal microarray studies confirmed the loss of a 1.1-Mb region in Xp21.1-p11.4, including XK and CYBB genes. The patient had negative antibody screens. Pre-donation hemoglobin and hematocrit were checked either through the core lab or using the HemoCue. Samples from each autologous donation were cultured for aerobic, anaerobic, and fungal growth."
}"
Cases.Follow-up Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 2-year-old male from an unspecified geographic location.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient had a history of multiple infections starting 2 months after birth, including ruptured appendicitis at 22 months. He presented with new-onset Nocardia lymphadenitis and multiple cavitary lung nodules. Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD) was diagnosed following an abnormal oxidative burst assay using dihydrorhodamine. Subsequent chromosomal microarray studies confirmed the loss of a 1.1-Mb region in Xp21.1-p11.4. The deleted region included XK and the CYBB genes, confirming the diagnosis of X-linked CGD with McLeod syndrome (MLS). Following maternal testing, this was determined to be a de novo mutation. The patient had remained transfusion naïve throughout his life with negative antibody screens. Due to the severity of the patient's immunodeficiency and disseminated Nocardia infection, allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation was deemed the best option for long-term survival.",

  "Physical Examination": "No specific physical examination findings were mentioned in the provided information.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of multiple infections starting 2 months after birth, including ruptured appendicitis at 22 months. He had X-linked CGD with McLeod syndrome (MLS) due to a de novo mutation.",

  "Initial Test Results": "The oxidative burst assay using dihydrorhodamine was abnormal. Chromosomal microarray studies confirmed the loss of a 1.1-Mb region in Xp21.1-p11.4, including XK and CYBB genes. The patient had negative antibody screens. Pre-donation hemoglobin and hematocrit were checked either through the core lab or using the HemoCue. Samples from each autologous donation were cultured for aerobic, anaerobic, and fungal growth.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "A PCR-based short tandem repeat sorted chimerism assay on day +64 post-transplant indicated complete donor cell engraftment of the myeloid cell lineage with incomplete engraftment of the lymphoid lineage (21%). Normal neutrophil oxidative burst was demonstrated by dihydrorhodamine assay post-transplant. The patient underwent four autologous 110-ml whole blood donations over 15 weeks. The preparatory transplant regime included daratumumab (×3 doses) and rituximab (×1 dose), followed by reduced-intensity non-myeloablative chemotherapy including high-dose fludarabine, intravenous busulfan, and rabbit-ATG. Post-transplant, the patient received weekly recombinant human erythropoietin (rEPO) for 4 weeks. Two 5-ml/kg autologous RBC transfusions were required on day +11 and day +13 post-transplant. Neutrophil engraftment occurred by 23 days post-transplant. Over 1-year post-transplant, the patient shows continued mixed chimerism of the lymphoid cell line (65%)."
}"

Cases.Final Name: Very long chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient was a female infant born at 40 weeks gestation to a 26-year-old first-time mother. The birth weight was 3340 g, and APGAR scores were 9 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The infant was initially transitioned to routine neonatal care. A few grunting episodes were noted on the first day of life but resolved spontaneously. She was being breastfed every 3-4 hours since birth without difficulty. At 30 hours of age, 2 hours after the last feeding, she became unresponsive, resulting in resuscitation efforts by neonatology and pediatric cardiology. Continuous cardiac monitoring showed a pattern of wide QRS complexes with peaked T waves refractory to intervention. Resuscitation efforts were discontinued after 2 hours. Newborn screening blood spot samples had been collected approximately 6 hours prior to the cardiac arrest. The newborn screen report was received 2 days after the infant died and indicated elevated levels of C14, C14:1, C14:2, C14:1/C12:1, and C14:1/C16.",

  "Physical Examination": "An echocardiogram showed no structural abnormalities. Postmortem examination revealed a structurally normal heart without hypertrophy, evidence of meconium aspiration on examination of the lungs, early ischemic changes in the stomach, renal tubular vacuolization, and microsteatosis of the liver. Examination of the placenta was notable for rare pigmented macrophages concerning for meconium present in utero.",

  "Past Medical History": "The infant was born following an uncomplicated pregnancy. There was no reported family history of medical conditions.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Initial venous blood obtained after 1 hour of resuscitation showed pH 7.002 with a base deficit of 10. Initial potassium was >10 mmol/L. The newborn screen showed C14 of 5.07 μmol/L (normal <0.70 μmol/L), C14:1 of 3.20 μmol/L (normal <0.60 μmol/L), C14:2 of 0.30 μmol/L (normal <0.10 μmol/L), C14:1/C12:1 of 9.13 μmol/L (normal <3.0 μmol/L), and C14:1/C16 of 0.25 μmol/L (normal <0.20 μmol/L)."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Chromosome microarray analysis from a postmortem sample was normal. Exome sequencing revealed biallelic variants in ACADVL: a maternally inherited c.1375dup, p.R459Pfs*4 pathogenic variant and a paternally inherited c.1678 + 3_1678 + 6del, p.? likely pathogenic variant.
