Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 51-year-old male from a family with a history of Fabry Disease (FD). He is from a geographic location where enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) and hemodialysis are available.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient initially presented with pain in the distal extremities in childhood. At age 20, routine health check-up revealed left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) and proteinuria. He was definitively diagnosed with classical FD at age 37. ERT with agalsidase alfa was initiated at age 38. At 42, he experienced a cerebral infarction with multiple asymptomatic brain infarctions. At 47, an arteriovenous fistula was created for blood access, but acute occlusion occurred. Hemodialysis was initiated after fixing the superficial left brachial artery. At 48, he experienced three repeated brain infarctions within 4 months, resulting in numbness of the left side of the body, opposite tendon hyperreflexia, decreased vocabulary use and comprehension, and no motion impairment. He developed stubbornness and low morale, leading to voluntary employment termination. For the subsequent 3 years, he displayed perplexed utterance and behavior, impaired attention, and disorientation. He repeatedly interfered with blood access needles during hemodialysis, visited the hospital at inappropriate times, and had difficulty returning home. He became reclusive and expressed awareness of dementia, appearing conflicted and depressed. At 51, he began using short-term residential care at a nursing home for 3 days per week and gradually lost interest in all aspects of life.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient had angiokeratoma. He developed numbness of the left side of the body and opposite tendon hyperreflexia but no motion impairment after repeated brain infarctions. He displayed perplexed utterance and behavior, impaired attention, and disorientation.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient has a family history of FD. His grandmother died due to stroke and heart disease. Three of her four daughters (including the patient's mother) were heterozygous for FD. The patient's younger brother was previously diagnosed with classical FD. The patient's two sons refused examination for FD diagnosis due to concerns about their father's behavior.",

  "Initial Test Results": "At age 20, a routine health check-up revealed LVH and proteinuria. At age 37, leukocyte GLA activity was 0.2 nmol/h/mg protein (normal range: 49.8–116.4). The estimated glomerular filtration rate gradually declined from 65.2 ml/min/1.73 m2 at the time of ERT introduction to levels indicating end-stage renal failure. Cognitive function tests at ages 49, 50, and 51 showed HDS-R scores of 6, 4, and 4 points, and MMSE scores of 15, 17, and 10 points, respectively, indicating progression to severe dementia."
}"

The estimated glomerular filtration rate gradually declined from 65.2 ml/min/1.73 m2 at the time of ERT introduction to levels indicating end-stage renal failure. Cognitive function tests at ages 49, 50, and 51 showed HDS-R scores of 6, 4, and 4 points, and MMSE scores of 15, 17, and 10 points, respectively, indicating progression to severe dementia.",

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "At age 37, renal biopsy findings included lamellated myelin-like inclusions in the cytoplasm of glomerular and tubular cells. Lacunar brain infarction, opacified lens, and angiokeratoma were also detected. At age 42, MRI revealed multiple asymptomatic brain infarctions. At age 48, MRI demonstrated new infarctions at the left pons and bilateral cerebral cortex. COGNISTAT examination showed remarkable declines in Orientation, Language (Comprehension, Naming), Construction, Memory, Calculations and Reasoning (Similarities, Judgement), with relatively good scores maintained for Attention and Language Repetition. Voxel-based Specific Regional Analysis System for Alzheimer's Disease yielded a Z-score of 0.49, indicating no specific loss of gray matter selectivity in bilateral hippocampal regions. The reduction in whole brain gray matter volume was 6.02%, suggesting no atrophy despite multiple brain infarctions."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 38-year-old Asian man.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with a two-week history of abdominal discomfort, lethargy, and jaundice. Two days prior to admission, he began experiencing altered mental status and was disoriented in time and space. Upon admission, he displayed severe jaundice, with yellow discoloration of his sclera and skin. He exhibited grade 2 hepatic encephalopathy, was noticeably disoriented and confused, with a Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of 10. The patient was diagnosed with acute liver failure (ALF) due to hepatitis A and E co-infection. He was admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU) and started on supportive therapy, including intravenous fluids, electrolyte replacement, and total parenteral nutrition (TPN). His Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) score was 28 at admission. Antiviral therapy with ribavirin was initiated due to evidence of active HEV replication. Lactulose was administered but showed no improvement and was tapered off. Hypoglycemia and electrolytes were corrected. Evidence of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) was confirmed through cranial Doppler ultrasound, and a bolus of mannitol was administered. Despite these interventions, the patient's condition deteriorated rapidly. He developed severe grade 4 encephalopathy and hyperammonemia, prompting the initiation of dialysis. Despite intensive measures, the patient's condition did not improve, and he died within 48 hours after admission.",

  "Physical Examination": "The patient's abdomen was tender, and his liver was palpable. He displayed severe jaundice, with yellow discoloration of his sclera and skin. He exhibited grade 2 hepatic encephalopathy and was noticeably disoriented and confused. His Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was 10.",

  "Past Medical History": "The patient had no notable past medical history. There was no recent travel or exposure to sick people reported. The patient's wife denied any history of alcoholism or recent drug intake.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Laboratory tests showed elevated liver function levels: aspartate transaminase (AST) of 2,100 U/L (normal range: 8-48 U/L), alanine transaminase (ALT) of 2,200 U/L (normal range: 7-55 U/L), total bilirubin of 28 mg/dL (normal range: 0.3-1.2 mg/dL), and an International Normalized Ratio (INR) of 2.4. Serologic tests for hepatitis A (HAV) and hepatitis E (HEV) viruses were positive, with immunoglobulin M (IgM) antibody titres of 1:2560 and 1:640, respectively. The patient's Model for End-stage Liver Disease (MELD) score was 28 based on his lab parameters."
}"

Liver function tests, including bilirubin, ALT, and AST, were done every 12 hours."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "A 54-year-old Chinese man presented with symptoms initially. He had no family history of rectal or penile cancers. The patient was from China.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient experienced penile pain and dysuria for 6 months before hospitalization. He had undergone abdominoperineal resection for rectal cancer 7 years and 6 months previously. Due to solitary penile metastasis, a total penectomy and paracentetic suprapubic cystostomy were performed. After surgery, the patient received chemotherapy and radiotherapy. Metastasis to the right regional nodes was found 23 months after penectomy. Genetic testing was performed after the patient completed right inguinal lymphadenectomy. Six cycles of chemotherapy were administered with Iritecan 320 mg d1 and Tessio 60 mg d1−d14 53 months previously, and radiotherapy with DT 59.6 Gy/32 f was administered 47 months previously. He had right inguinal lymph node metastasis 31 months ago, followed by right inguinal lymphadenectomy and additional therapy with Cetuximab, Iritecan, and continuously-pumped Fluorouracil 29 months ago. Pelvic bone and lymph node metastases were found 24 months ago, and treated with radiotherapy with DT 50 Gy/25 f 20 months previously, and the patient continued treatment with Cetuximab. PET-CT found multiple bone metastases, and genetic tests showed sensitivity to Bevacizumab 15 months ago. Bevacizumab, Iritecan, and fluorouracil were administered 14 months ago, and Cindilimab was used 13 months ago. Radiotherapy for pelvic bone and lymph node metastases with DT 50 Gy/25 f was performed 12 months ago, and additional radiotherapy with DT 60 Gy/30 f for lymph nodes, soft tissue, and femur tumor metastases 12 months previously. One cycle of Cindilimab, Bevacizumab, and Capecitabine was administered 10 months ago. Radiation necrosis, hip soft tissue infection, and pyogenic buttocks were found 7 months ago, treated with iodophor disinfection. Chest-enhanced CT showed lung metastasis, and Cindilimab was administered 4 months ago. Incision and drainage of hip and left thigh lateral root abscesses were performed 4 months ago.",
  "Physical Examination": "The physical examination showed multiple hard nodules of the penile shaft and glans with visible skin ulceration on the penile glans.",
  "Past Medical History": "The patient had a history of rectal cancer and had undergone abdominoperineal resection for the rectum 7 years and 6 months prior. There was no family history of rectal or penile cancers.",
  "Initial Test Results": "Contrast-enhanced CT scan showed postoperative manifestations consistent with rectal cancer. Pathological biopsy revealed multiple metastatic tissues in the penis, and immunohistochemistry confirmed rectal metastasis. Tumor cells were positive for CDX-2, Villin, CK20, and the Ki-67 index reached up to 50%; negative for TTF-1 and CK7."
}"

Cases.Final Name: Sudden infant death-dysgenesis of the testes syndrome
Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a male infant born to non-consanguineous Romanian parents. He was born vaginally at 39 weeks of gestation. Birth weight was 3175 g (14th centile), length was 52 cm (69th centile) and head circumference was 36 cm (69th centile). The APGAR score was 6/9/9.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The pregnancy was complicated by moderate pre-eclampsia. Antenatal ultrasounds mentioned a small genital bud at 22 weeks of gestation. The patient experienced transient respiratory distress requiring a 24-hour hospitalization with ventilatory assistance after birth. During the first days of life, the child presented multiple episodes of bradycardia with blockpnea, desaturation, and cyanosis, requiring a 1-month hospital stay in neonatal intensive care. He presented with extensive generalized hypotonia, gastroesophageal reflux, bilateral gynecomastia, laryngeal inspiratory dyspnea, intermittent stridor, and episodes of apnea/hypopnea related to severe laryngomalacia. At the age of 4.5 months, he presented repeated episodes of abnormal hyperextension movements with eye revulsions and desaturation. Within a month, the patient's neurological condition deteriorated considerably. At that time, neurologic examination showed major axial and segmental hypotonia, a low level of interaction, limb mobilization only on stimulation, and intermittent eye opening. Enteral feeding by nasogastric tube, nocturnal non-invasive ventilation, and daytime oxygen were introduced. At the age of 10 months, the patient was admitted to the intensive care unit for pneumopathy, which led to a deterioration of his neurological condition, including coma and multiple febrile seizures. His respiratory and neurological condition continued to deteriorate despite appropriate antibiotic and anti-epileptic treatments. The patient died 4 days later from cardio-respiratory arrest.",

  "Physical Examination": "At birth, low-set posteriorly rotated ears, retrognathia, convex nasal ridge, short lingual frenulum, cryptorchidism, hypoplastic bursae, and micropenis were noted. The testes were in inguinal position and there was no ovary or vagina.",

  "Past Medical History": "There was no relevant family history, especially no genital malformation or sudden infant death.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Electrocardiogram monitoring and polysomnography showed episodes of sinus bradycardia with peripheral apnea/hypopnea, suggesting vagal hypertonia. Cardiac ultrasound was normal. Hormonal assessment showed isolated hypergonadotropic hypogonadism and no immunodeficiency was noted, especially no lymphopenia. A targeted FISH study confirmed the presence of the SRY region. The multiple electroencephalograms were extremely pathological, showing slow, symmetrical, and alternating delta and theta activity with numerous episodes of multifocal, asynchronous, abundant, and diffuse spikes and spikes-waves, predominant in the central and occipital regions, interspersed with periods of hypoactivity without any spatial or temporal organization. There was an almost total absence of stimuli response. This discontinuous pattern without wake/sleep organization reflected severe epileptic encephalopathy."
}"

  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "Brain magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was normal at birth and remained normal when repeated at the age of 5 months. A 22 gene-panel comprising candidate genes involved in sexual differentiation disorders revealed two likely pathogenic variants in TSPYL1, in a compound heterozygous state: c.725_726del; p.(Val242Glufs*52) (ClinVar ID SCV001450719.1), and c.236del; p.(Gly79Valfs*36) (ClinVar ID SCV001450720.1). This result was confirmed by Sanger sequencing (transcript NM_003309.3). Exome sequencing did not return any additional candidate variants that could explain the epileptic phenotype."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "14-year-old boy, gender: male.",
  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient presented with nausea, bilateral flank pain, and urinary retention. He had a history of recurrent urinary tract infections since the age of six, constipation treated with MiraLAX, and voiding dysfunction managed with biofeedback and pelvic floor muscle training exercises. He had grade 3 vesicoureteral reflux on the left side, grade 1 on the right, and a potentially narrowed segment in the membranous urethra at age seven. A renal ultrasound at age 13 revealed severe bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and irregular bladder contour. He was already on medications including oxybutynin, tamsulosin, and nitrofurantoin for urinary tract infection prophylaxis. His psychological evaluation revealed anxiety, depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and attention-deficit hyperactivity syndrome, treated with sertraline and dextroamphetamine/amphetamine, while following up with a psychotherapist and psychiatrist on an outpatient basis. The patient was diagnosed with Hinman syndrome.",
  "Physical Examination": "No specific details provided in the original case information.",
  "Past Medical History": "Recurrent urinary tract infections since age six. History of constipation treated with MiraLAX and voiding dysfunction managed with biofeedback and pelvic floor muscle training exercises. Left-sided grade 3 vesicoureteral reflux, right-sided grade 1 vesicoureteral reflux, and a potentially narrowed segment in the membranous urethra identified at age seven. Severe bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and an irregular bladder contour noted on renal ultrasound at age 13. Diagnosed with Hinman syndrome. Psychological history included anxiety, depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and attention-deficit hyperactivity syndrome, managed with sertraline and dextroamphetamine/amphetamine, psychotherapy, and psychiatry follow-ups.",
  "Initial Test Results": "During the current visit, lab results showed acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 3.5 mg/dl and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 29 mg/dl, baseline creatinine was 0.6 mg/dl and BUN was 18 mg/dl."
}"

Left-sided grade 3 vesicoureteral reflux, right-sided grade 1 vesicoureteral reflux, and a potentially narrowed segment in the membranous urethra identified at age seven. Severe bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and an irregular bladder contour noted on renal ultrasound at age 13. Diagnosed with Hinman syndrome. Psychological history included anxiety, depression, obsessive-compulsive disorder, and attention-deficit hyperactivity syndrome, managed with sertraline and dextroamphetamine/amphetamine, psychotherapy, and psychiatry follow-ups.",
  "Initial Test Results": "During the current visit, lab results showed acute kidney injury with a creatinine level of 3.5 mg/dl and blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 29 mg/dl, baseline creatinine was 0.6 mg/dl and BUN was 18 mg/dl.",
  "Further Diagnostic Tests": "CT abdomen and pelvis showed bilateral hydroureteronephrosis and thickened urinary bladder wall. MRI of the lumbar spine was normal. Renal ultrasound demonstrated bilateral hydronephrosis, bladder trabeculations, an irregular bladder contour, and a thickened bladder wall. Fluoroscopic voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) showed progression of vesicoureteral reflux to grade 4 and a trabeculated urinary bladder contour. MRI of the lumbar spine showed normal findings."
}"

Cases.Initial Presentation:
"{
  "Basic Information": "The patient is a 27-year-old pregnant Caucasian woman (gravida 2, para 1) at 28 weeks of pregnancy when referred to the medical center. The fetus was male.",

  "Clinical Presentation": "The patient was referred due to the presence of megacystis and bilateral hydronephrosis on routine ultrasound at 28 weeks of pregnancy. Previous ultrasound examinations at 20 and 24 weeks' gestational age were completely normal. At 29 (6/7d) weeks of gestation, significant fetal ascites with an elevated diaphragm and thoracic compression were observed. Oligohydramnios was present with an Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI) of 2.7 cm. Urinary tract evaluation showed significant bladder wall thickening (6.2 mm) but the resolution of previously observed megacystis and hydronephrosis, suggesting a spontaneous bladder rupture with the onset of urinary ascites. The patient was admitted for cardiotocography (CTG) fetal monitoring, initiation of corticosteroid therapy for fetal pulmonary maturation, and further work-up. Initially, a minimal invasive approach was chosen. Percutaneous ultrasound-guided fetal ascites puncture was performed with the aspiration of 420 ml of fluid, followed by amnio-infusion of 250 ml. At 30 (4/7d) weeks, increasing fetal abdominal circumference with persistent ascites and oligohydramnios were observed. Fetal Doppler ultrasound showed a decreased venous return with presence of pulsative flow in the inferior vena cava and a continuous elevated fetal heart rate between 150 and 170 beats per minute, leading to cardiac decompensation. Due to these cardiovascular changes, repeat ascites drainage and peritoneo-amniotic shunt placement were performed. At 34 (6/7d) weeks, relapse of the megacystis was observed with bilateral pyelectasis and oligohydramnios (AFI 2.4 cm), possibly due to healing of the bladder rupture, after which elective cesarean section was planned. The male infant was born weighing 2370 g with Apgar scores of 9 and 10 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively, and there was no need for supportive measures. A 6 Fr transurethral bladder catheter was placed with drainage of 90 ml of urine, and amoxicillin uroprophylaxis was initiated. Exploratory surgery was performed to remove the prolapsed intra-abdominal tissue (part of omentum) and the peritoneo-amniotic shunt. The abdominal wall defect was closed. At 1 month of age, cystoscopy and resection were performed. Follow-up showed resolution of hydronephrosis and gradual decrease of bladder wall thickening over the following months. At 3 months of age, uroprophylaxis was changed to nitrofurantoin. At 12 months, uroprophylaxis was terminated. The patient has been followed up for 8 years, showing normal ultrasonographic findings and renal function. However, bladder dysfunction has been reported, manifesting as overactive bladder with daytime urinary incontinence, low bladder capacity and nocturnal enuresis. Standard urotherapy was initiated with limited result. Transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) was started as a second line treatment. Anticholinergic therapy (oxybutynin, 2.5 mg two times daily) showed better results with resolution of the urinary incontinence. Currently, anticholinergic treatment is still ongoing and dose de-escalation is planned.",

  "Physical Examination": "The renal parenchyma appeared normal on ultrasound at 29 (6/7d) weeks of gestation. Inspection of the peritoneo-amniotic shunt after birth showed prolapse of intra-abdominal tissue, which was found to be a part of omentum during exploratory surgery.",

  "Past Medical History": "The family history revealed a sister with a horseshoe kidney and a nephew with unilateral pyelectasis.",

  "Initial Test Results": "Analysis of the urinary ascites showed a normal male karyotype and a β-2-microglobulin value of 2.1 mg/L, indicating good renal prognosis. Fetal ultrasonography one day post-operatively showed no residual ascites, correct stent position, absence of hydronephrosis, and normalization of the AFI to 10.8 cm. Cystography performed 1 week after birth confirmed a right-sided grade I vesico-ureteral reflux (VUR). At 6 months, dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan and Cr-ethylenediaminetetraaceticacid (EDTA) study showed normal kidneys with symmetrical function and good absolute renal clearance of 71.9 ml/minute/1.73 m2. At 12 months, repeat cystography showed minimal residual gr I VUR on the right side. A repeat Cr-EDTA study at three years showed normal renal clearance of 151 ml/minute/1.73 m2."
}"
